text: Nice mats that do what they are supposed to do - help release foods from you cookie sheets.  You also have the advantage of not having to wash those nice cookie sheets unless of course you dribble something onto the edges when loading the mats.  Never have used one of these before and I'm happy I bought them because it cuts down on cleaning and assures me everything comes off the cookie sheet in perfect condition.

Really like this stuff - makes cleaning the iPad easy along with my iMAC and my MacBook Pro.  My laptop sits in my kitchen and it is amazing how much greasy film seems to settle on the screen so I clean that screen regularly along with my iPad.  Eight ounces will go a long ways and last a long time.  Takes only a small 1-2 pump spray onto a microfiber cloth, yes you will need one of those microfiber dusting cloths, to clean each screen.  I'm happy and so are my computers!

Really nice thermometer - big, easy to read and has an adjustable slide at the back so no matter how much you might have in a pan you can make it work.  Been very happy with this tool and use it regularly, cleans up easily and seems to give an accurate temperature readout.

Or anything else you wish to lay some weight onto when cooking.  I use this press mostly for floured bacon, paninis and sometimes chicken.  I have found that the size is larger than some of the other presses out there and a bit larger than a Lodge press that I've used for years.  The Lodge is heavier but smaller so depending on what I'm making will determine which press I use.  This one works very well when making two sandwiches at the same time and fits nicely in a Lodge cast iron 13 1/2" fry pan or even the 8" size.  Nice press and I'm happy with it.

This pizza cutter can really cut through a super large pizza in a hurry.  Nice and sharp and does not take a lot of effort to use.  My only recommendation would be to use a cheap wood chopping board that you slide your pizza onto because you can nick up a good board when you rock and roll this guy!  Love this pizza cutter, does take up some room in a drawer so keep that in mind as to where you plan to store it.  I put mine back in the box and store in my pantry until the next pizza night!

Every time I make tofu I'm always amazed what happens when you add the Nigari - pure magic!  I make about 8-10 pounds of tofu at one time which is 25 cups of soy milk (made from scratch from 6 cups of soaked beans) using 8-10 tsp. of Nigari coagulant and I get the most beautiful fluffy curds to press into blocks.  I find the flavor of the tofu is sweet and natural without any nasty lemon or vinegary flavor that you can get when using lemon or vinegar.  One pound of Nigari will last me maybe a year or more so I have lots of tofu in my future to eat....love the stuff!  Will buy again.

As the title says, I was curious about his product and whether I might like it.  It's a very interesting "sugar" made from the juice of the coconut palm tree NOT the fruit!  Has a taste unlike anything I've ever tasted, anyway that I can remember, except maybe sugar that has been burned!  It does not taste like brown sugar, date sugar, white sugar, raw sugar and it definitely is not a neutral flavor.  Do I like it?  Not really,  because it leaves a peculiar taste in whatever you eat or drink - sort of spoils the flavor of the drink or your oatmeal or whatever you put it on or in.  If this doesn't bother you and you don't care about tasting the original flavor of what you are eating or drinking then you might find this to your liking.  I will use the sugar until gone, sparingly, but I won't buy it again.

Love these bottles.  I first bought them one at a time but then finally decided to buy a whole 12 pack.  I transfer milk, cream, buttermilk, kefirs, juices, teas and even keep one filled with water on my night stand.  I have never used them to can with so I can't speak to how well they work but they are wonderful to get all those nasty plastic/cardboard containers out of my refrigerator and look so much better on the table - I'm fussy about those things - and I love that icy cold liquid that comes out of them too.  If you have a need for this many glass bottles for liquids then by all means go for it because they are a much better price when you buy them in bulk.  Share with a friend or family member the purchase and all of you will be happy!

March 4, 2014  UPDATEI bought this large 16 oz. bottle on January 27th, 2014 for $69 from Amazon and based on the reviews currently running (July 2014) on this product I would be cautious in buying again especially since $80 is a lot of money to wind up throwing out.  I believe I might have received an older formulation and therefore my stevia seems to be fine.  Here is a list of the ingredients as per their label on the bottle I currently have:Stevia Extract (Stevia rebudiana) (leaf)What is NOT in the bottle:soy, yeast, gluten, wheat, milk, synthetics, artificial colors or flavors, msg, preservatives, saccharin, aspartame, sucaralose, or artificial sweeteners.If they have changed the formula since January, then my review is based on the bottle that I purchased in JANUARY 2014.  There are no alcohol extracts or corn sweeteners in my bottle of Stevia either - NONE!  Here is a phone number if you wish to contact the company regarding their current formulation:  800-753-4372 (HERB).  The company is located at 2220 West 2nd Ave. #1, Eugene, OR  97401,[...], info@nunaturals.com.I DO AGREE with many of the reviewers here that this stuff does NOT taste all that great on food!  I've tried it in a variety of solid foods and I don't care for it.  Where it shines is in smoothies, iced drinks like tea, blender made ice creams and some fruit juices otherwise I use Splenda (wish I didn't have to but it's that or sugar).January, 2014 originally posted review.Have been using this product and buying in the 1 oz. size (5 or more at a time) for about a year.  Do the math, it is SO much cheaper to buy in the 16 oz. size.  Save your little bottles and refill when you need to.  Okay, the Stevia is fantastic in drinks, smoothies, ice cream but I don't like it on my oatmeal (not sure why) but it leaves a funny taste in my mouth but in my tea I love it.  Since drinks are really about all the sweet things I eat - or drink in this case - this is a wonderful substitute for using sugar or any nasty artificial sweeteners.  I'll continue to buy as long as I can get the larger 16 oz. size and there isn't anything now wrong with the current formulation.

Packed from beginning to end with lots information on the why's and then the how's of eating and making fermented foods.  I have made sauerkraut and the fermented salsa so far working with both a brine and then the whey method for the salsa.  The salsa tasted like regular fresh homemade but with a pronounced tang.  So far I've only managed to get 2 weeks of fermenting on my cabbage before I've run out of jars in the refrigerator and have to break into another 3 liter jar that is fermenting (3L will hold approx. 3 heads of cabbage shredded and packed) - it's that good.  Have to make more and faster.Side note for information sake.  I've been making my fermented foods in 3L glass jars with the bale and rubber gasket method that I learned about on MOFA (Maine Organic Farmer's Assoc.) and figured it sounded like a less expensive and easier way to go rather than spending big bucks for a fermenting crock.  Check them out and you decide.The only recommendation I can seriously make about buying the book, is to buy the book,  skip the e-book download if you are really serious about using this information.  I bought the e-book and have been about to pull my hair out on a few occasions using it on my iPad.  The pages DO NOT CORRELATE correctly with the numbers so finding a page is very difficult, search pages do not go to the correct page or read it with a pen and make notes.  You will want to refer back and forth when you are reading descriptions of recipes, making Simple Brine, etc. and try to find them, eeeeck!  Buy a used book because you probably will be using it enough that it will be fairly used and loved before you know it anyway and only slightly more than the e-book.Great book, full of tons of information, easy to read and understand.

I usually spend the extra money to get better craft supplies, but not for sidewalk chalk.  While these are brighter colors than the dollar store chalks, they crumble in my four-year-old's hands and crack if thy are dropped.  The dollar store chalk is much sturdier.

Whoops! I ordered these to keep my four year old busy and assumed it would be the size of a child's workbook.  This actually fits in my purse!  OF course, it's nice to have some cute little activities tucked into a pocket, but this is too small for my child's hands.

This is a great beginner program for a kid that wants to learn the basics.  The free version has some great videos that describe the most basic strategies in a very funny and entertaining format.  There are also "bots" at different levels to help kids practice.Some of the videos ask you to sign up for their subscription, which seems a bit overpriced, and we have not yet figured out how to play against other kids.  We start games, but the app doesn't seem to know who is online or how active the participants are, so after making first moves, have not heard back from any opponent.

I ordered two of these so my sons could play together.  This one was far less expensive, but at least as good as the ones from the zoo and Disney.  The bubble mix blasted out bubbles quickly, without getting all over their arms and hands, and when it ran out, I used plain old bubble mix, or just a dash of dish washing detergent in water with some glycerin.  Glycerin seems to be the magic ingredient that makes bubbles strong, and the $5 bottle I bought from the bakery aisle has made gallons of bubble mix.Anyway, this light up gun makes a great whirring sound, works well with my homemade bubble mix as well as the store bought stuff, and was definitely worth the few bucks I spent to buy them.

You are supposed to put ten drops in each ear, but my cat, who sometimes purrs during ear cleanings, tried to get away and shook her head like crazy.  The medicine streamed out with a light squeeze, so have no idea how I would have measured 10 drops out.Then she started moving her mouth strangely, so I had to give her a bath to make sure she didn't ingest any more since it turns out, this is insanely toxic to cats.  Now I'm sitting here with my wet cat waiting to see if she's going to get sick.

I was pretty excited to try this out, but am unimpressed and gave it away after my first try.  The tube is thick and hard and the end is cut on a strange angle.  So even if I saw a piece of lint a few inches away, there was no way the hard thick plastic tube was going to get it.  I could barely squeeze it into the gap, and nothing came up, even though I haven't cleaned it since I purchased the dryer two years ago.  I eventually used a balled up sock to clean out the hole and will have to keep my fingers crossed for anything deeper in the piping.

This is not the same high quality game we had as children.  The ships are cheap plastic that you cut off on a grid, and the various pieces that stick out make it hard to put pegs in the spots surrounding the ships, or to put the ships next to each other.  The peg holders don't close well, so pieces will fall out unless you put them in a plastic bag.  One player has red ships, so the red pegs didn't work well to mark "hits".  We just switched it around for other colors).  But after two days, the kids lost interest.  It hasn't been touched in two weeks.The game itself is a little too loud.For the price point, this game should be higher quality.

These erasers are terrible.  They leave behind marks, streak dirt and make eraser crumbs.  Sometimes they even tear the paper.  You would almost be better off spitting on your finger and trying to rub away your mistakes.I couldn't understand why this product had so many stars, so scrolled through and realized all of the 5 star reviews are a few years old.  I'm not sure why they changed the product, but these are awful.

There are cheaper pencils out there, but it's worth the slightly higher price to get these classics.  Cheaper pencils are harder to sharpen, or the tips break because they are poorly made.  These are a great product for a reasonable price.
These are a great value, and the kids love them.  The scents make them giggle.

Every winter, I buy my son new, Land's End thermal underwear.  It's fairly expensive, but he wears them under his clothes just about every day.  This year, I missed their sale, so ordered a few of these sets for a small fraction of the price to hold us over.  He likes these even more than the fancy sets, and they are far cheaper!  So far, the quality is similar, and he says they are just as warm outside, and just as cool inside.I can't wait to order a set for myself!EDIT: After a month of use, these are still comfy, but they are pilling and look worn out.  They are still a great deal as extras and for my little guy who will only use them for a few months before outgrowing them, but if shopping for a set that will look good and last through more than one kid, these aren't going to work.

This is a nice ruler, with some weight and a solid cork base that prevents skidding so my preschooler can enjoy using it to make lines or measure.  But as a reminder, this is 18 inches, not 12 - I ordered it by accident because I overlooked this, and while I love it, I originally purchased it for school and needed to buy a 12-inch ruler.

My son had a milk protein allergy and GERD, and am very active in various allergy groups - when someone suspects a milk allergy I always tell them to order this book immediately.  Even after speaking with dieticians, allergists and our pediatricians, this book had insights and ideas I haven't found anywhere else.  If you child has mild colic, he provides old fashioned advice, then provides the tools needed to understand if you need to get more help.The book discusses medications in great detail, but also gives advice about positioning, sleep, and detailed drawings that gave me deeper insights into the mechanics of reflux.  There was plenty of advice for breastfeeding as well as formula feeding, and even information about tube feeding systems.After reading this, I finally realized we weren't whiny, and that our child wasn't just crying, but screaming in pain.  Reading this book gave me the information I needed to advocate for my child and ask the doctors the right questions.

My son uses this in school for science class, and loves it.  Since the reviews were so mixed, I bought him two so he could choose.  This was the big light cheap one, the other one had a case and a built-in light. After two months, this is the winner.  It's light, so his hand doesn't get tired, huge so he can look at big things, and still fits in his desk.  No scratches yet, and the fancier magnifying glass has been lent to another kid - permanently.

An older version of this bag, with a silver lining, has lasted over three years, is easy to rinse, and the little kids' thermoses fit in them because the sides are soft.  The lining is now a flimsy white plastic that seems similar to the type I was replacing.  It will likely last this school year, but pessimistic about it lasting beyond that.

My son saw these and adored them - they make a really fun sound and stride rite is such a great shoe that I bought these as a birthday present.  After about a week, my son started to wear his ratty old shoes to school because he said the large plastic mask in the front made it really hard to run and climb.  He still loves owning them, but only wants to wear them to places where he has to take off his shoes!

We have been using Funtainers for over a year, and decided to add two more to our collection when I saw this great design.  It is holding up well in the dishwasher and my sons love them.  Instead of boring sandwiches, we pour hot water into the thermos to warm them up, then heat up leftovers and put them in.  The food is still piping hot at lunchtime, but if you don't heat up the thermos, the food will cool and grow bacteria.This will not fit in a standard child's size lunchbox, so make sure you order check the dimensions and buy the appropriate size lunchbox.These don't leak, even when tipped on their sides, but I am a little annoyed that I now have three different types of Funtainers and the tops are not interchangeable.  It's minor, but it would be nice to know I could grab any lid when in a rush, instead of needing the match.

My son loves face paint, so I bought this because just about every design requires a nice thick white coating or lines somewhere in the design.  Unfortunately, there is no way a little kid is going to sit still long enough to apply multiple layers of white, and even when I just did one quick layer, it smeared off onto his clothes (or my clothes!) as he ran around.I finally did some research and discovered Wolfe face paint - it's the brand generally used by professional face painters and it quickly spreads a nice thick white that doesn't smudge.  Snazaroo is a nice, inexpensive brand and easy to apply, but for white, I suggest splurging on Wolfe.

After buying a knock-off cheap loom that broke, I caved and bought the original version of this.  While the plastic hook is nice, the new metal hook, which we just got, is a nice upgrade and this is a few bucks cheaper than the $20 I spent at the peak of the Rainbow Loom craze.  If you haven't tried the loo yet, you are in for a treat.  It's a really soothing, relaxing activity, and the patterns and designs have moved far beyond bracelets.  I just saw a dress that made a fortune at auction made completely on a Rainbow Loom!The rubber bands are also higher quality than the cheaper knock off brands, but be warned: no matter how careful you are, you are going to find these bands everywhere!

This game is a winner for the right crowd.  Much like chess, this isn't a game where its worthwhile to teach someone all of the rules and details if you only want to play this game one time.  The game forces everyone to manage through limited constraints and adjust as the situation rapidly changed.  If that excites you, buy this game.  If it sounds frustrating, you will beg someone to take over for your game within two rounds.  The Dominant Species fanatics in our group have careers in design, consulting, IT and manufacturing.  The psychiatrists and artists don't seem to enjoy it as much.I recently attended a game for new players.  The first round, as we tried to understand the mechanics, took forever (again, think about how long your first game of chess took).  We were a pretty lighthearted group, so everyone brought their different styles to it.  One person simply wanted to control the spread of glaciers, another added new lands, another wanted to get as many new species as possible on the board, while another tried to adapt to the rapidly changing planet by increasing their food choices - and all of these were equally great strategies.As the night went on, we realized no matter what you had planned, circumstances change and you need to adjust your plans.  This is why the first few rounds took so long, because when our plan disappeared, we had to learn to adjust.  But by the end, we were all laughing and enjoying the fact that no matter what had happened earlier in the game, there were always plenty of opportunities to come back from a tough spot - and that's pretty rare for a board game, since most have a leader pretty early, then the game chugs along on autopilot.We all had amazing moves and horrible ones, and it was nice  to have one person somewhat familiar with the game to guide us through.  There are quite a few Youtube tutorials that can also help.  It took us four hours to play, but I'm fairly sure it will only take 2-3 hours moving forward, and once we get a bit more practice and calculate the running scores more quickly, we will be even faster.  We also really enjoyed chatting about the game as we played, which probably slowed us down even more.Overall, I can see why this game is addictive for certain personality types.

The game is a bit strategy, a bit luck, and a bit math. To play, you need a deck of cards, which you can tailor to your preferences. This little set has enough cards for players to change up their decks to reflect their own preferences and strategy. But over time, kids will want booster sets to tweak their decks to make them more effective. So while this seems like an inexpensive way to start out, you might as well pay the extra $15-$20 and get the sets that include the booster packs.Overall, Magic is a great game for kids,really forcing them to use their minds without a computer, and will bring hours of fun for them and their friends. Chances are, some adults in your life will also enjoy this.

While there is a smaller set available for those just starting out, this is the box to order if you have a few kids that all want to start building decks and playing each other.  With 36 packs, you will have enough for a few players to start decks and play against each other (quick tip: divide up the 36 packs while the packs are  still sealed - if thy open them all, the fights over certain cards might get ugly).The game is a bit strategy, a bit luck, and a bit math. To play, you need a deck of cards, which you can tailor to your preferences. This large set has enough cards for players to change up their decks to reflect their own preferences and strategy. Over time, kids can tweak their decks to make them more effective. The cards can be traded as well, with a few valuable cards generally hidden in a set like this.Overall, this is a great game for kids,really forcing them to use their minds without a computer, and will bring hours of fun for them and their friends. Chances are, some adults in your life will also enjoy this.  Beware, this game is pretty addictive!

Wolfe face paint is the best face paint on the market.  It stays bright and thick for hours, and with just a spritz of water, goes on well with a sponge for full coverage or with a brush for fine lines.  Once it dries, it won't rub off on clothes, which is fantastic. The white and black are generally used by just about every professional face painting company I have asked. This set is a great variety of  the basic colors you can use to all of the most popular looks, and this amount (30g of each color, plus the case) will allow you to paint hundreds of faces.  A little bit of this stuff goes a very long way.Buy this if you are looking for a good variety and have no color preferences, but if you want some flexibility, check out other suppliers that will allow you to customize your colors for a slightly higher price.

For less than $34, this is a great deal.  (Look at the price of booster sets alone to see what a deal this is). If your kid is nine-years-old or older, and you have just started to hear about this game, order this set.The game is a bit strategy, a bit luck, and a bit math.  To play, you need a deck of cards, which you can tailor to your preferences.  This large set has enough cards for players to change up their decks to reflect their own preferences and strategy.  Over time, kids can tweak their decks to make them more effective.  The cards can be traded as well, with a few valuable cards generally hidden in a set like this.Overall, this is a great game for kids,really forcing them to use their minds without a computer, and will bring hours of fun for them and their friends.  Chances are, some adults in your life will also enjoy this.Please "like" this review if you found it helpful.

This is a great kit, the colors are bright and easy to apply, but it does not have any face paint.  This kit only has the three crayons you see in front of the little girl's face in the picture.The crayons are  easy to handle and strong enough to last through several applications, but if you are planning to improvise, and either use this to cover a large patch of skin, or wanted to use a brush to get very fine lines, then this kit probably won't help.If you have a huge Frozen fan, then you can use this kit to improvise a cute Elsa snowflake or crown.Please "like" this review if you found it helpful.

This game is fun for adults, has fun art, entertaining puzzles and a great story.  There are no in-app purchases - you pay $5, and it never asks you for more money.There isn't any integration to share this across devices, but otherwise a great game.

We were looking for flour to make Colombian arepas, and decided to order this classic favorite.  This is great flour, but there are three details I wanted to share:1. Each kilogram is 2.2 pounds.  So this actually 13.2 pounds - not too bad a price since shipping is free.2. These are now labeled as "may contain wheat".  Since I love giving out the arepa recie to people with a wheat allergy, this is a bummer.  The search for allergen free continues.3. This is a fresh product, so won't last long. Only buy what you and your family can cook within a few months because the expiration date is only a few months away

This toy, when complete is amazing.  There are enough characters to conduct some truly great play fights between the opposing sides, and there are plenty of moving parts and vehicles to keep kids entertained for hours.  That huge lion mouth is a drawbridge that opens and closes.  There are weapons on the sides that shoot little sticks several feet.  And (my personal favorite), there are motorcycles under waterfalls that fly out on rails, pushing the waterfall out of the way as it rolls out of the temple.Of course, you have all of the good old fashioned lessons that are built into any Lego set.  Patience, attention to detail, and most importantly, a willingness to tear apart your hard work if you did something wrong and need to try again.  My six year old probably spent about 20 hours building this, and he was very careful to make sure the pieces were very firmly squeezed together to make the toy sturdy.  We have really enjoyed it.Please LIKE this review if you found it useful.

Disney seems to have yet another winning app on its hands with this new game.  I researched this on the Google play store before buying, and while many people bought this for their children, it seems the parents are hooked.  They love racing each other, scanning items, and even signing their names.  And the Disney characters are shown on the products you scan.  The reviews were glowing across many types of phones and is easy enough for a kindergartener to quickly learn and enjoy.

This toy is fantastic.  My kids always loved playing with this at other homes, so I finally got one.  I have watched kids ranging in age from 1 to 8 waiting in line for a ride.  I'm generally pretty risk averse, but this toy is fairly low to the ground, does not move very quickly, and the dip seems to really thrill the kids.  After all of the hours I've watched children play on this, I have never seen anyone fall off.  Also, since the ride is very quick and the car is easy to push back up, three or four preschoolers can easily play on this together without fighting.This is a pretty big toy, so for most people, this best fits outside, where the kids will also run up and down the hills and scoot the little car around.  If your ground isn't perfectly flat, the toy seems to work well anyway.  It's light, and my kids have moved this thing all over my lawn.  Like all Step 2 products, it's also incredibly well made.  Even though this toy is usually outside, I haven't heard of a single person who threw their roller coaster away because it broke.  Instead, they get passed down over and over again as kids sadly realize their legs are too long to even try riding this thing anymore.If you want to get a young child a gift they will adore and their friends will adore, buy this.

I'm not an alpha geek, so had someone take my PC right out of the box and set up all of the security just to make sure I didn't contaminate it before starting up.  Right away, I noticed the keys all need varying amounts of pressure and some stick (not great,but this was cheapish and had some bells and whistles so okay...).  The pad seems a little too sensitive and flashed in and out of various programs and the home page if my fingers got anywhere near the mousepad but chalked this one up to user error and figured I would eventually learn to type without my hands approaching the space bar.  Okay, that's kind of an annoying design flaw, but again, look at the price.But it also took quite a while for word documents to save, or to open up a website. These clearly were a glitch so after profuse apologies from the manufacturer, this PC was packed up and exchanged.The next PC had similar issues, so I went back to the tech sites and realized there were several reviews that mentioned slow internet speeds and glitchy programs, so returned the PC for a better model.

I ordered these for my left-handed nephew, but when they arrived, my right-handed kids wanted to try them because they looked so cool.  But these are uniquely made for lefties with flipped over blades.  I never thought about how helpful it is to have the top blade closer to my face as I cut, but it makes a huge difference.Despite the warning that colors may vary, the set we received looked exactly like the photo.  They are a great size for preschooler hands and the blade is sharp enough to cut paper without frustration.

One pound is 453 grams.  Each coffee pod has about 5 grams of coffee.  So this product sells you roughly 1/3 of a pound of coffee.I have a Keurig coffee maker, and on the medium size, it makes a decent (but not good)cup when I'm in a rush.  But these cups of coffee simply doesn't taste good enough to justify a $50+ per pound habit.  (Of course, this is true of all disposable k-cups, but I have found them for far less at local retailers.)  Instead, we bought a few of the reusable pods and fill them with really fancy gourmet coffee whenever we are waiting for something to finish cooking, and save buckets of money.  Variety is cute and nice when we have house guests over, but at these prices, its like lighting my fireplace with dollar bills!On the plus side, this set at least ensures I get a variety of strong coffees, which I like.  The mild ones don't taste very good to me, but that's a personal preference versus an objective review.Please "like" this review if you found this information useful so others will see it.

One pound is 453 grams.  Each coffee pod has about 5 grams of coffee.  So this product sells you roughly 1/3 of a pound of coffee.I have a keurig coffee maker, and on the medium size, it makes a decent (but not good)cup when I'm in a rush. Flavors vary, but I tend to refer the bolder and flavored coffees - the mild ones taste like dirty water to me, so this set is better than the variety pack. But this cup of coffee simply doesn't taste good enough to justify a $50+ per pound habit.  (I've also found them far cheaper at local stores. Instead, we bought a few of the reusable pods, fill them and keep them where this huge box used to go while waiting for my kids to come and spill them.  We fill them with really fancy gourmet coffee whenever we are waiting for something to finish cooking, and save buckets of money.  Variety is cute, but at these prices, its like lighting my fireplace with dollar bills!Please "like" this review if you found this information useful so others will see it.

I bought my husband a $35 Otterbox and this cheap cover for myself.  He is so jealous!  I am clumsy and have already dropped this a few times and so far, this case is working as well as any of the other fancy cases I bought over the years.  It even comes with a film to cover the front, which, in my experience, is not typical for less expensive cases.  This is a great deal.

I adore my older Rubbermaid set and was hoping to finally buy one more set and get rid of all non-Rubbermaid containers.  But this seems like a cheap imitation of the clear, sturdy Rubbermaid containers I bought at Costco.  I never put plastic in the microwave, but still want containers that look good, are clear and can resist staining from tomato sauce etc.  The price was the same, so the difference in quality was disappointing.

These are a great alternative to plastic.  My kids love the silver straws, and I have found them easy to clean with a plain old pipe cleaner, and simply don't let them hang around on the bottom of a sink.  One funny observation made by my son was that he disliked the little stripes at the bend.  Since they don't actually bend, he thought the fake bend marks were dishonest and they bothered him.  Another kid agreed!  They also get very frosty when used in frozen drinks, but overall, these are a great addition and guests always ask where they can get a set.I put these in my cart when they were under $12, and they jumped up to almost $20 by the time i submitted the order.  I'm used to some fluctuation on Amazon products, but this product seems to jump around quite a bit., so be careful.

A few months ago, I realized I could keep all of my flour, coffee beans, spices, veggies, etc in mason jars.  I had already canned things in the past, so this was an easy experiment for me to try.I use this funnel constantly.  It's easy to fit into a top drawer, and makes it incredibly simple to fill jars that look pretty on the shelves.  I even prepacked snacks for the kids to make it easier to pack for lunches, and use this to fill thermoses so the screw top threads don't get dirty when the lid goes on. When I fill a wide mouth jar with a liquid of flour, a little jiggle gets the food under the lip so the jar is filled, and the same trick seems to work when sliding bigger items into the jar.I've also used this to can, and it is light and sturdy enough to easily stay in the jar as I pour in the hot jam.This is a great purchase, takes up very little room, is dishwasher safe, and has helped me convert far more of my food storage to jars.

This is a fantastic tray for the price.  The little white dots have just enough grip to keep plates, utensils and glasses in place as you walk around.  Its the perfect size for one adult dinner or snacks, but isn't going to help you serve a large party out on the deck.The bottom also has nice white gripers but still holds up well in the dishwasher.  I ended up ordering a second so each child could have his own.

I don't like letting my son use paint in public places (too many brushes getting double dipped in the same paint all day long).  So I have tried Alex and Snazaroo paint to make him into a zebra before we leave.  But I couldn't find a paint that had good enough white coverage.When I came here to find a better paint, I saw the price of Wolfe paint and chickened out of the big purchase.  Then I saw this kit.  I didn't want to paint a vampire, but the kit still worked for us.  For less than $4, I can paint his face 10 times, AND it has the black stick so he can draw on his own stripes!  We also were able to use this kit to make a dalmatian.Compared to the $8 they are charging at the zoo, this was a total deal, and small enough to carry in a plastic bag in my purse so I can do it if he wants it done at a festival or something.Total deal, no nasty brushes, and no more long lines!Please "like" this  review if it helped you.

On impulse, I bought a bunch of looms for Christmas from a brick and mortar store (An amazon prime member went to a store?  Unbelievable, but true.) the kids were thrilled to open and use them, but within a month, they were all broken.  So I came back here to wonderful Amazon to buy the real ones.  They are so much sturdier they are even heavier than the cheap knock-offs.The kids all love them, it's not tv or a video game, it's quiet and calming and the little kids are very proud to be able to make gifts for loved ones.  As fads go, this is one to jump on.  Let's hope they transition to a crochet or knitting fad because those little bands are everywhere!I ordered this from Amazon last week, and it's the real one.Edit: Rainbow Loom has updated their product with a metal hook instead of a plastic hook.  The new hook is really nice, so its worth paying an extra few bucks for the newer kit.Please "like" this review if you found it useful so others will see it.

My kid really started to like these when he became about two and a half.  While he adores jungles, this is probably one of the dullest sets.  The color palette is more neutral, with more browns and no purple, and just about every picture has water, grass, and/or a tree.  It's a bit repetitive.
This was only a few dollars and really did the trick.  Easy to install, strong enough to hold back the door, and had that incredibly satisfying p-twang sound.  Great buy.
This very short book (less than 30 pages) really gives a great overview of where to start to ensure a great garden.  It's also well written and easy to read.

It looks like this app was a little scary in 2010, so it has a very bad, but very old review, that people see when they first look for this.  It's 2014, and it works well on my Kindle, seems safe and lets me download YouTube videos.  Very nice.

My son adores Maisy and flip books, so after taking this book out of the library three or four times, I finally bought it.  Its so incredibly cute.  Each pair of pages has a different scene, and giggly surprises behind each flap.

Since HBO can't be accessed via Roku and I refuse to pay for another DVR, this app on a Kindle is an awesome way to watch HBO in other rooms.  But I wish they had a quick rewind button, which seems standard for so many other apps.  Also the closed captioning is impossible to read.  I've tried every font available, but there seems to be an extra space between each letter, making some fast paced shows, such as Newsroom, impossible to read.

Like many other reviewers have stated, the worms die. (Btw, the kit doesn't include any worms). Worms like darkness and only sneak up to the light to grab food, which is decaying plant matter. So if you really want your kids to keep worms, get a five gallon bucket or a rubbermaid container and drill some holes into the side and bottom (put something underneath to catch leaks), then have the kids shred cardboard boxes and/or newspaper for bedding, and throw in your veggie scraps - about a 50/50 mix between paper and food is great. Then throw in worms. When your kids want to see the worms, grab a piece of the cardboard out and it will have plenty. if you really enjoy it after a few months, get a worm composter, or get a second holey bucket, fill with fresh stuff and the worms will migrate to the new food and you can toss your wonderfully rich worm compost (that will still have some worms and eggs) into a garden.Toy worm farms and ant farms are far too sterile to support bug life and you will end up with very disappointed kids that feel like they failed. If you make the cheap composter, your kids will get to see the circle of life, and it will even cut down on your trash!If this was helpful, please "like" this :)

I bought these from a neighbor because i thought they would be a great addition to our magnatiles and didn't realize how small they would be.  After the fatalities, and the final recall of magnetic buckyballs, it seems its not a wise idea to have strong magnets near children, because even ten-year-olds have eaten the buckyballs.  These are not just a regular choking hazard - if a child swallows two of these, they need to get to an ER to see if they can be pulled out, either through the throat or surgically.  I can't trust that these won't be swallowed, even by a guest, and if they are swallowed, the kids might not tell me since these seem harmless.I'll let my husband take them to the office - maybe they will make a fun desk toy.

Some of the shapes are obvious, such as candy cane, while shapes like the sleigh forced me to check the box just to figure out what they were.  After we used them, we rinsed them off and put them on a towel to dry and by the next day. they were rusted.

My son is only six, so this was an impulse but for Christmas.  I almost didn't wrap it.  But this toy us so veritable I tempted to buy a few for use around the house!  In the last two days, we have spent hours making dozens of things.  From a flood detector, to a motion sensor and am radio, every contraption has been exciting to turn on, and all of us know far more about electricity, light, sound and motors.My only complaint is the guidebook.  I wish they made it more basic, perhaps with flash cards to explain each piece so you wouldn't have to flip through the book.  The explanations seem to be written by engineers for engineers, so I'm trying tocreate a set of cheat sheets for us to use to better understand the mechanics of each piece so we don't damage anything if we try to create something on our own.

My two boys (6 and 2) love these.  The soft clicking as they snap together is such a soothing sound, and unlike Legos, these some apart with a good push.  Since I feel like our house is quickly becoming a Lego museum full of masterpieces that my kids never want to dismantle, I appreciate the fact that these are actually fun to knock down.There are only four large squares.  As I watched my son open it and start to build a box, I was worried that he would be frustrated by the fact there were only four large squares and a cube needs six. But he immediately realized he could snap together four small squares to make a large square, then snap together two small triangles to make a small square!  Everything that people have written about the open ended play, spacial awareness and educational value is totally true.  It's a great lesson in shapes, but lead to my only issue with these.But only complaint is about the long triangles, and I can tell this is going to drive all of us a little nuts.  When put together, they ALMOST make a circle.  Literally, it is a crack away from a huge gorgeous circle.  There are 360 degrees in a circle, so can't imagine why they wouldn't have made these exactly 30 degree angles to all fit together.  You can't even shove another piece into the gap, and the magnets aren't strong enough to allow us to pull them together into a bowl.  I'm going to put away half of these pieces so my kids stop trying to "solve" this challenge.My other suggestion is to buy a light box as a building surface.  They are pricey, but if you are already paying over $100 for these, look into a light box for the amazing effect of glowing pieces.  The light box is also so attractive that it encourages them to keep the pieces there, instead of scattered all over the house.If you found this review useful, please "like" this review.

These are fine for my husband to use on his commute, as they are light, but for anyone that needs a sturdier or thicker pair of gloves, you might be better off buying conductive thread and just putting a few stitches through your favorite gloves.  As long as the thread touches your skin and the device, it will work well.  But for the current price of $10, worth a shot.

I have two little boys that would grind down all of our pencils if given an electric sharpener.  But those plastic ones crack too easily, which can leave a blade exposed (!) and are hard to hold.  Frustrated, I looked for the metal sharpeners I had when I was a kid and here they are!  One sharpener lasts for years, and if, after a few years, the blade is dull, you can replace the blade, so its pretty environmentally friendly too.  The little dents make them easy for small hands to hold.This is the safest way to let children sharpen their own pencils, because the razor is sharp enough to do the job well, but the entire container is strong enough to safely secure the razor in a way that the child can't cut themselves.

The kiddo holds the two controller wings in their hands, and as they swoop around making lefts and rights, the plane on the ground copies the turns.  Just be sure to clear enough space, because they are going to play with this a long time.

I wanted to teach a group of young children to knit, and loved the fact that these were small enough to handle with small hands, and still long enough to handle a cowl (mini scarf) as a first project.  The two different colored needles is a great way to lead everyone to hold one color in one hand, etc.  They were about $4 a pair, so was able to get enough for a crowd to all have the same size and type without breaking the bank.

I drive a minivan and didn't really carefully assess how small this was going to look on a larger car (the car in the pic is a mini cooper).  I wanted this to be funny and obvious, but on such a big car, it's a little to hard too notice.  I also had to open the trunk and tie the nose around the hood latch to keep it on.  It's made out of fabric so is out there getting soaked in the rain ice and snow.But for $10, was worth the gag.
My nephew originally received one of these wrestlers as a gift, so needed a second guy so they could battle each other.  Good quality for the price.

So if this is currently $24, you are getting 4.5 ounces of play-doh for a dollar.  Not the worst deal, but other packages offer more colors and are a bit cheaper per ounce.  By the way, play doh is made of wheat, so be cautious if it's going be be around someone with celiac disease.

The container sizes always make it hard for me to tell which set is offering the best deal.  If this is currently priced at $5, you are getting four ounces for a dollar.  The other sizes seem to give you at least 4.5 ounces for a dollar.  By the way, play doh is made of wheat, so be cautious if it's going be be around someone with celiac disease.

This ladies watch is a VERY large design from the face piece to the wrist strap.  The watch face has a diameter of 36mm - if you look at the pictures on the Amazon website, they show several illustrations to help buyers visualize the difference between the different sizes.  The 36mm size is quite large - in fact, it is nearly the size of my husband's watch.  The watchband is slightly wider than 1/2 inch.  If you are small boned, I think this watch will swallow your wrist and you should look for a smaller design unless you prefer a really large statement timepiece.The design is gorgeous - the crystal pieces brilliantly shine and give the watch a luxurious feel and look. The pictures on the Amazon website perfectly illustrate the detail of this watch - it looks like a piece of fine jewelry.  I have a 6-3/4" wrist and I had to remove 2 of the links to have this watch fit better (and I still have about 1/2" width looseness after these two links were removed so the fit is now perfect).Although I'm not usually a fan of watches that don't have numbers the entire way around the watch-face, since this one has 6 large roman numerals  (rather than the typical 4) - it's easier to read the time.This watch arrives beautifully packaged however if you are giving this as a gift, there are several pieces of cling plastic (to prevent smudging when being packaged) that you will want to remove before presenting your gift.  The Lucien Piccard brand has a 5-year warranty.I am hopeful that the gold plating over stainless steel is durable and holds up through daily wear - if it wears prematurely, I will update this review to include this information.  This watch is truly beautiful - provided you are in the market for a large bold design, I don't think you will have any regrets over this purchase.

Horrible - I am stunned by the favorable reviews for this product and I've been scratching my head wondering if I possibly received a "bad batch" however I rather doubt it considering that it's a case of 12 with 3 different flavors.No, I did not expect this to be a sugary flavored sparkling water (it only has 10 calories per bottle and I prefer low calorie drinks) however I did expect that the "flavors" would actually resemble the fruits that they represent.  I cannot distinguish ANY of the individual flavors (Blackberry Pear, Raspberry Watermelon and Mandarin Lime) and each flavor tastes very artificial.All three of the flavored waters list only 4 ingredients on the bottle:  carbonated water, organic cane sugar, certified organic natural flavors and citric acid.  They are very carbonated (not a complaint merely an observation) but the taste of all 3 flavors is absolutely terrible (some of my tasters actually spit the product out rather than swallowing it - it was truly that offensive tasting to some people).  NO ONE in my family will drink these Sparkling waters and they leave a strange aftertaste in your mouth.  I don't want to belabor my point but I actually looked the product up on Amazon just to ensure that this wasn't a mixer of some sort that was supposed to be used in conjunction with other ingredients - it's not, it's a stand-alone beverage.I'd strongly recommend trying a single bottle (if you can find it locally at your grocery store) before buying the case to ensure that you like the taste.This was shipped in perfect condition.  It was packaged very securely and although these are glass bottles, they rest securely in an egg-shell like cardboard packaging material to ensure that they will not break during shipping.  That is about the only redeeming comment I can make about this product.

There squirties are adorable and are the perfect size for toddlers to grasp and play with.  Like any type of squirting toy, mold can (and will) form on the inside through time.  I find that the easiest way to sanitize these toys is to use a bleach solution every few days and allow this solution to remain inside the squirties for a few minutes.  I then squirt out the bleach solution and rinse it out with clean water.  This takes several minutes but I'm assured that the babies are not placing bacteria and moldy toys into their mouth.The tubes are seperate rubbery plastic that the 4 animals sit in.  You will therefore receive 8 pieces with this set.  The animals (owl, bee, puppy and monkey) have little indentations on the sides of their round bodies where your child can put their fingers to more easily squeeze them.  They float mainly face forward unless they are sitting in their tube.These are great squirties and the rubbery tubes can be used as teething rings when in the tube or pool.

This candle burns nicely with two wicks.  You'd think that two wicks might cause it to burn faster but it does not.The scent for this candle, warm buttered bread, is not a scent that appeals to me.  I find the smell very unnatural and artifical.  The color of the wax is a beautiful glossy butterscotch.  This candle brand looks very similar to Yankee candles.  It's in a stout fairly heavy duty glass jar that has a lid that fits snuggly.I'd definitely try this brand of candle again but in a different scent.It is shipped very securely so regardless of rough handling during delivery this should arrive in perfect condition.  It sits snuggly inside a box that has cardboard inserts on the bottom and top that adds more protection to prevent breakage.

This is a very thin crib sheet that significantly wrinkles and shrinks after being laundered.  It is so thin that you can see through the material.Poor quality that will not last - you'll be very disappointed in this sheet.

We have a 150 pound dog who is about 20 pounds overweight.  We like to have occasional treats to give him to reinforce good behavior and to bribe him when he is over-excited. When you have an over exuberant large breed dog, getting him back in line is like trying to wrestle a bear.  Having some tasty treats handy can gain his compliance pretty quickly.This treat is small (roughly 1"x1") and crunchy.  The real beauty is that they are only 19 calories, gluten free, and made WITHOUT meat by-products, wheat, corn, soy, artificial colors or preservatives.My dog loves these chicken/turkey sweet potatoe bars.  There are roughly 35-40 pieces per bag.

This bag is warm but bulky.  I had a devil of a time pulling it free from the stuff sack and once free - it puffed out and is very soft and fluffy however this also makes it a total pain when trying to compactly re-roll it to fit back inside the stuff sack.  You will want to purchase some type of sleeping bag strap to cinch the bag tight before trying to place it back in the stuff sack (or skip the sleep sack all together once you use the straps).  Otherwise, you will be rolling and squeezing, re-rolling and compressing, until you finally realize that unless you plan on rolling this bag up with two people where you both are pulling it taunt and using your knees to compress and push out all the air - it simply will not fit back in the stuff sack.This sleeping bag is reasonably priced and it is long and wide - feels very comfortable, even without a pad.  I like that you could zip two same-sized bags together to accommodate two sleepers.  The color is attractive without being so feminine that it would emasculate men if they needed to use this bag (and it can accommodate sleepers up to 6" tall).The draft tube is a nice feature to prevent air from leaking in through the zipper.  The zipper however constantly gets caught on the silky material inside of the bag (opposite side of draft tube).  Zipping and unzipping is therefore challenging - I only unzip this as far as needed to crawl inside and then I use 2 hands, one to pull the zipper tab and my other to push the material flat so that the zipper doesn't get caught.If you are a hardcore hiker/camper, I think that you'd prefer a more compact sleeping bag.  In addition, the rectangular bag is a common design however the mummy sleeping bags are warmer in colder weather.  Yes, you can cinch the top closed in this bag however since it is not in the shape of your head, I feel like I am smothering in this sleeping bag when I pull the top partially closed to keep in the heat.This is a nine bag for warmer temperatures (for me - no cooler than 40 degrees) and for recreational campers (i.e.:  you drive to a site and pitch a tent) however in my opinion, it is too thick to make it practical when you are hiking and you are trying to conserve space while carrying your other gear and it's not as warm as mummy sleeping bags.  In addition, the catching of the zipper drives me a little crazy.

My kids enjoy making these clings but I personally hate the mess.  Once the gel is poured into the mold, the tiny jar needs cleaned out.  You have to use paper towels to wipe out the interior and the lids however they are such teeny tiny containers that they are difficult to clean (and they have to be cleaned before you make another batch).  DO NOT make the mistake that I did by throwing the jars in hot soapy water to clean them - this just makes even more of a mess as the gel residue gets slick and simply balls up on the plastic and is almost impossible to remove.  You can also simply let the residue harden in the jars and then peal it out - I find that is the easiest solution when we are finished using this game.The instructions claim that the materials that made the clings could stain.  We only use this product under a piece of large flat cardboard.Once the cling gel is made, it sets up quickly so kids have to be really quick about pouring the gel into the mold.  The instructions claim that it must be used in 5-minutes but I think it's significantly less than that.  When we tried to make 3 colors to swirl the colors in several molds, the first color we made was already half-way hardened in the jar after all 3 colors were made (which was under 3 minutes - and the hardened color was then unusable).  Each jar of cling gel is enough for only one of the included molds.  Swirling colors is really a "learned" technique.  We've tried it several times and the results have been rather ugly but filling a mold half-way with one color and then a different color for the next half looks pretty nice (we just let the colors gently blend in the middle by merely running together).Filling the jars with the 2 mixtures to create the clings is difficult as the first gel that you squeeze in the tube is clear.  You're therefore squeezing this CLEAR liquid into a tiny CLEAR jar until it reaches the "fill-point" which is identified with CLEAR lettering and a CLEAR ridged line of where you need to stop (do you get my drift?).  I feel like I need to use a lighted magnifying glass to help my kids accurately fill the jars and even when you add the "color" gel, it sinks to the bottom so you are still trying to gauge if you've added enough of the colored mixture by assessing if the clear liquid has risen to the next letter and line which is (you guessed it) more CLEAR lettering (Agh.......if only they included bottles that had black lines on them so you didn't have to squint to see the fill lines).It's an interesting concept but it's a rarity to get the clings to remove from the molds without having slightly torn edges.  Having said that, they are not "perfect" clings but my kids think they are AMAZING and immediately placed them on our windows throughout the house and in their bedrooms.  They cling well to windows and you can rinse them off when they get dusty (or if you drop them on the floor and they pick up lint) however the longer they are hung on the windows, the less flexible they become and they loss some of their cling stickiness.  They tear REALLY easily and I actually ripped one in half while trying to re-position it on our window.I should also note that my kit was missing one of the jar lids so Crayola's quality assurance is slipping a bit (you can't use the jars without a lid so we have to rotate and share lids).  I only note this for information purposes - this problem didn't negatively impact my rating.The refill kits for the clings is pretty expensive (like half the price of the toy itself).  Additionally, there is no way to store everything back in the box after it is assembled and you cannot remove the orange "activator chamber" (the directions suggest that once it snaps in place that removing it will probably break it) so it doesn't fit in the box well which could lead to some pieces getting lost.  Sigh.....I really wish that manufactures would consider permanent storage (sturdier and slightly larger boxes) when they package toys that have many pieces so they could conveniently be placed back in the box.

This operates like a glorified magnetic drawing board.  It didn't take but a week before this toy had dent impressions on the screen and some of the magnetic filament was permanently marked on the bottom of the screen and could not be erased.  The small computerized screen (black imagery on a gray pixel background) is fairly hard to see since it does not light up (and it's very difficult to see in low-light).  The crisp images on all the photos is an over-representation of the clarity of the images that you'll see.  There are buttons for multiple activities (lessons, drawing to music, guess the picture).  Unfortunately, many of the spoken directions or instructions for the lessons are so long that by the time this is finished, my niece (who is almost 4) totally lost interest in the activity.  This is not a stand-alone system where the device recognized right and wrong answers - you'll need to shadow your child while they are involved in the lessons to ensure they are accurately following the instructions (this isn't a complaint - merely an observation).  My niece did like the drawing to music feature.  A pack of stencils is included with this product for children to practice tracing images and these stencils are stored in the back.  The 2 magnets that came with the game also fit securely in their slots so they wouldn't easily fall out.  With all the "high-tech" educational technology that is available for kids - these activity centers seem really primitive.  If I were considering buying something like this, I'd probably pass on the ineffective low-tech computerized aspect and opt for a better quality magnetic table for drawing.

This fold up design allows young users to help when carrying their equipment to and from the field (it's very lightweight).  Assembly is easy.  Once the 2-piece blue base is put together and the bendable rubber hinges are attached, you CANNOT take the two pieces apart to store it back in the box (if you were interested in doing that).  When folded up, the bat and tee fit inside the base and the balls fit somewhat snugly in the ball openings.To lock the 2-piece blue base into its open position, you turn a plastic knob clockwise to lock the base in the open position and counter-clockwise to unlock it.  The image of the lock which shows which direction to turn the knob (clockwise or counter-clockwise) is almost impossible to see because the color all blends together (its blue on blue - you really can't see it unless you tilt it to the light).  In addition, when you fold these two pieces to turn it into the carrying case it wants to stick in the open position and one of the two latches on my product was loose and it wouldn't stay locked when it was in the fold-away position.As previously mentioned, once this fold away batting tee is assembled, it will no longer fit in the cardboard box.  I would have much rather had this product arrive assembled (which would have only required the box to be about 1-/1/2" wider but it could have also been about 3" shorter.  That way you would have the option of keeping the sturdy box, fold everything up, and then place the folded unit inside the box during longer storage period (such as through winter to keep it clean).This is an average batting tee set with an above average price tag (I would have pegged the price to be around $12-15- it's actually double that).  The brightly colored tee screws into the blue base and if your batter misses the ball and hits the tee - it's going to tilt over because the base is not weighted (not a complaint - just an observation).  The MLB sticker on the bat was peeling off right out of the box so the bat will be without its sticker in very short order because what kid can resist pulling at something that is peeling off (I've certainly never met any).  This is simply not worth the bloated price of $30 and unless the price reduces, I would recommend that you look at different models as I think you'll be disappointed (you can probably find the Little Tikes T-Ball set for half this price at most Department stores - without it being on sale).Good luck shopping and PLAY BALL!

This software is fairly easy to use and installation was fast with the included disk.  Although not all the features in this software are intuitive - once you do figure them out, it makes sense and is easy to replicate.The biggest new features include text wrap and and "Magic Move" tools. There are on-line tutorials if you are on the fence as to whether this software is for you before you make the commitment to buy.  Text wrapping is a cool feature where your text instantly wraps inside any chosen shape.  The biggest drawback to the text wrap is that there is not a spell check.  Magic Move feature allows users to select what you want to move (or delete) and the software will fill in the background with the simple click of a button.  It takes a little practice to get the hang of how to use this feature but once you figure it out - the result is pretty cool.  In cases where you have the perfect picture "except for....." you now have more editing power to truly achieve that perfect image by sliding subjects closer together, removing unwanted distractions (i.e.: maybe the dog photo bombed your picture, etc).I like this software.  If your editing is basic and you don't think you have the need for text wrap or magic move - you might want to consider the prior version of this software (it'll cost less yet still have most of the quality editing features that you'll like want and need).

Once again.....what was old is new again (my 11-yr old loves this binder).  This is a nice conversation piece for young/new star war fans.  It really is cool that rather than simply having images of the main Star Wars characters, that the images represented are image outlines that include an assortment of descriptive words for each respective character (i.e.: for the image of Yoda, his face is made up with the words: Great Jedi, Master, Yoda, light saber, Force, leader, warrior, and many more).This binder is basic but it serves the purpose.  Although it is only 1.5" it holds A LOT of paper and significantly stretches.  Right now, it is holding 3, 70-sheet spiral notebooks and there is still a lot of room to hold more paper if need be.  There are folders on both the inside flaps that securely hold papers.This binder has been used for several weeks now by a 6th grader who is rather hard on his school supplies - It is holding up beautifully.

This is a heat and serve soup - it does NOT require you to add any additional water.  The carton easily tears open (you don't need scissors - simply squeeze the 4 corners together and then tear along the perforated line).The taste however is very bland.  It has 200 mg LESS sodium than original Campbell's Chicken Noodle.  Considering however that each serving still has 690 mg of sodium (which I still think is a lot) - this soup was tasteless and everyone in our family was searching for the salt and pepper to add more seasoning.

This shirt offers a classic flannel look but to achieve the crisp look in the photos - you'll definitely need to touch this up with an iron after EVERY wash.  To achieve the least wrinkles, this shirt should be laundered and dried until about 80% dry - then hung up (however you'll still have wrinkles - just less).  The material is fairly lightweight.If a slightly mussed shirt doesn't bother you,or if you are okay with pulling out the iron to get a more pressed look, this shirt is a good choice.  The sleeves are also a bit on the short side - I ordered an XL for my 6'2" husband and the sleeves just reach his wrists (it truthfully looks a teeny bit too small for him).The color isn't quite as nice as the picture illustrates.  The color is more of a grayish-blue - not the crisp blue in the photos.

This shirt would have been a 5-star product if is were a bit more wrinkle free.  It is a classic style but to achieve the crisp look in the photos - you'll need to touch this up with an iron after every wash.  To achieve the least wrinkles, this shirt should be laundered and dried until about 80% dry - then hung up.If a slightly mussed shirt doesn't bother you, or if you are okay with pulling out the iron occasionally to get a more pressed look, this shirt is a great choice.  I think it looks great on my son - even when it's a bit wrinkled.The red color of the images on Amazon.com are also a bit over-saturated.  It's a really nice color of red but it's not as cardinal red as the images illustrate.

Excellent value.  Wrangler jeans have greatly improved the look of their jeans and pants.  The material is soft and of medium weight.  I washed and dried them and they did not shrink however they wrinkle more so than Wrangler denim jeans.  My son doesn't mind the informal wrinkled look (which saves me some ironing) however I do touch them up if he wears them to church.  The material irons very easily and quickly.The instep for size 16 is 27-1/2 inches.  The waist circumference when the pants are buttoned is 34." There are red tabs on the inside to cinch up the waist if the fit is a little big.  The bottom of the leg openings are generous with a 21" circumference (my son hates jeans that are too tight around the legs).  The material is 100% cotton and it does not stretch very much.These cargo pants look really nice - it they only came out the the dryer with no wrinkles - they'd be a 5 star product.

This is a sizable label.  Since these are not meant for use in the printer, I'm okay with the 4 x 6 size (you'll receive 2 labels per sheet).I personally find that I have limited applications for this type of label.  Chalk is a rather chunky writing instrument and I simply couldn't achieve any type of salvageable printing with traditional chalk (the letters would be too large). These labels definitely work best with chalkboard markers (which is not the same as dry eraser markers).Although they are quoted to be "write, erase, and re-use," the re-use factor, at least from the perspective of continuing to stick it somewhere is really marginal.  These are removable labels however once removed, they loose a lot of their stickiness.

This battery operated turtle is so loud!  When you push the button on the bottom and the turtle begins to move it's legs and crawls (or swims) it sounds like a cheap wind-up toy.  I'm actually stunned by the overwhelming positive reviews of this toy with no mention to how loud it is.We have owned several Little live pets (and we loved them); this however is by far the worse sounding.  I like that it's waterproof and you could put it in the bath tub or swimming pool however there is nothing realistic about this turtle since it emits such a large mechanical gear winding sound.  It looks adorable however however it's appearance is greatly over-shadowed by the grinding mechanical noise when it moves around.If your child is young (age 3 to 5) or has never owned any Little Live Pets then perhaps they won't mind the ruckus this toy makes.  My 9-year old lost interest in this really quickly and suggested that we give it to her 4-year old niece.The plastic tank is well designed and the only thing you really need to be mindful of is to not fill it too full with water or it will leak out the vent holes on the top when the turtle begins splashing around.  The lid can also be a diving area when it is fully opened.You can get this toy in a variety of colors: pink, green, light blue, dark blue with a star on its back and yet a darker blue with swirls on its back.  The turtle is small (roughly 5" long and 2-1/2" wide) and the swim tank doesn't take up a lot of room (8" L x 6" W x 4" high - not including the height of the handle if it's upright).I personally think there are a lot of mechanical pets on the market that are far superior to this one. Having said that - if your child loves turtles, they may think this is the best toy ever and if it is priced under under or around $20 then I think you're getting a toy that is in line with the quality.

Nice concept however the product I received may have been defective.Two cars are included, one with a girl driver and one with a boy.  The car with the girl driver consistently drives off the track prior to reaching the bottom (it must be weighted incorrectly or perhaps the wheels are misaligned however when comparing the cars side by side - they don't look any different so it's puzzling why this one doesn't work properly).  The boy driver stays on the track without any problems (which of course gives my son and husband great pleasure and makes my daughter irritated).  In addition, the top handle that is twisted to collapse or expand this product does not stand upright on my produce - it tilts at a significant angle therefore I also believe that this piece is defective.The process of collapsing and expanding this product is not quite as intuitive nor as smooth as other Play-Stow-Go products.  You basically put the toy on a flat surface and pull upward on the handle (while holding down on the base) and rotating the handle clockwise.  You'll hear clicks as you are doing this and as the Amazon product illustrations clearly outlines, there are 4 sets of red arrows that you want to align.  Once this occurs - your ramp is fully extended and ready to play with.  You will twist counterclockwise to prepare the toy for storage.  The cars "park" on their side and securely rest on 2 tabs to keep them in place while in storage.  The images of the boy and girl (or the opposite side which are stickers of kaleidoscopes) rotate as the cars race down the track.The toy also incorporated a "press and go launcher" at the top of the ramp.  Users can place the rear wheels on the yellow launcher pad and then press the yellow button and the car will race down the ramp.  There is a gate at the end of the ramp so toddlers have the option of having the gate down to stop their cars at the bottom, or have the gate up so the car continues to race forward.Noteworthy also is that there are several stickers on this toy (each car has stickers on each side and there are 2 stickers on the top handle) so if you like to occasionally soak toys in a water/bleach solution to sterilize them, you won't want to do this as it will eventually deteriorate the stickers.Had my product not had the defective car and if the handle wasn't defective, I would have rated this a 4 star product.  It simply doesn't have the same sturdiness of some of the other Play-Stow-Go products.  The portability of this product however is wonderful and I really look forward to seeing how other toys are being re-created to incorporate space saving ideas.I included a photo of my product so buyers can see how the top handle/garage wall leans.  If your product does this, I believe that it is defective and you should return it for replacement as all the images online and in the instruction manual illustrate this part of the garage as standing straight up (not leaning).

The collapsible design of this product makes it very appealing for parents on the go.  All of the plastic shapes fit inside of the sorter and the kitty head flips down so they do not fall out when being transported.  There is also a handle incorporated that also looks like a tail.  There are no stickers so when you need to wash off this product - you can simply soak it in the sink with bleach and water to sterilize it  without worrying that sticker embellishments are going to wash off.  When expanded, the flexible rubber sorter base is almost 4-1/2 inches high.This is an excellent toy for toddlers and it's suitable for boys and girls.  The pieces are brightly colored and each of the 4 shapes is a two piece unit that can be either put together and placed in the sorter as one piece, or separated and inserted individually.  In addition, each piece has a textured image of an an animal on top with their corresponding food on the other matching piece.The 2 piece connectable shapes include:Light blue circles with a kitty and fishPink hearts with a mouse and cheesePurple triangles with a bunny and carrotYellow stars with dog and boneThe bottom snaps open and as your child's fine motor skills develop - they will eventually be able to open this on their own to retrieve their pieces after they have sorted them.This is an excellent toy that is educational and offers convenient collapsible storage for parents who will not only appreciate the space saving features but will also appreciate that all the pieces fit inside the kitty.

Lorde and her music have fascinated me for months. There is a certain quality to her music and persona that is compellingly mysterious. She first piqued my interest when I learned that she was mocking Bieber and his kin, then caught my ears with her song Buzzcut Season (this soulful sound is coming from an 18-y-o?!), and then once I saw her ecstatic dancing in the video for Yellow Flicker Beat my attention was now fully rapt. Who is this person and what is she trying to do with our attention???Before I start proffering opinions, its important that we lay some facts on the table:-- Lorde is 18. There is some skepticism about her age because she does not seem that young, but whats undeniable is that she was in high school until last year.-- Lorde is outspoken about popular music and societal values more generally. Ive already mentioned the Bieber criticism. She also did a unique/cool thing of posting a photo of one of her magazine glam shots next to an un-photoshopped version of her un-made-up face (with less-than-pristine skin), presumably to say something about the unfair expectations for beauty we impose on [young] women via celebrities.-- Lordes music is largely written by *her* (in collaboration with Joel Little), which is noteworthy because nearly every other popular musician outsources their songwriting to dance-pop factories.-- Lordes lyrics mention almost none of the things typical of popular music: I dont remember hearing the word boy in any of her songs, and she rarely even sings about love. Even dancing only comes up in the context of alone.Those are the things we can agree upon. Its now going to get messier as we dive into the question that haunts me.What exactly is Lorde trying to do with our attention? I dont know. I cant tell. Someone please explain it to me. All I can do is eliminate possibilities.She is clearly not just trying to earn the entertainment dollar like other popular musicians, because otherwise she would have outsourced her songwriting to the dance-pop factories. Neither does she seem to be trying to break any musical ground. Although she is critical of Bieber et al., and although her lyrics are very atypical of popular music, her sound is very much consistent with the electronic/hip-hoppy/soul-singing feel that predominates today. She doesnt even seem to be trying to shake or inspire us. Her music is pleasant and enjoyable but doesnt seem to aim for moving or provoking us. She doesnt even seem to be trying to say anything in particular. If there is a message or core belief that runs through her songs, I havent found it.Its clear that Lorde has seen the vapidness of popular music and popular culture more generally, and has shown the courage to criticize it and to forge a different path. But until someone convinces me otherwise, Im going to assume that Lorde doesnt currently know what path she is trying to forge. She knows she wants to divert from the Bieber path, but she doesnt seem to know in what direction she wants to head. It seems that shes just going with the flow, making music because she likes music and shes good at it and because why not? Which is perfectly acceptable for an 18-y-o. We cant reasonably expect an 18-y-o to have figured out her core values/beliefs and to know what to do with the giant responsibility that has been thrust upon her via her popularity as a young person. But then again, we cant reasonably expect an 18-y-o to be as independent-minded or as soulful-sounding as Lorde, either. ("I am only as young as the minute is full of it.")The bottom line is that I believe Lorde is awesome and awesomely talented, and I love that she is independent enough (at 18!) to mock Bieber et al. and to write highly atypical song lyrics, but her directionlessness distresses me. It distresses me because I believe that if she had a direction (an anchor, a purpose, a core set of beliefs/values), she could have Madonna-level influence to drag us as a society away from Bieber values. But she can't drag us anywhere unless/until she knows where she's headed.We need you to save us from Bieber values, Lorde. Please find a direction. We are counting on you.

Scott Adams is brilliant and entertaining and persuasive and successful, and I believe he had generous intentions with this book. He wanted to give back by sharing brilliant advice about how to hack your life to be successful like him and thereby live a better life. I am not being facetious when I call Scott Adams or his advice brilliant. He truly has a top-percentile IQ, and a lot of his advice truly is brilliant (see, e.g., systems vs. goals).
