In this film, which has been named to several top-10 lists (including Ebert's) and which has been called Ozu's masterpiece, we see a contrast between modern, post-war self-involved "busy" people and the glowing version of Ozu's ideal woman - and person - in Noriko (Setsuko Hara), a woman who is infinitely kind and self-sacrificing. One novelist said of Hara, "We would sigh or let out a great breath from the depths of our hearts, for what we felt was precisely this: Can it be possible that there is such a woman in this world?"Like all of Ozu's films, Tokyo Story's pacing is "calm," and important events are often not shown on screen, only implied. The camera never moves so as to elevate the feeling of calmness, which is quite unlike what you might be used to seeing in your motion pictures.It's remarkable how relatable and moving this film is after 60 years, especially since it originated from a culture that couldn't have been more different than my own. But if you aren't familiar/comfortable with meditative films, I might suggest that before jumping into this film you get your feet wet with films like Gates of Heaven or The White Diamond, which are equally as meditative but have more modern pacing and camera work.

Imagine this: A 28-year-old steals a 35 mm camera from a film school, heads to the South American jungle, and, with a miniscule budget, convinces 450 actors and extras - many of whom do not speak his language - to not only endure jungle heat and insects and sleep in a communal barn but also to trek over a muddy mountain with alpacas and horses and with heavy equipment on their backs and to board small, hand-crafted rafts on a river that, if you fell in, you'd be sucked under and killed. And imagine that this 28-year-old, after making up the script as he goes along, shooting most of the scenes only once, and editing the film in only a month, ends up creating what Roger Ebert named one of the 10 best films, period.The story of the making of this film is almost as insane as the film itself. On their way to the jungle, the cast and crew were at the last minute diverted from a plane that ended up crashing, killing 90+ people. (28 years later, Werner made a documentary about the sole survivor called Wings of Hope.) Once there, resources were extremely scarce. Werner sometimes had to sell his boots or his wristwatch just to get breakfast. The total budget was $370,000 (or about $1.9 million in today's dollars) and one-third of that went to the lead actor, Klaus Kinski. Kinski, by the way, was about as mad and uncontrollable on the set as he appears in the film. One night he became so infuriated at the noise created by the partying extras that he randomly fired three shots into the barn. He was lucky he didn't kill anyone. Later he hit someone so hard in the head with his sword that had the person not been wearing an iron helmet his skull would have been split.When Werner was asked how he dealt with all this when he was only 28, he responded, "I had a clear perspective and I was fortified with enough philosophy to get through it."That perspective/philosophy is not only what allows Werner to complete such ambitious films, it's also what makes his films worth watching. There is a reason he went through all the jungle-imposed trouble. Said Werner, "In this film, human beings are put to the real test. You can learn more about ourselves this way than from a film that takes place in a car, a restaurant, and on the telephone. The purpose of the jungle is to explore what is the bottom line of our existence, and how do we behave under particular strains and stresses, and then you gain much deeper insights into our very nature."In this film (and in all of his films), the jungle is not just a scenic backdrop, it is a character itself. It causes the other characters to go insane and it, too, grows increasingly insane. But Werner doesn't consider the jungle exotic. "It's just another forest."What's particularly hypnotizing about the movie is the images. Images like the woman in the royal gown walking straight into the jungle, or like the 400 monkeys scurrying around a raft full of corpses, or like the unendurable silence that everyone knows means death, or like the horse being shoved off the raft and then standing on the shoreline, perfectly still but slowly disappearing. The film alternates between spontaneous documentary-like shots and highly-stylized frozen still-lifes. Instead of showing close ups of the actors' faces, it shows characters from behind so that we have to project emotions into them. It uses a choir organ that sounds vaguely but not quite like the human voice. And the bird calls are carefully timed to maximize tension.As much as I adore this movie, it doesn't sit well with me that this is Herzog's best-known film (outside of Grizzly Man). At times, it has the feel of a movie created by a 28-year-old. Especially in comparison to his later movies, there is more blood and action and dark humor and overt metaphors. Fitzcarraldo is, in plot, a very similar film, but since it was created 10 year later it is substantially more mature. Please don't let this be the only Herzog film you see. (Psst, check out The White Diamond and Encounters at the End of the World.)---Here are some other things to help you appreciate this film:* Werner kept telling Kinski to "move like a crab." Kinski did this to great effect--genuinely frightening most of the cast.* Since there was such a small budget, Werner did all the costume design himself, with "help" (quotes deserved) from Kinski.* The corpse shown in the 50th minute is a real mummy. It is extremely fragile so bringing it to the set was a real challenge. They actually purchased an extra plane ticket for the mummy and sat it next to Werner's brother on the plane.* Werner: "I've never storyboarded anything in my life. I think it's a disease of Hollywood."* At one point, over an artistic disagreement of how his character should behave, Kinski threatened to leave the set. Werner threatened in return that if he turned around, there would be 8 bullets in his back. He was serious. Kinski was well-behaved "for the next 10 days."* The same stolen camera that he used for this film he used in 8 other films. But he doesn't like to consider it "theft." "It was just a necessity--I had some sort of natural right for a camera, a tool to work with."* Much of this information comes from the commentary available on the DVD. Highly recommended.

These BiC's, which made their first American appearance in 1959, were designed exceptionally if not bizarrely well. And I don't mean in a quaint, historical way. These pens respect principles of space, form, structure, density, and gravity. Because of their hexagonal shape, they require minimal plastic while also retaining a surprising strength (try snapping one), and the hexagonal grip points give the pens impressive writing stability. A tiny hole drilled in the barrel's body keeps the air pressure the same both inside and outside the pen. Gravity feeds the thick ink down a tube to a free-spinning ball bearing that was manufactured within a fraction of a micron of accuracy. The result is that when the pen is pressed against paper, the ink slides out cleanly and, well,... perfectly. It's not only one of the most inexpensive pens, it's also probably the most efficient pen, with a single pen able to write over 100,000 words (or about 2 novels). A true masterpiece of design. I'm not the only one who thinks so. They have their own exhibit in the Museum of Modern Art.This particular pen is a slight variation on the original, with a slightly wider foundation and using slightly more ink (hence the "Bold"). It's still great, you just probably wouldn't be able to write 2 novels with it.

***The point/mood of the movie***The [intensely dark] mood and point of this movie I think is best summarized in a monologue given by a priest-actor at a funeral in the 107th minute:"Everything is more complicated than you think. You only see a tenth of what is true. There are a million little strings attached to every choice you make. You can destroy your life every time you choose. But maybe you won't know for 20 years, and you may never ever trace it to its source. And you only get one chance to play it out. Just try and figure out your own divorce. And they say there is no fate---but there *is.* It's what you create. And even though the world goes on for eons and eons, you are only here for a fraction of a fraction of a second. Most of your time is spent being dead or not yet born. But while alive, you wait in vain, wasting years, for a phone call or a letter or a look from someone or something to make it all right. And it never comes, or it seems to but it doesn't really. So you spend your time in vague regret or vaguer hope that something good will come along, something to make you feel connected, something to make you feel whole, something to make you feel loved. And the truth is, I feel so angry. And the truth is, I feel so f'ing sad. And the truth is, I felt so f'ing hurt for so f'ing long, and for just as long I've been pretending I'm okay, just to get along. Just for---I don't know why. Maybe because no one wants to hear about my misery, because they have their own. Well, f everybody. Amen."The real point of the movie, though, is what Sammy says minutes earlier: "I've watched you forever, Caden, but you've never really looked at anyone other than yourself."---***The point of the surrealism***This film, while ambitiously trying to capture all of reality in 120 minutes, injects a hefty dose of absurdity and surrealism. The point, I think, is actually to make it feel realer by suckerpunching you with some unconscious yet poignant images. David Foster Wallace said it best when describing David Lynch's Blue Velvet:"Blue Velvet captured something crucial about the way the U.S. present acted upon our nerve endings, something crucial that couldn't be analyzed or reduced to a system of codes or aesthetic principles or workshop techniques. The movie helped me realize that first-rate experimentalism is a way not to `transcend' or `rebel against' the truth but actually to *honor* it. It brought home that the very most important artistic communications take place at a level that not only isn't intellectual but isn't even fully conscious, that the unconscious's true medium isn't verbal but imagistic, and that whether the images are Realistic or Postmodern or Expressionistic or Surreal or what-the-hell-ever is less important than whether they feel true, whether they ring psychic cherries in the communicatee."---***The effect of the absurdity/surrealism***There were two scenes that especially rung my psychic cherries. One was in the 39th minute when Caden explains his theatre ambitions to Hazel as if to impress her, and yet she couldn't look more bored or uninterested. It was both hilarious and distressingly sad. Here's the quote:"The idea is to do a massive theatre piece--y'know, uncompromising, uh, honest. [Hazel's cheeks deflate, her eyes sag.] Here's what I think theatre is [Hazel looks down to find her tea, sips, raises her eyebrows in faux interest]: It's, um, the beginning of thought. It's, uh, the truth not yet spoken. [She looks back to the table, purses her lips in faux respect.] It's what a man feels like after he's been clocked in the jaw. It's love, in all its messiness. [She rests her head on her chin, then looks to see the source of the faint chatter behind her.] I want all of us, players and patrons alike, to soak in the communal bath of it. The mikfah, is what Jews call it. [Looks back again.] Because we're all in the same water, after all, soaking in our, uh, very... menstrual blood. And nocturnal emissions. This is what I want to try. [She finally shows genuine excitement because her soup has arrived!]"The other cherry-ringing scene, easily the saddest of the film, was in the 101st minute when Caden goes to find his grown daughter. He watches her tattooed naked body dispassionately dance and blow bubbles behind acrylic glass. She doesn't recognize him. She doesn't even notice him. "Olive, it's Daddy," he says as he knocks on the glass, growing increasingly more frustrated that she remains perfectly apathetic to his existence. He screams desperately, pounds the glass, and is escorted out. She keeps dispassionately dancing and blowing bubbles.----***In comparison to other similar-yet-not films***I've recently been on a kick of watching those films that Roger Ebert has declared the very best, the ones that seemingly try to and mostly succeed at capturing the enormity of life within their tiny bounds. It was really interesting to watch this film after watching Gates of Heaven (a documentary about a pet cemetery) and The Tree Of Life (an even more ambitious film than this one) because the message, at core, is eerily similar if not exactly the same while the approach and mood is so dramatically different. If you were only going to watch one of those three, my strongest recommendation would be Gates of Heaven.

If you still think that John Mayer is a hokey teen-pop star who sings about puppy love amid a sea of blankets, then you urgently need to give him another listen.This album is quite good. "Queen of California" is probably the best track-- its final 75 seconds of complexly layered guitar will make you melt. "If I Ever Get Around to Living" has the rare and gratifying combination of delicacy and soulfulness. "Walt Grace's Submarine Test" is one of the best story songs since Bob Dylan's "Boots of Spanish Leather."This album has more of a folksy and country taste than his others, but it's subtle and varied. There is pedal steel on three tracks (Queen of California, Shadow Days, and Whiskey Whiskey Whiskey) and lap steel on another (Born and Raised). I don't recall if this is JM's first time using steel guitar, but he uses it well. In fact, my only complaint is that he doesn't use it often enough.Continuum is still his best album, and it isn't really close, but Born & Raised is a worthy and timely addition. Given the rapid musical desertification that is occurring at the hands of dance-pop glitz infested radio, Born & Raised comes as an intensely quenching and relieving swig of cool water. We should support this album for that reason alone-- to show that we still crave popular music that has soul.P.S. - If you adore this album, then you'd probably also adore a similarly folksy and steel-guitar-y album from Ray LaMontagne: God Willin' & The Creek Don't Rise.

It's hard to believe how obscure this series is given that it had 9 episodes on Comedy Central and given that it stars Zach Galifianakis. And especially given how rib-hurtingly hilarious it is. This was and remains the funniest series I've seen. Period. Only _The Sarah Silverman Program_ and _Community_ have come close.If you like awkwardness-based humor, and if you like subtle non-verbal humor (facial expressions and voice inflections and mannerisms), then I feel confident saying that Dog Bites Man will make you pee your pants.

It's hard to believe how obscure this series is given that it had 9 episodes on Comedy Central and given that it stars Zach Galifianakis. And especially given how rib-hurtingly hilarious it is. This was and remains the funniest series I've seen. Period. Only _The Sarah Silverman Program_ and _Community_ have come close.If you like awkwardness-based humor, and if you like subtle non-verbal humor (facial expressions and voice inflections and mannerisms), then I feel confident saying that Dog Bites Man will make you pee your pants.

Except for Dog Bites Man, no TV series has induced more rib-hurting laughter in me. I adore this show.In my humble opinion, Sarah Silverman is freaking hilarious. What she says is funny, but it's *how* she says it - subtle inflections and mannerisms - that makes her extraordinarily funny.And if you think that she is spewing vulgarities and bigotry just to get a few shock-giggles, you aren't paying enough attention. She is more morally-serious than you probably realize. She does these things to magnify absurdity--to make them ironic and dumb.And Brian and Steve... oh my, what a pair. Other than Troy and Abed on _Community_, I haven't seen a better dynamic between two characters.You won't find many (any?) shows as hilarious, conceptually interesting, and risky. May you make many more TV shows, Sarah Silverman.

America's conversation about vaccines is complex, involving not only medical risks and benefits but also ideological beliefs about parental choice and the limits of government. It's also culturally interesting that the "medical and public health establishment" is treated with such skepticism by the broader public, and how the emotionally charged activism of non-experts (parents, celebrities, politicians) is competing with - and largely winning against - the dry and logical thinking of experts.P.S. - All Frontline programs are available for free online, including this one. There is a Wikipedia page ("List of Frontline (PBS) episodes") with links to and brief descriptions of each.

Without trying to be, this is one of the most stomach-churning programs I've watched. It leaves you feeling utterly helpless in the face of enormous scientific and ethical complications. I understand the issues a lot better after watching this 60-minute program, but at the same time "understanding them better" just means realizing that there is no simple answer.P.S. - All Frontline programs are available for free online, including this one. There is a Wikipedia page ("List of Frontline (PBS) episodes") with links to and brief descriptions of each.

These boys are onto something. You can tell by the crazed looks on the concert-goers' faces.You can also tell by their finances. As of June 2012, according to the chairman and chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment UK, One Direction represents a $50 million business empire. Aside from their music sales, the band has already published three books and the top-selling calendar of all time. And they have commercial endorsements with Pokmon, Nokia, HarperCollins, and Hasbro.So, people - and in particular, girls - love them. And that's not necessarily bad. Certainly you'd rather have your daughter loving One Direction than, say, Pitbull. Their image is clean and wholesome. I would use the term "puppy love" if I could do so uncondescendingly.And the band takes steps to ensure its parent-friendly image. Certainly you wouldn't want your daughter reading the steams-of-consciousness of 18-y-o boys on Twitter, but they've got that covered: A team of social media experts tweets on their behalf.The one thing that doesn't sit well with me is how manufactured the whole thing is. They don't make their own music, they don't tweet their own tweets. They don't dance or sing or just generally behave in the way any normal self-respecting 18-y-o male would. It's as if Clear Channel Broadcasting, Inc. handed us some carefully constructed characters singing carefully constructed songs to appeal to the young-female mp3-buying segment in a very specific and primal way.That makes me fidgety.

You should watch this program. Why? As Jewel would say in the L'Oreal commercial, "Because you're worth it."Here was the synopsis that convinced me to watch it: "Each year, legions of ad people, copywriters, market researchers, pollsters, consultants, and even linguists--most of whom work for one of six giant companies--spend billions of dollars and millions of man-hours trying to determine how to persuade consumers what to buy, whom to trust, and what to think. ... This 90-minute documentary explores how the cultures of marketing and advertising have come to influence not only what Americans buy, but also how they view themselves and the world around them."Although I generally liked it, I was disappointed that very little attention was paid to the last part about how "persuaders" influence how we see ourselves. Most attention was paid to the behind-the-scenes stuff of how marketing works and some of the science/philosophy of it.I think to summarize it in one sentence, it would be exactly what the guy said at the very end of the program: "The secret of all persuasion is to induce the person to persuade himself." It's all about appealing to the unconscious/emotion/reptilian brain--making you feel (rather than think) that the product/idea/politician/whatever serves your own selfish primal desires.One marketing guru formed his marketing philosophy by studying why people join cults. The conclusion? People join both cults and brands for two reasons: (1) to belong, (2) to make meaning. "We need to figure out what the world is all about, and we need the company of others. It's as simple as that."My favorite moment, by far, is at the beginning of Chapter 4 "Science of Selling" when a market researcher probes a poor guy with a very awkward question: "I've got a whole list of emotions here. I just want you to tell me yes or no as to whether you feel that emotion when you're eating white bread."...Accepting?"The guy's eyebrows furl. He pauses. Looks to the side."Do you feel accepting when you're eating white bread?," the market researcher asks again, as if the guy didn't understand the question.Another 2-second delay and then the guy finally answers, "Yeah. I would say yes," in the least convincing possible way.----P.S. - All Frontline programs are available for free online. There is a Wikipedia page ("List of Frontline (PBS) episodes") with links to and brief descriptions of all of them.

I tried to think of how to summarize 4 hours of programming in one sentence. This is the best I could do: People did (and continue to do) things that were legal, rather than things that were right.As usual with Frontline, they give us clear explanations and objective(ish) reporting. I appreciate the ambition and man-hours that went into this program, I only wish that in 4 hours it could have been a bit more insightful or surprising.P.S. - All Frontline programs are available for free online, including this one. There is a Wikipedia page ("List of Frontline (PBS) episodes") with links to and brief descriptions of each.

Trivia Q: What do the following things have in common?:* Monsterama* The Girls Next Door (and its spinoffs)* Empire of Dreams: The Story of the Star Wars Trilogy* America's Book of Secrets* Bridget's Sexiest Beaches* Ancient AliensAnswer: They were all created by Kevin Burns.Kevin Burns (not to be confused with Ken Burns) is a master of the art of TV documentaries. He is one of the most successful men in Beverly Hills, having created over 100 TV documentaries in the past 17 years, and yet you probably know nothing about him.There is a line from his IMDB biography that I find mildly haunting: "After the sudden death of his father in 1988, Burns decided the time had come to seek his fortune in Los Angeles." I struggle to see how that logically follows. Why would the death of a father inspire Hollywood fortune-seeking?If his film credits are any indication, Burns is an unpretentious guy who loves monsters, celebrities, movies, and sex. (Who doesn't?) But what's fascinating about Burns is that he went from a fraternity president at a private boys' college in NY with a couple of highfalutin majors (English literature and history) to making TV documentaries about playgirls and aliens."It's all about good storytelling," Burns says in an interview with TV Week. "It has to be worth your time."All of this is interesting context from which to understand Ancient Aliens. It's created by a history major, yes, but it's also created by a guy who is an unabashed fortune-seeker.

Because the points are so subtle and the layers are so seemingly bottomless, this is the most intellectually challenging film I've seen.Roger Ebert picked Gates of Heaven as one of the 10 greatest films because "it is totally impenetrable. It is a mystery after 50 viewings that I have never solved. You can approach this film in a dozen different ways. It just doesn't have a bottom. And you can't decide, no matter how often you've seen it, if it's a comedy or a tragedy."Werner Herzog, a mentor to Errol Morris, literally ate his shoe in order to see this film get made. Here's how Werner described it: "It's not a film on pet cemeteries. It's a film on the family behind all that with all their failures and all their dreams and all their dramas. It's the only authentic film on love and emotions in Late Capitalism, and maybe it's the only authentic film on loss of emotions and distortion of feelings and degeneration of feelings. It's a very, very sad film, and very purely done. It's an extremely pure film. And a very mature film. It's Errol Morris's very first film and it's a film of a very mature filmmaker."I'm glad this wasn't the first Errol Morris film I had seen simply because it's so immense and challenging that only through seeing his later films -- and in particular, Mr. Death and Tabloid -- could I understand, at least vaguely, what this film meant to him.

I got this album when it was first released 6 years ago, and I liked it--I thought it was good and pleasant and catchy. But I would not have described it nearly as glowingly as I do now. I think Disc 1 might be one of the best rock albums released so far this century. I can't think of a better one. Even with the songs that seem safe and relatively banal, like "Snow (Hey Oh)" and "Hump De Bump," there are magical stretches with so much complexity and energy that I can't help but to shut my eyes and Rock Out.

I got this book fully expecting to write a mean, sarcastic review. I envisioned leading off with an Onion-like headline: "The key to Good Living finally revealed: Secret discovered by two Los Angeles shrinks."Subtitle: "Secret now available on Amazon for price of a few cheeseburgers."This book, from the outside, appears to commit the most deplorable of self-help crimes: selling clichd half-truths to existentially anxious go-getters under the empty but marketable guise of "motivation"--telling people, for instance, that the bountiful gifts of the universe are theirs if they just use their mind as a magnet, and/or practice 4 simple exercises.This book, though, to my utter shock, not only isn't reprehensible, but also is very much worth reading.This is not to say that the book is without flaws. Even some glaring flaws. Namely, (1) syrupy and vague language, (2) sometimes relying too heavily on mystical thinking, and (3) overselling the "tools" as the focus of the book and the solution to all your problems. But when you dig down to the book's core message, it is non-obvious and persuasive and I'd even say _urgent_.The book ought to be re-named to something like, "How to stop seeing yourself as the world's protagonist, and why it matters." That's really what it's about. The authors tell you this directly, they answer all your nagging questions and concerns, and they give concrete ways to do it--namely, by giving you scripts (ones which've worked with their clients) and advising you when best to use them.The bottom line is that I strongly recommend this book unless you (like me) have trouble seeing past syrupy and vague language. In that case, check out David Foster Wallace's version: This Is Water.I put below what I thought were the most important points of the book.---Notes: (1) this does not include any of the actual "tools," which I think ought to be treated more as friendly tips, and (2) I put many of these points in my own words.* Beware of goals like power or wealth or status, or even goals like a loyal spouse or healthy children, simply because they are external. With these goals, you will be endlessly unsatisfied, always craving more. The only goals that matter (and, coincidentally, the only goals we can control) are internal. (p. 52; 162)* "Usually we think of love in a moralistic or religious context; we try to be loving because it's the "right" thing to do. But the abstract concept of "doing the right thing" isn't enough to change your behavior. ... I never tell patients to be loving because it's the right thing to do. I tell them to do it because it's in their self-interest. I remind them that they don't want to live in a state of rage--not because it's bad, but because it's painful and debilitating." (p. 85-86)* The authors criticize our usual notion of "love," which is felt only when another person is pleasing us. "You feel it for your child when he smiles at you adoringly, or your partner when she looks particularly attractive." Like children, we expect love to be effortless and immediate and instinctive, but the only kind of love that matters is independent of impulses. It takes work to be truly loving. (p. 78-80)* Until you can control your own mind, you will be immature. Simple as that. (p. 160)* What we call "spirituality" is just recognizing that there are things bigger than yourself, and the real value of it is that it's stronger than your impulses, so you are better-equipped to navigate the day-to-day tedium without getting hung up on petty desires or ways that you've been "wronged." (p. 90)* What we call "evil" is just the part of you that has an impulse to act out of pure self-interest without regard to anyone or anything that gets in the way. "This manifests itself in selfishness, greed, or, when your aims are thwarted, hatred or destructive rage." (p. 132)* Everyone wants to feel that as an individual we have value. But our immediate reaction is often to look outside of ourselves for evidence--for approval or validation. But when you crave the approval of others, you give them power over you. They become authority figures who define your value. (p. 108-9)* We are often uncomfortable "speaking out" because of what others might think of us. The danger of not speaking out, though, far beyond discomfort, is that you don't get to hear yourself. You don't get to find out who you are. (p. 123)* In our cosmology, it is either feed or be food. We see ourselves as alone against an uncaring universe. Feeling we won't be provided for, we become obsessed with controlling our future. (p. 151)* Normally we envision peace of mind as a resting state. But that isn't peace, it's passivity. Peace of mind takes work; it is an active state. (p. 162-3)* "Success is paralyzing for a simple reason. It makes you feel as if you did it all yourself. Ironically, the moment you claim all the credit for your success, you also have to take the blame for any future failure--and that's terrifying. This makes you risk-averse, less creative, and afraid to move forward with new ideas and new projects." (p. 165)* Everyone succumbs to worry, fearing that things are far beyond our control, and in a very primal way, we take refuge in the only activity that seems to offer a sense of power--thinking. The paradox is that that's exactly when our thoughts spiral into uncontrollable worry. (p. 171-2)* The fundamental danger of living in Late Capitalism is letting a consumer mentality seep into the depths of your psyche. If you let this happen, you will expect a reward for the slightest effort--or better, for no effort at all. And you will care only about what you get from the world, not about what you might add to it. (p. 204)

The cover of this book is amazing. A hefty man with a crew cut and a sleeveless shirt kneels to put his nose to the ground. He wraps his chubby hand around a small orange flower growing out of a weed growing out of gravel. He smells it. It's probably odorless. His imposing (and pale) right arm pushes on the ground to give him balance to prevent his nose from falling into the ground, and yet the same hand appears to rest on the ground almost limply.I'm not sure what the metaphor is, but it's overwhelming.Oh, the book? I think I spent more time staring at the cover than reading the pages underneath it. I was unable to get lifted into George Saunders's world. I read the first few chapters, skimmed the middle, and then read the last. It has all the elements that I normally love in a book - absurdity, humor, cultural observations, morality, heady prose - but there was something that prevented it from being compelling to me. Maybe it's because it's sometimes almost sci-fi heady and abstract, or maybe it's because I couldn't find a clear point or theme in the chapters--they seemed instead like cultural observation after cultural observation after cultural observation, without ever hammering a single observation persistently or deeply enough to strike a vein.

This book provides tough love that many of us 20-somethings need, which is best-summarized with the last sentences of the book:"As I gathered up my maps and turned to go, I hesitated and asked the ranger, 'Am I going to make it?'He looked at me and said, 'You haven't decided yet.'He was telling me what this book has been all about. The future isn't written in the stars. There are no guarantees. So claim your adulthood. Be intentional. Get to work. Pick your family. Do the math. Make your own certainty. Don't be defined by what you didn't know or didn't do.You are deciding your life right now."Reading this book, you get the sense that Meg Jay was gritting her teeth as she wrote it. She does her best to be sympathetic to the 20-something psyche, writing with all the delicacy she can muster, but you can still sense an underlying current of, "COME ON, PEOPLE, WHAT ARE YOU THINKING?!" That's good. We need that. We've been coddled for too long.If you are thinking of working at a coffee shop because that seems non-corporate, or going backpacking in Europe in order to "find yourself," or putting off marriage or children until you've finished grad school, then Meg Jay is talking to you, and you should listen.But there's one thing about this book that I found troubling: It has a rather Me-Against-the-World sentiment. In the epilogue, Meg Jay writes about her favorite sign, one posted at Rocky Mountain National Park that says MOUNTAINS DON'T CARE, meant to encourage preparedness against an uncaring wilderness. She views the world as out-to-get-you unless you are tenacious and strategic and forward-thinking. You've got to acquire all the resources you can as quickly as you can to ensure your safety before the world GETS YOU.She even views marriages and families this way, as resources, something to be acquired for safety's sake. She even suggests that we be "ambitious" in picking a good partner, and she advocates having classes and guidance counselors to help us pick a spouse much as we have them to pick a career.This book would have been more convincing if instead of emphasizing the importance of accruing-resources-before-it's-too-late, it emphasized that certain things are too important to be treated as "resources."

This is the only Errol Morris film that I will give less than 5 stars. It's hard to believe I'm going all the way down to 1. That needs explaining.This film could have been equally as good if not better than all the rest. Morris had heard about a rural town in Florida where people had been severing their limbs in order to receive insurance benefits. Certainly there's some substance there - something interesting - not just in the brutality or absurdity but in what it says about us inhabitants of Late Capitalism.But then once he got to Vernon, FL and started filming, he found extreme resistance-- he actually received death threats warning him against including anything related to limb-severing in the film. Understandably, he abandoned the storyline. The result is a movie that is literally about nothing.What's worse is that the movie ends up having a thick whiff of elitism. That's because Morris salvaged his funds by interviewing local eccentrics and including their goofiest quotes in the final cut. Because there're no events and no storyline, we don't get to see who the people really are; we only get to laugh at their surface personas. It's as though we're people-gazing from the sidewalk.  If this movie appeals to us at all, it appeals to the worst parts of us.This was the first Errol Morris movie I had seen and I was so un-smitten that it was years before I tried any of his other films, and, for me, that's this movie's most reprehensible crime. It is seriously disturbing that Vernon, Florida is more popular and more highly-rated than Gates of Heaven, which Roger Ebert has long kept in his top-10-of-all-time list, or than Mr. Death, which might be both the most well-crafted and most meaningful movie I've seen, or than Tabloid, which is the single best "love" (quotes deserved) story that I've heard, and includes two of the best moments in recent film memory.If you choose to watch Vernon, Florida, please keep these things in mind.

This is the only Errol Morris film that I will give less than 5 stars. It's hard to believe I'm going all the way down to 1. That needs explaining.This film could have been equally as good if not better than all the rest. Morris had heard about a rural town in Florida where people had been severing their limbs in order to receive insurance benefits. Certainly there's some substance there - something interesting - not just in the brutality or absurdity but in what it says about us inhabitants of Late Capitalism.But then once he got to Vernon, FL and started filming, he found extreme resistance-- he actually received death threats warning him against including anything related to limb-severing in the film. Understandably, he abandoned the storyline. The result is a movie that is literally about nothing.What's worse is that the movie ends up having a thick whiff of elitism. That's because Morris salvaged his funds by interviewing local eccentrics and including their goofiest quotes in the final cut. Because there're no events and no storyline, we don't get to see who the people really are; we only get to laugh at their surface personas. It's as though we're people-gazing from the sidewalk.  If this movie appeals to us at all, it appeals to the worst parts of us.This was the first Errol Morris movie I had seen and I was so un-smitten that it was years before I tried any of his other films, and, for me, that's this movie's most reprehensible crime. It is seriously disturbing that Vernon, Florida is more popular and more highly-rated than Gates of Heaven, which Roger Ebert has long kept in his top-10-of-all-time list, or than Mr. Death, which might be both the most well-crafted and most meaningful movie I've seen, or than Tabloid, which is the single best "love" (quotes deserved) story that I've heard, and includes two of the best moments in recent film memory.If you choose to watch Vernon, Florida, please keep these things in mind.

I like Mindy, sort of in a little-sister way. She's sweet and cute and friendly and says funny things. I would use the word "fluffy" if I could do so un-condescendingly.At first I was frustrated by the book because of its...well...fluffiness. Have you no existential angst?, I wondered. Don't you see death and misery and loneliness? Aren't you supposed to be a comedian, and aren't all comedians "tortured"?She has problems and insecurities like any human - she goes into them in-depth in the book - but "tortured" is not a word you'd use to describe her. Selfishly, I wanted a little more depth or darkness from her, but that's just not who she is. And she doesn't need to be. The book works for what it is.One reviewer nailed it: This is a great book for the treadmill. It's almost like a long magazine article. It is easy and pleasant and it even contains useful tips, including tips for guys about what women are looking for in a man (Answer: not a boy).If you're looking for something a little darker and funnier, my strongest recommendation would be Sarah Silverman's The Bedwetter: Stories of Courage, Redemption, and Pee. If you're looking for something so dark that it will wipe that miserable smile off your face, check out Michael Ian Black's You're Not Doing It Right: Tales of Marriage, Sex, Death, and Other Humiliations.
Conflict in Blood by Ariel Tachna is a 2009 Rainbow Awards Honorable Mention (5* from at least 1 judge)

This book totally had me sucked in from the moment I started reading it... I didnt even mind that it was weirdly formatted... Definitely going to be reading this one again and seeing what else the Author has out...AWESOME!Really good YA novel. Both MCs are well developed, and intriguing, going past stereotypes and showing how important it is to look beyond the apparent surface to the person beneath. Similar to Sara Alva's "Silent," this book is a brilliant YA novel as it teaches tolerance and openness to new ideas.

New to me author and if you are into Lesbian werewolves this is for you. Will be a must read going forward. Terrific mix of plot, character development and romance. A very clever take on the fable Little Red Riding Hood.
I really enjoyed this 2nd installment of Tara Lain's Tales of the Harker Pack series. I particularly enjoyed the dynamics between the two MC's.
I may be a huge fan of paranormal fan and at times this book was intense... it had me sucked in from the very first page... I will be looking for more of this authors work for sure.

I'm a sucker for stories about Native American folklore, curses, and supernatural creatures, and this story grabbed me from page one. Well-drawn characters and a serpentine plot added to my enjoyment. A very entertaining read.I really loved this book! I had never read a book about a windigo before. I was fasinated by the detailed story and the writers' brilliant telling.

This is a well written shifter story that many are sure to love. I like that the author had a character like Will, a bear shifter with a temper, who worries about how his animal reacts to certain situations as opposed to just going with the flow. Although part of a series, it was easy for me to be drawn into this world even though I have not read any of the previous books.

In terms of plot, this one was all over the place, but in a good way. It pulled in bits and pieces of several genres to freshen up some classic tropes from sci-fi and romance. I was thoroughly engaged by the characters and the story.Beautifully researched in all aspects, tight plotting, satisfying ending... this book is simply terrific.  I'm getting tired of stories where everyone is wealthy, but even that works given the backstory.This is my first book by Mr. Nolan and it grabbed my attention from the first page. I loved the little twists and turns the story took and could not wait to see what would happen next.
Overall the book was highly entertaining. Loved Midnight Messages, Batteries Not Included, Lost And Found, Sisters Of The Moon and Wolf Moon.

I really enjoyed how all of the pieces of Claires story were slowly revealed and then came together. I was really rooting for Claire and Jodie through the whole book.This was a fantastic story. Filled with action, adventure, and an intense criminal/legal aspect that immediately pulls the reader in. That the main character is a lesbian is more of an adjective rather than a plot point. Which makes it so much better. The setting was brilliantly described, to the point that I could practically taste the sand in my mouth, could feel the sweat rolling down my back, and feel the sun beating down on my skin, scorching my flesh. The characters were delightfully fleshed out. Everyone I was supposed to hate, I hated with a passion, and everyone I was supposed to love I loved fiercely, and the ones I was supposed to be on the fence about, like Faye, I waffled in my feelings over until the end.
This was one of the better books I've read so far this year.  The author tells the main character's tale in such a heartwarming way.Loved it from beginning to end.
Charming - not much else to say. Just very, very charming.

I loved these characters so much. It was really hard to go on the journey with them and not thank the author afterwards.Gripping characters and story told in an absolutely unique style. And it made me cry.

Amazing setup for a dark, dystopian fic. While many would baulk at the rape themes, I can read postapocalyptic stories with it in the understanding that the world we live in  and its morals  are dead. It is a well written, extremely deep story that hides its message beneath a pile of kinky sex. You have to go away and think about it for a while or youre just going to flip. So Ive thought about it, and only given its ratings now, once the whole, rather than the shocking surface, sunk in.

The first three stories were almost flawless. Only the fourth and final story was a bit lacking, but overall, this was my favorite of the five books, by far. There were great ideas, strongly set in specific times and places, with believable, likeable characters and fascinating story development. I actually ordered this book from Amazon after reading it because I want my own copy. It's a book I'll read again.Overall a great read. Loved The Golem of Mala Lubovnya and Made for Aaron.
This was a good little story that sucked me in... Im sure Ill read more of this authors work.
I like this one... I like reading stories where the characters survive something and come out the other side a little stronger... Beautiful read.
Top tier erotica author - graphic sex and a compelling story made this an awesome read. loved it!

Each poem in this collection is a wonderfully told gem that glistens in its own right. From unrequited love to seduction, lust, desire, and obsession, the author runs the gamut of emotions with a deft writing style. 5 Big Stars.Each piece is of love lost and growing up and into who you are. Beautiful and heartbreaking.So evocative and visceral. Rich and intense. I am there - in each short world.

An excellent story that is both sweet and romantic. I adored Jason and loved that he found a family with Ben and Tim. Ben is one of my favorites in the series and it was wonderful to see him again! I'm glad Ben and Tim got their happy ending.

The tomato & basil soup has a really great homemade flavor.  However, there was an inedible hard piece of herb stalk that I had to spit out of my mouth.  Since I only had the one box, I can't say how common an occurrence that is.

UPDATE: The manufacturer did send a replacement bug vacuum.  In a month, it had one brief blip where it wouldn't turn on, but in general it has worked.ORIGINAL REVIEW:This was a very nice idea with some nice features, but unfortunately it's of very poor quality.  Within 2 days, the vacuum portion no longer worked.  My husband who does repair work disassembled it and discovered the problem was that a very cheap microswitch inside of it was broken.  It would have cost only 50 cents to use a decent quality one in the first place.Also, before the microswitch broke, we had discovered that the batteries that were included had almost no charge left.  They died in less than 48 hours and had to be replaced.  Once replaced, the suction was much stronger than when it had arrived.  So it's not like my kids had used it excessively and worn it out; there wasn't much oomph left in the batteries to begin with.Quality is really lacking.

The cover is very nice.  However, it's too thick and the holes for the rings set too far in so that the cover rarely completely closes on one try.  I usually have to go down along the edge and press it the rest of the way down the ring.  And it's only 21 sheets of paper.  You're really paying for the higher price for the cover, which keeps the planner from closing.

Nice idea.  Very good taste.  If you're using this at work or don't have young kids like I do, this can be especially convenient and left on the table or counter if you're a frequent coffee/tea drinker.  As is, I keep it on an upper pantry shelf.  It's nice that it doesn't need to be refrigerated, but the bottle does state that it's best used within 30 days of opening.Be aware that the nozzle opening may need scraped clear periodically.  Mine ended up with dried crusted creamer.  Until I figured it out, I could only press it down very slowly or it squirted creamer out to the side, missing my cup.

It's a nice idea, but the discs had rough seams at spots along the edge.  So the first time I used this, it scratched up my tabletop.  Also it's a bit more awkward to maneuver around because the discs can't pass over the dough or it gets cut.Also be aware that the disc measurements are nice even round metric numbers (10, 6, and 2 mm) that do not translate to commonly used dough thicknesses in America.
Nice, sturdy bags.  They are rather narrow.  Perfectly shaped for loaves of bread or other long thin items.  Different from the standard more square shaped cloth grocery bags.

I haven't received the final product yet, but with Vine's time limit on reviews, I'm forced to write one now.This seemed like a promising idea.  It would have been nice to see a bit more variety allowed.  All pages are set up to have a picture at the top and several lines of text at the bottom.  The instructions with the kit could have been a bit clearer as they basically said use only marker, which is difficult for writing words.  Once we looked on the website, we found pen would be fine.The main thing will be what the final product looks like, and so this review will be updated after it's received.

I was very disappointed in this product.  Even immediately after it dried, there was almost no bad taste with only brief contact.  I don't see how this would work to stop nail-biters.  As for thumb-sucking, you have to have it in your mouth for several seconds for the taste to kick in, and even then it's a mildly unpleasant taste that I could see many determined thumbsuckers just ignoring until it wore off.  By comparison, our old standby Mavala Stop - Helps Cure Nail Biting and Thumb Sucking, 0.3-Fluid Ounce has an immediate nasty taste even 24 hours after applying.  Buy that instead.

The book continued the author's previous pattern of lots of coincidences and soap opera elements to further the plot and cheaply create drama.  But it didn't have the pluses that were in the first two books to balance that out.  The characterization was shallow with actions that didn't naturally flow from it.  There were lots of short scenes as we jumped from one story line to one of the many others.  The main male characters just were flat and uninteresting.  There was a lot of telling the reader rather than showing.  In several areas, the dialogue or narrative felt forced.

As with the first book in this series, there were way too many coincidences and melodramatic events for my tastes.  I wasn't as engaged by Abby's story.  I was actually more interested in the other characters'.  So, it was difficult at times to get past the convenient plot elements.

The whole book is in poetry form.  I thought thered be some poetry included, but no its the entire thing.  But it doesnt really meet my definition of poetry.  Much of it is just really prose that has been broken up into little fragments all over the place, or sometimes its just relatively incoherent fragments, all of it at least double-spaced so every page is mostly white space.The sentences are brokenInto pieces like shardsLaying on the sand.It makes this a very annoying book to read.  My 12 yo son adores history and will read just about anything thats history-related.  He wouldnt touch this book, and I dont blame him.  Which is very unfortunate, because I think the author could have written the book more normally, and it would have been much more enjoyable.I'll end with an excerpt from the book, and yes the double-spacing is how it's presented so that it takes up 4 times as much space as it should.There are so many choicesfor ways to spend paydaythat I almost feel temptedto go off by myself and keep mystingy silver wages so that I can buypaper and pencils to sketchevery wonder that I see when I walkthrough the forest, or even right here,on this bustling Bottle Alley streetmade of mudand rum.

There was some helpful information in this book, but given what was in it, it didn't need to be anywhere near this long.  Lots of charts and such that took up a lot of room but weren't particularly helpful.  Wordy, etc.  Then the contradicting advice that basically says we shouldn't make any food sound "bad" but we need to restrict the "fun food" (desserts, "junk" food, etc), because it's... bad.If you're interested in "fearless feeding," I'd recommend checking out the Feeding Doctor online instead.

Updated reviewMy original rating was 3 star, as I felt the binder seemed closer to flimsy than to heavy-duty, but was waiting to see what happened.  I was right.  It took less than a year for the binder to start falling apart.  It didn't even get heavy use.  Just a modest number of pages in it, not knocked around, only looked through gently.  But the cardboard front and back are tearing away from the binding.  Definitely will get a different binder this time.Original ReviewI do have to say that this binder doesn't feel especially heavy duty to me.  It probably doesn't feel any different than the regular binders I remember from the 90s.  The pockets are rather shallow.  Overall, it's okay.

We currently have this air purifier in a room that's roughly twice the size of the 100 sq ft this air filter supposed to be good for.  And it's keeping up wonderfully.  It's a room with a lot of storage that's shut up and gathers lots of dust.  Before this air filter, I'd walk in and within a few minutes be sneezing and eyes itching with dust allergy.  That's no longer a problem.The indicator light to show the quality of the air is kind of neat, though not essential.  It is a nice feature that it adjusts the fan speed depending on air quailty, speeding up if things are not in the green.If space is an issue, this fits very nicely and unobtrusively in a corner.  While I prefer Honeywell 50250-S 99.97% Pure HEPA Round Air Purifier as our number one purifier, with one running in the open floor plan downstairs and one in our master bedroom, the The AeraMax 100 Air Purifier is nice for a single room.

I found this bib a pain to clean.  This bib needs to be immediately wiped clean.  If you throw it in the sink to wash with the dishes, the top part takes forever to dry.  So you can only wipe, and you must do it immediately before food dries on since you can't soak it.I didn't find the roll-up factor enough of a plus to compensate for the cleaning.  We won't be buying this bib in the future.  Our old standard pocket bibs Summer Infant Bibbity, Green can fold in half nicely to fit in a diaper bag.  They can be washed in the sink.  And they're about half the price of the Oxo Tot Roll Up Bib.

I've had the larger fudge graham cookies in the past, and enjoyed trying these miniature sized ones.  I thought they tasted pretty good.  My only concern is whether the chocolate would tend to melt and make these messy if these were kept in a hot vehicle, etc.

My stamping children enjoy this stamp set.  It's a nice collection of cute stamps.  My children don't have any trouble with the storage tray and are quite happy with it.  Though I'm not sure why the colored pencils were included, as 5 colors (red, orange, green, blue, brown) are really not sufficient.  All in all a nice set.  It should be very durable.  I've always been quite happy with Melissa & Doug products for their above average quality, and on the rare occasions that there has been a problem, I have always been more than satisfied by their customer service.

This is the third electric pencil sharpener I've used, and it is by far the best.  It sharpens very evenly, not too fast or too slow.  The adjustable holes are wonderful, so that I can also sharpen my younger children's jumbo pencils.  It's easy to see when the shavings need emptied, because the part that holds them is clear, and it's easy to take out.

I purchased this book because I strongly suspected one of my children had an auditory processing disorder.  He seemed to have normal hearing when we tested him by whispering, saying his name when his back was turned, etc, but he had a lot of trouble with following oral instructions, misremembering what was said to him, etc.  This book was a great resource to help me understand what my son was experiencing.  The book is very easy to read, very understandable, written in a somewhat conversational style with lots of helpful examples.I would have liked more specific information about the different types of auditory processing disorder, therapy for the various types, etc.  I wanted to go into his evaluation fully prepared and armed with all the information I could get.  However, this book is probably informative enough for the average parent.What I most appreciated about the book was that she was both optimistic and realistic.  She made it very clear that much could be done to help with the various difficulties, but also recognizing that not everyone will be able to overcome all their difficulties completely.  Realistically, that their auditory processing disorders, even after therapy, may place some limitations on career, etc.  But, none of us cannot truly be anything we want to be, as we each have our own areas of weakness and difficulty.  I appreciated the fact that she didn't allow the reader to believe that there was a magic pill that would totally fix APD for everyone.As for my son, it turned out that we were right about his hearing being normal and in thinking that he had APD.  He has significant difficulty with auditory memory and with hearing when there is background noise.  This book gave us a better understanding of what he is dealing with.  I would definitely recommend this book to parents of children with (suspected) APD.

This book is interesting reading.  The author does a good job explaining different conversational approaches in a wide range of areas, and she uses a lot of good examples.  I don't quite agree with her take on it that there's never a style that is inherently inferior, but she definitely helped me have a better understanding of how two people might mentally approach a conversation and the troubles that can arise if they don't understand the other's approach.  However, the book is definitely light on any sort of how-to as to what you do with what you've now learned, very little about how to different types can improve communication, etc.  Still, it's thought-provoking and enjoyable reading.

It's smaller than I expected and doesn't have the weight of muslin so it's exactly like any other cheap bed sheet you'll find out there and doesn't hang well, you'll need to secure it yourself.  It doesn't really photograph well in use as I'd hoped as the pattern is lighter than pictured here.

Hard as a rock...my dog, "the destroyer" finally broke her older softer ring toy.  Thought this would be worth a try, it's almost too hard for us to play tug of war with unfortunately, but maybe that's OK for others.  On the plus side, she hasn't been able to destroy it yet!

Exactly what I was looking for.  First, it's thick and heavy, which is sort of the point with these.  The color scheme matches my rings which adds to the look I was going for.  I get compliments and eyeballs almost every day and refuse to tell people how little I paid for it, "It was a gift" is my answer.This is my second Invicta watch, and I'm very impressed with the quality of the signature series.  For the money, I haven't seen a better watch.  The band is also nice quality and easily adjusts.
Yep, it's green alright. Wrinkles are a nuisance and pretty much force you to use a stretch frame or iron them out.

After years of BT headsets and my most recent BOSE single earpiece actually delivering bass I wasn't expecting much but was pleasantly surprised by the excellent sound quality.  My Note Edge sounds amazing and my older GS3 doesn't offer the same bass response, but still sounds very good.  I use "Player Pro" from the Play Store.Ordered another pair within hours as my GF now owns my original pair :-)

Works well with my Canon XF100 and short HDMI jumper.  Color and brightness aren't editing quality but it gets the job done and makes your work a lot easier in any situation.  The Sony batteries it uses are really cheap which is nice.It has 2 quick controls for the D pad you can pick brightness, volume etc so no fumbling or searching.  Happy with it so far.

After using the leaky Breville JE98XL for a year I pulled the trigger on the Omega.  What a difference, the juice is not a pulp fest and gives a much better yield.  It's also nice that it doesn't sound like a train going through the house like the Breville.  Takes a little longer to juice but well worth it.I wasn't sure I'd stick with juicing but really wish I bought this one from the start.

Overnight charging only shows 60%-70% charge for both using two different chargers.  I have other larger capacity Sony batteries that charge to 100% every time.  They come in handy for LCD displays and are lightweight.

Nice set.  Glaze was good with a couple small "pits" on smaller plates that I never would have noticed if another commenter hadn't brought it up.  For stoneware I'm very happy, nice hefty feel and arrived from Amazon well packed and nothing broken.

Doesn't work unless you press down on the screen while on the pad to make the contacts connect.  Disappointing but to be fair I can't be sure if it's the cover or the phone at fault, as the phone should have a higher standard I'll assume it's not the culprit but can't say for sure.Update: Added a tiny bit of tinfoil to the two charging pins on the phone, placed cover on top and connection now works every time.
Saved me from having to repaint the whole bath...went on easy and looks great

After having only used high end laptops for the past few years, I was hesitant on this one.  Pleased that performance is very good and with an SSD upgrade, the i3 is more than tolerable.The screen is large enough to actually get some work done, but the viewing angles are terrible.  What was a nice surprise was seeing how crisp the screen was, can't really see individual pixels unless you really try and having the GUI larger due to scaling is actually a lot easier to use.Never liked 8.1, but with touch, it's not bad for some things.  While you'll rarely use this as a tablet due to it's weight, it's nice to have.For around $400 (Thank you Black Friday), I couldn't be happier considering I paid $400 for a Nexus 10 not too long ago.  My old laptop was 14lbs (desktop replacement) and a pain to travel with, this one is relatively light and much easier to deal with, even the "brick" is small and light.The worst problem is very low audio, luckily the media players (Media Player Classic) and VLC let you boost the audio, so everything but an occasional Youtube video is OK, but it really is just too weak.I looked at a lot of laptops/convertibles and this had the best bang for the buck, the next real step up puts you close to $1000 and unless you're a gamer with eagle eyes, you won't miss the extra HP much.UPDATE: Aug 22 2015 - Recently upgraded to a larger SSD and decided to do a fresh install of W10.  This took a bit of research to adjust bios settings to finally accept the USB thumb to boot and the W8 license did not transfer for me.  W10 is noticeably faster that 8 and is all the better without the crapware.  All hardware drivers were present except the card reader which mounting an old 8.1 Macrium reflect image and pointing w10 to that directory to search for the driver succeeded.  If you don't mind the privacy issues of w10, it's a nice upgrade for this machine
FALSE Advertising.  Marketed as soft leather.  This is NOT leather.  C'mon Amazon, stop allowing bogus reviews and now I have to worry about product descriptions too?

My Canon XF100 would get around 8ft usable distance with built in lamps.  With this, it reaches out as far as I can see.  Seems well built, shipping was under 2 weeks despite warning 2 months was possible.  The beam itself looks like a flashlight  beam on camera, a big round light cone in the center of your image, it's too bad the lights couldn't spread a bit more for a better field of view.We're planning on shooting a local "Ghost hunter" type project and I'm not sure if I can use this as the center circle is distracting to the viewer.

Works great for our Bedroom PC.  Short distance so no connection issues.  Works even better than I'd hoped.  Takes a little getting used to when double clicking a file, any movement results in mouse movement, but accuracy is good, universal programming worked for TV but not Panasonic soundbar.Very happy for under $25!

For under $20, I'm very very happy.  Just the idea of a monopod wasn't something I'd considered for the longest time, but if you do a lot of field work, in my case with a Canon XF100, this saves you the chore of lugging around a heavy tripod.  You can still get reasonably good pans with a little finesse and the freedom to move around so quickly and easily is the real advantage.
Metal, durable ...oh and it stores data!  This one is built right.

Nice to find a product that has decent durability and build quality.  Too often EVERYTHING is plastic and the only effort into anything is to fool customers into believing it's better than it actually is.  This product is steel, feels secure and strong and simply works.  Under $40 it can't be beat.

After upgrading the inside of our house with this style we decided to finish it off with the front door.  Like the others, this had everything you'd expect and a bit of extra hardware for different frame situations.  The finished look is great and was an inexpensive way to improve things.The seller was also fantastic (Cabinet Hardware 4 less) in that they quickly replaced a lower knob that had a small dent.  It arrived with keys that matched our first order and we're very happy with both the product and seller.

I first started listening to Brian Tracy decades ago and used his techniques throughout my sales and management career.  From day one they've made me money and empowered me to confidently get more sales.  Hearing this series again was a great refresher and all I can tell you is that he has a ton of excellent training out there that goes deeper if you're interested.  One thing that struck me was when he said how amazed he was at the number of professional salespeople that NEVER do a single thing to become better at their craft.The techniques here are great for sales but will serve you in so many other ways.  His delivery is excellent and I just enjoy his style over most others out there

This book is comprised of the initial portion of a web serial that is still available for free on the web.  Of course, the price is well worth it for the convenience of reading it in book form.This chunk of the web serial is the "young want to be heroes going through the hero training program".  There are some detours in which we are introduced to the world and its problems, including "Monster" an unstoppable villain, but generally, the book sticks relatively closely to the hero training program.  It is very well done for what it is, currently the #5 ranked web serial on one of the major sites that rates web serials.  It is (very roughly) similar in quality and approach to Super Powereds, the #3 rated web serial, also found in book form.  There are differences in tone, as well as plot.  Super Powereds feels lighter, and has the young heroes involved in a 4 year certification program, whereas Citadel gives the young heroes one book's worth of training and immediately sends them out into the world.  The over-arching plot(s) in Citadel aren't fully in place yet, and its tough to know where its going.  That said, I'd say that the major difference is that there are a lot more books/pages done in the Super Powereds universe, and the author of that serial has a longer track record of delivering updates on a schedule.  Although he has sped up recently, Mr. Clevenger has been fairly uneven in the pace of updates.  Still, no reason you cant try both if the concept appeals to you.

Continue Online is one of the better written web serials.  Its available for free if you go look for it.  This portion that you are considering buying is deemed book one, book 2 is also done online, and book 3 is well in progress based on the online postings, with the author maintaining a good pace.  Continue Online combines a "guy gets into a VR world run by AI that is more then it seems and has its own agenda" scenario with some in depth character development, with both elements being well done.  The main character is initially very depressed, and the overall feel is accordingly a bit heavier then something like Sword Art Online (an anime, but the best I can do for a comparitor).  It seems that because of the heavy characterization vis-a-vis the main character, some fans of lighter fare such as Sword Art Online are not enjoying Continue Online, while others are really appreciating the in depth exploration of the main character.Although, I am enjoying Continue Online, it might work better as a web serial than a book.  While there are a variety of sub-plots, mostly related to the VR game, the overall plot development is very slow and meandering, and even by the middle of book 3, the overarching plot is thin enough that I could easily describe it in a few sentences.  Even in book 3, the various adventures in the VR world have not really been linked up to the over-plot or explained.  In this respect, Continue Online is a bit like an anime but with stronger development of the main character and his struggles.  I am enjoying this mix, but those who want their books to read like a book with a central plot, a beginning, middle and end could have a different reaction.How I ultimately feel about Continue Online might depend, to an extent, on where its going, and whether the over-plot ripens into something meaningful.  That said, I am enjoying the serial, and definitely do plan on continuing.

Villainous is a breezy fun read, but it feels like there is a lot less book here then the first go round - only 164 pages this time around vs 244 for book one.  Moreover, the POV switches to Black Valentine, and she is a pure comic book cut-out consisting only of a smarmy wise cracks about misdeeds she could commit punctuated by worry about her family.  The result isnt funny enough or likable enough.  By contrast, in book one, White Knight, battling his own body, confused by what what was going on, and struggling with the consequences of being in love with a super-villain, seemed more 3-dimensional and felt more "real".  The plot is also a bit thinner this time, with Black Valentine having to identify and develop evidence on a new drug's supplier to make a deal to prevent White Knight from going to jail for the events of book 1.  She achieves this in the simplest fashion, by making phone calls, asking for meetings, and reading minds when she gets there.All of that said, the book IS still breezy fun, and I got through it in a day and a half.  There are a few points where the book approaches the quality of the first book, such as the ending, which is terrific, and I'm hopeful the series can get back on track in book 3.

Mr. Harries is a skilled writer, infusing these stories with interesting characters struggling with interesting events of a sci-fi flavor.  The characters are three dimensional and feel real.  You should be aware, however, that most of these stories dont have a traditional ending, and in a couple of instances its frustrating.  Nor do they have a "big idea", with a possible exception or two.  In at least once instance, a story involving two genetically engineered boys raised together, the story teased a big surprise revelation, but ended up not going there.  Rather, these stories are mostly of the "slice of life in odd/crisis times" as some sci-fi event intrudes on the lives of ordinary folks.  From the blurb, that appears to be the point -- ordinary people in extraordinary situations, doing the best they can.  Personally, I prefer more of a traditional story, even in novellas, but if the concept appeals the writing is fairly good.I should note that I did not get through all of the stories.  I dont usually do a review before finishing a book, but I'm not clear I will finish all of the stories, and I got through enough that I think this review is informative.

This is a pleasant and easy going book, but the writing style renders it rather slow, and there isnt enough plot here to keep things interesting.  This book is written in the first-person and feels like its 80% exposition at times, which really kills the pacing.  I feel like with a little more practice this author could write something pleasant and readable, but I had a hard time finishing this because the writing style (first person, with lots of exposition) gave it a detached airy vibe.  I dont always mind the first person perspective; for example, In Confessions of a D-List Supervillain, it kind of adds to the humor.  Here, it just didnt work.As far as a plot summary, the main character is a form/power shifter that can basically do anything.  As the world goes to pieces (nano-zombies), only he/she can so much as scratch his/her nose.  He/she builds gadgets, heals the sick, can drop armies with radiant energy and dance like there is no tomorrow.  I'd call it wish fulfillment, but the main character's internal thoughts are so boy scout vanilla that they are a bit dull, and its hard to relate.Overall, I found the book sort of pleasant and was able to finish it despite the problems noted above.  That said, I do not plan to read the sequels.

I enjoyed the first Prospects book and gave it 5 stars.  The second Prospects book expands the cast, bringing the portion of the made-for-tv team that stepped up and acted like actual heroes into the fold.  This expansion isn't particularly beneficial, given that we didnt have all that much time with these characters in the first book (i.e. we dont really know these characters at the start of the book).  Moreover, ALL of the characters, old and new, have problems, and all get pages.  Insecurities about weight, about powers, about relationships and the like.  Not a single well adjusted character to be found given that even good ole Agent Farrel suffers from continuing marital problems.  So its a bit hard to settle into this second book and get comfortable, at least at first.  The proofreading errors were a bit of a distraction at times (this may be improved by the time you read this -- the author mentioned he would address the issue.)The "train the misfits" plot that worked fairly well in volume one is absent here.  Instead, the heroes get involved with a super villain through a chance discovery, and gradually learn what it going on while tangling with the villain.  While this plot is perhaps a little overly comic-bookie, the real difficulty is that without the concreteness of the training, this plot is one of the two major drivers of the story, and I'm not sure its quite up to the task.The other main driver of the book is the characters, all of whom are struggling with various personal demons and insecurities.  Unfortunately, there are now, in this second book, so many separate characters with screen time that its a little difficult to get terribly involved with any of them -- i.e., there are so many different mini-story arcs for the various characters that it distracts from the flow of the story at times.  The Prospects is not A Game of Thrones, and having so many different characters with separate stories in the context of this much shorter and simpler story, doesnt fully work.Conclusion.  The second Prospects book passed the time and was a mostly enjoyable read, but tighter editing and greater focus would have helped the book considerably.

Grim Reapers giving people powers?  The premise conjures up several pretty bad movies from recent years and just seems . . . silly.  If you have been a reader for a while though, you understand that sometimes the one or two paragraph plot description you get before taking the plunge is hopelessly inadequate, and a dumb-sounding premise can be:  (1) so well fleshed out and/or (2) so well done that you forget you initially thought the premise was goofy.  And this is the case here (both 1 and 2).Forget the idea that this is about Grim Reapers or zombies; its not, at least not in any sense that matters.  The Zombie Knight is essentially a superhero novel or novels, featuring a strong foundation with concrete factions fighting for concrete reasons (some of which are only revealed as the story progresses).  The author has a good sense of humor, and some of the dialogue is quite funny.  The powers and action sequences are also very well done.  Perhaps most importantly, the characters and factions are sufficiently well done that the reader cares about them.  While Hector, the main character, suffers from painful shyness, and is a bit annoying initially, he grows on you given his bravery in other contexts, and as his shyness fades.  The world of the Zombie Knight is more than dark enough that one will genuinely worry about whether favorite characters will live or die.  Heroic rescues can fail, and plans can go badly wrong, with tragic consequences.I usually give a plot summary in my reviews, but here the plot is spooned out quite slowly, and sufficiently complex that its hard to summarize anyway.  Suffice it to say that shy Hector is essentially reborn, and when given the chance to actually make a difference, seizes the opportunity even though it thrusts him into constant danger.  His troubles change and morph as we learn more about the world and its factions, and he acquires a variety of companions from the heroic to the flawed.FYI, this started as a web serial, and its still available for free on the web.  Once you get caught up (the serial is just past page 1000), its hard to stay as enthusiastic because the author seems to have slowed down a lot, and the story develops slowly.  The author is apparently having some job troubles, and hopes to speed back up after changing jobs, but right now the pace of updates is quite slow.Highly recommended for fans of action packed fantasy, especially those with a fondness for superheroes and villains, with the caveat that I am started to have some concerns about the author's ability/desire to finish the story.

I loved the first book every bit as much as any of you I'm sure.  Madcap zainy superhero & villain humor, with charm and 3 likable main characters.  A few other reviewers were troubled that the sequel takes place almost entirely in space, but I think that is only the starting point for the problems here.  The excuse to get Penny et al into space is painfully thin, and space turns out to encompass a baffling array of alien factions (four!), two new human factions & a huge number of new mad science technologies (from Penny, other mad scientists and aliens) all thrown up in whirlwind fashion, and all having nothing to do with the first book.  Its hard to figure out and remember what is going on.  Its not remotely possible to summarize the plot, as the trio go from space station to space station, from faction to faction, like ping pong balls, and more or less accidentally have some involvement in complex inter-faction events that are difficult to care about.
