What she doesn't expect is that the brutality of war has changed Melik and that her sacrifice might come at a price she's unwilling to pay.The plot is fast-paced and action-packed as Wen faces one challenge after another in her struggle to bring news of the war effort in Gochan Two to Melik. In a finely crafted story that's very visual Sarah Fine builds intensity and suspense especially when Melik surprises Wren with marriage to protect her from the wrath of his people just as they face a horde of mechanized spiders that threaten to destroy his home in Dagchocuk.Although the atmosphere is dark, bleak and hopeless for much of the plot there are moments that are poignant and even triumphant as the battle heats up. The bond between Bo and Wen continues to grow even as he girds his body in steel. There are touching instances when you sense the depth of his love for Wen and his tragic fixation with protecting himself that are often overshadowed by his immaturity and the soul-wrenching darkness that threatens to consume him. Wen is realistic about Bo's strengths and faults, loving him more as a sister/friend, yet sadly realizing he wants more from her.In "Of Dreams and Rust" the depth and complexity of personalities driven by their flaws and faults as the world explodes around them, are unforgettable. Fourteen year old Sinan like Bo is highly intelligent and thirsty for knowledge. He's capable, confident and boldly unafraid. Melik in this story seems cold and heartless at times hiding any compassion or mercy for the enemy. It's his unforgiving and hard traits in the midst of war that erodes his relationship with Wen. From two very different societies they often have trouble relating, but with time and patience (as well as a little push from Sinan, Bo and Anni) confront the hurtles that plague their love.I thoroughly enjoyed Sarah Fine's "Of Dreams and Rust" a page-turner from beginning to end with its imaginative plot and well-developed characters. As a fan I look forward to reading more of her novels in future.

"The Moon & More" is a romantic roller-coaster that begins with eighteen year old Emaline who has just graduated from high school and preparing to head to college in the fall. Like every summer her life seems perfect working for family-owned Colby Realty in the beach town she loves, and hanging out with her closest friends and long-time boyfriend Luke. But as June rolls around Emaline finds her life deluged by changes that begin with a breakup with her boyfriend; her friendship with Theo Burns, an ambitious assistant New York City filmmaker who's in town documenting the life and works of a reclusive local artist; and reuniting with her biological father who missed her graduation after reneging on paying her tuition to Columbia University. Yet through all her ups and downs she clings to the stability and warmth of her family, especially her mother who wants the moon and more for Emaline's life.Sarah Dessen creates a unique blend of touching warmth and romance in a plot that looks at a young woman's developing maturity as she tackles not only betrayal and a broken heart, a new friendship, but also changes in her family relationships. The story progresses smoothly as events unfold that have Emaline facing a father who shrugged off his responsibility as a teen after impregnating her mother. Yearning to make amends he agrees to pay her tuition if she gets into an Ivy League school only to renege and leave her befuddled when he stops communicating and doesn't turn up at her graduation. With skilful dexterity Sarah Dessen takes Emaline's feelings of rejection and turns them into a victory of love when he returns for the summer and she bonds with her ten year old half-brother.Similarly the author weaves realism and heartbreak into the betrayal and breakup with Emaline's fun-loving and good-natured boyfriend Luke. Although devastated she recognizes the doubts and insecurities that's troubled their relationship, rebounding into the arms of Theo a driven documentary filmmaker who wears girl jeans and wants to make their dates the "Best" of Everything. Sophisticated and overly ambitious his denigrating attitude of all Emaline holds dear soon erodes their relationship only to be fully destroyed by an incident that brings a major loss to Theo and a reward for Emaline's hard work.The characters in this novel are fascinating and complex. They all add passion, spirit and depth to the dramatic intensity of a story you can't put down until the end. Emaline is the hardworking, family-oriented and spontaneous young woman who was determined as a child to connect with her biological father on some level. Although their relationship is rocky she yearns for his affection which will always be denied by distance, time and reality so selflessly fights to have him recognize his responsibility to his affectionate , impulsive and emotional ten year old son Benji. Yet it's her mother, step-dad and her family that Emaline depends on to anchor her with their love. Luke Templeton her easy-going, accommodating boyfriend loves her but is troubled by their relationship while Theo Burns is a geek, bullied in high-school who's driven by a need to make his mark as a documentary filmmaker. He's a conundrum, craving a relationship with Emaline, but letting his worst traits- arrogance, pride and criticism- undermine it. Unlike her two boyfriends Morris plagued by a negligent family background is loyal, loving, kind and supportive. With encouragement and help especially at the end of the story he transforms into more than just a slow-moving slacker. Morris is the one boyfriend who's truly devoted to his girlfriend Daisy Ye, Emaline's morally-centered, fashion-conscious and highly-intelligent best friend."The Moon & More" is more than just a simple teenage romance as it combines the yearning heart and empowerment of a young girl as she matures into womanhood. Within the seriousness and heartbreak that change brings to Emaline's life there is humor , friendship and love that makes it well-worth reading.

"The Rule of Three Fight For Power" continues Eric Walters' exciting survival adventure ten weeks after a global blackout. The military force that threatened the neighborhood has been destroyed and lies in the valley below the bridge. Even their base of operations has been deserted. Afraid that the danger has not been eradicated, Herb, the ex- CIA agent has stepped up Adam's flights in his ultralight and has Brett's team exploring and scavenging at night.But as the neighborhood continues to maintain tight security and to refuse refugees admittance to their haven, trouble is brewing outside the gates with a new tent town. When an enemy storms the tents killing the innocent while they sleep, Adam and Herb begin to suspect that danger lurks in an unexpected direction; a menace that could disrupt the harmony in the community.The plot begins ten weeks after a global blackout left humanity without power, scrambling for food and water and gangs of armed people attacking small communities to survive. In a fast paced, mesmerizing sequel to "The Rule of Three" threads of this story follow not only a surprise raid on the military base; a mysterious fire in a nearby condo; but an attack on the tent town that's sprung up near the wall. In the turmoil, tragedy and death that stalks the neighborhood, the inhabitants try to hold tight to their principals of decency, justice and fairplay, but with the rationing of food and fear of another attack, cracks in the neighbourhood's solidarity begin to show. As the hopelessness and anxiety mounts, doubts and uncertainty leave the community unsettled and the atmosphere tense.Eric Walters in this absorbing struggle for survival slowly builds tension and suspense as loyalties are tested and a psychopath starts making plans to kill the community's leadership and take over the reins of authority. The intensity of the plot is often broken by Todd's wit and humor as well as the ongoing romance between Adam and Lori.In this story the well-developed and realistic personalities of some very unforgettable characters continue to grow in complexity. Sixteen year old Adam Daley who believes in doing what's right and continues to voice his opinions still trusts explicitly in Herb and his mother's judgement. He often distances himself from the problems on the ground, taking to the air whenever he can. Upright and conscientious Adam will have to confront his worst nightmare when he has to kill or be killed. His highly independent girlfriend Lori grounds Adam with her compassion and empathy for the tenters. She's smart, level-headed, strong and suspicious of Brett's erratic behaviour. Herb the tough, skilled former agent is the key organizer and planner, who will finally make a mistake in judgement that could cost lives. As Brett becomes more and more of an adrenaline junkie his personality takes on sinister and reckless undertones. Smug, cocky and over-confident he changes, becoming more of a "plastic action hero" rather than someone Herb and the Committee can depend on.What I like about "The Rule of Three " trilogy is its believability as the story grows and takes on momentum especially after a betrayal rocks the community bringing death and destruction. The story is intoxicating and the action gripping as the neighborhood struggles to survive in a chaotic tempest, hoping that their troubles will soon end. It will be interesting to see what Adam and his family face in the next adventure.

"Terminal" the final chapter of the "Virals" series begins when Tory Brennan and her pack discover they are not alone, that Chance Claybourne's experiments with Karsten's parvovirus strain has borne fruit, not only infecting him but unleashing another pack of virals on Charleston. Determined to discover the identities of the reckless and vengeful Trinity who" love to flaunt their powers, play games and draw attention to themselves", they are lead into one trap after another. But the danger is more insidious than they ever could have imagined when they discover another nemesis - a covert government organization- is also determined to capture them. In this story not only are the pack's powers tested, but their loyalty and friendship especially when a decision has to be made that could change the Virals future.In a spell-binding, fast-paced story the Virals face one challenge after another as they not only tackle the lethal actions of a rogue pack, but are stalked by a government organization who are determined to harness their abilities and use them as a secret weapon. Whether the Pack is zip-lining from the top deck of an old naval destroyer or jumping from the third floor of a house into a pond, the danger, and suspense continually escalates; the tension broken only by Hi's cutting wit and humor. Kathy and Brendan Reichs not only create an electrifying thriller in "Terminal", but weave historical landmarks into a descriptive background setting that brings Charleston and the surrounding area to life.In this plot Tory's life becomes even more emotionally complicated as she deals with her attraction to Ben and her crush on Chance. After both boys declare their love, she continually has to contend with Ben's jealousy and their confrontational outbursts as tempers flare and fists fly. Like her father's engagement to his girlfriend which could jeopardize her life on the island, and the risk to her friendship with Ella, Tory begins to deal with the roller-coaster of emotions she'd like to ignore and that threaten to swamp her, even making a choice between Ben and Chance.As in all the Virals novels the characters are realistic, well-developed and complex like Ben Blue whose temperamental mood swings are exacerbated by his jealousy. Yet when he has to make any decision that could affect Tory, he's selfless and loyal; following his heart. Chance Claybourne can be secretive, arrogant and irritating, but is unshakeable in his determination to protect Tory and the pack. Although all the characters are unforgettable, in this thrill-ride it's the cold ruthlessness of the Trinity and the deadly menace of the sinister undercover organization that incites chilling excitement and high-energy as events unfold."Terminal" a thriller with a heavy dose of science fiction is a page turner from beginning to end although the epilogue left the reader with a lot of unanswered questions. I hope this is not the end of the Virals saga and that we'll read more about Tory Brennan and the Pack in future.

"Exposure" the fourth novel in the "Virals" series begins when the Gable twins -Peter and Lucy- are abducted from Bolton Prep. Although their powers have been becoming wild and unpredictable Tory and her Pack decide to investigate.Threads of this thriller follow the Virals' investigation into the disappearance of the twins; their search for Dr. Karsten's files to unravel the mystery of their physical and super- sensory capabilities; and Tory's struggle to deal with Chance Claybourne's exploratory research into the disastrous medical experiment that created the virus that changed their DNA. With only zodiac cards and a blood stain as clues Tory and her pack also have to deal with contentious police detectives, an irritable high school principal and a black BMW that continually follows them. The story heats up with multiple twists and turns as the they draw closer to the killer, and the case takes on sinister overtones when a third classmate is kidnapped. Yet throughout the adventure as tension and suspense builds, the seriousness of each new challenge is often diluted by Hi's humour and Tory's exasperation with her father's overzealous girlfriend and her befuddlement with her growing feelings for Ben.Like all the novels in the Virals series, the characters add energy, excitement and zest to the unfolding drama. Tory Brennan continues to be impulsive and confident until her link with the boys becomes erratic. With Ben's betrayal and the erosion of her bond with the pack she fears for their future. Ben Blue with his dark moods and temper seems arrogant and reckless until events unfold that prompt Tory's forgiveness. Hiriam (Hi) Stolowitski continues to use his quick wits and razor -sharp tongue while Shelton Devers the clever cyber- hacker remains resourceful, but skittish when called into action. Eighteen year old Chance Claybourne after spending time in a mental hospital has lost his playful side and is tenacious in his determination to uncover the secret that Tory keeps hidden.Like all of the Virals novels to date I enjoyed Tory and her pack's criminal investigation in "Exposure" and look forward to reading the next book in the series.

"Of Metal and Wishes" is a haunting story that begins in "the Ring" in Gochan One, a slaughterhouse rumoured to be haunted. Sixteen year old Wen Guiren who assists her father in the medical clinic is not superstitious until one of the Noor (labourers hired for the factory) publicly humiliates her and she makes an impulsive wish that not only the Ghost grants but which triggers a violent act that leaves her assailant maimed and susceptible to a virulent flu breakout. Enthralled by tales of the Ghost, Wen begins to investigate the mystery behind a superstition that has bred kind and cruel acts throughout the factory.Feeling guilty and looking for forgiveness for her disastrous wish, Wen befriends Melik the outspoken leader of the Noor , giving medical aid to his stricken people. As their love blossoms, Wen walks a fine line between a forbidden relationship with Melik and her Itanyai friendships; people who ridicule and despise the Noor. As tempers rise and conditions in the factory worsen not only does an explosive confrontation between the Ghost and factory bosses send the Noor into hiding but it tests Wen and Melik's love and loyalty.Sarah Fine sets the stage for this emotionally-intense plot in a slaughterhouse where a company boss swindles the Noor the cheap labour force who work for a pittance, only to have excessive charges whittle it away. In the hopelessness of the factory the Noor contend with the ridicule, prejudice and hatred of the Itanyai defying the evil that threatens them by holding on to their pride and clinging to their close-knit relationship.In an atmosphere of cruelty and strife, threads of the plot follow Wen's struggle to appease a Ghost who's determined to protect her against any threat, her fight to control her fate even when bullied by an "Underboss" who preys on the virtue of young girls, and her forbidden love for the radical leader of the Noor. The plot progresses smoothly and quickly as events unfold and Wen's courage, determination and strength are the only weapons she can muster against the evil that stalks her in the factory. Yet within the suffering, grief and violence that's so vividly described there's the beauty of love, loyalty and friendship.Sixteen year old Wen Guiren haunted by the death of her mother who she remembers every time she wears one of her intricately embroidered dresses yearns to be a doctor, but can't afford to go to medical school because of her father's debts. With few friends and threatened by the conniving, bully Mugo, the factory's "Underboss" she seems weak and compliant hiding her cleverness, kind-heart, determination and bravery. Melik the Noor leader is stubborn and proud, determined to fight the injustices in the factory. In contrast the Ghost, a broken and lonely man fights from the shadows building an army of mechanized spiders and waiting to unleash their power and horror. Prone to cruelty and childlike in many ways he like Melik loves Wen but only one rules her heart. These main characters as well as many more add depth, dimension and power to a story you can't put down until the end and even then, the startling climax leaves you begging for the next novel in the series.Like all of Sarah Fines novels I thoroughly enjoyed "Of Metal and Wishes" with its shades of Phantom of the Opera and its imaginative robotics. I rate it highly and look forward to reading the next chapter in Wen's life.

"UNCAGED" a fast-paced, action-packed crime thriller begins with a break-in at the Singular Corp. research laboratory in Eugene, Oregon. In the ensuing chaos that leaves one of the radical animal-rights activists of "Storm" seriously injured, Odin Remby their brilliant hacker escapes with a set of highly encrypted files and a post-surgical dog.After sensational headlines hit the air waves about the disastrous raid, sixteen year old Shay Remby finally receives a desperate phone call from her brother, filling her in on Singular's nefarious and inhumane research programs. With little money and a knife for protection she heads to Hollywood to look for Odin fearing the lethal consequences if the company's security team finds him first. What she doesn't expect is to garner the help of Twist a wealthy artist who she calls "Cat in the Hat" and the homeless kids he harbours in a seedy hotel.In a well-developed plot that keeps the reader mesmerized from the opening prologue to the explosive ending with a cliff-hanger that begs for a sequel, the thrills never stop especially after Shay joins forces with Twist, Cruz, and Cade. Within the threads of the plot Shay not only climbs her way to notoriety in Twist's pro-immigration action and a sign raising excursion to the Hollywood Hills, but draws attention to the ecological difficulties of keeping beached sperm whales alive until high tide. But what fuels the high-intensity and suspense of the plot stems from the ethical issues around animal and human experimentation and testing by a multi-million dollar corporation.The characters are realistic and unique the complexity of their personalities adding excitement and high-energy to the drama as events unfold. Odin Remby is the brilliant computer hacker who's autistic so socially awkward and sensitive around people, but cognizant and perceptive to the pain and suffering of animals. His sister Shay in contrast is a math whiz and a tough, shrewd and aggressive teen who flees the nightmare of foster care to find her brother. Wilful, defiant and brave she quickly wins the admiration and respect of the resourceful, artistic Twist; the suspicious and daring Latino, Cruz; and mouthy, cocky but clever Cade. Yet it's the cold-hearted, ruthlessness of antagonists like Stephen Creighton (Sync) the head of Singular's security and Harmon, the intelligence chief that add a frightening chill to this intoxicating tale.I thoroughly enjoyed the finely- crafted intrigue and suspense of John Sandford, Michele Cook's novel "UNCAGED" and look forward to reading the next book in the Singular Menace series.

"The Rule of Three" is a dystopian vision of a new world that begins when the lights, computers and iphones go out in sixteen year old Adam Daley's school in Milton. Amid the fear and chaos that follows, Adam's neighbours guided by the sound advice of Herb Campbell a retired enigmatic government spy and his mother the Captain of a local precinct, band together pooling their talents and resources as government and security break down.With his father away and the electrical outage global, Adam quickly matures taking on responsibilities that have him facing death, ducking bullets and voicing humane ideas for survival to the community's leadership. But even as guards patrol the protective walls circling the neighborhood, a sports field and lawns are dug up for planting, and patrols are sent out to scout and rummage for supplies, a danger lurks only miles away that could destroy all that's being built.The plot is well-developed, imaginative and very realistic; the main theme dealing with Adam's neighbourhood surviving challenges like transportation, security, food and water consumption. It's fast-paced and action-packed especially when events unfold that have Adam and Herb dodging bullets , escaping a Cessna in the ultra-light and even a surprise raid against a merciless and ruthless encampment of mercenary soldiers. The novel is a page turner from beginning to end, climaxing with a violent explosion that begs for another novel.In a story filled with violent clashes, the seriousness of the theme is often broken by humour and romance. Adam is continually teased by his friend Todd about his blossoming romance with Lori Petersen, although I did wonder (like several other details that weren't apparent) why her rich, possessive boyfriend didn't find a way to get in touch with her. Amid the turmoil issues are often raised that have ethical implications like restricting families seeking a safe haven to only professional or skilled individuals, and the morality of killing when innocent by-passers are accidently murdered.Adam Daley is a likeable sixteen year old who's resourceful, reliable and hard-working; completing the ultra-light he and his father had begun building. In contrast to Herb Campbell Adam is optimistic and proactive, looking for the best in humanity. Herb a former spy is a wealth of information, having served abroad in operations that required organization, soldierly skills and cunning. He's tough, sharp-edged and clever as mysterious as he is cynical. These two main characters and others add passion, energy and tension to this exciting and highly entertaining tale.I enjoyed "The Rule of Three" a great story without the graphic language prevalent in many other teen novels. I look forward to reading the sequel.

"The Kiss of Deception" is a compelling fantasy adventure that begins when Princess Arabella (Lia) of the House of Morrighan flees her wedding to the Prince of Dalbreck, escaping her father's trackers and starting a new life in Terravin, a small community near the sea. Working as a bar maid Lia becomes entranced with two enigmatic strangers unaware that one is the Prince she abandoned at the altar and the other an assassin from Venda whose mission is to kill her.Mary E. Pearson begins this compelling tale in the Kingdom of Morrighan where Lia's father the King is determined to cement a crucial alliance with the Kingdom of Dalbreck to avert a war with the Kingdom of Venda. In defiance against a duty that has no room for love Lia rebels especially when the Prince refuses her request to "let her inspect him" before the wedding. She flees with her maid Pauline leaving a tenuous political situation behind.This well-developed and gripping plot heats up when marauders begin wreaking havoc in the countryside and tragedy strikes. Settling into a simple lifestyle Lia not only begins falling in love with Raff a mysterious unemployed farmhand, trusts Kaden the seemingly honest and trustworthy trader, but makes a momentous decision that sweeps her up in a storm of dangerous and unexpected events. With every challenge that Lia faces as Raff hunts for her across miles of wasteland, excitement and suspense mount as deception and lies are revealed.Amid the turmoil there are underlying strands of subplots including a prophecy hidden in the pages of two ancient books that Lia stole from the Scholar as well as her "gift" a power that's only begun to emerge and will impact her future. Even the note that spurred Raff to seek his runaway bride keeps coming into play especially after she's captured and he's driven to make a daring rescue plan. The action never stops in this riveting page-turner as events climax in an exciting cliff-hanger that begs for a sequel.Included among the main characters that add power and passion to this captivating drama is seventeen year old Lia the fearless, impulsive and quick-tempered Princess of Morrighan who sets events in motion when she flees her wedding. Defying tradition and wanting love in a marriage, she finds contentment in a simple life where she's not only hardworking but shows resilience and bravery. After falling in love with Raff she never expects that he's actually Prince Jaxon of Dalbreck, a skilled warrior who's determined to find the runaway bride whose note peaked his curiosity and amusement. Contemplative, shrewd and confident, love blossoms when Raff least expects it after losing his heart to the feisty maiden. Similarly Kaden, the brooding Vendan assassin who's haunted by a cruel past has been ordered to kill Lia. He masks his lethal intent behind kindness and consideration, never expecting that he'll be attracted to her. His steadfast loyalty to his country and duty will be tested as he discovers the depth of his feelings for a royal he thought he'd despise.With bold characters and a wealth of description Mary E. Pearson brings the fantasy world to life in " The Kiss of Deception". This is an intriguing story that I couldn't put down until the end. I recommend it to those who like the fantasy genre and look forward to the next chapter in Lia's adventure.

"Agenda 21" a dystopian thriller based on a United Nations program for handling the economic and environmental deprivations of the world is an exciting and absorbing story; a page turner from beginning to end. Set in an America plagued by economic recession, wars and government distrust, an Authority of non-elected officials have formed a "Republic" gaining their power under Agenda 21 to herd citizens into Compounds where the primary goal is to generate clean energy and breed. In a world where total equality and impartiality is suppose to exist, Emmeline has begun to ask questions especially after losing her parents, a mate and having her baby daughter swept away at birth to be raised in the Children's Village.With years of being indoctrinated with rules and taught to obey, Emmeline feels trapped and powerless, her only outlet a new job in the Village so she can see her daughter Elsa, and a pairing with David, a kind and loving Gatekeeper. But life is fickle and rumors are spreading that the children aren't thriving and have to be relocated to another Compound further away. Driven by motherly love and fear of losing her, Emmeline decides to escape, taking Elsa and David with her; an undertaking that could prove dangerous and deadly.Set in a futuristic communistic-type of society characterized by common ownership and equality among the masses, the populace in these Compounds is oppressed existing in "Living Spaces" their food and water rationed according to their productivity. In this society fertile men and women are paired but can be separated if no offspring are born. The atmosphere in the Compounds is dark and hopeless; people having lost their individuality, rights and freedom.The story is fast-paced and filled with suspense as Emmeline begins to look for answers to her past and to plan for the future. Woven into a plot that's well-developed and very realistic are symbols of love and freedom like the flowers David picks for her, a hidden Bible and the photograph of Emmeline and her mother. In a society marred by fear, hatred, prejudice and deceit qualities of love and family loyalty standout.Emmeline a young girl who has been taught more about the past than the society she lives in, is vulnerable and solitary, searching for information. Trained to be obedient by a father who fears the power and control of the Authority she feels trapped by regulations that forced her to examined for fertility at fourteen and paired with a man years older. Jeremy the youth she's paired with after George's death has been raised in the emotional sterility of the Children's Village. Immature, obnoxious and sullen, he hates Emmeline choosing to run away rather than stay with her. In contrast David a kind-hearted, generous and honest Gatekeeper attracted to Emmeline from the first time he set eyes on her will do anything to help secure a future free of the Compound. All these characters and others add power, passion and drama to this innovative story that's disturbing with the core of truth revealed at the end."Agenda 21" is an intense and gripping novel, a story you can't put down until finished. It's not only captivating but chilling as Emmeline struggles to survive and escape from this hostile environment. I thoroughly enjoyed it and can't wait to read the sequel, "Into the Shadows".

"The Gray Picture of Dorian" is an unusual science fiction thriller that begins with Dorian, a highly intelligent but arrogant programmer at a leading AI software company who's been demoted to a no-win job in its Customer Retention and Relationship Department. But Dorian plans to climb the ladder of success and has begun a secret project developing a robot, D-Rian ( the Dynamic Response Integrated Anatomic Neurosystem) using the latest technological enhancements from his firm.In a short fast-paced story that's chillingly realistic Dorian creates a robot that begins to sound and look exactly like him as it gains his knowledge and emotions through a neural bridge. The story quickly heats up building intensity and suspense when Dorian who's relationship with his wife Briana has grown strained steps away from his marital responsibility and lets D-Rian begin interacting with her on a social then physical level. Although slow at first the plot progresses smoothly and quickly as events unfold that end in a disturbing and shocking climax.Dorian an MIT graduate is vain and smug, wallowing in his conceit who creates a being like Dr. Frankenstein; a robot that's far exceeds his expectations when he begins to interface with it. But like that radical doctor he doesn't realize the implications of using science to play god. D-Rian is the technologically advanced being that becomes in many respects more human than its inventor and begins to plan its own future. Both characters add dimension and depth to a drama that's powerfully intense for such a short story.I liked "The Gray Picture of Dorian" but think it could have been even better with further character and plot development.

In "Pale Kings and Princes" the sixth book in the Shadowhunter Academy series Simon Lewis comes face to face with the Clave's prejudice and discrimination against Otherworlders while facing his own fears and insecurities in his relationship with Isabelle Lightwood.The novella is fast-paced and intense as the Shadowhunters-in-training learn about Helen Blackthorn's parentage. Exiled to an Arctic outpost after the Dark War, Helen agrees to expose the deception and cruelty of her mother, the Fey Queen Lady Nerissa towards her father Andrew Blackthorn and his brother Arthur in return for a brief respite away from the island to marry her lover Aline Penhallow. Her lecture is emotionally-charged and forces Simon to confront the weaknesses not only in Clave logic, but his insecurities in dating Isabelle.Although short in length the story is engaging and reunites the reader with many of the engaging characters from Cassandra Clare's Shadowhunter series. The ending of this tale is tragic in some ways after the truth behind Andrew's love affair,Helen's parentage and the Fair Folk's code of honesty and love is revealed, but triumphant in other ways as Simon overcomes his insecurity to finally reach out in love to Isabelle.It is interesting to journey with Simon Lewis who prefers words to weapons as he trains to be a Shadowhunter, and even more intriguing to wonder where he will end up when the author concludes this series.

"We'll Always Have Summer" continues the story of the heartbreaking romance between Belly Conklin and Conrad Fisher that begins two years later when she learns of Jeremiah's infidelity at Spring Break. Instead of breaking up with him Belly, who fears losing love again agrees to his proposal.With the wedding two months away she dives into preparations, staying at Cousins Beach when her mother refuses to be part of Belly's unwise decision. But her worst nightmare comes to life when Conrad, who's visiting from California decides to stay at the Beck house. She's never gotten over her first love and is determined to hold on to Jeremiah, her first kiss but her heart's divided and she must choose before it's too late.With twists in the story that keep you wondering if Belly will make the right choice Jenny Han weaves a finale to this poignant tale that keeps the reader riveted from the first page to the last. With a wedding drawing closer that she wants to keep simple and uncomplicated Belly discovers that her decisions are becoming more difficult and emotional especially when her mother refuses to participate, Jeremiah won't make any decisions, and Conrad finally gives voice to his love for her. The story flows naturally as Belly finds herself torn between the brothers she loves and making a choice that she can live with forever.Having been crushed by Conrad's rejection, rebounding to the safety of Jeremiah's love and fearing another loss with the pain of his betrayal, Belly clings to her plan to wed the youngest Fisher refusing her mother's advice and even the continual warnings of her heart. Although for two years she's loved Jeremiah she's never been tempted to consummate her feelings sexually, perhaps because it would have finally severed her connection to Conrad. Although confident and assured in many ways, a head-strong and stubborn Belly refuses to listen to anyone's advice, even her mother's.Jeremiah who has always competed with his brother for the love of his father fears losing Belly and will do anything to hold on to  her love including proposing, after he makes a grievous error in judgement. Immature in many ways, a partying frat boy at heart he doesn't help her with any of the decision-making, leaves the expense of the wedding to his father and is upset when she refuses his choice of apartments. Easy-going, arrogant and feeling his love threatened, Jeremiah struggles with doing what's right when he learns that Conrad and Belly have voiced the truth about their feelings.Conrad angry with his father's imperfections and the loss of his mother, feared hurting Belly so hid his feelings behind a promise to protect his brother. Loving Belly and fearing losing her forever to his brother, Conrad tries to distance himself from her. Yet he's very protective, not wanting to see her hurt so helps heal her breach with her mother as well as with planning decisions. Desperate, he tells her the truth, facing her rejection when he can't break down her defences and loyalty to Jeremiah. Like all of Jenny Han's novels, the complexity, depth and realism of her characters add to the emotional power of the story.I loved "We'll Always Have Summer"a mesmerizing story that kept you guessing until the end, and highly recommend  Jenny Han's "Summer" trilogy.

In "It's Not Summer Without You" Susannah Fisher has died leaving a hole in the hearts of all those she loved especially her sons, Belly and her best friend. With her relationship with Conrad on the rocks after a disastrous evening at her Spring prom and looking forward to a dull summer far from Cousins Beach, Belly is surprised by a call from Jeremiah Fisher with the news that his brother has disappeared just before his mid-term exams. Lying to her mother about where she's going, Belly embarks on a trip that takes her back to the summer beach house to confront a surly boy with a shattering secret, and to romance in the arms of her friend Jeremiah, the easy-going, amiable brother.Told from not only Belly's perspective but Jeremiah's the reader is swept into a contest of wills as both brothers vie for her affection. Shattered by Conrad's betrayal at his mother's funeral and his lack of interest in her, Belly not only struggles to break free of her feelings for the temperamental teen, but finds herself gravitating towards his fun-loving and even-tempered brother Jeremiah.With a fluid writing style and natural dialogue Jenny Han creates a story that's intense and emotionally-charged as romantic loyalties begin to shift, and emotions run high in the wake of Susannah's passing. Conrad, shattered by the death of his mother finds solace in his anger searching for a reason to live, a new purpose and finding a new enemy as he searches for a solution to the possible sale of the summer beach house. In doing so he alienates Belly further pushing her into the arms of his brother and leaving the reader to wonder if their love is finally dead. Into this page-turner that progresses swiftly as events unfold the author weaves friendship, sibling rivalry, family relationships and the impact of grief on individuals.In this story Belly Conklin, haunted by guilt after making a scene at Susannah's funeral is determined to find Conrad, make amends and to sever their romantic tie. Strong-willed, impulsive and loyal to Susannah's memory Belly doesn't hesitate to help Jeremiah track Conrad down, but easily falls into an emotional trap that has her getting drunk so she can express her feelings. Conrad Fisher continues to lead Belly on an emotional roller-coaster with his thoughtlessness, distance and destructive moodiness while Jeremiah craving her love wins her affection with his strength, kindness and devotion. The characters which also include a loving and supportive Laurel Conklin and a heartbroken, determined Adam Fisher all add to high-energy and drama of a riveting story that you can't put down.I liked "It's Not Summer Without You" and can't wait to read how Jenny Han ends this fascinating story in the final book

"The Summer I Turned Pretty" is a teen romance that begins in Cousins Beach where Isabel (Belly) Conklin and her family vacation in the summer with Susannah (Beck) Fisher and her two boys, Conrad and Jeremiah. Since childhood Belly has felt left out when the boys get together but the summer of her sixteenth birthday things start to change.For years Belly has had a crush on Conrad yearning for the day he will begin thinking of her more than just a tag-along kid. This summer she's blossomed into a pretty young woman which hasn't gone unnoticed either by the Beck boys or newcomer Cam. But her emotions are topsy-turvy because Conrad the boy who stole her heart as a child has changed in disposition, and her mother's best friend Susannah who's been like a second mother is facing a health crisis.Narrated by Belly with flashbacks of childhood memories the reader is swept into the close relationship between two lifelong friends and their families - the Fishers and the Conklins - as they deal with life's capriciousness. Belly has always yearned to be part of the boys circle and this summer they have not only begun to notice her, but Conrad who she's loved for years has changed; his mood sour and remote. Frustrated by their heated chemistry and his mixed signals, Belly is distracted by Cam a smart, straight-edged guy who likes her for her brains as well as her beauty, and the romantic overtures of her friend Jeremiah.Well-written with realistic dialogue and emotional intensity the plot not only follows the romantic ups and downs during Belly's summer vacation but also both family's struggle to deal with the pain of Susannah's progressing illness. The story's electrically-charged and intense, although often broken by laughter and humorous situations.For Belly Conklin the summer is a journey of self-discovery as this intelligent, naive and feisty teen not only chases love but faces the pain of loss. A spoiled, tattle-tale as a child, Belly can still be shallow and inconsiderate especially when she's influenced by her friend Taylor Jewel who's a self-absorbed, flighty tease. Yet as the story progresses her kindness and deep love for her extended family shines through in her words and actions. Conrad the eldest and most sensitive of the Fisher brothers is aloof, quiet and moody, caught up in the agony of his own pain. Although it's apparent he cares deeply for Belly, he remains unattainable and unavailable, toying with the affections of other girls and snubbing her. In contrast Belly's brother Steven can be an obnoxious and insufferable tease, but also very protective; the very popular Jeremiah funny and likeable; and the new boy Cam thoughtful and caring.Of the other protagonists who add passion and power to the drama, Susannah Fisher is a kind woman with a heart of gold who can be resolute and stubborn especially when dealing with her husband's infidelity and her illness. In contrast Laurel, Belly's highly independent mother is confident, reasonable but very secretive. Jenny Han has a flare for creating characters that are unforgettable even with all their flaws and faults.I enjoyed reading "The Summer I Turned Pretty" and can't wait to read the next book in this absorbing trilogy.

"Between Us And The Moon" is a young adult contemporary romance set in Cape Cod where Sarah Levin and her family vacation each year at her wealthy aunt's house. Unlike her eighteen year old sister Scarlett who's preparing to study at the Julliard School in New York Sarah eagerly plans to track a comet, watch the stars and apply for a scholarship until her boyfriend Tucker Jackson who she's loved since kindergarten shatters her dreams in his desire "to experiment" with his social life and arguing that she only watches the world but doesn't live in it.Shattered Sarah rebels and initiates "the Scarlett Experiment" determined to be more like her beautiful and popular sister. Adopting Scarlett's clothes and rhetoric she catches the eye of nineteen year old Andrew Davis who not only makes her feel special but loves the geeky quirks that make her different from any other girl he's known. But as their romance quickens her lies threaten to destroy their love, bringing them both a lot of pain.In a flowing writing style Rebecca Maizel weaves a well-developed plot that revolves around two troubled teens; one who hates living in the shadow of her older sister, and the other who lost a friend in a tragic accident and can't move on. Although the main plot deals with the romance between a sixteen year old girl and a nineteen year old boy the forbidden aspect of their love seems to arise from a stigma related to the difference in their ages when in reality any issues would result from her drinking illegally and from his obvious maturity having been out of school for two years and living on his own. Yet there are underlying themes that are very real in this story like sibling rivalry, family relationships and the crushing impact of grief.With an emotional-intensity often broken by snatches of humor Sarah nicknamed "Bean" goes on a journey of self-discovery learning lessons about herself and her family as she realizes that life and love can be fickle. The tension heats up in this mesmerizing tale with a hurricane that not only ruins her sister's going- away party but flings her into a steamy situation that brings heartache after Sarah's lies are revealed. Quickly progressing to an intense ending, the climax seems to be somewhat anti-climatic with more questions than answers.Sarah Levin is a highly intelligent teen with a logical, hyper-detailed mind who loves math and astronomy. She's not very social, fearing rejection but in loving Andrew changes becoming more confident and outspoken, realizing that there is more to life than science. In contrast Scarlett Levin is a graceful beauty who's overconfident, popular and funny, but very phony. Tucker Jackson Sarah's best friend for nine years is a geek who's insecure and wants to be well-liked, choosing to dump Sarah to make his dream a reality. Sensitive, good-natured and loving Andrew Davis is haunted by the death of a friend but finds solace and an anchor in Sarah. When he discovers she's been lying about her age and going to MIT, his pain turns his love to disgust. All these characters and many more add passion, depth and power to the captivating dramatic events that end with a secret, small smile.Reminiscent of Jenny Han's young adult romances, "Between Us And The Moon" is an engaging story from beginning to end and has to be read to be enjoyed.

The Spirit of Redd Mountain"  is an enthralling mystery thriller with a haunting atmosphere that begins in 1963 on the dangerous wintery slopes of a mountain after tragedy strikes when the careless bullets of a hunter causes an avalanche that sweeps six novice skiers and a rescue ranger to their deaths; their bodies never found. That day a legend was born. Over the years multiple reports have surfaced about a skier in a red parka who diverts accidents on the slopes, and of an invincible Red Elk that acts as a decoy to save wildlife in the forest.Thirty years later when Gerry Bruce (Jr.) advertises a hunt for the Red Elk, renowned hunter Warner Barney ,the man who triggered the snowslide returns determined to kill and mount the head of the elusive quarry in his den. But Gerry's father a former guide and Oliver Barry, the park ranger have other ideas. With their party of conservationists, a veterinarian, an animal rights activist, a journalist and photographer they chase the hunter and his prey over the mountain little realizing as events unfold that fate is leading them towards a final showdown.Larry Auerbach sets the stage for this exciting page-turner on Redd Mountain, a group of peaks clustered together and separated by ridges. Here ski runs are separated from hunters by a non-hunting zone that an arrogant and careless hunter crossed in the 60's stalking a prey that will come back to haunt him years later. This well-written, fast-paced plot not only follows Warner Barney the obsessed hunter who's chasing the Red Elk , the ranger and guide who are planning to thwart him, but also the egotistical reporter who will do anything to write a sensationalistic story on the weird happenings on the mountain.In an riveting and gripping tale where the people in the hunting party chase the Red Elk for different reasons, some will come away from the adventure with a sense of self-discovery while others will face their self-recriminations, and guilt from the past. In a plot where the author builds tension and high intensity with continual appearances of the spectres and premonitions that raise cautious fear, the action never stops as the party faces one challenge after another in their chase across the mountain. Amid the mystery and uncertainty as curious, paranormal events develop ideas about careful and selective hunting versus unlimited killing are voiced. Yet the seriousness of the party's undertaking is often broken with the odd dash of humor and the stirring of romance between an influential and knowledgeable old rancher and a reserved and lonely veterinarian.The characters are engaging and unforgettable as they deal with skepticism , guilt from the past and their individual flaws; like Warner Barney the trigger happy fanatic who ran from the consequences of his deadly action years before. He's a self-absorbed, arrogant, abrasive bully who thinks money can buy anyone or anything. In contrast Gerry Bruce (Sr.) a rancher and former guide haunted by guilt is a man of integrity who wants to see justice prevail just as Parker Woodson the sensible and determined ex- ranger and Oliver Barry impulsive and perceptive head of park and skier safety do. All these personalities and many more including an overly ambitious, controlling reporter and her conscientious, amiable cameraman add to the energy, passion and drama of this absorbing tale.I thoroughly enjoyed "The Spirit of Redd Mountain" and recommend it as a must- read for all those that like a haunting story you can't put down until the end.

"The Defiant Bride" is an entertaining and delightful romance with a dash of mystery and intrigue. It begins when Lady Dariana defies King Henry V11's order to wed a Spaniard or have her father suffer the consequences. In an age when women are submissive and obedient especially to the commands of a King, Dariana defies his edict faking her death and hiding out in a cabin in the forest. After several months of loneliness and boredom with no respite in sight, she sees a knight felled by an arrow not far from her hideout. Unable to move the man she cleans his wound, makes him comfortable and goes to her friend Lady Tamara for help, never realizing that the encounter is about to change her life forever.Leslie Hachtel sets the plot in England in 1508 in a time when women have no rights and are owned and bartered like property. In this period Lady Dariana raised by an indulgent father after the death of her mother is unusual, refusing to have her life bargained away so the King can cement his alliance with Spain. Yet when she meets Lord William, the Earl of Darnsworth her defiance is challenged when she's impelled to marry him, but her anger at his high-handedness soon turns to a love that defies any force that threatens it.For a short story, "The Defiant Bride" is well-written and evocative of the period, the pace flowing smoothly to a satisfying ending. The romance quickly heats up when the besotted William awakening from his injury is determined to find the "angel" who nursed him and make her his own. As Dariana and William's chemistry ignites there is a clash of wills not only before they wed but afterwards as they challenge anyone who would keep them apart. The novel is a page turner from beginning to end as the author mixes romance with the deadly intrigue of enemies that want vengeance not only against William but Dariana who dared to thwart her marriage to a wealthy Spaniard.The characters are fascinating and engaging, their love affair quickly heating up the pages of this absorbing story. Eighteen year old Lady Dariana is headstrong and independent in her desire to choose her own husband. She's proud, willful and stubborn even after being thrust into marriage with a man who knows her secret. Lord William is the arrogant, confident noble who's enthralled not only with Dariana's beauty but her cleverness and kindness. An honourable man well-liked by the King and a strong, powerful warrior he will defy anyone who tries to take Dariana from him.Yet like all good stories it's the villains that add chilling excitement to the tale. Cedric of Beckford is William's half-brother, a troublemaker who feels he's been wronged. Masking his cold-heartedness, envy and intimidation behind false charm, he's intent on gaining what he wants even if the cost is murder. Melissa, William's former betrothed and Cedric's ally is a mean, vindictive woman with a hot temper who will do anything for money and position. All these characters add passion and high energy to the drama as it unfolds.I thoroughly enjoyed "The Defiant Bride", rate it a solid 4.0 and look forward to reading more by Leslie Hachtel in future.

"Awakening" the first book in the "Shadow Realm Saga"  is a captivating fantasy that begins in Noren City when Lilly Lowreth is frightened by a stranger in a long coat wielding a sword. Terrified he's trying to kill her she flees into the heart of a temple where a dramatic twist of fate will sweep her into a world of light and shadows, and into a war between the luriel and daemons.Lilly quickly learns that deep within her burns the light and power of a luriel and that the man she thought was an assassin is her mentor and protector, a daemon slayer- Mychel Viltis. Even after discovering that she's a celemae, a fledgling luriel stalked by daemons from the Shadow Realm who want to kill her, Lilly clings to a life of normalcy in her world, resisting the truth of old myths that suddenly seem very real. With her emotions already topsy-turvy from a recent breakup, Lilly flees her unexpected discovery by spending a night out with her friends and rebounding into the arms of good-looking and magnetic Darrac, a daemon in human form who is determined to win the favour of his leader by killing her. What neither expect is to face changes that will have Lilly's powers maturing and Darrac changing as their bond grows stronger.Melanie Nilles sets the backdrop for this intoxicating tale between the Gray Realm where humans cling to a firm belief in science and technology, and the Shadow Realm where luriel and daemons fight an ongoing war. After the Sundering when an ancient race split into daemons and luriel, the latter broke off pieces of themselves and attached them to human souls so they could multiply. These celemae, fledgling luriels must find Enlightenment if they are to survive the threat of daemons who want to kill them. As a celemae Lilly must embrace her power if she is to live and help in the fight against the daemons, but she may be different, her power the healing force that could end the war.Although slow at first as Melanie Nilles introduces the reader to the shadows of a hidden world that suddenly collides with mankind, the pace quickly picks up as events unfold that have death not only stalking Lilly but monstrous creatures plaguing humanity. The mood is sombre and dark as Lilly confronts her fear and insecurity struggling to grasp her newfound power, Mychel fights to protect her and Darrac, the daemon sent to destroy her begins to evolve, his allegiance changing. In a fluid writing style (except for the unusual brackets around some of the dialogue) Melanie Nilles sweeps the reader into an imaginative and innovative world where everything is not what it seems, and the battle between good and evil may not be that clear-cut. Even the climax which ends in an explosive confrontation leaves more questions to be answered.Although the characters add power and excitement to the plot-line with their complex personalities, I felt little rapport or sympathy for Lilly and wasn't caught up in her romance with Darrac. Perhaps with more details to her breakup with Rian, it would have created some sympathy and given more substance to Lilly's feelings and actions. In the story she's lonely and naive, rebounding from a broken heart when she meets Darrac. Fearful of losing his interest she clings to him, craving his acceptance and yearning for love. Even as her power as a luriel builds and she senses the presence of a daemon, she never questions Darrac's sudden presence in her life and relegates Mychel who encourages, protects and anchors her, to only a friend. Lilly is overly skeptical, naive and unpredictable until near the end when she begins to show courage and spirit. Darrac is a hard-nosed, calculating and confident daemon. As a roguishly handsome, dark-haired human he easily sweeps Lilly off her feet, ensuring his angry, heartless leader, Torek that he will kill her at the first opportunity. Yet as he spends more time with her, slyly drinking-in her energy at night, his loyalty and ideals begin to change.Even with my criticism of "Awakening" I was thoroughly mesmerized by this unique fantasy from the first page to the last. I look forward to reading the next chapter in this saga.

In "At Any Moment" the storms of life continue to pound Adam's and Mia's relationship especially when she has to make a decision to terminate her pregnancy so she can continue her chemo treatments or risk losing her life. Tortured by her choice and constantly on edge as she battles the mental and physical trauma of cancer treatments, Mia leans on Adam's strength not realizing how guilt and fear are weighing him down and that in his pain he's begun to psychologically distance himself from her, putting up a defensive wall in case he loses her.The final book in this captivating trilogy centers around not only Mia's battle to survive, Adam's struggle to help her, but their fight to communicate honestly and openly, to break down the barriers that have destroyed their trust in each other. Emotionally-charged the plot is electric and intense especially when Mia reaches out to Adam hoping not only for comfort but to reignite their sexual passion. In fear and pride he backs away, nursing old wounds and terrified of a future without her while she hides the bodily scars she not only finds repulsive, but is frightened he will.In a flowing writing style that breathes realism into a well-written storyline, Brenna Aubrey creates a plot that vibrates with the pain and suffering of a couple struggling to heal a broken relationship while dealing with the agony and heartbreak of life's unpredictable misfortunes. Yet throughout she keeps the plot linked not only to Mia's website in articles about using the " respawn" button to restart a life, but the world of gaming using the quest in Dragon Epoch to bring solace and hope to Mia's yearning heart. Even the journal that Mia keeps as she battles her demons brings enlightenment and healing as Adam reads her thoughts.The characters are unforgettable, realistic and complex with all their flaws and faults. Emilia (Mia) Strong an independent feminist feels she can deal with all her problems on her own, alienating those that love and want to help her. Making a crucial and informed decision that could save her life so she can make her dreams a reality, she instead wallows in self-hatred and recriminations that can break her if she doesn't seek help. Stubborn and insecure about her physical appearance and her love for Adam, she's brave and strong, refusing to give up as she begins to look for hope and healing.Adam Drake a brilliant problem-solver continually fights his fear and powerlessness as Mia battles for her life. Trying to overcome his high handedness and the control that helped him build a gaming empire but which could destroy his relationship, Adam effectively avoids admitting his worry, censure and guilt, keeping a wall around his heart and impeding any sexual encounters. Only when Mia and Adam begin facing their issues does the "I" in their relationship become an "us" and love spark anew.Like the contemporary romances of K.A. Tucker and Katie McGarry with their broken lovers who find love and redemption Brenna Aubrey takes a brilliant geeky couple with bright futures whose loving relationship is shattered not only by the tragic storms of life,the fears and insecurities from their past but their lack of faith and trust in each other. I rate this novel especially high with its well-developed and riveting story told from both Adam and Mia's perspectives.

"At Any Turn" continues the romance between millionaire CEO Adam Drake and Geek Girl blogger Mia Strong whose ambition is to become an oncologist. As the story opens Adam has just spent weeks hiking across country to Yosemite Park contemplating his life while Mia has been missing him and waiting for a letter of acceptance from a school of medicine. Reunited they're eager to revel in the happiness of new love until she receives a letter from the John Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore Maryland. Frightened that their relationship will not survive a long distance relationship and with the press hounding him because of a lawsuit against Draco because of the murder-suicide of a gamer addicted to Dragon Epoch, Adam isn't able to move so far away. In a desperate attempt to keep Mia close he forces her to make a decision by proposing marriage ,only to be rejected and have their relationship slowly crumble after she moves in with her best friend Heath.As time passes with heated arguments , secrets and trust issues on both sides Adam discovers that Mia has developed a serious health problem that could mean losing her forever. Stricken by a feeling of helplessness especially after the loss of his sister, he must learn to take a risk, stop trying to control all the variables in their lives and to trust her judgement.In a story where hidden plots, lies and secrets threaten their relationship Adam and Mia face a storm of problems that not only threaten Draco Multimedia, but her health and any promise of a future together. With clever dexterity Brenna Aubrey builds tension and passion into the pain and turbulence of a shattered relationship that has the lovers facing not only their weaknesses but a tragic crisis.The author uses the backdrop of the gaming industry to voice the controversy about the destructiveness of players' addiction to online games as well as integrating facets of Dragon Epoch and Dungeons and Dragons as vehicles to move aspects of the story forward. With a writing style that's fluid, dialogue that's natural and steamy love scenes that are often troubling in their intensity the story progresses quickly as events unfold.Told from Adam's perspective, the reader is immediately struck by his fear and powerlessness in stopping his breakup with a woman he not only loves desperately but who anchors him to a normalcy in life which he hasn't known while building his gaming empire. A genius haunted by abuse and tragic loss, Adam's stubborn, manipulative and feels helpless, struggling with severe migraine headaches as he deals with a relationship spiraling downwards, out of his control. In comparison Emilia (Mia) Strong with her feminist ideals is highly independent, strong-willed and refuses any outside interference in making decisions, even from someone she loves. Rather than being honest and asking for help when sick or even giving Adam a chance to explain his actions she avoids any unpleasantness, shielding herself by running from a problem or putting up a defensive wall around her heart. In this story neither Adam nor Mia has had any experience in the relationship department, both have serious trust issues and are unable to communicate honestly with each other."At Any Turn" is an emotional roller coaster that paves the way for the final book in a rocky romance that you hope will end in Adam and Mia finding happiness,

"At Any Price" a titillating stormy contemporary romance begins with Mia Strong's "Virgin Manifesto" as she offers her virginity for auction online. Her rules are clear; the highest bidder must be unmarried; have a lab workup to ensure no STD's; no criminal history; proof of payment in an offshore holding account and a contractual agreement that there will be no contact after the contract's completed.But the auction goes awry when the winner, Adam Drake the CEO of Drake Multimedia Entertainment snidely voices his own conditions and Mia begins having second thoughts. Only with charm and playing on their steamy chemistry is he able to take control of the situation so the game can begin. What neither expect as the romance heats up and they reveal past pain and suffering is that love can heal even their worst demons if they 're strong and brave enough to accept and trust each other.The story comes alive in the world of gaming where geeks like Mia Strong set aside their troubles playing Dragon Epoch, the latest innovative game from Draco. But Mia's no stranger to problems; struggling to pay her bills, studying for her MCAT, and trying to help a mother recuperating from cancer whose teetering on the verge of losing her ranch. Motivated by money and a sense of security, a feminist who's determined to control her destiny, Mia puts her only asset of value up for auction even though she's continually warned that nothing good can come of prostituting herself for money.This well-written plot vibrates with emotion and sexual tension as events unfold that have two people troubled by the past and adhering to a "no dating" policy to pursue their dreams,  find love in a wacky contest of wills. With wit, humor and steamy sexual foreplay Brenna Aubrey builds a story filled with tension and passion where trust and love can be irreparably destroyed by secrets and lies.Mia Strong haunted by a brutal assault and the rejection of her "biological sperm donor" is overly practical, insecure, afraid of failure and avoids relationships preferring the safety and control of the imaginative world of Dragon Epoch. As her sexual barometer heats up, craving more stolen hours with Adam, she changes into a virginal wanton becoming daring, bold and empowered but reeling from the truth of secrets that could undermine her growing attachment. Adam Drake the brilliant child prodigy who's the founder and CEO of a rising company and plagued by family tragedy isolates himself from love hiding his emptiness behind an excessive work ethic. Only with Mia does he come alive and awaken to the possibilities of love. Both characters are engaging with complexity in their personalities that fuels the drama with energy and passion.Although at times I found Mia a bit too high-strung and over-dramatic , the story is riveting, a page turner from beginning to end. I look forward to reading the next chapter in Mia and Adam's steamy romance.

"For the Win"  is a sizzling romance that begins after a heart-broken April Weiss makes a bad decision, hooking up with a stranger at Comic-Con and accidentally recording their night of hot sex only to have it go viral over the Internet. As an intern working in the CFO's office of privately-owned Draco Multimedia Entertainment, a company on the threshold of going public, she knows the video could be damaging to their image as well as to her, personally and professionally if anyone learns that it was her moans of ecstasy on the sex tape.Jordan Fawkes, April's sexy millionaire playboy boss knows the players identity in the steamy night of sex that exploded across the Internet, and holds the key to her future if she exposes the secret. But obsessed by the delectable body he was intimate with disguised as Falco the Bounty Hunter and afraid of a leak or blackmail that could injure the future of the Company and his career, Jordan is beastly enough to make the life of his lovely, talented and sexy intern hell as his lust and inappropriate behaviour grows while piling on the work and treating her with disdain.In a high- stakes game of cat and mouse Jordan and April's chemistry and passion ignites as they do everything in their power to hide a secret that could have them both fired and their plans for their futures ruined.In an emotionally-riveting, fast-paced plot filled with tension and high-energy, Jordan and April relate the events of a love affair that's as turbulent as it is passionate. In a fluid writing style that sparks with wit and humor Brenna Aubrey brings to life the brilliant innovation of a gaming company on the verge of making its owners billionaires. Challenged by a scandal Jordan rushes to reassure banking investors of their integrity while the CEO implements sexual harassment sessions for his employees. Amid the turmoil Jordan and April not only ignore their vow keep their distance from each other, but begin to forge a bond that exposes secrets from their pasts that have moulded their personalities. Brenna Aubrey weaves a story of brokenness that only the fortitude of love can heal.April Weiss plagued by the betrayal of her mother and an indifferent father has always felt like a chameleon, never standing out, eager to please and avoiding ugly situations. A bright, hardworking intern who's eager to prove herself at Draco, working for a letter of recommendation from this up-and-coming hi-tech firm, she's bookish, tender-hearted, clever and resourceful. Yet with a devilishly charming,attractive, insensitive and rude "beast" for a boss April quickly learns to be cheeky and bold, rebelling against her natural insecurity and timidity.Jordan Fawkes is the partner in a rising gaming company with business smarts and know-how. But, haunted by the infidelity of a childhood love, enraged by the rejection of his angry father, embittered but guilt-ridden by his subtle method of revenge, he's become cold and hard, wallowing in shallow and meaningless affairs, trusting only select friends and embracing the carefree lifestyle of a millionaire playboy. To April, he's egotistical, heartless and downright mean, only showing tenderness in their scorching hot encounters. Yet as the depth of his feelings grow, he begins to show genuine sensitivity, protectiveness and caring especially when confronted by her self-indulgent mother and the ex-boyfriend who broke her heart.The lovers soon realize they have similar family situations though the personalities involved are very different and that only love can heal their wounds. Both characters are engaging and complex, igniting their burgeoning romance with electricity and passion.Although not a fan of novels with a high- level of graphic language, I found "For the Win," to be a well- written, sexually-charged contemporary romance with a cast of memorable characters. It keeps you captivated from the first page to the last and I intend to read more stories by Brenna Aubrey.

"Alien Me", a blend of science fiction and urban fantasy intertwined with romance begins at Duncan High School in Likely Minnesota after Darcy Hinson is cyber bullied into publically apologizing to her date after being accused of poisoning him when he passes out at a movie. Angry and frustrated she's further humiliated at school when the stones in her jewellery burn her skin after new student Sean Banks enters her class. Forced to flee Duncan High after being attacked by assassins in the principal's office, Darcy quickly learns that she's far from normal and has been endowed with some strange and unexpected abilities.Swept deep underground to Geminay the home of the Original People, a technologically superior alien race Darcy's life becomes further complicated when she learns about her creation as a human-hybrid and that she's duty-bound to obeying the commands of her high-born creators. But in this heartless, unemotional and logical world of lies and deceit nothing is what it seems. As Darcy begins to fall for Sean, a love that's forbidden and slowly rebels against the constraints of her creators she uncovers a plot to destroy humanity, a plan she will do anything to stop.Emma Accola sets the stage for this captivating tale in Geminay where the Original People settled after being hunted by the Tarkwin, a callous warrior race. In this rigidly structured society ,high-born houses rule under the direction of two royals, and do little work leaving that to the low-borns and discarded classes. In a social order where Mechanics created human-alien hybrids called Sworn Assets, Darcy quickly learns that her role is not only to be a conduit for the yellow sun above but an energy source to help the people return to their homeland. But although she's richly provided for in a beautiful setting, the mood is dark and sinister and death the cost of free will.Fast-paced and filled with suspense the intensity of the plot heats up when Darcy begins to learn the extent of her power as a "missusan", someone who can kill with a touch. As events unfold and the danger that threatens their lives escalates Darcy and Sean not only draw closer, romance blossoming, but they unravel clues to an evil plot that means freedom for the Original People and death for humanity. The story is fascinating from beginning to end especially with a cliff-hanger after an explosive confrontation that begs for a sequel.The characters are engaging and complex, adding energy and passion to the emerging drama; especially sixteen year old Darcy Hinson who's insecure, easy-going and highly submissive to adult authority. As the plot progresses she begins to change becoming more altruistic, resourceful, confident and brave. Sean Banks who was strong and self-assured on the surface quickly becomes compliant and passive, fearing the high-borns control. Forbidden to fall in love, Darcy and Sean's friendship and trust quickly grows deeper underground as their attachment grows stronger.Yet it's the antagonists that add chilling excitement to this tale especially Lady Naomi who's ruthless, cold-hearted, merciless and will do anything to ensure that that her relationship with Lord Sylvan continues and that they can return home.At first I thought events progressed too quickly with little build-up to the momentous actions that have Darcy and Sean fleeing assassins. At times the dialogue was stiff, and unrealistic for a sixteen year old facing such an unexpected and significant change in her life. But as events progressed the story flowed more smoothly, becoming enjoyable and entertaining. I look forward to reading the sequel as Darcy and Sean struggle to keep their love alive as they fight to save mankind from extinction.

"Amanda Lester and the Pink Sugar Conspiracy"  is a tween adventure filled with mystery and intrigue that begins when twelve year old Amanda Lester a descendant of Scotland Yard Inspector G. Lestrade is reluctantly enrolled at " Legatum Continuatum: the Enduring School for Detectives" at Lake Windemere in England. A filmmaker at heart Amanda not only deplores any connection to her bumbling ancestor who worked with master sleuth Sherlock Holmes, a detective she considers egotistical and overrated but being forced to study at the secret detective school.But as Amanda makes new friends especially the good-looking, magnetic Nicholas (Nick) Muffet and strange events begin to unfold that rouse her curiosity she slowly becomes embroiled in a mystery and a conspiracy that goes far beyond an assigned school project.Paula Berinstein sets the stage for this captivating tale of secrets, lies, murder and deceit at the Legatum Continuatum a covert school that teaches the young descendants of famous detectives the "tools and tricks of the trade". Divided into five houses with fifty students each the plot heats up when Gaston Thornkill the headmaster advises the students that they must solve a crime before the end of the term and that the winning house will receive future privileges. But to Amanda and her friends who have found blood spatters and heard noises in the walls the mystery has already begun.With an explosion on school grounds, a pink powder found in odd places and suspects murdered not only does the author build tension and suspense but the intensity and pace of the plot escalate. And if that's not enough to start Amanda's investigative skills boiling, her father disappears and she begins receiving threatening emails. With natural dialogue and humor Paula Berinstein cleverly captures not only the emotional upheavals of being a tween but in the case of Amanda her angst and her family's interaction when she's forced to move away from all she knows and loves, as well as the flattery and confusion of a first attraction.Like the plot the characters are realistic and engaging especially Amanda Lester who was told she's close-minded, dictatorial and a micromanager by her girlfriends in the Stick Dog Filmmakers Club. Yet in the detective school her flaws are minimized as she becomes more of a team player, showing a resourceful, clever and impulsive nature. Smitten by the dashing and creative Nick Muffet who has a similar interest in film, she's quickly enchanted by his niceness and easy smiles that mask secrets and a connection to an infamous villain.Of the other characters who add their intelligence and expertise to the investigation are blind but perceptive and cheerful Ivy Halpin; her loyal, curious and likeable dog Nigel; the strong-willed and moody Amphora Kapoor; and the brilliant, dependable, but awkward and sometimes annoying Simon Binkle.I thoroughly enjoyed reading "Amanda Lester and the Pink Sugar Conspiracy" and highly recommend it to tweens and teens alike. I look forward to seeing what's in-store next for Amanda and her friends.

"Fashion Academy" centers around Mackenzie Williams a sixth grader who has been addicted to fashion since she was old enough to style her dolls hair and dress them with her unusual flair. Wanting to be a designer "who colours outside the lines and thinks outside the box," Mickey is excited when she receives a full scholarship to the Fashion Academy of Brooklyn (FAB). But when she arrives with her avant- garde style, she's ostracized by smug Jade Lee and her friends. Wanting to pursue her dream and socially fit in to the academy, Mickey makes friends with Javen Cumberland a "doggy design genius" who reinvents her image. Becoming the chic fashionista Kenzie Willis, supposedly the daughter of Finnish designer royalty, she quickly makes friends, but the lie could cost her the individuality that makes her unique.The story is innovative and inspiring for young girls who dare to dream. It's filled with humour and amusing incidents like the stink of decay from the red cabbage and berry juice on the t-shirt she designs. In a plot that progresses quickly as Mickey takes a journey of self-discovery there are heartwarming moments as her crusty and dreary Aunt Olive warms to her clever and affectionate niece.Mackenzie (Mickey) Williams is an ambitious, driven young girl whose life becomes an exciting adventure as she explores her dream of becoming a designer at the Academy. Javen Cumberland (JC) who "believes less is more" in fashion is the smart and talented friend who helps Mickey change her image so she'll fit in, while stodgy Aunt Olive is the "germophobic bird-watcher" who transforms under her niece's love and guidance. The personalities of all these characters and many more breathe life into a charming tale.I enjoyed "Fashion Academy" and intend to have other middle schoolers who dream about their future read it. I'd rate it 4.5 if the scale allowed.

"Storm Fall" the fast-paced sequel to "Rebel Wing" heats up as Aris Haan overcomes the demons haunting her after her last dangerous mission as Aristos and she rejoins her search and rescue unit. With new purpose in being the public face of enlisted women in the military and as a Lieutenant training new flyers at the Spiro stationpoint, Aris's work has grown harder especially with the men in her unit undermining her authority with taunts and snide comments.
