Encouraged and supported by her best friend Dysis, her sectormate Pallas and her commanding officer Major Milek Vadim who she's fallen in love with, Aris is determined to overcome the men's hostility, and to help find the Safaran torturer who scarred her and burned Ward Galena Vadim's face.Tracy Banghart sets the stage for her second mesmerizing novel in Atalanta where war with the Dominion of Safara continues to rage not only with the deaths of soldiers but innocent villagers. Plagued by the cruel and brutal leadership of Ward Belias who's determined to gain the rich resources of Atalanta the Safarans suffer from starvation and illness, their children stolen to serve in his army. In a fluid writing style she breathes realism into a plot where the war seems endless and the Atalantan military are killing a faceless enemy only to discover a hidden truth; they're no more than children. As in every war story it's filled with tragedy, brutality and violence but often diluted by love, courage and mercy.The plot is action-packed and mesmerizing with every dip and turn of the wingjets, every explosive encounter with the enemy, and all the political intrigue. Threads of the story not only follow Aris's foray into the battle zone to discover the whereabouts of the Safaran torturer; her blossoming romance with Milek; but also the problems and strategies of Ward Nekos and Ward Vadim as they try to end the war while the love they thought lost rekindles. The plot's innovative with its futuristic look at the power-hunger and greed that undermines a senseless war as well as imaginative with science fiction devices like the diatous veil, solargun and sythin. The pace never stops, holding the reader captive until the startling cliff-hanger at the end which begs for another book.The personalities of the characters continue to be realistic and strong adding fervour and high-energy as they're challenged by one crisis after another. In this story Major Milek Vadim the authoritative, stern-faced officer who's cool and in control under pressure begins to show a softer side as he falls hopelessly in love with a strong-willed, independent and tougher Aris. Although their love's forbidden in the heat of war, they steal moments alone, their feelings growing in intensity. When Aris is thought to be dead uptight and principled Calix Pavlos breaks the rules, deserting his post to search for his former girlfriend with the rescue team. Regretting words that not only hurt but severed his bond to Aris, Calix shows resourcefulness, kindness and bravery.In the violence of war for every heart shattered and friend lost, new romances are born or rekindled like the attraction between Dysis and Calix, two opposites in personality drawn together in a secret mission to save Aris. And there's the volatile chemistry between Ward Nekos and Ward Vadim who can't forget the past, their love rekindled as they strategize to find the spies within their Dominions and to end the danger and brutality of the war. Yet in every crisis it's the antagonists that add chilling tension and heighten the suspense; like Elom, Galena Vadim's cruel and brutal torturer and Ward Belias the dangerous, heartless and deceptive Safaran leader.I thoroughly enjoyed "Storm Fall" and highly recommend it. As a new fan of Tracy Banghart's series I look forward to reading about Aris's next exploits in the war against Safara.

Set in the future in the Dominion of Atalanta "Rebel Wing" is a mesmerizing, fast-paced blend of military action, romance and intrigue that begins when eighteen year old Aris Haan's boyfriend is drafted as a field mender in the military and leaves for war.Desperately in love and feeling adrift without him, Aris makes an impulsive decision to use her love of flying and join Calix on the battlefront but there's a problem- the military's prohibition of women. Undeterred Aris discovers a way to become a soldier but it means giving up her life in Lux, her family and friends, and changing her identity.In a novel that's a page turner from beginning to end Aris makes a transition in her life that transforms her from a weak, helpless, protected young woman into a brave and skilled flyer who overcomes trials and survives the violence of battle to find her calling in saving lives as part of the search and rescue unit.Tracy Banghart sets the stage for this innovative plot in Atalanta one of Five Dominions, a country rich in resources at war with Safara. As the story opens Aris and Calix are planning their life together and about to join one of five services - Health, Commerce, Technical, Environment or Military. But fate has other plans for the young lovers when Calix is conscripted into the army and Aris decides to follow him into a war that Atalanta appears to be losing.Threads of the story follow not only Aris's self-discovery and bravery under fire, but the kidnapping of the Ward of Ruslana by the Safarans who are determined to isolate Atalanta from any help from her allies. With multiple twists and turns Tracy Banghart slowly builds tension and suspense in an unique plot filled with exciting exploits and imaginative technology that can change a person's appearance. Even the intensity of Aris's romance with Calix who refuses to bind her love to him with a "Promise" until after the war, begins to change as she transforms into a strong, determined soldier with a new purpose in her life.The characters are unforgettable, adding power and passion with the complexity of their personalities. Aris Haan (aka Aristo) a sheltered young woman after illness left her with a limp is a romantic in love with her boyfriend Calix, but even more with flying her wingjet. Floundering after he leaves for war, Aris makes an impulsive decision that will eventually change her into a tough, courageous and determined flyer in the military. Practical and overprotective Calix Pavlos is not a rule breaker. When he discovers Aris's ruse he becomes judgemental and distant; his love conditional. In contrast Major Vidar Aris's tall scarred commanding officer is a stern, hardened soldier but calm and level-headed under duress. What begins as admiration for Aristo's flying skills slowly grows deeper when he discovers he's really a woman.I thoroughly enjoyed "Rebel Wing, a thrilling blend of romance,intrigue and the imagination of science fiction. I rate it highly and look forward to reading the next book in the series.

In "A Book of Spirits And Thieves" the spin-off series from "Falling Kingdoms" Morgan Rhodes weaves an urban fantasy filled with dark magic and mystery that begins in the Speckled Muse Bookshop in Toronto where Crystal and Becca Hatcher open a parcel with a strange book written in an unknown language. When the light of magic flares within its pages and Becca falls into a coma a dangerous adventure begins where worlds collide.Swept away to Mytica Becca Hatcher's spirit meets Maddox Corso a struggling necromancer who's beginning to discover the depth of his power. Believing only Maddox can help her find a way back to her world, the pair begin a journey that will have them confronting the power of Valoria a dark, power-hungry goddess who's bent on not only ruling her realm but all the unseen worlds beyond it.While Becca and Maddox search for a way to thwart Valoria's schemes, Crys Hatcher explores the mystery of the ancient book that left her sister comatose in the hospital. What she will uncover is not only a secret society that threatens her family but a dangerous attraction to a rich bad- boy Farrell Grayson, a member of the organization's inner circle.Morgan Rhodes sets the stage for this captivating tale between Mytica where an evil immortal sits on the throne slowly stealing the people's liberty and enforcing their total obedience , and Toronto where a mysterious leader of a secret society kills in the name of truth and justice. In a plot that brews slowly as it twists and turns, the action soon heats up when Becca and Maddox challenge Valoria's evil plot and Crys has to make a decision whether or not to hand over the powerful ancient book to the leader of the Hawkspear Society. As the intensity and suspense of the plot escalates lies and secrets are revealed that not only shock Crys, but have Becca facing an unsavory truth. In a natural flowing writing style that brings realism to this fantasy and with witty banter that breaks the growing tension the author builds a story that keeps the reader guessing even with a cliff-hanger at the end that begs for a sequel.The characters are unforgettable and complex as they struggle to overcome one challenge after another. Crystal (Crys) Hatcher is a nearsighted teen insecure about her looks who hides behind black glasses and an argumentative, defiant personality. Truant at school and troublesome at home Crys takes refuge in her love of photography. Yet for all her flaws she's relentless, a pit bull in discovering the mystery of her family's past and the book that holds the sister she loves hostage. In contrast Becca is pretty, responsible and self-confident. In ancient Mytica her spirit is drawn to the young necromancer Maddox Corso who's the only one who can see her. Plagued by his guardian's abuse, insecure and suspicious of a power he's only begun to tap into,Maddox's strength-of- character and determination shines through with each new challenge, even when he loses the girl who encouraged and supported him. In contrast charming but aimless Farrell Grayson the irresponsible and reckless son of a prominent Toronto family who's haunted by the loss of his brother and yearns for the respect of his parents seeks solace in the dark intrigues of the Hawkespear Society. A nineteen year old who relishes control over others and thinks money can buy him anything has a weakness for his brother and a young woman who smells like strawberries.Yet like all stories it's the antagonists that add a chilling excitement to the drama; in Mytica the merciless and heartless Valoria and in Toronto the controlling deceit and manipulation of Markus King.Like all of Morgan Rhodes novels, I thoroughly enjoyed "A Book of Spirits And Thieves" as dark magic flares, and an ancient and modern world collide.

To be honest, I don't know if *I* would love these, but let me tell you, the dogs go nuts for them - it's almost like crack to them.The only real down-side is that if one of the dogs finishes before the others, they'll try to "steal" the not-yet-eaten treats from their "siblings".  In our house, this is more of a reason for "only give when supervised" than any possible choking hazard than can occur with any food.We have 5 dogs and one of these boxes is usually good for 1 - 2 servings each.

I got this to go with my cheapie 7" Windows 8 tablet (got it for $60).  It works great and allows me to do presentations, or watch a movie, from my little tablet onto either an external monitor or a projector.  This is a must-have accessory that's small enough to "never leave home without it."

This may not be the brightest UV light on the market, but it gets the job done, just turn the lights off.Having dogs, my wife and I have seen them have "accidents" (sometimes "intentionals" if they're in a mood) on the carpet and would clean them up.  Well, with this little gem, we found there were many, many more spots that we didn't know about and can't see unaided.  Our near future has a lot of carpet cleaning in it.I also used this to test the cleaning company at my workplace by putting UV-fluorescent dye in strategic locations.  It's easily water soluble and doesn't even stand up to getting splashed with water, much less wiped with a damp cloth.  Let's just say between the dye and "bodily fluids", I don't even want to go near the restrooms at work.  Once you've seen it, you can't un-see it - ignorance was bliss, no matter how unsanitary that bliss was.  Needless to say, I'll be looking for a new cleaning company as soon as possible!

I'm something of a flashlight-o-holic.  I almost always carry a 960-lumen Nitecore light on my belt and I've been itching to find a very-small but very-bright keychain light.  This new Nitecore offering fit the bill perfectly.Sure, there are other similar-sized lights on the market, but the integrated USB charging port and rechargeable lithium ion battery elevate this light above the others.  Two preset levels of brightness plus an "infinitely adjustable" level further set this light apart from the crowd.It's really hard to beat this light, especially at its price.

I've been wanting to delve into a Windows tablet of my own since a few Surface Pro 3's came in for some of the sales force at work.  Alas, I don't have $1,000+ laying around for such things, so when I saw this little gem advertised on sale, I had to get one.  As many others here have done, I got mine at Microcenter for a whole, whopping $59.I work in IT, so instinctively, the first thing I did out-of-the-box was start loading Windows Updates.  It didn't take long before reality came along and smacked me upside the head (in other words, C: ran completely out of space and Windows became very unhappy in a hurry).  A "Reset to Factory Fresh" later, and I was ready to try again.  You see, this tablet has only 16GB of "hard drive" space and half of that is tied up in the Recovery Partition (which, I've learned, is where *most* of Windows actually runs from on this tablet).  Of the "available to the user" space on C: drive, just over 2GB is tied up in various necessary directories, so right off the bat, C: is down to just 4GB free space.  A visit to www.microcentertech.com for a quick download gets you a utility that will free up 2 GB of C:, bringing it up to 6GB out-of-the-box.  6GB still isn't "spacious" by any stretch, but when you're talking drives this small, every little bit counts.  Mercifully, there is no "bloatware" pre-installed on this tablet like you find on most desktops and laptops.Lessons learned, I immediately turned OFF Windows Update so as not to run into those particular space problems again.  I also used every tip and trick I could find - and made up a few of my own - for making the most of my tiny C: drive.After getting past the C: space issues, I'm finding this little tablet to be surprisingly able and functional.  Since it's running "full blown" Windows 8.1, and it has a real USB port (a powered "host" port), installing anything you like is easy as can be.  The USB port even powered a (mechanical) USB hard drive.  Of course, as soon as you start installing stuff, you're back to the C: drive space problems.  I strongly recommend buying a 64GB MicroSD card and using it as a "permanent" install location for any and all programs that give you a choice of where to install them.The tablet comes with a one-year license for Office 365 Personal (licenses to install 2 devices, plus 1TB of OneDrive cloud storage) for free.  That, by itself, is $65 so buying this tablet is sort of like buying Office 365 and they give you a tablet to run it on.  Sweet deal.I've tried to see how far I can push this little guy.  It runs most programs fairly well, but CPU-intensive apps (like video encoding) run slowly and produce "low memory" errors.  All things considered, though, it's a remarkable device that is well worth its price.  While it won't be a desktop replacement any time soon, it beats everything else hands down in portability and convenience.One last note while I think of it...  All the specs I see note (or at least imply) the headphone port is output only, but (not surprisingly) the headphone jack also provides microphone-in functionality in addition to stereo output.

I liked this cable a lot while I had it.  It only cost about half of what Radio Shack wants for a cable half the length.  I'm going to have to buy another one, though.  I left it with the sound board at church and it grew legs and walked off.  At church, for Pete's sake!!

I needed to convert a "regular" microphone into something that could serve as an external mic for an iPhone.  Thanks to the wiring on the TRRS jack in an iPhone, a plain-old "PC compatible" mic won't work without an adapter.This solves the problem well.  Unfortunately, though, it is not meant for audio monitoring while recording video on the phone.  Without being able to monitor the audio "live" it took a lot of trial and error to get the levels right, but it works!It would not have been possible without this adapter.

Before stumbling across various Anker accessories on Amazon, I had never heard of Anker.  Now, though, I swear by them!  I have several of their power accessories and they're all awesome.It's tough to find dual USB car chargers that pump out 2.1 amps at each port simultaneously.  Most are "up to 2.1 amps, total", but this one provides the full power necessary to charge two iPads at the same time.  And does it quickly, no less.This is the only USB car charger you'll need.

I already had a Nitecore SRT7 with the batteries, charger, etc. but needed another one...  When my father-in-law met my SRT7, I almost couldn't get it out of his hands!  So, when father's day rolled around, my wife and I got him his own.  He never leaves home without it!I wrote a full review of the SRT7 elsewhere here on Amazon.

My wife was having a love-hate relationship with her Nokia Lumia Windows phone.  She loved the 30-something megapixel camera, but hated that many apps she had become used to having on the iPhone don't exist for Windows phone.  She wanted to go back to iPhone, but didn't want to completely lose the superior camera on the Windows phone.This adapter/converter set solved the problem handily.  You can use it to convert a nano-SIM to any other size SIM.And for less than $5 with free Prime shipping, you can't beat the price.

My wife was making a "diaper cake" (I never heard of one before either!) for a colleague at work and wanted me to add a little "extra" to it with some LEDs.The description says this is for CR2032 batteries, but 2032s are way too large to fit.  This holder does, however, fit a 2025 perfectly.  Lucky for me, I had some 2025s that had come from an eBay mix-up and the seller told me to keep them.I was able to complete the mini-project for my wife.  But this holder only gets 3 stars because of the incorrect description.

These brake pads look great and they claim to fit my 2006 Mazda 6.  But looks and ad-copy can be misleading.  I don't know what vehicle these pads are made for, but I personally guarantee you that it's NOT a 2006 Mazda 6!!  In the middle of my brake job, I had to use the other car to go buy the right ones from the local auto parts store.  At least I was able to return these for a full refund.

It irks me to buy 5 resistors at my local Radio Shack for almost $2, when they should be a couple cents each.  So, I bought a package of these on Amazon for a do-it-yourself LED project.  You'll want to have some soldering know-how, but if you manage to burn one of these up, it's no big deal - there's like a gazillion in the bag!

I'm using these in church to send an audio-only feed out from the sound board to a video camera that's about 40 feet away (straight, "mostly" unobstructed line of sight).We wanted to get a "clean" feed into the camera without requiring the Pastor to wear an additional microphone.  There aren't many options when it comes to where I can place these units and I was concerned about people walking through the line-of-sight, but these are performing more than fine.I have not used them to transmit video, so I cannot speak to how well video comes through.  But, the audio works great!These units are extremely easy to set up and use.  Strongly recommended.
A very interesting and insightful documentary.  Packed with science and Biblical insight, this is a must-see.

Everyone who has a DLP television will, sooner or later, hear the inevitable "pop" that signals it's time for a new bulb.  In my case, that sad sound came about a week after my 4-year extended (including bulbs) warranty on the TV ran out.  I figured I was "in for it", looking at a $200, $300, or even $400 repair.  Ugh.But, Amazon to the rescue!  Several 1 and 2 star reviews note "infant mortality" of these bulbs - they pop or burn out within the first month.  But, hey, for less than $30, I was willing to chance it.  So far, the gamble has paid off - it has been installed in my TV for a little over a month with no sign of trouble.This bulb comes in a complete cartridge, making it as easy to replace as it is to swap out ink cartridges in a printer.  Actual replacement time was about 5 minutes - including pulling the TV away from the wall so I could access the lamp compartment.  In short, I don't think it could be much easier to do.That was it.  Turned the TV on and presto! there's the picture!  Sweet.  My wife and I noticed that the picture is significantly brighter than it was with the old bulb.  We're not sure if it's because the replacement is meant to be that way or because the old bulb was "on its way out" long before the pop.  Whatever the reason, this bulb is fantastic.If you have a compatible DLP TV and need a replacement lamp, look no further.  You can't go wrong with this sub-$30 replacement.

This is one of those things that I just had to try out.  I was a little apprehensive because the stated requirement of "iOS 6 or newer" (for Apple devices) is a little old and I have the latest and greatest iPhone, but it was inexpensive enough to be in the "low risk" category (little $ to lose).  It works great with my iPhone 6 Plus running iOS 8.0.2, so I'm very happy I took a chance on it!This remote shutter release is remarkably easy to set up and use.  First, turn this little remote "on" and then go into the normal pairing process on your smartphone.  "Keyboard" may appear momentarily but is quickly replaced by "AB Shutter 3".  Tap on it and it's paired.  I had it ready to go in just a few seconds.  Using the remote is also simplicity at its best - open the camera app on your smartphone and press the corresponding button (iOS or Android) on the remote to take a picture.  There are no "hidden" settings to find or anything else to do.  Truly, it could not be any easier.  Pressing the "Android" button while paired with an Apple device has no effect.Some other reviewers reported that this remote "lost" its pairing every time it was turned off and back on.  I have purposely tested that because it would be pretty annoying, but I am not able to replicate that problem.It's not documented in the instructions that come with this remote, but if you want to reset the pairing and use the remote with a different smartphone, just turn it on and then press and hold both buttons (iOS + Android) for about 2 seconds.  The LED on the remote will flash rapidly to indicate it is in pairing mode.  If you do this and then wish to go back to using it with the first smartphone, you need to tell that smartphone to "forget" this remote.  Then you can proceed with the normal pairing process.It's pretty easy to open the battery compartment to replace the CR2032 button cell.  Unlike some electronics, there are no screws to remove or twisting motions.  The cover just slides up after a little initial resistance and then lifts off.  Knowing that I tend to fidget with stuff in my pockets and toss my keys onto my desk carelessly, I added a small piece of tape to help keep the battery cover on.  I did not deduct a star for this because it would not be fair to "dock points" for my bad habits - besides, needing to keep "eyeglass" screwdrivers on hand just to replace batteries is a pet peeve of mine.Included in the package is a drawstring pouch and a wrist lanyard.  Additionally, the key-loop on the remote is large enough to accommodate most key rings, so they've really covered all the bases for carrying, using, and transporting this little device.In summary, this is a remarkably simple and easy to use device at a very inexpensive price.  I would not hesitate recommending it to anyone who wants to do any kind of photography with their smartphone.

I had a plastic phone mount that came with my Joby Gorillapod, but my new iPhone 6 Plus doesn't fit, so I needed something different.  When I stumbled upon this metal one, I was very excited to try it out.One of my fears with the plastic mount was that it felt delicate - like it wanted to break at the most inopportune time.  That fear is no more with this beautifully machined aluminum mount.  Sure, it's bigger and heavier than the plastic one (which even folded flat), but this metal one is tough to beat.  In today's world where cheap plastic is abundant, it's nice to see a product with good, solid, quality, metal construction.I also like that rather than having a spring, which can wear out, this mount employs a simple thumb-screw to adjust the size and lock the mount onto the phone.  There's virtually nothing to wear out with this and I have no doubt that it will provide years of reliable service.This "XL" version fits my iPhone 6 Plus with room to spare.  The "jaws" open extra wide to accommodate almost any behemoth phone you might have - up to 3.6 inches.  For smaller phones, like the iPhone 4 or 5, there's a "regular" version..  The rubber pads protect your phone from damage while in this mount (just don't go nuts torquing the thumbscrew too much - it's not necessary for a secure hold).  Best of all, the standard tripod thread means you can put your phone on top of virtually any tripod of your choosing.There is really nothing not to like.  This RetiCAM mount is perfect and I'm thinking about buying another one just to have on hand in case I misplace or lose this one.

These screen protectors may be inexpensive, but they're not cheap!I ordered two of these screen protectors - one for my mom and the other for a friend.  My mom used to have a film screen protector on her iPad but, the iPad case caused it to peel up and it started being a general pain - to the point that she cut it so at least part of the screen was protected, but the nuisance part was gone.Having had good success with real glass screen protectors, I bought this as a replacement for the film and have no regrets.  Mom agrees there is nothing like the look and feel of real, honest-to-goodness glass instead of plastic.  Installation was relatively easy, but you only get one shot to get it right when using glass protectors, so you need to take care and take your time.  Also, from experience, I learned to ditch the instructions that come with the protector and use the "hinge method" to install it.  Search on Google or YouTube for the "hinge method" of installing a glass screen protector.  It's almost fool proof and yields PERFECT results when done carefully.The protector, itself, seems to be of top-shelf quality and is everything you'd want it to be - clear, responsive, etc.  It's hard to go wrong with this.

My wife and I bought this doggie life jacket because we were taking our beloved "Tink" with us on vacation and knew that boats and water would be part of our trip.  Since Tink had never been on a boat or in the water before, we didn't want to take any chances.The life jacket fits quite nicely and the straps offer a wide range of adjustments.  It also features a convenient handle on top if you need to pick up your pooch in a hurry - or pluck her from the water.  As it turned out, Tink was more than happy to stay cuddled between my wife and I on the boat, so she would have been fine without the jacket, but we're still glad we had it just in case things turned out differently.The quality and workmanship seems to be very good and the price here on Amazon just can't be beaten.  Highly recommended.

I like this little drive. Don't let its diminutive size fool you - this thing packs a punch!Right off the bat, we're talking 64GB of flash storage for under $30, so there's a lot to like before you even open the packaging.  But then came a nice surprise - the transfer speed.  The first time I transferred a 20MB file to it, I thought something was wrong because the progress bar popped on the screen for a fraction of a second and then was gone.  I have other flash drives that I used before this one that would take about 30-40 seconds to do the same file copy from the same USB port.  I even went back and tested exactly that with the other drives - this one is pretty quick and leaves my others in the dust.  I guess I had just gotten used to slow speeds.Besides the subjective "feel" of the flash drive, I ran the Black Magic disk speed test (Mac, Mac app store) on it and got results consistent with other reviewers - about 15MB/s write and about 21MB/s read.  I know that's not much compared to some others, and certainly close to nothing compared to USB 3.0, but it's more than quick enough for my needs.I'd feel comfortable recommending this flash drive to anyone who's looking for a "big" flash drive with a small price tag.

I bought an SSD along with this enclosure so that I could upgrade my 2009 MacBook Pro.  It facilitated my using Apple's Migration Assistant to move from the mechanical drive to the SSD.  Transfer speed with FW800 (my '09 MBP does not have USB 3.0 ports) was reasonably fast, considering it's housing a 5400 RPM mechanical drive running at SATA 1 speed.But, along the way, I wanted to boot off the now-external drive in this enclosure using FireWire.  It worked fine - one time.  Now, if this enclosure is connected and I try to boot from it, the activity light blinks a little intermittently, but the drive doesn't spin up and it doesn't show up as a boot device.  Strange that it worked once, but not after that.  I reset the PRAM and such, but the drive still won't spin up to boot if it's connected with FireWire.  If I connect via USB, the drive does spin up and I can boot from it, but USB 2.0 feels like slow death - not the fault of the enclosure, just throwing it out there.  I tried FW by itself as well as with a dedicated power cable (from another drive) plugged into a 2-amp iPad power supply, so it's not a matter of not having enough "juice" to power the drive and enclosure.Oddly enough, if the operating system is up and running and I plug this drive in , it works like a champ - regardless of whether I'm connecting with FireWire or USB (no need for that extra power cable either).  I make my living in I.T. and I've been running on Mac for at least 7 years.  Maybe someday if I have nothing better to do, I'll bring it in to the local Apple store and see if the Genius Bar has ever seen anything like it.Until then, I'll just give this a middle-of-the-road 3-stars.  If I ever find a solution for booting via FireWire with this enclosure, I'll update my review and possibly raise it another star.

I'm liking this bracelet for several reasons:  1) price - I've seen comparable ones for almost 5 times the price of this one. 2) Feels strong and durable; not flimsy at all. 3) virtually care/maintenance-free stainless steel construction.  4) two-tone (brushed/polished) finish.As another reviewer noted, this bracelet is sized for a gorilla - well, at least a larger man.  Fortunately for me, I have big hands and large wrists, so this fits me fine.  I feel like it's just a tiny bit too long - not much, just a hair.  Some quick measurements tell me that removing one link would make it too small for my wrist, so I won't be doing that.  As it is, there's no possibility of it slipping over my hand while it's clasped (without serious damage to the bracelet or - more likely - my hand), so it's fine.  Besides, I see no way to resize it.  Other reviewers say it can be done by a skilled jewler or a clever MacGuyver type, but I don't purport to be either and I won't be pursuing it anyway.The bracelet arrived in a small box.  Inside the box, was a pouch.  Inside the pouch, a plastic bag.  Inside the plastic bag, the bracelet was wrapped in a heavy-duty vinyl material to prevent it from scratching and marring itself during transit.  Of course, all that is inside an Amazon-branded shipping box.  In short, considering that the bracelet is solid stainless steel, the packaging bordered on overkill, but if you're giving it as a gift, it may or may not be "nice enough" depending on your personal taste.As stated earlier, the entire bracelet is constructed of two tone (brushed/matte with highly polished accents) stainless steel.  It is substantial and heavy and feels very well made.  It measures 8.85 (roughly 8 7/8) inches in length when fastened, .5 inches wide, and roughly .19 (3/16) inch high.  My postage scale weighs it at 82.1 grams / 2.9 ounces.  If "understated" and "lightweight" are attributes you seek in a bracelet, this one probably won't excite you.The clasp is a fold-over design and snaps (with an audible click) closed.  It took a little getting used to - had to work on that "manual dexterity" a little bit, but in almost a week of wearing it, there's been no sign or indication whatsoever that the thing wants to come undone by itself or that the bracelet is weak and might fall apart.  Exactly the opposite.  I'll say it again - it feels solid and well-made.I would have no qualms about recommending this bracelet to anyone.

Prior to buying this SSD, I had been mulling over getting one for my early-2009 17" MacBook Pro for more than a year.  High costs and relatively small sizes of SSDs kept me away - until this little terabyte-class gem came along.  My only regret now is that I didn't do it sooner!  Had I known how much the SSD would help, I would have spent the money to do it sooner.As other reviewers said it would, this SSD breathed new life into my aging MBP.  Boot up from the apple logo to a responsive desktop dropped from almost 4 minutes all the way down to 24 seconds!  Actually, a freshly-installed Mavericks (Mac OS X 10.9) booted in just 15 seconds, but that doesn't really count because it had no programs, user data or settings, or anything else installed.In the interest of full disclosure, it wasn't all peaches and sunshine from the start.  I had intended to install Mavericks fresh and clean on this SSD and then use Apple's built-in Migration Assistant to pull in my programs, settings, etc. from the mechanical drive (that is now in a firewire enclosure) as I had done many times with hard drive upgrades in the past.  For whatever reason, this SSD didn't like Migration Assistant.  Sure, it ran and completed, but then booting the computer exceeded 8 full minutes and ran at a snail's pace afterwards.  Clearly something was wrong, but I don't know what it was and I wasn't completely opposed to rebuilding the computer fresh-and-clean all the way.After this less-than-stellar result, for Plan-B, I reformatted the SSD and reinstalled Mavericks and then re-installed all my programs, re-created my preferences settings, and easily copied my home directory from the external drive to this SSD.  Everything installed fresh-and-clean from the ground, up.  The results were nothing short of astounding.  Fully loaded with antivirus and firewall software, full suites of productivity apps, and a few extras, the system boots in less than half a minute.My Windows 7 Bootcamp partition made the trip to the new SSD unscathed thanks to Winclone and now also boots in less than 30 seconds.  I thought about leaving it behind, but while my personal computing is 100% Mac, my professional life is 100% Windows.  Incidentally, Winclone is more than worth its purchase price if you're using Bootcamp on a Mac and want to move your Windows partition to a new drive.The SSD, itself, is tiny at only 7mm thick as compared to the standard 9mm size, but fits comfortably without a spacer in the MacBook Pro thanks to Apple's design.  A 2mm self-adhesive spacer is included for other mounting configurations.The only other thing worth talking about is the limited write-life inherent in ALL SSDs.  There are two types of SSDs - SLD and MLC - and the entire Crucial M500 line uses MLC, which is regarded as the lower-end, slower, consumer-grade type.  This worried me a little, so I did some homework.  This M500 starts with a full terabyte under the hood, but Crucial employs some unique data verification and integrity techniques that cost 40GB right off the top, hence the 960GB label.  Along with wear-leveling and other life-increasing measures, Crucial calculates that one would need to write 40GB to the SSD every day for 5 years to wear it out.  An independent review I read said they went about torture-testing some SSDs of various brands - an M500 included - and concluded that Crucial's estimate is conservatively low - the drive is capable of much more.  As for being slower - it's all relative.  The drives rated throughput far exceed the capabilities of the SATA controller in my early 2009 MacBook Pro.  So, while there are "faster" drives out there, my on-board SATA controller can only do what it can do and I won't benefit from a "faster" drive than this M500.  All these factors eased my fears and I went with it.  Besides, when was the last time I wrote 40GB to any disk any day (except for rare occasions)?In short, it's a great drive at a value-price that I would not hesitate to recommend to anyone.  Sometimes, after spending "big-bucks" ($450 is big-bucks on my budget these days), I'll come down with a case of buyer's remorse.  But not this time!

My wife and I have three printers scattered around the house that all take these ink cartridges.  Somehow, it seems, they always run out of ink at the same time and we just hated spending $40 per printer to replenish the ink.  We spotting this ink here on Amazon and we were a little skeptical - after all, it's well known that you generally get what you pay for - so we "gambled" a few bucks and ordered one set.These cartridges turned out to be a great deal and we just ordered three more sets!Be sure to do yourself a favor by reading and following the included instructions before using these cartridges.  As other reviewers have noted, you'll need to dismiss a message on the printer stating that these are not genuine cartridges and the ink levels are essentially "unknown", but for the price, you can't go wrong with this ink!  Besides, the cartridges are somewhat translucent, so you can open the cover of the printer and see how much ink is in them.Aside from the error message and no electronic indication of ink level, these are great cartridges well-worth the price if you're willing to live with those shortcomings.  They print quite nicely and the colors are rich and vibrant.  I would not hesitate to recommend these cartridges to anyone.

First, read past the poorly translated description that reads as though it went through a word blender.  The highlights are that this tempered glass screen protector is 0.4mm thick, has an oleophobic coating to resist oily fingerprints, is chemically hardened to 8-9H, and is sized for the iPad Mini.  The edges of the protector are chamfered (rounded) to help prevent chipping.This, like any other glass screen protector, is a one-shot deal when it comes to installing it.  You'll want to take your time because once it's on your iPad Mini, you will have spent your one-and-only chance at getting it aligned just right.  Taking it off "may" (read as "will") degrade the adhesive and it won't stick properly, so take your time.Getting a perfect alignment while following the included instructions, I respectfully submit to you, would be virtually impossible.  The instructions show a "free-hand" approach to lining it up and getting it installed, but I don't think anyone is capable of getting it perfect on the first-and-only chance with that approach.  For this reason, I strongly recommend the "hinge method" - Search Google and YouTube for it.  Using the hinge method (and a small suction-cup for a little more control), I achieved a PERFECT installation - at a casual glance, it is very nearly indistinguishable from the iPad Mini screen, itself.  This hinge method works for smaller iPhone screens as well.  Of course, you'll also want to THOROUGHLY clean the iPad Mini screen and make sure it is free of dust and smudges before you stick the protector on it.The screen protector is actually just a tiny little bit smaller than iPad Mini screen.  With a perfect alignment, there is an approximately 1mm margin all the way around the edges of the protector to the edge of the actual screen.  Again, use the hinge method (and a small suction cup, if you have one) to install this protector and take all the time you need to get it lined up perfectly.There is nothing like the look and feel of real glass on your device - just the way it was designed in the first place.  Of course, this protector doesn't do anything to help alleviate glare, so if that's something you want in a screen protector, this one is not for you.

Sometimes, it seems that certain authors try to impress you with complicated vocabulary and "lofty" writing that ought to come with some sort of decoder kit.A.W. Tozer is NOT one of them! There's nothing complicated here and this book is a surprisingly easy read.Tozer's writing is crisp, clean, and directly to the point. He doesn't mince words or pull punches; virtually nothing is left to interpretation - he pretty much spells it out for you in straight-forward English.What impresses me most is that this book was essentially written 50 years ago, but very well could have been written yesterday.  The references to things like "people these days" or "our times" still ring true and are completely accurate today - possibly more so now than when he first penned them.  It is clear that Tozer had a very good understanding of human nature and it's also clear that human nature hasn't changed much over the past 5 decades!  His observations are truly timeless.Easy to read, easy to understand, and profoundly moving.  What more could one want?

Pros: heavy duty protection; very clear; barely noticeable; compatible with iPhone 5S TouchID; does not impair any features/functions at all.Cons: no installation instructions in the package; as with all glass protectors, you only get one shot at installing it correctly - the adhesive is not reuseable (but read on to learn how to get it right the first time).Be warned: this protector does NOT include any application instructions, but here's what to do:Not wanting the crooked installation I had with a previous glass protector, I Googled for advice and found the "hinge" method on YouTube.  Basically, before peeling the backing off the adhesive, get the protector lined up perfectly and put some scotch tape (painter's tape, masking tape, or similar non-marring, non-residue tape) along one edge so that the screen protector now swings like a door on hinges on the phone.  When you're satisfied that the alignment is perfect, "open" the door, clean the phone's screen THOROUGHLY, make sure there is NO dust on the screen, peel the backing off the adhesive, and "close" the door.  Perfect installation that anyone can do.  As mentioned, YouTube has some videos showing this excellent method of installing glass screen protectors.With the protector perfectly aligned, it is barely perceptible.  You might be the only one who realizes that there's a screen protector installed on your phone.  It is very nearly invisible and, as noted earlier, does not impair any features or functions of the phone.  TouchID, proximity sensor, and the front-facing FaceTime camera all work perfectly woth this protector installed.The fit and finish of this particular protector is comparable to the expensive name brands, but is delivered to your door at bargain-basement prices.  In fact, you can buy two of these for the price of one of the least-expensive name-brand.  The quality of this protector is excellent!Once you go with a real glass screen protector, you'll never want to go back to the "traditional" vinyl or plastic ones ever again.  Not even the highest quality film protector has the look or feel of real glass on your phone.All told, I could not be any happier with this purchase and would happily to buy it again.

It's hard to go wrong with an Otterbox Defender.  Especially when a 6-year old may get a hold of your precious new Christmas gift.We got my in-laws iPhone 5C's for Christmas and with a 6-year-old granddaughter a frequent visitor, we thought heavy-duty protection for the devices might be in order.This particular Green/Lime case matched the green iPhone 5c perfectly.  Good aesthetics and superior protection.  What more could one want?

I got this for my wife hoping that she could use her "old" Bose MIE2i (made for iPhone) with her new Windows phone.  Looking up the headphone port specs online, two of the conductors are switched between iPhone and Windows phone.  This should undo that switch, thereby bringing the Bose headset over to Windows phone.At least in theory anyway.  Not so much in actual practice.  Oh, well.  For the price, I'm keeping it just in case a use for it comes up down the road.On to the next...

It used to be that if you had a string of Christmas lights, either they all lit up or none lit.  Then a few gyrations later, there are sets that, at most, every other bulb would go out.  Then we made the move to LED Christmas lights.  Not even half way through the first season, small sections of the string - about 10 bulbs or so - would go out, but the rest of the string was fine.  By the end of the season, all the LED sets had these "burnt-out" sections, some sets had more than one section out.  Second season of LEDs, we bought all new light sets and, within a week of being on the house, those sets have the same "small section" problem.  Needless to say, these LEDs are getting expensive fast and making me wonder if going back to the tried-and-true incandescent lights wouldn't be better.Fortunately, a friend mentioned this little light-fixing gadget to us, but the one he had was only for incandescent lights, not LEDs.  My wife and I searched all the local stores and couldn't find it the LED one, but Amazon came to the rescue.I'm not sure why we kept last year's "bad" LED light sets, but we did and I'm glad we did.  Less than 10 minutes after opening this gizmo, all of last year's "bad" sets are good as new!  The directions for this LED Keeper are easy to follow and the device is simple to use - and a real money-saver.The way it works is you plug the light set into this battery-powered tool and then follow the directions to figure out which bulb (or bulbs) is (are) at fault.  The problem is the cord isn't all that long, so you need an extension to test light sets that are already "in place" on the house.Nonetheless, it's a great tool!  If you use LED Christmas lights, do yourself a favor and pick up one of these.  You'll be glad you did.

I was looking for a tripod mount to use with my phone when I stumbled across this gem.  In a word, "awesome".The "tripod" part has fully-articulated legs.  Each segment is attached with a ball-joint to the next segment, giving the legs quite a lot flexibility.  They can be wrapped around stuff, or just re-shaped to suit the surface on which you place it.At the top of the legs, there's a lockable quick-release mechanism for the "head" to rapidly be detached or re-attached.  This head has a typical tripod screw mount.The bracket that holds the phone has spring-loaded arms that hold the phone securely and can be folded down for easy transport - even on a keyring, if so desired.While the highly-articulated legs are great and give you possibilities limited only by your imagination, possibly the best feature is that the mounting screw is the standard size found on all tripods, meaning that you can take just the phone-holding bracket and attach it to any standard tripod, not just the gorillapod.  The only down-side is that my wife, the shutter-bug, is eying up stealing it to use with her phone so she doesn't have to haul the DSLR around!  (Yes, her phone takes better pictures than our old DSLR - technology these days!)Anyway, for the asking price, you can't go wrong.  This is an A+ "gadget" from start to finish.

As far as I'm concerned, the Otterbox Defender, Griffin Survivor, and Lunatik Taktik are the best, ultra-protective cases on the market.  That being said, I ordered this particular case by accident.  I was looking for a "defender" for my iPhone 5S to replace the somewhat extra-bulky Taktik, got "dizzy" from the multitude of choices, and ultimately ended up buying the wrong case.  This case is as marked - for the iPhone 5, not the 5S with the Touch-ID fingerprint sensor.  It was entirely my own mistake, and online return was quick, easy, and painless.  Way to go, Amazon!I have since discovered the Tech21 Impact cases with D3O material.  Go YouTube some video drop-tests or look up the D3O material demonstrations.  The Tech21 Impact provides very nearly the same level of protection from bumps and drops as the Otterbox, but at a fraction of the size and less cost.  But, there is no integrated screen protector with the Tech21, so if that's important to you, stick with the Otterbox.  On the other hand, there are some really nice screen protectors out there - the oleophobic glass ones are particularly nice and very affordable.

When one reads "for iPhone 5S", one would think that ALL the features of the iPhone 5S would be accessible.  At least that's the way I think.  Anyway, the case that arrived was marked as "iPhone 5" and blocked the touch-ID sensor.  The pictures in the description are also useless - they show an iPhone 4 case and/or a proper 5S case, but the one that case that showed up at my door was for a phone without the flagship feature of the iPhone 5S - the fingerprint sensor.Normally, returns are quick, easy, and painless.  Imagine my surprise when I got a message that said "Special handling is required. Please call customer support."  I did and the Amazon representative was friendly and helpful.  We got my return/refund squared away in a few minutes.  It was far from being an "ordeal", but it was 15 minutes out of my busy day.
My wife needed this to help her plantar fasciitis.  It's comfortable to wear, easy to adjust, feels very well-made and fulfils its role perfectly.  It gives my wife the relief she desperately needed.
Good quality HDMI cables at rock-bottom prices - what's not to like!  These cables work great and I have no complaints.

This charger has so much "juice" that it's almost scary.I've been in the market for an external "battery pack" for those times a wall-charger is impractical or just not possible.  In my search, I found this beast and could not be happier.  It's now possible to recharge my iPad and my iPhone multiple times without needing an AC electrical outlet.  The freedom and possibilities are endless.As some other reviewers point out, yes, this unit does have some design oversights.  The power button is really way too easy to press, or get pressed in your bag, thereby wasting some of its power.  It is a little counter-intuitive to need to turn the unit on to charge it.  And I don't really have a need for a flashlight built into the unit, but I guess it's not so bad to have a backup light-source, just in case.Also, as some other reviewers note, you don't get to use the full "claimed" capacity.  This charger is rated as having 15,000mAh capacity, but you only get roughly 10,000mAh, or so, of use.  The included manual clearly states that about 30% of the stated capacity is lost to the voltage/current conversion and regulation that powers the USB ports.Recharge time from "dead" is definitely steep, but can be mitigated with a more powerful wall-charger.  Unfortunately, it does not come with a wall-charger.  Although you can use any USB port to recharge, if you're thinking about using the USB port on your computer, be prepared to spend a LONG TIME.  Most computer USB ports only supply 500mA, one third the minimum recommended by the manual - so that would take quite some time!  The best bet is probably an "iPad" type charger, if you've got one handy.Nonetheless, even with all these potential short-comings, this is still a stellar product and has a "crazy" amount of power packed into a relatively small package.  I'm only docking one star for all the negatives.Seriously, all the negatives aside, this thing is amazing!  It puts all others to shame and I have no reservation strongly recommending it to anyone.Also, if you're in the market for a VERY powerful wall-charger - which, by the way, will do an excellent job giving this unit a full charge - Anker provides a discount on some of their other products when you buy this one.  I took advantage of the offer and picked up their 36W/7.2A quad-port wall-charger (2 x 2.1A and 2 x 1.5A ports).  Any of the ports on that other "monster" will give this portable charger all the juice it needs for a "speedy" charge (albeit, "speedy" is relative - it's still at least "overnight" or more).The discount offer details are in the product description.

Now, this is a charger!  I got this to replace a lowly 2A (10 watt) 4-port wall charger and, boy, this thing delivers!  It's awesome to be able to charge an iPad, an iPhone, and a few other misc accessories, all at full speed.  It's fast and works great!Because I bought this along with another Anker product (an Astro E5 portable charger), Anker gave a discount on this charger.  It's a sweet deal.Highly recommended.

The perfect "accessory" for RGB LED light strips.  The flat, four-conductor wire is easy to solder directly to the LED strip to go around corners or create unlighted sections in your lighting project."Just what the doctor ordered."

This LED color-changing strip is very bright; it can easily light a whole room, but it is dimmable with the remote control.With some basic soldering skills, cutting the strip (after every third LED) and inserting wires into the strip to allow bends or areas without light is a snap.  I'm lighting some small shelves with 3 LEDs at a time and while prepping and placing the 4-conductor wire extensions is somewhat slow and tedious, soldering them directly to the strip is a breeze.  If you don't feel comfortable soldering directly on the strip, various snap-on connectors and wiring kits are available.The rather minimal instruction sheet that was included leaves something to be desired, but it's not difficult at all to get the hang of setting colors, intensity, and do-it-yourself (DIY) shortcut buttons.Unlike some other reviewers, the unit I received did not have any "mixed up" colors on the remote (i.e. press green, but get red).  Mine worked perfectly right out of the package.I haven't used the adhesive backing on the strip yet, but have a hot-melt glue gun on standby in case the adhesive does not work out, as other reviewers have had mixed results with it.Overall, I'm very pleased with this light strip.  It makes a great, affordable way to get into some LED lighting.

I saw this sort of EL wire at RadioShack, but couldn't bring myself to spend $30+ (wire + battery box) on a "novelty" for which I have no specific purpose.  Buying on Amazon, though, I got more stuff for less than half the RadioShack price.The wire lights up brightly enough for dim/darker environments.  The light is not plainly visible in bright environments and is virtually invisible in sunlight.The wires have "quick" connectors, so it's easy to use one strand or the other or both as you see fit.  If only a single wire is connected, it does light up brighter than having both wires connected.The only down-side is that, as other reviewers noted, the battery pack emits a buzz/hum noise when it is turned on.  It's not very loud, and is easily masked by almost any other ambient sound or conversation.  But, it is noticeable in quieter settings.  If you intend to use it in a quiet environment, it's something to keep in mind.Since this battery box is boosting 3VDC to over 100VAC, so I suspected that you'd be hard-pressed to find one like this that doesn't make some sort of sound in the process.Overall, it's a good value for the money.For the really curious:  Being the techie that I am, I analyzed the hum quickly and found it's composed of several frequencies at around 2kHz, 4kHz, 6kHz, 9kHz, and 13kHz.  The predominant noise, by a wide margin, is the one around 4kHz.  With only a single wire active, the predominant noise is around 6kHz.

This charger feels very well-made and packs a lot more power than any other I have seen.  True to its advertising it is capable of charging two iPads and an iPhone simultaneously.  This is some SERIOUS juice!Although this device is worth 5-stars, I have a couple small nit-picks...The "legend" showing what ports can provide what charging current is on the back of the device.  The front (where the ports are) have descriptive labels ("iPad", "Samsung Tab", etc.).  It would be better if the charge current were printed by the labels instead of the opposite site of the device.The only significant improvement would be to do away with the short AC cord and integrate one of those "flip out" plugs.Nonetheless, this is one awesome charger.  Strongly recommended.

Pros: Real glass!  Feels great, looks fantastic, does not interefere with front camera or proximity sensorCons: you only have one chance to get it rightWhen I purchased my iPhone 5S, I also picked up a Lunatik Taktik Strike case to go with it.  The obvious disadvantage of this case is that it does not have an integrated screen protector.  I put a "film" type protector on, but there's nothing like the touch and feel of real glass.  Just recently, I stumbled upon this Tech Armor Ballistic Glass screen protector and ordered it immediately.When it arrived, I read the instructions and watched the on-line video tutorial.  I strongly recommend you do the same.  Other reviewers noted that the instructions were wrong.  My instructions were correct.  Either way, if you take 5 minutes to watch the video tutorial, you'll see exactly how it is supposed to work.  The video shows two protective layers - one on the top side of the glass, one on the adhesive side.  My unit had only one protective layer - on the adhesive.This protector is awesome!  There is no discernable difference in screen clarity with it on and I see no evidence of it interfering with the front-facing camera.  It feels just like the actual screen, but can easily be replaced if it is ever damaged.  It's the perfect addition to the phone!The real disadvantage - and the only reason I subtracted a star - is that you only get one shot at installing it correctly.  If you've ever applied any screen protector to your iPhone, you know how tricky it can be to get the protector aligned perfectly.  Unlike plastic and vinyl films that can be taken off, reapplied, and otherwise adjusted to perfection, this protector allows only one chance at getting it right.  Once the adhesive side of the glass touches the screen, you're stuck with it for better or for worse.  Removing the protector can be done, but the perfectly transparent adhesive will be damaged in the process.For this reason, I went through several "dry runs" of installing this protector by leaving the protective backing on the adhesive while I went through the motions and practiced handling it with the included suction cup.  Once I was satisfied that I had a decent technique and a reasonable chance of getting it right, I did it for real.My efforts mostly paid off.  It's about 2mm away from perfect, but there's no way to adjust it without damaging the adhesive.  The perfectionist in me will learn to live with it.  The tiny misalignment is enough for my case to squeeze the corners, causing SLIGHT bubbles in the very corners, close to the edge.  There are no bubbles in the viewing area of the screen.The slightly imperfect application is a price I'm willing to pay for the touch and feel of real glass.

Like many others, I was wanting a way to use my iPhone-compatible earbuds with mic that have a 4 position (a.k.a. "TRRS") plug with my computer for Lync calls.  The issue being that the computer has two separate jacks for headphones and mic and can't use the TRRS plug on the earbuds.  For under $8 and free (Prime) shipping, this adapter was worth the gamble.As soon as the package arrived, I eagerly got to testing the adapter with my earbuds and made a Lync test call.  It works perfectly!I probably should have gotten two - one to leave in my office at work and the other to have in my computer bag.  Maybe I'll pick up a second one.Anyway, this adapter works great and lets me do what I was hoping to do.

I bought this to because my wife and I "lost" our original charger and all our batteries were depleted.  I figured it would be hard to go wrong with a charger AND a spare battery at an unbeatable price.The charger works well - recharging the last of the batteries now.  It doesn't feel as sturdy as the original, but with the AC "prongs" built right in, it's much more convenient than having a long cord (like the one on the "factory" charger) to deal with.Like I said, it's hard to beat the price and you get an extra battery, too.  Great deal!

I use this mic with my iPhone primarily for recording and it is surprisingly sensitive.  With the right recording app (the free Tascam PCM Recorder app works well) and the mic gain turned up, it can pick up a whisper so quiet that you couldn't even hear it without this.  It's also capable of recording loud sounds that would be well into the pain/hearing-damage threshold without distortion.Perhaps the best feature is the headphone adapter that's built-in, allowing real-time monitoring of what's being recorded.  Combining this feature with good noise-cancelling headphones allows you to hear ONLY what's being recorded. It's almost like having a recording studio with you.Since you can download a calibration profile specific to the mic's serial number, it's also a great mic for audio analysis and measurements.  It really comes in handy for some of the audio engineering in which I moonlight.

I have a case on my iPhone that causes the headphone jack to be very narrow and very recessed, making it impossible to use most 3rd-party headphones and accessories.  This adapter fixes the problem completely.  It's still a tight fit because of particulars of my case, but this adapter fits and I can use any of the headphones or microphone accessories on the market with my iPhone.

Pros:  Thick and substantial, hard to tell it's even there, great scratch protection, mild impact protection, tear off handles make it easy to apply without fingerprints.Cons:  seems to attract dust and fuzz like a magnet while you're trying to apply itI've used many different screen protectors over the years, but this is the best I've found.  The Wrapsol is thick and substantial but, unlike the Invisible Shield, it doesn't dramatically change the feel of the screen.When you first apply the protector, it will be virtually impossible to remove all of the air bubbles with the squeegy (included in the box).  Don't sweat it and be patient.  All but huge bubbles will work themselves out over a day or two.  I find that they work themselves out a little quicker if you keep the phone in your pants pocket with the protector pushed against your body-heat.  Still, though, it takes time.I'm not sure how I discovered this, but I figured out that if the protector is pretty close to the placement you wanted, but it could be a little more precise, it's possible to apply firm finger-tip pressure onto the surface of the protector and scoot it slightly it into place.  If the placement is off by quite a bit, you'd be better off peeling it back up and re-applying before tearing off the handles.  This sort of fine-tuning is very much like what you would do with a wet-application protector, but without the risks of intentionally spraying water on your device.The biggest drawback is that like most dry-application protectors, this one seems to attract dust, fuzz, hair, etc. like a magnet while you're trying to apply it.  It can be extraordinarily difficult to apply it and not find some dust or something trapped under the protector afterwords.  Depending on the size of the debris, you might just want to live with it.  Eventually, over time, the protector will form-fit itself to whatever is stuck underneath and it will be hardly noticeable.If you find a particularly large piece of debris or fuzz trapped under the protector, you may need to peel it back off.  If you've already removed the handles, scotch tape or similar helps and prevents damage to the protector.  Trying to "pick" the debris off with tweezers or fingernails will be virtually impossible.  At this point, you're best off washing the protector under running water with soap or dishwashing liquid.  Yes, I know, you're thinking that would wash the adhesive off it, but it doesn't - it works.  Just shake it thoroughly to dry.  Don't try to use a cloth or towel or you'll be worse off than you were before.  There will probably be a few tiny water droplets still on the adhesive side when you reapply it to your device, but you should be able to squeegy them out.  When using the squeegy, be sure that you have some sort of protective layer between the squeegy and the screen protector or else the protector can be scratched by the squeegy.Wrapsol proudly proclaims this screen protector to provide some impact protection.  Conceptually, I can understand that, but I wouldn't go tossing your device around willy nilly - even with the protector, the screen is not indestructible.All in all, Wrapsol makes a great product and I would strongly recommend this screen protector for your iPhone.

Pros:  Extreme protection, innovative mute/silence switch mechanism, feels good in the hands, access to all ports and functionsCons:  Adds some bulk, no screen protector, and 6 screws deter quick-and-easy case changes, headphone opening is a bit smallI picked up this case for my new iPhone 5S and it is awesome.  I previously used a Taktik Extreme on my iPhone 4S and although Lunatik is coming out with an Extreme for the 5S, it will cover the TouchID sensor, rendering the sensor useless - a compromise between protection and functionality I'm not willing to make.  This case has no integrated screen protector, so none of the phones's functions are hindered in any way - including the TouchID - but, the screen could be vulnerable to being scratched.  Mitigating this potential risk is the fact that the screen is "recessed" by about 4mm by the bezels.  Nonetheless, I also added a Wrapsol Ultra Xtreme screen protector to the phone.The case has 3 main parts: the front bezel, back bezel, and silicone impact truss.  The phone sits in the impact truss, which is then sandwiched between the bezels, providing impact and drop protection far above and beyond that of most other cases I've found.  The bezels are held together by 6 small hex-head screws.  The case comes with a tool to fasten the screws.  The included tool is adequate, but is pretty small for my large hands.  A precision screw driver set with a larger handle is my preferred tool.  If you lose a screw, the case comes with one spare.  If you need more than one spare, Lunatik may provide replacements.  Otherwise, the information about the screw specifications can be a little hard to come by, so I'll tell you here:  Metric 1.5mm socket head, M2 thread, 8mm length, 0.4mm pitch (black from heat-treating).  A box of 100 screws (plenty to share with friends and family) will cost you about $12 from McMaster-Carr (part # 91290A015) and are indistinguishable from the original screws.Since the case is screwed together, getting the phone in and out of it takes some work - it's not the sort of thing you'll do on a whim.  On the other hand, I don't want to take the phone in and out of the case often, so it's not a problem for me.Unlike the Griffin Survivor, this case slips easily in and out of my pockets without turning the pockets inside out.  Also unlike most other cases, rather than cut-outs for the volume and mute switches, there are form-fitting buttons molded into the impact truss and the mute control slides up or down to actuate the switch.  In the Taktik Extreme for 4S, the mute control "lever" (for lack of better word) was quite a bit longer, making it easy to actuate accidentally while in your pocket.  In this Taktik Strike, the control is *just* long enough to provide its function and accidental movement is virtually eliminated.Many people complain about the narrow headphone and sync/charge port openings, so if you're thinking about this case, be warned that - like all the Lunatik cases - the openings are pretty slim.  It fits the standard Apple headphone and lightning cables, but after-market headphones (and to a lesser extent, lightning cables) are a hit-or-miss proposition.Despite any potential shortcoming of this case, the level of protection is second to none.  If anything, it might be a little overkill, but if you're worried about dropping your phone, this case will let you rest easy.

If you like action and you like comedy, but tend more towards action, then this is the movie for you.  It doesn't take itself too seriously, but it's a lot of fun.It's your typical super-agent genre, featuring highly trained (former) operatives with insane levels of skills and abilities and some humor thrown in for good measure.  This movie is cut from the same cloth as "This Means War", "Mr. & Mrs. Smith" or TV's "Burn Notice" so, if you like those, there's a good chance that you'll like this.

I almost bought just one of these back scratchers but when I saw how inexpensive three were, I couldn't resist. I have one bedside, one in my home office and one at my second office. Boy, do they get right to where I most need to be scratched! Super scratcher!

I'm wearing this now and love the color! I've had a few minor chips that I've touched up but I usually change polish every week and I've pushed this to two weeks. Really like the feel of the liquid sand. I use a top coat even though instructions say not to.As far as removing the polish, that's a job that's easier using a tip by another reviewer. I soak cotton balls in remover, put one on each nail and wrap each in aluminum foil. After about 10 minutes I do a sideways swipe as I remove the cotton ball and remove any remaining polish. Much easier than trying to do each nail separately!

My husband is hard on watches so when his previous watch stopped telling time accurately I wanted to find him a fashionable, reliable, watch that didn't cost a fortune but looks like it might. After looking at numerous watches, I ordered this one and we're very happy with the size, performance, and overall durability!After watching a Youtube video, I was able to remove three links since the watch has a band that should be adequate for any wrist size.
I've been collecting OPI polishes for about 6 months and have 40 different colors. I wanted a silver that was really a SILVER and this is it. It's like painting aluminum foil on your nails.

Occasionally, when I'm meandering around my garden with more than one gardening tool, I will put one down in the grass to use the other one. This super nice leather holster works perfectly to hold my Tabor pruning shears so I don't put them down and forget them in the grass. This is a super sturdy leather with a nice belt clip.

As soon as I took these pruning shears out of the box I knew they'd be a favorite tool. I'm a "hobby gardener" who enjoys collecting tools -- quality tools. Being able to get quality tools at a discount for an honest review is about as good as it gets!These are good looking, hefty and serious cutting shears for routine maintenance throughout my garden. They're not going to take out the thickest branches but I have a hefty Tabor lopper for that.

When I got a chanced to buy these at a discount for an honest review, I jumped at the chance. I have a couple smaller pairs of garden shears but I wanted shears that would cut decent sizes branches on bushes. This lopper does exactly that and feels very sturdy when using it. The blades are sharp and cut cleanly. My search is over.

Bought this for a cruise and kept it folded in my purse the entire trip. When I got home I found it is the perfect gardening hat. Definitely would recommend to anyone needing a nice hat to keep the sun off hair and face.
The only liquid makeup I use. I've tried many over the years but the True Match gets it right and I have no need to keep searching for something better. The price is right, too.

I needed another pair of pruning shears and when I was offered these at a discount for review, I jumped at the chance. The blades are very sharp, the handles easy to grasp, and I really like the locking feature at the bottom since I have other shears that don't close so securely.I also like the 12-month warranty although I doubt I'll have to use it.Nice job, Tabor!
This was larger than expected and looked great hanging in the front yard during November. He was replaced by a large Santa during December.
Love the toothbrush. Need to order more since there was only one in order.

I knew a real Christmas tree wouldn't hold up to the scrutiny of our cat so I looked for something that would work for the holidays. This cardboard tree was perfect! I stuck a Command hook on the wall, made a small hole just under the star and hung it on a living room wall. We put gifts on the floor and hung very small ornaments on the tree and slipped Christmas cards in the slots provided. It's packed away now for next year.
Replacement wallet for my husband after his other Fossil wore out. Very nice!
Because of the pricing on Amazon I was able to buy a very nice gift without going over the maximum allowed for the gift swap. Several of the men vied for this wallet after it was opened. Super nice!
Our rescue cat tosses this around and sometimes will lie on top of it. I refresh the catnip periodically. He likes it so I'm happy.
This is the only hat my husband will wear. When he left his last one in the overhead bin of an airplane I was glad to find Amazon now has them available.
Really cute as a gift for a friend who admits she doesn't like housework. She laughed when she opened the package.

This is my third order of lederTEK solar lights. I have one shorter string of white lights that lights up a corner of my garden year round. For the holidays I bought a short string of Christmas lights for a shrub in the corner of the front yard and liked it so well I bought this longer string for the walkway. They work brilliantly! So well, in fact, that my neighbor is ordering some for next year.
This is one of several cat beds I purchase recently for an adult rescue cat. This is definitely his favorite.
Exceptional value for a very, very pretty case. Tab fits perfectly and no excess bulk or weight.

My hair does not travel well... Regardless of how nice the hotel, after sleeping on regular pillowcases my hair is impossible. So, I now carry this pure silk pillowcase and put it over the hotel's pillowcase. I got the brightest, boldest, colors I could find so that I wouldn't leave it behind when checking out.It works!

I've used other NuVue products so know the quality. As we faced the first frost of this year I needed larger wrap for plants that were now taller and wider. I bought two of these 10x20 pieces, cut them into 10x20's and wrapped them around taller plants. Perfect solution!
Cats make mistakes. It's natural. And this carpet cleaner does the perfect job of cleaning up those mistakes.

Bought these to grow grass for adult rescue cat. Work extremely well. Have them on patio ledge outside kitchen window and bring in one at a time when grass is high enough to "serve." Ordered a second set so there would always be fresh grass.

I cut this into strips to place on kitchen cabinets and other places I don't want my adult rescue cat exploring. If he does decide to jump onto a cabinet or go somewhere he's not allowed, the upward points discourage him. A lot kinder than other methods and he doesn't blame me.

I have a collection of travel pillows, some very expensive. None have provided the comfort I've been looking for when flying so I've kept looking. Frankly, I thought the reviews for the J-Pillow were exaggerating the comfort but with a five hour round trip coming up I decided to give one a try.What a surprise! I actually fell into a deep sleep during both flights! That's not something I've been able to do, especially on a fully packed plane. I slept through the beverage service and wasn't awake for the pretzels.Yes, the J-Pillow is a little bulky but I carry my "comfort" items in a Blue Q Cargo Tote ( http://www.amazon.com/Blue-Q-Cargo-Shoulder-Tote/dp/B0049U476K/ ) so, along with headphones, iPad, tablet, snacks, and travel blanket, there's room for the J-Pillow.Finally! I've found the perfect travel pillow.

I have a small Arizona Spruce to the side of my front door that I want to use as an outdoor Christmas tree. Not wanting to wait until the last minute, I searched for solar fairy lights to put on the tree. The various reviews of this particular string of lights caused me to order them and I'm very happy I did.Even though the solar panel isn't in full daylight all day, these little lights are super bright every night. I won't hesitate to buy more if I can figure out where to use them.

Beautifully made! I have just assembled it for an adult rescue cat who is very leery of anything new. I'm sure a bit of catnip will get him into exploration mode.Tips for assembly... all learned by experience...The bottom is 26x24. Make sure that you have the 26" as the width (facing front).The three longer posts go 2 on the left and 1 at the back right. The 1 at the back right will be offset from the back.Use the correct bolts. There are 2 shorter bolts that are used to attach the smaller/lowest house to the platform.The platform is attached to the 3 taller posts; make sure all 3 bolts are attached as one goes under the smaller house.All the holes are drilled in the right place. If you don't have a hole and bolt matching up, check your assembly starting at the bottom.

I wanted just one of these to store cat litter but doing the math, it was much more cost effective to get 6 rather than pay the price for one. These are excellent! And, along with cat litter, I am using the other 5... 1 for potting soil, 1 for plant foods, 1 for fertilizers, 1 for cat toys, and 1 for cat food.Super, super, super!

I wanted to hang beaded curtains in corner windows in a bathroom. There is no outside visibility from the windows so coverage isn't important. These string tassel panels are more substantial than strings with a few beads, are reasonably priced, and work very well. Once they were hanging I easily cut them to the length I needed. One window is larger than the other so I have ordered a third panel which I will divide between the two windows.There was one string that was unraveling on one panel but a few snips with scissors eliminated the problem.They'd also look nice in front of a window with curtains to the side or in a doorway.

My husband and I do not check bags after a couple "lost bag" episodes. And with some airlines being so critical about the size of carry-on bags, we have a choice of sizes for travel depending upon the airline.These Blue Q Cargo Totes are fantastic for a weekend's worth of clothing and toiletries -- one for him and one for me. And they're smaller than the size requirement from all airlines we travel on.The square design means easy packing and the bag's lightweight construction doesn't add unnecessary weight. They also fit easily under the seat in front. The last time we used them I overhead a pilot telling another pilot that his wife had "one of those bags."
