I have an Omron cuff blood pressure monitor but wanted something smaller for travel. The reviews were good on this unit which is why I bought it plus the Omron brand.In checking the accuracy against my cuff monitor I've found the readings to be within 5 points which I think is reasonable.I wanted to see how it compared with readings taken at my doctor's office. After the nurse took my blood pressure I pulled out this wrist monitor and strapped it on. It took longer than usual to produce a reading which was ridiculously high: 189/186! I tried again and got a reading within a few points of the nurse's result.I think this monitor is good enough for what I need. If I ever needed absolute accuracy I'd pay the big money for a cuff monitor found in doctors' offices.
I don't know that this will save my life although carrying it in my purse does make me feel a bit safer. Will know in a couple weeks if it makes it through airport security.

When I couldn't find a spare micro USB cord in my office I checked to see what was available on Amazon. I only needed one cord but couldn't resist this colorful collection. Very nice!Because they're flat, I can use a marking pen to write which electronics a cord will work with which is extremely handy when traveling with chargers.

This is bigger than I thought but that's not a bad thing. It was delivered flat with a rolled plastic strip... and instructions for set-up in three different languages -- none that I understand. It was easy enough to figure out that the two slits along the top of the bag were for insertion of the plastic strip. Once it was threaded from one opening through to the other opening, the bag stood upright.It's the perfect yard waste bag for my patio. Definitely would buy again!
Heavy duty, easy to position, and holds a 75' hose with room to spare. Will buy another one for other side of house.
I bought two of these to put at appropriate corners of my flower bed to prevent the hose from dragging over the plants. They work perfectly. I will order more for other beds as I need them.

Sandy's poetry is always fun to read... and then re-read. "Quirky" is a good description for much of her poetry. "Thought-provoking" is also appropriate. This is is her second book of poetry; hopefully the third won't take as long to be published!

My regular doorbell, tied into an intercom system, hasn't worked in years. It's repaired, works a couple days, then stops. I finally gave up and up a "please knock" sign over the buzzer.When a neighbor mentioned her wireless doorbell I immediately looked for one on Amazon. This one had good ratings and a good price so I ordered it. I used the tape provided to put it on top of the existing doorbell/intercom, tested it, and was very happy with the results. There are a lot of nice songs to choose from, also.During a particularly nasty thunderstorm I looked outside and saw the buzzer lying in pieces near the front door. Once I retrieved them and dried them off, I re-assembled the buzzer. It still worked. I re-attached it with heavy duty outdoor tape this time.I'd absolutely recommend this wireless doorbell to anyone looking for a reasonably priced alternative to a non-working wired doorbell.

I love the slow close lid and lift of hinges, love how solid it is, but it STAINS like crazy. Right now I'm trying to scrub off a bunch of blue marks from a crayola bath colors, the seat is the only thing that has stained in the whole bathroom (and everything has been thoroughly stain tested by the kids). I clean the bathroom frequently but since most of the seat is no longer white it looks like a scary gas station toilet. If I can figure it out I'll sand it and paint it but it's less than a year old and shouldn't have this problem.

Although it was barely used one of the handles snapped. I did actually buy a "potty hook" (potty training temporary insanity) and this didn't fit on it. It was easy to clean except on the handles there are stickers that can't get wet without wrinkling up. Because the only place to keep it was on the floor between the toilet and cabinet the stickers did end up getting wet. Yeah.It also wiggled and slid around on the seat, not very "secure" for a kid who is already nervous about sitting up on the big toilet. My son used it once or twice and decided it was too much of a hassle to keep using it.Not a great buy, I don't think it helped very much.
This isn't my favorite Shel Silverstein book and as far as my kids finding it delightful they seem to feel the same way I do about it. We read it once and they haven't asked for it again.
I have read this book before, by another name. This is a good version for my own kids, although I did have to look up the pronunciation of some of the character names because I wasn't sure.
Our other case is hard plastic, this is a pretty cushy little ride.

My dog walks well on her leash 99% of the time (loose leash, right beside me)... the other 1% she totally flips out. This of course seems to happen when I'm walking her and pushing a stroller and we're crossing a busy intersection. I have almost lost her and she has knocked me down a few times. With the head collar on I can shorten her leash and when the going gets "ruff" she is forced to walk right by me looking almost straight ahead. We can walk past herds of corgis, dozens of squirrels, gigantic dogs that could leap their fence if they really wanted, etc.The best things:She will suddenly back up to get out of normal collars and harnesses, the buckle on this collar means if she does get it off (she did the first time we tried it out) she is still stuck with me on the end of a leash.She's learning she doesn't get to host a super awesome surprise party every time she sees another dog. Instead all she gets to do is huff a little while looking at them through the corner of her eye. This is awesome for me. At first she would try as hard as she could to get out of the head collar so she could really start up the act but now it's not such a big deal because there is no exciting reward for acting like an idiot.People mistake her head collar for a muzzle. A lot of people don't like that but I consider it a bonus.
This shoe did not fit at all - too small and too narrow. It seemed two sizes too small. Otherwise it was a good shoe.

Vacuums are very loud and annoying and I didn't know these things existed, so in that way this is very awesome and I love it. It gets dog hair off the floor - not all of it but neither does the vacuum. The only problems are I'm afraid the kids are going to bend the thin, hollow tube that makes up the handle and the rubber (gaskets? things?) on the back keeps popping off and it's hard to put back on.

OH MY GOSH this one does NOT LEAK. We have quite a collection of water bottles that all leak. Some a little some will soak everything in his backpack. We have regular old water bottles, pogo, first years "spill proof", the metal thermos ones they sell by the lunchboxes at target and they all leak this one doesn't. I pack ice water every day in my son's lunchbox and every other water bottle leaked right away or began to leak after a couple months. It also doesn't have any straws to clean out or to lose entirely! We haven't had any problems opening it or getting it snapped shut again.

I use this with my Nexus 7 and it is a big improvement from our previous charger which required taping in. This charges it a lot faster, too. I didn't want to have to buy a (third!) charger but I didn't like having to tape the other cord on and wait three days.

These are cute - except for the shiny metal name plate on the side, and they are comfortable - except they gave me blisters on TOP of my feet. I usually put in cushions on the back of every dress shoe because the back of my foot is narrower and the shoe will rub against the back of my foot. But I have never had a shoe that rubs the top of my foot raw and I can't say I'm a fan. I would not wear them if I knew I'd be walking around more than half an hour, ouch. I do like the height and they were the right price.

It's made of a rubbery kind of plastic that I'm not sure will hold up but so far it has been fine. Small children have fought over it and it hasn't broken or come close. The chomping action is fun. It looks nice and scary, although it isn't easy to set on a shelf or on a table in a scene - this t-rex is a little tipsy. We have some other dinosoars (cheap dollar store ones, schelich (?), and 90s dinosaurs) and it is one of the nicer ones as well as the largest.

I'm glad I bought these. I'll give them to someone else when my kid outgrows them, too. I had been buying disposable ones and 1) they cost more and 2) when you run out you have to get more. We haven't had any "incidents" in these but I think they would keep anything solid just as well as a disposable swim diaper.

It wouldn't be SO bad but it has bright white edges that you can seen across the room. Where is this supposed to go? Only on the underside where no one can see it? Why not just use duck tape? I could try to color it in with a permanent marker but it doesn't stick particularly well anyway. I ended up taking it off after a couple weeks, and by then it was peeling up with lint and cat hair stuck to it. A dumb purchase on my part.

The stickers I got are all the same as the product image, except no mickey mouse or raccoon. There are some not in that picture of course. Anime, video games, quite a few halloween stickers that were OK. There were some stickers that weren't duplicates but they were of the same thing. Like two different stickers of the superhero guy or two pictures of different lips. Some seemed like they were designed for a discount child's product or show that fell through. About 15 of them were just painfully dull, like a red t-shirt or a stock photo of a film reel - three different line drawings on a beige background. Like, why even make this into a sticker?I cherry picked some stickers to go on top at eye level and there were maybe 10 stickers that I would buy, maybe 30 that weren't so bad, and the rest I didn't care for. I don't know why there were any bad stickers, like someone just accidentally printed off 2,000 "peeling sticker effect" pumpkins or 700 sitting cows and needed some way to get rid of them.

The nexus doesn't really fit in it very well - it is really crammed in there. The corners have velcro on the back so they are adjustable and they are all slightly outside the "frame" of fabric. The nexus is a little too wide and is bending them out, too. It also isn't easy to zip up, one of our kids broke off one of the gigantic zipper pulls already - less than a week after we got it. It would be a better fitting case for anything smaller than the Nexus 7, I have no idea why they are selling it that way. It does seem like it would protect the tablet if it was zipped up and so far it hasn't popped a corner so I don't "hate" it, it just isn't something I would recommend or buy again.

We have one of those super cheap cushioned character potty seats with handles on the side. I can get the seat to hang on the hook but it takes some maneuvering and my toddler has a hard time getting the seat off the hook by himself.He does really try to get the seat off and the hook.The hook makes a great lever.Fortunately we didn't lose a toilet lid but it was time for the hook to go.Since it is made to hang off a toilet it is too narrow for a door! And it says potty hook on it so that would be a little weird.

9:30 am I put a black line of this eyeliner on my top lid, by lunch I had a blobby gray mess along on my top and bottom lashes. Cool day, no eye rubbing or watering just straight up failure to sit there on my eyelid which is the only thing it needs to do. Easily the shortest lifespan of any eyeliner I have ever used and I don't typically spend this much on eyeliner. "16 hours" "infallible" "never fail" and there I was, emo mom. Boo.

I have had this for over a year. It used to always smell a little like sauce from cooking but since I started using a dishwasher it has smelled soapy, even after a good rinse in hot water. Some meals have been "weird tasting" and it was this spatula making the food taste a little like dishwasher soap.Not everyone could taste anything funny. If you don't have very sensitive taste buds be careful when using silicone utensils when cooking for others, they might think you're a bad cook due to the extra flavors. Or just hand wash, I use wood and have to hand wash those anyway.

I have this at the top of the stairs with a banister on the right and a wall on the left.  I had a pressure gate (with caps screwed into the walls) at our old house but didn't want to use it at the new house.Our banister is slightly wobbly and sits ever so slightly back from the top step, so we couldn't put pressure on the banister and we couldn't use a gate that had to go straight from the banister to the wall because there would be a gap between the step and gate. I also did not want a gate with a bar across the bottom because I don't want a tripling hazard at the top of the stairs.This gate doesn't have the bar on the bottom, it can be installed at an angle, and it doesn't use pressure to stay put. I also did not have to drill into the wood post. It is also taller than our old pressure gate and does not provide any footholds for climbing.It was a little tricky to install (the pictures were not helpful at all because the grays blended together) and I could not get the bubbles level without putting the gate at a bizarre tilt (could be my house). The plastic pins probably won't last forever and the handle you squeeze to release the main pin is probably going to be the first thing to break. The banister padding is held on with cheap velcro and these thin clips that keep coming unclipped (and the kids love trying to undo the clips and velcro which does not help). It is also quite an eyesore with the velcro sticking off the chunks of padding, the hunks of plastic screwed into the wall, and the skinny wobbly looking white bars. But it keeps my kids upstairs where most other gates would fail so I would buy the same gate again if I needed to replace it.
My iron does not fit. Since my iron is not an unusual size I expect the typical iron holder to hold it. Otherwise it is alright and looks nice installed on my wall.

I thought this would mean I wouldn't have to lug my vacuum up and down my carpeted stairs. I need 17 feet of hose from the back of the vacuum to the bottom step but this hose is not long enough to reach the last two steps. It gets difficult (having to keep the hose stretched and not twisted up) about halfway down and I am completely stopped at around 15 feet.It is a big improvement to the original hose but it is not 20' or "close enough". I don't really need the additional length for anything else and my vacuum is now more cumbersome and more prone to tipping over.Three stars because I can vacuum spiders off a high ceiling.

Last year I brought it to a family gathering for Easter and the kids had a blast until the dye ran out.We couldn't find anything that worked as well as the packets that came with the kit. We tried using dye tablets from another egg kit and straight food coloring and the toy went from being awesome to being a disappointment.This year I was hoping to find refills for sale but they still don't have them. I tried looking online for suggestions or refills and it seems the company is very aware of the refill issue and has no intention of selling dye packets. I wasn't able to find anyone who came up with a replacement - you just have to use regular food coloring which doesn't produce the same results.It was easy for the older kids (5 and up) to use but a little too difficult for a three year old - the first push is the hardest and it works best if you are able to get a little momentum going.

I like the box a lot - it's kind of a thin brown cardboard. I wouldn't mind if more decks were in boxes like this, especially if it's a little more environmentally friendly.I like the green cards - however dark green may not be the best color to use in place of red. Like it's been mentioned  in other reviews - it's not as easy to tell the suits apart. More nice looking than practical. However I don't mind using them for solitaire games and it's not impossible to play regular games - and it could add interest to games like Speed.Cards have an army green rider back, the other colors used are a lighter (olive?) green, black, and gold. Not sure why they didn't use gold in place of red.

Standard deck with dark blue rider back - a little darker than the blue in the 125th ann. cards also made by Bicycle.Ace of spades shows the WWP logo. Nice deck to make a donation and spread the word about the Wounded Warrior Project - I had never heard of it before.

Cards are good quality, artwork is charming and thoughtfully executed. Kind of whimsical. Every card has a TIDY hand-drawn look to it and the face cards all have wild animals on them (each suit is a different area: jungle, arctic, grasslands, swamp).The box is pretty fancy, too. Soft matte paper, embossed. Like a nice wedding invitation.I casually collect cards (over 40 decks) and this is my favorite deck overall. I like the look, love the fact that the face AND number cards are "special" without adding distractions.An explanation: Some decks only change the backs and jokers, some change the face cards but don't try anything with the rest of them. After that it seems like too many decks will add pictures or busy looking effects. The Animal Kingdom cards managed to find a balance between too much and not enough. It's nice.

I was thrilled when I found out these cards existed. My preschool son likes lumberjacks (he has a plaid shirt and a toy chainsaw and pretends to chop down trees in our yard) and I collect cards! I wasn't thrilled when I zoomed in on the product picture and noticed the text on the axe handles. After I ordered them.Even if I wanted rude cards (I generally don't mind crass humor, I like Cards Against Humanity!) I don't think "SAVE A TREE. EAT A BEAVER." is so funny or clever that it needs to be printed twice on the back of every card.I'm glad I saw it in time to cancel my order since these aren't refundable.Maybe the description should add a disclaimer since the innuendo changes the tone of the cards quite a bit. Like, maybe these wouldn't make a cute gift for your kid or little sister.

When I took it off of the box I have to say I was surprised! I am aware of how much I paid for this hat and was still surprised. Maybe you've bought a hat from a dollar store and you think you're prepared for this hat. No.If one person were responsible for assembling and shipping this hat I would have to assume that person doesn't like hats or children and seriously did not care about what happened after the hat went in the box. (Note: I do feel sorry for whoever made this hat and I'm sure they aren't child-haters.)The hat arrived in a perfect looking box, so this isn't about shipping. Some of the straw was damaged (wrinkled looking and flaking) but I was expecting a little of that.So, here's my beef with the hat:The star on the front was glued on crooked and off-center by about an inch. The strings were put in crooked. The narrow strip of "fabric" around the inside of the is hat is wrinkled and crushed - and I'm not even sure why it's there. It's paper thin and doesn't appear absorbent. (I took pictures of this since it's difficult to describe.) Since that band inside the hat is crushed it makes the hat more uncomfortable than it would be without it, so it isn't there to protect the head from the hat. It doesn't appear to be adding any stability to the hat.The brim is curved all the way around instead of dipping in the front so it looks goofy on anyone wearing it (even babies!), it's also crooked and I can't fix it.

I have not officially used these yet, but decided to do a review to share additional information about the product.Color: I'm getting them for a children's birthday party and I was hoping they would be the color shown in the picture (bright blue and yellow). Not a big deal, just would have been better colors. The picture on the box was of red and blue horse shoes, inside the box were red and black horseshoes (two red, two black). Twist ties were difficult to undo - have wire cutters ready if you don't like dealing with difficult ties.Material: hard glossy plastic, I assumed they would be thinner and more flexible but they probably work better this way.Injury potential: I wouldn't want to get nailed in the face with one but I think kids could throw them at each other (we all have the uncle who starts it) and not do any serious damage. Like frizbees.Stakes - Two pieces that connect together: red stake and white pole. Hollow plastic. Stake end is cut at an angle to create a tapered point. The tip of the point has been cut off so they aren't sharp. Might want to use something else if you have hard dirt, I may as well try putting them through concrete.I wasn't sure what I was going to get, but after examining them I think they're going to be pretty fun. We like horse shoesand I think they're a fun twist on horseshoes for regular players as well as small children.

My 4yo likes brown mice, he even thought this mouse "looked bad".What I was hoping to get based on the picture: A perky little brown mouse with pink ears and tail and stiff little whiskers. Inquisitive looking little fellow.What I got: A yellow-and-black mouse with squishy cream ears and a fuzzy yellow braided tail with a poof of loose threads on the end. Thick string whiskers.Eh.

Bought this a couple years ago for a hallway. It has to be adjusted "just so" in order to remain both upright and operable. I was readjusting it every few days to keep it in that range. Too tight and the door wouldn't open, too loose and it would get knocked out of place or just completely fall over with a little pressure. I had a bench against it for awhile so it wouldn't fall over if it was leaned on by my toddler. After a few months I decided to just keep it adjusted too tight and stepped over it instead of bothering with the door.Generally rattly, wobbly, unstable. Definitely more of a deterrent than anything else (can't trust the thing, definitely wouldn't use it above stairs).Guests had no problem with our other gates but this one was confusing people and getting knocked out of place. I took it down when my in-laws were over and never put it back up.We have two other gates (plastic supergate, wood pressure mount gate) and we've been using them for over four years with only a few (very minor) complaints.Looking back, this regalo gate was a mistake. Wouldn't take a free one.

My parents bought this brand for our cats growing up because one had urinary problems as a kitten. All three cats were overweight and two of them developed feline diabetes. I researched feline diabetes and found out this kind of food (mostly corn and corn by product) is really terrible for cats. As an adult I feed my own two cats better food (high protein, no corn, fist five ingredients are meat) and they are sleek, slim, active, healthy cats. They are free-fed indoor cats and almost six years old. They don't eat as much so we don't need to buy as many bags. The extra vet trips and supplies for a diabetic cat (test strips, insulin, needles) are also pretty expensive.Your cat might like to eat this food but it's not a good diet for them. Any food with corn as the first two ingredients is a poor choice.

I have a Graco Snugride 35 from 2012 and it doesn't work with the carseat design. The carseat's handle is curved, so the toy is either above his head (unreachable) or the tiger's eyes are about 2" away from the baby's. Not a bad toy (I even like the music), we just can't use it the way it's supposed to be used. I tried to put it on a baby: carseat, stroller, swing, bouncer, and jumper (all popular brands) and the toy bar doesn't work with any of them.

Anything better would be bigger and probably more expensive. If you have similar toys you know what to expect - pretty sturdy, accessories and hair/clothes tough and flexible, difficult but not impossible to get him to stand on his own. I don't like it when the toy's face looks totally wrong and this Legolas looks pretty close to the movie one, especially considering the size.

I wanted a cz ring after my real one was damaged. The center stone looks alright in the picture but it is comically huge in person. I wore it out to see if anyone I knew would notice my new ring and more than one person noticed it was fake. You know it's bad when someone is bold enough to ask! It's just too big and too silvery looking. Later on the stone fell out.I posted photos and they are unfortunately not visible on the product page for some reason. You can see them if you look at the photos in my account though. You can also see how huge the stone is and how poorly it's set (look at the prongs). If I had noticed that before the stone was lost I may have tried to return it.The description says it's 1.5 carats but I've found it being sold elsewhere as 2. Wouldn't recommend it as an engagement ring but it could be a ring to wear for fun.

If you've recently found yourself living with Tarzan or King Kong, this is the toy that will push him over the edge and send him into a disoriented rage.If you have a baby/toddler it will probably amuse them. The songs will get stuck in your head but so long as you weren't raised by gorillas you should be OK.

2nd case I've had, the first one worked pretty well but I couldn't find the same one. The top shell on this one pops off when I slide the phone open. Most of the time it falls onto the floor. So I have to pick up a piece of my phone whenever I try to send a text message. It does stay on otherwise.

My husband's favorite character is dry bones, but until recently there hasn't been any toy versions of the guy. We have angry birds, yoshis, some Disney characters for the kids.Comparing it to other toys - the fabric is really cheap and thin. This is not a very "plush" toy. Kind of like a cheap toy you might get at a carnival or arcade. But unless you want to pay a professional to make one (an expensive prospect) this is as good as it gets. Glad I found it, glad I didn't pay more for it.
The sticker was easy to put on and a few weeks later still looks good. It's not too small, not too big. I have a dark car so the black sticker is pretty subtle. Happy I bought it.

I don't think the reflection is all that distorted - it's good enough to use to apply eyeliner (if you're planning on doing that with it...). Since it's a "soft" mirror I could see where some would be worse than others though, and if it's squished a little it's going to get distorted.It is easily scratched - when I tried to wipe it with a piece of soft flannel it covered the mirror in scratches. Akin to dragging scrunched up aluminum foil across a CD. That happened maybe three hours after we got it so that was pretty disappointing. The scratches aren't very deep but the mirror obviously isn't going to take a lot of abuse, I don't see it faring very well against a baby old enough to grab it or bang toys on it.Otherwise, it's cute enough and babies do like mirrors. I don't have a problem with it falling over on the floor because the velcro sticks to the carpet we have. Cheaper than other mirrors, safer than a glass one. My almost-3mo is really trying to get his arm up to hit the ladybug (spinning ball).

It isn't winter yet here, but I wanted to give a pre-winter review for those still looking.It's inexpensive, and probably not suited for severe cold (below zero, freezing winds) but it will do for playing in the snow for an hour on mild winter days. It could be layered with a fleece sweater.The outer layer feels like a thin nylon jacket, the inside like inexpensive fleece. I think it is typical quality for a toddler coat from a big box store.

I'm kind of rough on things (and I have kids who are less careful than I am) and so I was looking for a pretty sturdy case for my Nexus. This was the right one! It's rather thick, and seems like it will stand up to a lot of abuse in and outside of my bag. With the hand strap and sleep/wake function it's an improvement to using the tablet alone.The case doesn't prohibit use of any of the buttons or plug-ins.I think they went a little overboard with the card holders.The leathery case is pleasant to hold and looks sharp.

I like to use screen protectors, this is the fifth or sixth one I've used. I am not happy with it.For some reason this particular one seems to hold more oil than any of the others.  I have pretty clean, dry hands and I don't eat while I'm using my Nexus. It still quickly became a situation where I was pushing grease around on the screen. I even double checked the screen protector on my phone to make sure I wasn't imagining things. The one of my phone feels more slick and snappy while this one is a little more "gummy" or rubbery. Less like glass, more like a glossy photograph.It isn't the exact right size for the screen. I know they aren't going to fit perfectly but this one is too far off for how much it cost combined with the fact that it claims to be specifically for the 7" Nexus Tablet.I did have to use the second screen protector because I (like other reviewers) picked at the corners trying to peel off the third layer. The film seems thick enough to have another layer involved.I'll give it two stars because it's not bad enough to give up and throw it away. It will do what it's supposed to do and protect the screen. Wouldn't buy it again though.

I previously owned a baby gym with a single bar that was attached to the mat with velcro. The bar and mat were pretty floppy (and cheaply padded) and my baby was able to take the bar down with a firm grab/kick. When I washed it, it got lumpy and curled up along the edges. Awful thing.This one, however, is very sturdy. The bars aren't going to fall over or collapse, they are able to hold up quite a few toys and get jostled around. It's regularly abused by an older child (over 40lbs) and bounces right back. I've already washed it (the mat, not the bars) once and it still looks like new. The toys are all cute and provide a wide variety of play methods. My son (that it's meant for) is only a month old and likes to lay on the mat and look around. I'm confident he'll like it even more as he learns new skills.Also, I bought this back in February on sale and didn't open it until July. The tiger light didn't work but I was able to quickly get a replacement tiger after filling out a form on the company's website.

The animals are really adorable, it's sweet and simple. I like the music - I didn't think it was creepy at all. I have a significantly more expensive mobile that projects pictures on the ceiling (or on a spinning canopy with little toy animals) and this one is just as entertaining at a fraction of the price (and no batteries!).

It is really hard to get the shapes back out. Another reviewer said the string holding theirs together broke, making it easy... I've tried breaking the string in the one I have (no luck). I usually hide it from my son, I'm just going to get rid of it.My son likes it, and actually uses it (unlike the ones that just have a shape sorting lid sitting on top of a box... just can't win with these things).Update: The string (or rather, the plastic it was attached to) broke! Now with a little tug the two halves of the ball come completely apart. Five stars for the (actually useable) broken version, two stars for the toy as it's made.

I had a small rectangular step stool, but it was a little too short and didn't offer a lot of maneuvering room for a toddler trying to climb onto the potty. This is a big improvement. It makes it easy for my 3yr old to get to the seat, gives him a "floor" once he's up there, and it doesn't need to be moved out of the way when he isn't using it.It doesn't slide around and it's pretty sturdy (not sturdy enough to be used as a general step stool but fine for in front of the toilet).

I had purchased one of those cushioned removable potty-training seats but it meant for a round seat and would shift back and forth when my son sat on it, resulting in his refusal to use it. Not good. I have a built-in seat on the basement toilet (spent less than ten bucks for it at a hardware store, on sale) and I thought it was great, but I couldn't find anything similar for the elongated toilet.This one cost a lot more than the other, and it is better in some ways and worse in some ways.PROS:- The cheaper seat is thin plastic, this one is more solid and doesn't seem like it will bend or crack if it's ever put to the test.- The potty seat on the cheap seat is held onto the lid with clips, so it's a little harder to put the seat down or clip it back on. This one is held to the lid with a magnet - it stays up when you want it to, and it is really easy for a little kid to put it down.CONS:- At least on our toilet, if you have the lid and the seats up, the adult seat will suddenly fall down with a BANG. I don't mind the seat being down, but I'm sure it wouldn't be a pleasant surprise for it to fall down while someone was using it.- The adult seat isn't plastic. It's a nice, solid seat - but the "high gloss finish" is cracking/wrinkling up (so far it is just underneath the seat). It isn't enough to see any wood, but it isn't pleasant and I am looking forward to replacing the seat when we no longer need it for potty training. I've had it about six months.- The "easy clean and change" hinges... WHY?!? In order to lift up the child seat I have to put the lid down, let the magnets connect, and then lift the lid up again. If I try to put the child seat up by lifting it up the way you would normally lift a toilet seat, it pops right off (it's easy for kids to pop off, too). I don't see how removing the seat makes it easier to clean, I don't normally take off adult-sized seats to clean them. Am I supposed to be putting the child seat in the dishwasher or something?Overall: Three stars. It has some things about it I don't like but it is functional.Almost a year later: My son spilled punch on the seat and it stained a ring around one side of the adult seat. I have tried a few things and it's here to stay. If I scrubbed it with anything abrasive it would damage the paint (paint on the bottom of the seat is a testament to this). The magnet in the child seat fell off, never to be seen again. Screws on the right side fell out leaving behind stripped holes. Seat has become an unsanitary eyesore and I am on here looking for a different one.

My son had thwarted every other "child safety lock" I tried. He either figures it out or destroys it with his Hulk strength. Even the pricey magnetic ones that are a pain to install. So the only place I can store things in his room is in his closet, which has sliding doors.I know some children have broken this lock, but it's been up for a few months and I think he's given up on it (he did break the actual door by laying on the floor and kicking it in, I fixed/reinforced the door and he *still* has not gotten past the kidco lock).Some tips:- He can tear off anything mounted on foam tape in a matter of seconds, and if I screwed it down he would figure out how to push down the tabs (or he'd just break them off). So I put it well out of his reach. That's kind of a given.- The other thing I did was to take the knobs off and make sure the closet door was flush against the door frame when locked. If he was able to pull a handle or wedge his fingers between the frame and the door he'd just pull with all of his weight and break the lock off that way. With it flush against the wall he doesn't have any leverage.- I don't open the closet door with him watching. I don't know if he's really ever noticed the lock, but he hasn't tried pushing a chair/stool over to the door to reach it so I'm not going to point it out. If we're both in his room and he wants something out of there I just tell him "it's locked" and I open it when he isn't paying attention. If your child is really insistent on getting into the closet, pretend your child is a detective and the closet is full of evidence that will put you away for a long time. "It's locked, maybe if you turn around for a second or leave the room it will mysteriously open."

I am not careful with my phone (keep it loose in my purse with keys and things, throw it on the counter, drop it on the floor, I have a toddler who runs off with it sometimes, etc.) and the cover still looks about the same as it did when I got it. Stands up well to abuse. The quality of the illustration is nice - it's sharp looking.I'm not crazy about the overall quality of the cover in other ways... the bare gray plastic edges are pretty noticeable up close. Not so cool. It is also bulky, and part of it will occasionally pop off - although not very often. If you made a habit of taking the cover off/catching the edges of the cover on things you would surely break the delicate tabs.UPDATE: I tried to throw onto a counter from a hospital bed and managed to hit the counter and then the tile floor with the phone. It put a 1/2" crack in the corner of the back cover and the front cover popped off, but I clipped the front cover back on and didn't notice the damage to the back cover until the other day. I might end up supergluing it so the crack doesn't grow any larger. Phone is fine!Add. UPDATE: Broke after dropping it again. Case pictured is different than the one I bought, and I'll be buying a different one.

I used to own a Canon A95 and a Fujifilm J10. I replaced the A95 with a Powershot SX20IS. After I dropped the Fujifilm and broke the lens (whoops), I replaced it with this Canon A2200. I bought it on sale, and with an employee discount and I am still dissapointed with it. It isn't bad because it's an inexpensive camera, it's just bad. I don't trust the Canon name anymore.Even in ideal lighting conditions most pictures turn out awful. The other day I took my son out to the zoo. It was really nice out - sunny, but not too bright. I thought I could trust the A2200.First picture (auto mode): the lighter colors are washed out (with white patches, even), the rest of the colors are muddled. Fuss with the settings a bit - my son's pink cheeks are blotchy red, his jeans are neon blue. Fuss with them a little more - his face is either bright white or bright pink, his hair is either gray or dark brown with a funny looking "crown" of reflected light. He is either frozen by an overly-aggressive flash, or he looks like a grainy blur. I finally fuss with it enough to get a really fantastic looking picture (as good as I would NORMALLY get with any of my other/previous cameras) and the next ten pictures I take look overexposed. Sometimes I can get a good photo - but most of them are way off.This camera might be fine for some people, but from my experience it is not a good camera compared to others in the same price range. Keep looking.

The quality is good for the price. I was not fond of the menu, but the pictures turned out pretty well most of the time.I had mine for a couple years. I got it while my regular camera - a Canon A95 - was getting repaired (can't miss a month of baby pictures).I liked the small size - similar to a deck of cards. I ended up dropping it on my porch while the lens was out, and that's what killed it. My fault. It took pretty good pictures. I always had to use the flash (unless it was outdoors on a very bright day). I was happy with most of the pictures it took - the colors were not entirely accurate, all of them were "warm" but they weren't washed out and they weren't blurry (so long as I used the flash). I have a Canon PowerShot SX20IS and a Canon PowerShot A2200 - and, on the fly, this camera takes much better pictures than either of them. (With a lot of set up, the SX20IS takes much better pictures, but the auto mode is junky - it cost 3x the J10).The similarly priced A2200 takes abysmal pictures. I REALLY regret breaking my J10.

I bought this camera in ~2004. It was my first digital camera, I chose it because it took AA batteries, it had a metal case, a flip screen, decent macro, and the lens retracted. Loved this camera - but it kept getting purple streaks (after five years of use). Canon repaired it for free (even replaced a part of the case that had a dent in it while they were at it). Customer service was great, especially considering it was a few years after I had bought it and I assumed I'd be paying for repairs. Unfortunately, the purple lines returned less than a month later. It was ~2010 at this point, and I went out and bought a "better" camera (Canon Powershot SX20IS) and although the camera had better features - I got better pictures out of the Canon A95. I barely ever used the flash with the A95 and my pictures turned out great most of the time. The Powershot it a pain to set up (auto on that camera is terrible) and the pictures don't look as nice. I wish I could find a camera I like as much as the A95!

Both of my grandparents had campers, and after I put these up I was struck with a pang of familiarity... these are totally camper curtains. Stiff, woven polyester with a white liner on the back. Ha!Anyway.They come packaged with a bunch of justifications about how the room may APPEAR bright, but that's just because sunlight is very bright and the curtains have been through tests and are in fact blocking almost all (99%) of the light.Well. The room is still bright enough to read a book in - with these curtains AND with white poster paper taped over the glass. I put some "customer images" up to illustrate.I have velvet curtains in my living room, and when they cover the windows the room is pretty darn dark. When I bought these, I was expecting them to be at least as good as the velvet curtains. They do make the room darker - darker than a regular unlined curtain or a bedsheet, anyway.  I bought them on sale (with a discount) so they were pretty cheap and they work enough so that my son isn't waking up at 6am (sunrise) anymore... so I'm keeping them. They are OKAY.

I've had this for a couple years now. My son likes it a lot. I'm not crazy about it.- There is no way to keep the sand and water separate - I realize that's a "no duh" thing but there really is no point to having a divided table. The whole table will be soupy wet sand in no time. Even if you have a very careful child the sand and water will get mixed up when they pour sand/water through the funnels. The wet sand is a mess and it takes awhile to dry out. I just put sand in both sides and I don't intentionally add water.- The cover is not waterproof. When it rains, the table gets an inch or so of water in it and the cover protects the rainwater from sun... so the water just sits in there. Heating up. In the dark. With dead bugs in it. There are drain plugs on the bottom of the table, but they are under the sand. If there is a lot of standing water I tip the table over to dump out the water (and a bunch of sand). Word of warning: I sewed a layer of vinyl underneath it. Don't do that, the moisture trapped between the two layers isn't a good thing. Eventually the cover blew away (I'd put it under one of the legs while the sand was drying out). Now I just keep the table in a sunny spot on the porch and it is usually dry (has some debris mixed in, but it's dry).- The cover does not protect the table from insects. They can get in from the sides, and there is also a big hole in the center of the table (like for an umbrella).- Don't put gravel in the table. I bought a bag of sandbox sand thinking "sand is sand". The chunks were too big to go through the funnels and the trays were a muddy mess.- Sand in the table isn't great either. I cleaned out the gravel and bought a bag of play sand (very fine, neon colored) that works with the funnels, but it also clogs up the moving parts. The wheels on the cars don't turn, the spinners don't spin, the tippy thing is jammed.- Rice works okay (had the table indoors for awhile), but then you can't use water.- Water-only provides optimal performance, but then you don't have a sandbox. If you don't have a bathtub or room for a kiddy pool this table would be great for playing in the water.My son still likes the table a lot. Compared to a regular sandbox it's smaller, and it's raised. So it can sit in the corner of a small porch, it's pretty easy to move around, you don't have to buy as much sand (I bought a couple bags, used half a bag to fill the table and so I have plenty of extra sand to replace/restore), and your kid(s) won't be sitting in a pile of sand (although they can still dump it on themselves). My son likes the funnels and cars, and moving sand from one side to the other.

I bought a 150 coil spring mattress for my son before he was born, after two years it is no longer supportive (he does love to jump before going to bed and after waking up). This mattress was the best one I could find in my desired price range. I was worried a foam mattress would be mushy, which is why I bought a coil mattress before.I liked what the other reviewers said about this mattress, so I decided to risk it. I was worried when I picked up the box because it was so light, but I was pleasantly surprised. This mattress is firm. And when I say firm, I don't mean to say that it is hard... it is more like the foam is very dense. I can't think of an exact comparison... maybe a piece of cake vs. a brownie (this would be a brownie).And my favorite part: no jumping! It isn't bouncy like a coil mattress. Mwahahaha!

I haven't "installed" it yet but the set looks a lot better in person than it does the picture. The sheets and comforter went through the wash without any problems.I spent awhile looking for a bed set & had a hard time finding some for a boy (these would be great for a girl, too) that weren't sports-themed/TV characters/just ugly. This set is bright and cheery - and I think the pattern on the comforter will be fun for my kid to look at. If I didn't already have a shower curtain I like I would have bought that, too!

My toddler really likes my blender, and so I thought a toy blender would be a good Christmas present. It was. So far he isn't all that interested in putting liquid in it, although we tried making chocolate milk in it (it worked).Some mischievous relative showed him he could put toys in it - and it still works after a few months of cars and other toys getting shoved in there.Update: It's March of 2013, we've had this since Christmas 2010... still blending! Which is more then I could say about my real one.I've only changed the batteries once, maybe twice.

Bought these to use for my son's birthday party after looking everywhere for car plates that weren't "Cars" (the movie) plates. They are cute and bright, I don't have any complaints regarding quality. Five stars. Would buy again.

I'm a cashier, I've seen a lot of bags. If you want your bags filled fast and well - these are much better than the flimsy windbreaker-fabric bags. Whenever someone has those bags, they fumble around trying to unfold them (a lot of times they are folded/wadded up into pouches), and then they are difficult to fill because they don't stand up on their own. It takes longer, it's sloppier, and since the bags don't have a square bottom everything gets crushed together when the bag is picked up.Compared to the reusable bags sold by Walmart/Target/etc. these are bigger - they are also tall and narrow. If you are going to get a lot of large boxy things (toys, cereal, paper towels, kleenex boxes) these bags would be a great size. They would be too big for a lot of yogurt/baby food/makeup sized items.These bags are well made (they are not too stiff, not too soft - sewn well - reinforced seams), the reason I'm not giving them five stars is because they don't have the little loop (so the bagging person can hang them on the plastic bag holder to keep the bag up and open so they can fill it up better/faster) and they don't have an insert in the bottom. Most reusable bags like this have a rectangle of plastic that fits in the bottom - which I think is pretty important. Let's say you put a bunch of cans in the bag... if the bottom of the bag is just fabric, everything is going to move and squish together when the bag is picked up. I'm going to put some plastic canvas in the bottom of mine. Another option would be wrapping cardboard up in duck tape (so it doesn't get wet).

The book read like a magazine article for "finding the perfect swimsuit for your body type" - I wasn't surprised to read that the author has a background in fashion magazines.While reading the first few chapters, I determined that this is typical fashion B.S. To say that there are three "types", and plus size versions of those three types - is idealized (to put it lightly). I didn't fit neatly into one of the three categories - a lot of women probably don't. I could see where someone up in the clouds of the industry would believe that. About half of the clothes for my "type" (or at least the one I thought I was closest to) are things I would NOT look good in - e.g. short shorts, pencil skirts, and halter tops. After taking out the things recommended for taller women, I was left with some no-duh things that anyone could wear. Things that I already wear.Some advice was solid, but I found myself scoffing more than nodding. The absolute worst part was the bra section. I know a thing or two about bra fitting - and this section was totally off.After disregarding the $$$ stores, body shaping undergarments, and tailoring (because: no.)... I wasn't left with much. I wanted to look a little more put-together, and this book was incredibly unhelpful in that regard.And I agree with others who have rated before me, this book would have been much more helpful with some pictures, preferably of real people with the body types wearing the clothes.

We have a basketball, a small soccer ball, a bouncy red ball, a big yoga ball, smaller plastic balls with bells and rattles in them, a ball with liquid and glitter in it, and I think there is a tennis ball around here somewhere. This ball is by far the favorite ball.Out of all of the toys we have, this is easily one of the top five. And it is sure to remain a favorite, as it isn't necessarily a "baby" toy. His uncles were over and they were downstairs throwing it at each other for a long time, and they are all over 20. People are kind of drawn to it, I've noticed. They want to toss it around. It's weird looking. I'm sure if I left it in the yard someone would take it.As for toddlers: The ball is easy to hold on to, it is light, brightly colored (ours is orange) and translucent, it is the perfect size, and due to the bumps it can suddenly change direction while rolling (which makes it a little more exciting than other balls). Five stars.

My son is a little over a year old, and can get on and off the toy but hasn't figured out how to move on it yet. I can sort of push him while he is on it, although I have to be really careful about holding up his feet. There isn't a lot of room between the wheels for dangling feet or for big steps.The vroom-vroom noise is fun, and so is the honking. I could do without the super-cheery singing voice button and I'd pry it off with a screwdriver if my son didn't like it so much. He likes to sit on the four wheeler and push the buttons with a big grin on his face.It doesn't "do" tight corners, although it can make wide turns just fine. It travels straight just fine as well, and since we use it back and forth on the sidewalk, this isn't an issue.It is pretty cool looking for a little boy, and it doesn't take up much room at all.

I'm not certain that this chair is the exact same one I have. Mine doesn't have the basket/net thing in the back, but it is Winnie the Pooh and has the same fabric, shape, and honey pot.I've had this highchair for about five months or more, and it has been working out pretty well. It is roomy and comfortable, and the coloring is attractive. I don't like character-themed baby gear, but the Pooh bear stitched into the seat is actually kind of pleasant looking. The honey pot attaches underneath the tray and is easily removed. It was a bit of a distraction.I like that you can (easily) tilt the back of the seat, and move the seat up higher or lower on the legs, although the lowest setting on ours isn't usable (it doesn't connect correctly). It was that way out of the box, and I probably should have just returned it, but didn't want to bother since I bought it on clearance and it was pretty difficult to put together.As for the buckles, my son really hates being strapped in once he realizes he can't stand up in the chair, and so the buckles have been put through quite a bit of stress. The buckles are fine. They're set up similar to seat belt buckles. I removed the straps that went over the shoulders (that is an option). I haven't had any issues with the lap belt, and I'd say the belt was just fine.I can take the tray off with one hand, rinse it off, and snap it back on - that has saved me a lot of trouble.The fabric on the seat isn't waterproof, so it starts looking dirty when baby food soaks into it. It is a little difficult to take the cover off, and the straps are also difficult to remove and replace. I have never been able to completely clean the fabric by wiping it down, but it comes out of the washer spot free. Most of the chairs I looked at had this same fabric.

PROS: When I tried to switch my son to bottles, it took a few months of frustration before I found these. He was having a hard time tipping the bottle back to drink out of it, and it was just horrible. Months of this went by, making zero progress, and then I bought him a cup with a straw to try out. He loved it. That was the last day of nursing, ever. So, 10 stars out of 5 for this cup so far.CONS:  We've had this cup for awhile now, I've gotten picky about it, so we're down to 3 out of 5 stars. It is still a good cup, I still use our cups all the time and would buy another one. BUT...I've always had issues with cleaning it. I use a bottle brush for the bottom part and lid. The bottle brush cleans out the bottle just fine, but the lid is full of nooks and crannies. I think I'm cleaning it out really well (scrubbing, hot water, soap) and then I notice some accumulated grime in part of the lid - the horror! The straw is another frustrating cleaning issue. I bought pipe cleaners to clean out the straw portion, which is a little gross to me, but there isn't a better way to do it. Milk will sometimes collect and dry along the edges of the outside of the lid, and that takes a second to blast clean with the dish sprayer. The straw will discolor when dark juice is used (even though I water it down a great deal) and so the straw is stained. We have two of these cups, and every night after my son goes to bed I have to take some time to thoroughly clean both of them out. The straw is difficult to thread back through the lid, but since I've been doing it awhile it barely takes a second to get it through - you get the hang of it. You just have to twist it through, and give it a little tug. I forget about it being an issue, but I remember the first time I couldn't get it back in I thought for sure I ruined the cup.It leaks a little bit. When it was new it didn't, but the valve inside the straw cracks a little right away, and so it leaks if the cup is left on its side (or upside down in the diaper bag). There is a little piece of plastic on the inside that goes over a little vent, and it helps if you have the plastic firmly over the vent like it is supposed to be. And, it does leak while upright. If I have a lot of milk in the bottle (formula and whole milk both did this) it will somehow manage to "leak" while the bottle is upright. I've watched it happen. If you have the lid closed the leaking isn't really an issue.I wasn't aware that it was any kind of choking hazard (like it says on the page). My son is pretty destructive and has had it since he was about 9 months old (he is over a year old now), and it hasn't ever been an issue.The cups have been dropped many (many, many) times and one of them did break when it hit the floor, and the cup had only been used a few times. It cracked on the bottom, and had to be thrown away. It only happened once, and it was in the kitchen. I would have been pretty upset if it happened in a store or elsewhere - then we would have a big mess and no bottle.

My son is a little over a year old, and has had it for maybe four months or so. He doesn't get bonkers about it, but he does like the music and he likes to have it in his crib and in the car. He sleeps with it and when he wakes up in the middle of the night he turns on the "bedtime music" by himself and falls back asleep. I think it is really great for that reason alone - especially when we're away from home. I think it is a toy that he will have and enjoy for a long time.I like that you can pick music out on the website, and change what the dog says.Cons...It has gotten a little grungy looking despite my attempts to keep it clean, but it isn't that big of a deal. It looks well-loved.It isn't annoying (we had another, similar puppy that was pretty obnoxious and not nearly as lovable), but it is cheerful to the point where it is a little unnerving - like the little girls in The Shining. It would be nice if it had even more music to chose from, and if the ADD-INS weren't so STAGED sounding (My favorite color is... RED, is that you're favorite, too?). I don't like the way it says my son's name - it sounds kind of mean/teasing. So I would change that, too, if I could.

When I think of toys with bright, primary colors and music - it brings to mind words/phrases like "annoying", "obnoxious", "overly pleasant", or perhaps "dorky looking". This guitar is not any of those things. It makes other toys seem *condescending*.My son got this for his first birthday, and it was a big hit. He likes his grandpa's guitars, so it was important that a toy guitar for him had strings on it. He likes to pluck the strings, and hit the buttons - and he didn't even notice any of the other toys after we opened this one. It has been a couple months, and he still plays with it all the time - he dances and rocks back and forth like he his having the best time of his life. He hugs it. We haven't had to change the batteries yet.The songs aren't irritating (no peppy voices), it has two volume levels, and it lights up in an attractive/cool manner.I let him play around with the keyboard version in the store, and I think it would be as good as the guitar.The only negative thing I can think of, is that the sticker is getting grungy looking. It doesn't detract from the enjoyment of the toy, so it really isn't a big deal.

The brush we had for cups and other dishes didn't fit in the bottles we had, so I bought this. It works. I've been using it for the better part of a year, and haven't had any issues. I'm not overly fond of the foam/sponge thing on the top, because it doesn't exactly scream "sanitary" - although it dries out pretty quickly. I've seen brushes with a base, and that would probably work out better, but this one is just fine.

It was a gift, I had heard negative things about sleep positioners and wedges so I wasn't planning on using one. I tried putting my son in it when his nose was stuffy from a cold, and didn't care for it. It was awkward. He didn't seem to like it very much & I didn't feel like he was very secure in it.

It is really easy to install rear-facing, and a little trickier to install forward-facing. I wouldn't recommend trying to install it the first time in a hurry, or while sleep-deprived, but once you figure it out it is easy-peasy to do again. The seat is sturdy and seems to be very safe and well-made. I think it was well worth the price, and as a concerned new parent it was very comforting to get this seat in the mail, after considering seats in the store that weren't as nice. I remember going back in my son's room quite a bit before he was born, and every time I went in there I would look over this seat with a feeling of accomplishment. Yeah, that is pretty goofy, but aside from his crib it was the nicest/most expensive thing we bought when getting everything ready for the baby. It, unlike a bunch of other baby products we bought, was not something I regret buying.I've had to fuss around with the buckles and other parts as my son has grown out of one setting or another, and I've had to take it apart to clean it out a couple times. Nothing was difficult to do. It all comes apart and goes back together without a lot of trouble, and nothing comes apart when it isn't supposed to. I've been using it for about a year now.I started off with a (hand-me-down) infant-style seat when my son was first born, and definitely prefer this seat. I think it is a lot more comfortable than the infant seat we had, and I think my son felt the same way (he wasn't as fussy about being put in it). For the same amount of money you could get two cheap seats - one for an infant, and one for a toddler, or you could get one seat that does both jobs, is easy to use, and that is worthy of admiration.For an infant, you might want to get one of those c-shaped pads for supporting the head while the baby sleeps. Some seats come with it, this one doesn't, but they sell them just about everywhere and they aren't expensive.I did have to cut the instruction book out (it is attached inside the seat with a short cord) so I could read it and install the seat at the same time.

This handle cover has been wonderful in the kitchen... I just wish I had bought one years ago!  I use a lot of cast iron cookware, so these get super hot in the oven and I've been burned a time or two (or three). With the handle cover in addition to an oven mitt, my hands are so much better protected and I can better balance the weight of my cookware. I just hope these go back down to add-on prices so that I can stock up on some gifts for the holidays!

I'm so happy I decided to try out this sleeve! Just like all other reviews have said, it fits PERFECTLY in car cup holders. Definitely helps to insulate warm drinks and keep cold drinks from dripping condensation. My only issue (other than the high price) is that this black and white design gets stained VERY quickly.  Sure it's easy to wash and luckily the stains are on the bottom, but it's a bit of a hassle.  Anyway, overall I reallyreallyreally LOVE the sleeve and am using it for just about all my tumbler and canned drinks!In each of the included pics, the sleeve is holding various 16 oz beverage containers (perfectly snug around plastic tumblers, metal, ceramic or paper cups, and aluminum cans). Really a great fit, and not awkward or top heavy at all!

I absolutely, positively LOVE my iPad Mini 3 Speck StyleFolio case!!!  The design is eye-catching, and the material is definitely durable (just came back from a weekend getaway and my new iPad was definitely well-protected). Loving the magnet on/off feature, as well as the additional latch (though this may be difficult for some to open as it does tend to stick). The wrap-around case is good, thick plastic and goes over the edges of the tablet. I had a previous Speck case for my iPad 2, and it just started falling apart after four years of daily use; so I'm definitely happy with Speck quality.  Full disclosure, I purchased my case from BB on sale which worked out to about half the retail price (which I think is a completely fair price for such a small item).

This bar fits my ten year old Whirlpool fridge perfectly (even a bit on the snug side).  The lightweight aluminum bar is shipped in two different outer boxes, so be warned of excessive packaging. The bar also does NOT include the endcaps of the original; save these if you have them, otherwise be prepared to use something else. Definitely a must-replace item after years of use, but just wish these didn't cost so much!

I can't say how much I love these reusable straws!!! I've had my eye on these the last few weeks at the various Starbucks locations I've visited, and I finally bought some to use at home and on the go. They are so incredibly bright and colorful, and I love the summery designs. While I've only found these in Grande size, the straws are big enough to use in standard reusable cups (the 24oz PINK or Copco brands are what I use). I wish Starbucks would include a straw brush, especially for the price (yes $3.95 retail isn't much, but consider these probably cost pennies to make and package). Also wish they were available at the online store, but alas these are only sold directly in Sbux shops or through third party resellers.

I ordered this headband here on Amazon as an add-on item, and I have to admit that I'm glad I only paid a couple of bucks. Sure it's cute *and* it's a 40th anniversary items, but it's so small my kids can barely wear it!  A must for collectors and great for adding to a gift, but don't pay too much for this little accessory.

This is an adorable cinch bag which can be used for many things, by pretty much any age! I bought it at the Sanrio site on clearance, for car and travel use (either as an extra tote, an inexpensive shoe bag, or catch-all bag). For those who don't carry much with them, this is easily a cute little lightweight backpack. Aside from the Tokidoki signature heart and crossbones and the black branding tag on the side, the graphic is Hello Kitty.

I was able to order this gift with purchase from Sanrio (which has been offered twice in the last few weeks, so keep an eye out!) and I have to say that I am in LOVE with this set! There is also a similar My Melody set of pastel chopsticks offered on the site, and both designs retail for eighteen dollars. The sizing is just right for regular use (not the oversized chopsticks some sets include). Super cute, super useful, great for any age (and chopstick skill)!

This luggage tag was available as a free gift with purchase from Sanrio online.  The retail on these Tokidoki tags is thirteen dollars on the price tag, and I have to say given the size (about 5.75" from the top of the ears to the feet), weight, and detail make the tag worth it!  While I wouldn't trust the tag to survive TSA and the rough handling of checked airline bags, this definitely works great for a carry-on, backpack, golf or gym bag, etc. The name and address portion is VERY small, so you might want to consider printing any info on a label and then sticking that onto the back of the tag.

My son had been eyeing this Hot Wheels set for months and finally received it for his birthday. He still loves this and uses all of his cars, not just the color shifters. The set itself is a decent size and breaks down into separate components for storage. The "elevator" and dunk tank are fairly easy to maneuver. No the (expensive) color shifter cars aren't the best at changing, but it's a neat detail. Other big box stores offer this set with up to five extra cars, but we were able to stock up during a buy two get one sale at our local supermarket. This is honestly one of the funner sets out there!

Fun shirt graphics, but the blend is more poly than cotton.  The fit is also on the shorter side, with the hem hitting right around the end of the waist band on a pair of jeans. Purchased this at Kohl's, so you may want to look around your local store first. Also, careful where/when you wear this shirt... definitely get some funny looks sometimes!

Really cute top for a bargain price, but the fit is just a bit off. The shoulder area fits just right, but the hem is super loose and gets all billowy.  If this were a high-low hem, maybe it would lay flatter on the tummy. But really for a casual top or as a cover up, this is perfect.

This Gearonic flip case ("wallet") is very basic and honestly at this low price, that's all I'm really asking for. I need something to protect my entire iPhone 6, and I don't want to shell out a fortune for it since I tend to swap out my cases alot. This has a white shell for the back which holds the phone securely in place (so secure that it's a bit difficult getting the phone back out), and a magnetic tab closure for the 'cover.' Except for the volume buttons and those on the front screen, all other ports and buttons are unobstructed when this cover is closed. The stand feature (really just breaking the inner cardboard) messes the clean lines of the case, BUT again as this so low cost it isn't a big deal for me. Good extra coverage for those times when I carry my phone in my back pocket, GREAT for added insulation when it's cold out, the stand makes this perfect when traveling, and the best thing is that Amazon fulfilled this directly. Yay.EDIT: Why didn't I realize that the magnet could be a problem?!?! While leaving my phone in this case, there have been a few times when the battery was drained overnight (phone was left on at almost a full charge, then was completely dead upon waking up with NO apps, wifi, or 4G running in the background). I've taken it out of the case, and the battery percentage has remained steady. My diy fix was putting stickers where the magnet pieces meet. Oh well, still a useful case just watch out!

This MyBat case is pretty, visually very cool. Super slim design and all the buttons and ports are unobstructed. And while I don't think this case provides anything more than a back cover, it's definitely eye catching (especially against the gold) and better than nothing. The plastic itself is actually slick - super stiff and very unforgiving. If you pull it off too quickly, it will likely crack. The curves at the top and bottom are just a tad bit sharp so you should definitely be careful when changing this cover. Okay for just a few bucks, but all you are getting is an inexpensive piece of plastic with a cool design.

Love this wallet! The white and yellow is a super bright, very cheery color combo. The overall size is more compact than other wallets, but still holds cards, your cash, and even your iPhone 6 (a bit snug tho)!! I've used this for the last few months and that new leather scent is still there. Because I fold the wristlet and Coach hangtag inward, the yellow is becoming discolored right at that edge. And although the card slots are also a bit snug, in general this is still a great everyday piece!EDIT: I still love this wallet, but it still has yet to soften after months of use. Unfortunately, the white paint around the corners continues to wear off from daily opening and closing. Oh well, not everything is perfect...

These squares are delicious, but the "celebration tin" is nothing to celebrate as it only has 13 pieces of chocolate. And no, that isn't a fluke as the nutritional information on the side actually states there are 13 pieces! The tin is very nice, but only the very bottom is filled with chocolate. We ordered these for ourselves, so we weren't embarrassed to give this as a gift. But your money would go way further if you purchased a deluxe bag at your local grocery or club store!

I purchased this purple set from Sam's about six months ago and used them for grilling, when pulling a pizza out of the oven, etc. I used only these last month for Thanksgiving food prep and they definitely saved my skin from a few painful burns when roasting the turkey. I'm a decent cook, and I mostly use cast iron in my oven... so inevitably accidents will happen on occasion. These mitts don't "fit like a glove," and they're not supposed to anyway. One entire mitt covers my arm all the way to the elbow, and if needed I can bend my hand to grab hot handles. This is a great back up set, or for those who need a little extra safety when they cook.

Purchased at Sam's for under ten bucks. As these slippers fell apart after just two months of light wearing around the house, even the "fair" price was paying too much! A snug fit when wearing your normal size, and they keep your feet super warm. The soles are still clean, however the entire right slipper has pulled apart from the footbed. So disappointed in the overall basic lack of quality, and really NOT worth even returning directly to Isotoner for a replacement (they charge you $5, according to the warranty on the box).

Compared to the previous two albums, the 2.0 editions are definitely enhanced - bigger (twice the space, because there are now more discs being released), much sturdier (this feels like a REAL album, and not the Disney Parks type of books), and with the 5 power discs included (the featured two Lion King, Aladdin, King Louie, and Calhoun are exactly what you get) this means that the retail is bumped up to over twice what the older albums originally cost.This is a bull's eye exclusive (at least that's what the T website claims {the Marvel Superheroes album is a TRU exclusive}), and it retails for twenty-four ninety-nine. According to the find in store feature, this album is widely available in stores.  However, I ordered it right before Thnxgvng and it was delivered less than a week later. I ordered it on a whim to go with other 2.0 gifts, and even my husband was impressed at the overall improved quality of the newer 2.0 items. Definitely worth getting, but NOT worth overpaying - you'll shell out enough just collecting all 40 discs!!

This Frozen comforter completes the look with any Frozen sheetset. The colors are vibrant and beautiful, the images on the comforter are Anna and Elsa on one side and a field of flowers on the other.  I wish manufacturers would go back to cotton blends in their bedding, but overall this is a nice addition to your girl's bedroom decor.The packaging is super compact (though the plastic was torn in one end) and arrived in the typical oversized Amazon box (so no worries if you are sending this as a gift). I paid a retail of twenty-nine here on Amazon about a week ago, and now it's even lower at about twenty-four and change. Absolutely worth it!

Such a fun kids watch! While very simple, the numbers on the face (glow in the dark hands!) and outer minutes dial are easy to read. Hamm may not be a current fave character, the case may be seen as a bit too plain, and the band is a bit stiff and scratchy. But this low price definitely makes the watch worth getting.

Such a cute plush and blankie set!  The Olaf figure is cute (though there ARE better looking ones ones out there), and the blanket is perfect for cuddling on the couch, in the car, or packing in a carry-on.  The blankie has a fair isle print, and is extremely colorful.I'm docking a star for two reasons: 1) this Khl's "exclusive" is ridiculously overpriced at fifty bucks retail... so don't pay TOO much either at the store or third party. And 2) the set reeks of plastic and took a full day of washing and airing out to smell normal.

I ordered a dozen of these Disney Fairies Pez candies, based on the unbeatable subscribe & save deal and the helpful advice of the other reviewer on here.  The 'assortment' included four each of Tinkerbell, Rosetta, and Silver Mist.  These were intended as party favors for a girl's bday party, so we weren't exactly picky based on both the price and our experience.The first Pez shipment we received was of Marvel Pez - a huge hit with the boys in our family, BUT not with the bday girl!  Her reaction was pretty hilarious, and Amazon made it right and expedited the correct item at no additional charge. The Fairies carton was pretty beat up and the packages themselves were dented a bit (all were still sealed, so no issues there). Word of wisdom: definitely make sure that the Pez item number on the box matches with the Amazon barcode. Seems many of these Pez cartons are mislabeled and folks are getting the wrong item (raising my hand here).

LOVE these mummy Cheetos! Picked up a ginormous box at Sam's (will definitely be getting more before the 31st) and my kiddos were over the moon about the graphics and the glow in the dark bags.  The Cheetos themselves are the small lunchbox size, but the packaging is awesome and great for treat giving!! The Universal Monsters stamp is a cool touch, just wish there was a bigger presence! Overall, a terror-ific alternative to Halloween candy!!!

This is a cute tee, but the fit is very strange. The sleeves are normal, but the overall shape is more like a dolman top.  The colors are bright and vibrant, but the material is very thin. Not my favorite Disney Parks tee, but it's a good buy if you can find a low price.

This white 2014 hoodie is adorable and incredibly cheery.  It's definitely oversized, so if you prefer a more fitted look then you should consider sizing down. The embroidery is well done and VERY colorful.  And while the zipper pull is a stamped 2014 on metal, the pink zipper itself is cheap plastic and easily gets stuck.  I also noticed small bits of black thread in the seams of the jacket I received (purchased directly from Disney). Overall though, really a fun option for any age.

Picked this brush set up at Sam's Club on mark-down for about fifteen bucks.  This is a great deal, for all that's included.  The long brush and connector work well, with lots of other helpful uses besides car washing (like cleaning house windows)... However, the brush bristles leave white lint on the car (I've only used a few times so far). The squeegee and microfiber are decent and work ok, BUT feel too flimsy because of the plastic (compared to a metal framed sponge). The tire brush is actually really great, because the shape really gets between the spaces. The included microfiber towels also work well.Good deal, if you can find this.  Even better for those height-challenged like me!

I've never heard of the Green Tea apparel company, but I am so in LOVE with this vest!  It's super cozy, the inside of both the vest and hood are lined with a snowy white sherpa-material, and the faux-fur on the outside of the hood is very soft as well.  All of the zippers on the front and pockets have convenient toggles.  The only negative - other than the "retail price" - is that the vest fits a bit on the small side. I generally wear a medium or large, and the large with all of its filling makes for a snug fit... Having read reviews of other Green Tea products here on Amazon, it seems the tops run small and the bottoms are more generously sized. I definitely should have sized up, however I'm incredibly glad I didn't size down!!I purchased this Green Tea vest (in a much darker shade of purple) from Sam's Club online for about a quarter of the supposed "retail" price.  Not worth returning, as the Sam's return policy is a pain to deal with. Thankfully I still love the vest!

These shorts are sturdy and definitely have that Levi's feel.  The cut is generous, as the size 4s have to be folded at the legs and belted around my kinder kiddo's waist.  Besides all that, these shorts were such a deal here on Amazon and we'll obviously get plenty of use out of them before he grows out of this size.  Absolutely a must have!

These jeans are a perfect fit for my new school ager! He's small for his age, so the 4T was the right choice - longer length than comparable jeans and a more generous waist too. The wash and backpocket design were a fun change, too. While their sizes run on the bigger side, Request is a great brand that has quality boys clothing (ie: they last!!) and usually has deals on wardrobe staples (Amazon, Macy's, etc.).

This shirt made my kiddo extremely happy when she saw it, until she tried the medium on.  Normally she is very easy going about clothes, and doesn't like the thought of returning anything.
