They feature a truly fine sounding single balanced armature design and hands down the best microphone in the Apple headphone industry. And their true deep insertion design allows real near total physical sound isolation. Not for use when you need awareness of stuff going on around you.For compromise use in just about any situation, I have preferred Sony's XBA1i single balanced Armature model, which is now discontinued but can still be found NOS for under $30. A very fine inexpensive headset with refined sound and light compact design. Lacking in deep bass like the Etymtic but sounds just beautiful anyway.I have left the Sonys home for these new Senns. The Momentum in-ears have surprisingly balanced frequency response for a dynamic design. Fast and engaging midrange and acceptable highs. Best sounding dynamic IEM I have, better than my much-loved metal bodied JVC Micro HD Carbon Nanotube Japan imports.And very solid bass without overplaying it like those ridiculously tuned Beats. I have some very expensive 4-driver Sony balanced armature phones and these sound as good in most aspects for a third of the price. Sony's hybrid BA/dynamic designs deliver more engaging sound but boy do you pay for it and they're HUGE. Ditto JVC's multi-driver dynamics.What Sennheiser has done in this $100 package is deliver a headset that sounds wonderful and is an acceptable compromise of the virtues discussed above such that if you only want to own one pair of headphones this Momentum IEM is a strong contender. Excellent small size, comfortable shape,decent shallow-insertion isolation, beautiful sound with great bass, good cable, mic and remote, durable construction.All for the market sweet spot price of a hundred bucks and worth every penny.Some aftermarket Comply-type foam tips can improve isolation still further if you wish, and there are triple flange insertion tips out there that will turn these guys into true isolation stars. I don't like either of those options and find the included silicone tips to work great.In short, these are great, bone stock right out of the box. If you are so interested that you are reading customer reviews, consider this a full-throated endorsement from a true IEM junkie.My new all-around favorite. The Sony single BA is relegated to listening in bed. I still recommend it, but these have real bass, stay put better, are far better built and more comfortable.Total win. Best IEM I've ever tried from Sennheiser.

The "salad spinner" mop is not a gimmick. It really does help you get your floors cleaner and is usable on all types of hard floors including expensive hardwood you want to clean without water seeping into joints.This one is a minor step up in construction and durability over the one you see on tv with the plastic foot pedal that looks like it will be the first thing to break. I've used this mop for two months now on every square inch of hard flooring in my house and it has performed better than any other mop or wet jet thing I've tried. If you mop everything weekly, you will only need cleaners in the water occasionally.When mopping up spills, this thing shines. It can soak up a huge amount of crud, release it in the bucket, come back to the spill damp and clean up the rest. By far the most time consuming step in spill cleanup is filling your bucket.Most of the time I only use white vinegar in my mop water but there's nothing wrong with a little pine sol with this mop. You can spin as little or as much mop water out as you want before hitting the floor.I also have a large bay window behind a sectional sofa with big horizontal blinds that need to be dusted occasionally. The second microfiber head is what I use on that handle to get to those blinds without having to move the couch. Hallelujah, it works. Overhead dusting can be done with this mop. Just understand the shape limits the spaces it will fit. It still works for me. I put it in a bucket of clean water after initial dusting, spin the heck out of it so it's almost dry, then go over the dusty trouble spots again.Heads are machine washable and reasonably inexpensive.There are more expensive spin mops out there for commercial duty, and cheaper ones too. This one seems to hit the sweet spot: a mop and bucket that doesn't cost much more than a standard mop and bucket but outperforms the heck out of them.I'm sold on spinner mops. This one has been good so far.

Upfront: I have some expensive multi-balanced armature phones from the likes of Shure, Sony, and Etymtic. Some fairly pricey dynamic cans from Audio Technica, JVC (a favorite), Monster, Klipsch, Sennheiser and a bunch of others.I have cheap ones, expensive ones, open fit, canal fit, on-ear, you name it. Quite a few that fit a little better, sound nicer, have a better mic, or are better built.But for sixteen bucks shipped, this is the most extreme value I have found in iPhone compatible IEMs. They sound the best of all sub-$20 earphones I've ever listened to. They could use a chin slider and that's the only knock I'll give them at this price. For another dollar or two I'll take a bit of memory wire over the ears please.They sound smooth and huge, if a bit veiled at the top end. Very neutral and pleasant, non-fatiguing sound, and physical comfort for my ears is top notch.I could have gone out with my super duper Sonys or Shures, but I'm out and about, listening to these Nixons, happy as can be. For those times when you want to leave your spendy cans at home, you can have full control and passable sound without fear of damaging something expensive.At this price I'll be getting the white and the red too.

Wow, such nitpicking.First of all, this type of shelving has ALWAYS used wood composite for the shelves. Rapid Rack, Gorilla Rack, Edsal, whoever. You can't buy these without particle shelves. I have had my Gorilla racks in my basement for 16 years, moved multiple times. Some corners have been knocked off in all that repeated disassembly and reassembly but I've never had to replace a shelf. They were the strongest racks I owned before this one.My newer Gorilla racks have thinner steel and thinner laminated particle board. They are rated for less weight but more moisture resistant so they're in the garage. They survive moving much better than the originals do.Now, this Edsal rack. Its frame is far heavier duty than anything else I have. It is a hero of a shelf. You can get these $30 cheaper from the Sam's Club website.The thin, light shelves are similar to the ones in my newer Gorilla racks. They are all most will ever need. I needed a little more strength so I grabbed some construction adhesive and some Hardibacker board, cut to fit and glued to the underside of the stock shelves. You can do the same with light gauge OSB and skip the glue. Just put the stock shelves right on top of your OSB for any shelf that needs reinforcing. I just used what I had and it added enough strength. Adding an OSB shelf under the stock unit will be stronger. Gluing them together will be stronger still, if you won't need to move in the future. I'd just throw the nice one over top of the strong one. Any home improvement store will cut to fit for you.The fit and finish of these shelves is outstanding, though much heavier than the old Gorilla designs (which Edsal also makes for less money).I would not worry about the thinness of the included shelves. These are so customizable that if you need to hold an anvil on one of your shelves, a $10 board from Home Depot will make that a cinch. The rest can stay stock for easy moving.

This is a fantastic wedding/hostess gift. They will think you spent far more than you did.Matching chalk slate nameplates and holders are cool and the cheese knife set includes tools for hard and soft cheeses. With an artisan salami, some wonderful washed rind semi soft wedges, a special order aged white cheddar and a nice Stilton, some grapes and Door County chopped cherry jam, you have an unbeatable presentation.I put a shallow plate with fresh Burrata next to the lazy Suzan on the end of an oblong cracker board.Get two sets, so when your hostess inevitably asks where you got it, you can say, "oh, this set is for you. Merry Christmas."

lucky me, these fit my outer ear as if they were custom fit. I've been a big fan of Sony's hybrid ear tips since they were introduced but never heard a pair of Sonys I wanted to own until now.I own phones from Etymtic (a favorite), JVC, Ultimate Ears, AKG, Audio Technica, Hifiman, Monster, Sennheiser, Incase and others. Since my phone has become my go-to music player, I've gravitated to high efficiency IEMs with iOS inline remote.Of that group, these Sonys are clearly the best for music. For calls, Etymtic has that superior mic.I have Sony's XBA-2ip and several of their 1ip buds, which are the best balanced armature deal on the market now and the best sound per dollar you can probably buy right now. They're discontinued so buy 'em up while you can.Back to the 4 driver Sonys. Quick rundown: fine isolation with hybrid ear tips. You can get better noise isolation with a pair of Etymtics but you have to jam them halfway into your head. Comfort on these, even with their bulky housing, is great. Sony should not have discontinued these but made them available with a custom ear mold.Sound is as clear as the single driver XBA-1ip but with more sparkling highs and much deeper, more solid bass. You can listen to these at quite moderate levels to great enjoyment. They can go very loud if you wish to deafen yourself but there is no need. They just sound beautiful.For calls, the mic is above average and the controls all work right.Which brings me to my main concern here: durability. Any pair of headphones with a retail price of over $200 should come with a detachable, user replaceable cable. These do not, so when the cable fails you're hosed.I guarantee when that happens, I will be pulling out the EarPods from an old iPhone box, some heat shrink tube and solder, snipping the pods off the ends and DIY'ing some Frankenbuds.These are way too good to toss when the cable goes bad.

Perfect lightweight, acoustically transparent and COMFORTABLE replacement for Koss Sportapro headband.Simply pop the Parts Express speakers off and put them in the garbage where they belong, and replace them with the drivers from your Koss Sportapro headset.Bingo: a cheap lightweight over-the-head pair of headphones that is comfortable, doesn't look too dorky and sounds good.If you really want to get into modding your Sportapro drivers further, look into removing material from the grills. It really opens up the sound.

As a point of reference, my home cans are Sennheiser HD650s driven by a very nice sounding Creek amplifier.I buy a lot of portable headphones for the iPhone. I have a few pricey ones like a pair of Etymtic ER4s with custom ear molds and a very fine sounding pair of Ultimate Ears Triple.Fi multi-driver balanced armature IEMs that have a ton of bass.I have had dozens of inexpensive IEMs from just about every manufacturer in the sub-$100 market. Dollar for dollar, JVC's carbon nanotube Micro HD buds are outstanding like most of their Micro HD line. I've had Monster Turbines, Beats (too tipped up in the bass department), AKGs, Denons, Klipsch Image phones (pretty good value there), and an endless parade of small manufacturers' buds.These are not tipped-up bass monsters. If they were, I'd have no use for them. If you like accuracy with a dash of smoothness at an amazingly low price, the Sony single driver BA buds are your friend.The tiny size of this model makes them ultra comfortable for hours of fatigue free listening. Listen to your classical or jazz favorites on these and you'll understand why I like them so much. They make a very good seal with Sony's hybrid tips and that seal really helps the bass. I can listen for a long time at low volume with these and their non-fatiguing sound and shape is a joy.Sony has discontinued their BA only line so you have to get their hybrids if you want these nice BA drivers. A limited number of this budget model are left in old stock. When they're gone, they're gone. The hybrids have hella bass and sound very good but they are quite expensive. I would get a couple pairs of these while you can. I did.Bottom line: I can't believe you can get IEMs of this quality, with inline iOS remote, for under $40. Just amazing value for money.

I use and recommend Oregon blades for lawn equipment. I go through about three edger blades per season, or at least I did. The steel in these Oregon blades looks and feels the same as the stuff I've been putting on my Power Trim edger for years.But now, it is October and I've only changed edger blades once this year. Oh, it needs changed now, but I think I'll make do with the nub of the first Oregon blade for the final mowings of the season, then put a new blade on to be ready for spring.So I now have these three replacement blades for the single Oregon blade I bought last May. I may have enough edger blade now for the next TWO seasons.

Arrived before my iPhone 6 did. I always get an inexpensive slim case for my phone and then put a peel-and-stick steel plate on the back for my magnetic phone holders. I have those at my desk, my car and by my bed. They are just awesome.Went with Spigen because they always have nice tight tolerances that give the phone a perfect fit with no sliding around.If you're looking for a great-fitting slim case for iPhone 6, this one works very well.
Good looking red in my chocolate suede chukkas. Goes great with olive socks.These laces not only look good but their waxed weave makes them stay put when I tie them.I will buy more colors.

People, THESE ARE NOT SWEATS! KingSize markets many different styles, colors, designs and weights of sweatpants. If you wanted sweats, why did you buy a pair of jersey-knit pants?Anybody home in there?And then, to show off your lack of cerebral acuity to the world, you post a one-star review of these "sweatpants."My review is not actually five stars. It's more like three because of the low quality of the jersey knit fabric in question. Find a better supplier with just a bit more heft to your jersey knit, KingSize, and you have at least a four star product here.I put five stars to balance out the 1-star intellect who posted his complaint about these "sweatpants."

We recently sold our home and went back to being renters. After having built in a couple of home theaters, I was worried about having my accustomed experience without being able to drill through walls. Luckily the room getting the treatment has crown moldings which were easily removed to hide long runs of surround sound wiring. But there are still some sections of wiring runs that remain exposed.These clips, coupled with Monoprice's excellent OFC clear-jacketed wire, give me very unobtrusive exposed runs which can then be camouflaged behind plants, wall hangings and furniture.They work wonderfully and inexpensively.I will recommend this solution to anyone whose wall drilling options are limited.

This is Crucial's latest mass market SSD. It is very, very fast, much faster than their previous offerings in the category. You lose a couple gigs of raw capacity to provide this blazing speed.I really doubt you'll miss that space. I used this drive to rejuvenate my desktop replacement style Asus notebook. It has twin quad core i7 processors and was still getting bogged down by a full c drive.So now the hard drive is relegated to media storage and this excellent drive is the booting heart of the system. Windows 7 boot time, from bios loadup to desktop stability, has gone from several minutes to under. ten. seconds.As of 2014, there is a short list of half terabyte SSDs you should consider for your computer upgrade. The Crucial M550 definitely makes that list.Excellent performance and excellent value. I am willing to spend extra for better performance but with the M550 I don't have to. If the M550 performs for you as it has for me, prepare to be, in Jony Ive's clichd phrase, "surprised and delighted."
Doesn't every homeowner's garage have one of these on a shelf? Essential for your blowers, trimmers, clippers, chainsaws and any other blue smokers you have.Best tool for gas/oil mix I have found.

I am the proud owner of 4 different sizes of flat, black-seasoned, smooth-as-a-baby's-butt Griswold skillets. 2 of these were rusty when I found them and required full cleaning and seasoning to get up to snuff. But my favorite one has been done right and has been smooth ever since my grandmother got it in the 1920s.She told me, "never use soap on these. It'll take off that nice smooth black seasoning." And she was right--80 years ago. Soaps back then had caustic agents such as lye or borax that would strip a cast iron skillet so fast it would make your head spin. If you look hard enough today you can still find some cleaners that contain these caustic elements. But all liquid dish detergent is perfectly safe to use with your cast iron and will not harm your beautiful seasoning in any way. I've been cleaning my Griz with a splash of hot water, a drop of Dawn and a nylon beaker brush for decades. Cleans swiftly and completely while leaving seasoned finish intact.So when somebody tells you not to use soap on your cast iron, tell them, "Eww. Remind me not to eat at YOUR house!" Just clean it while it's nice and warm, rinse well, paper towel dry, put it back on the burner for that last bit of heat dry, then paper towel it with a little bit of peanut oil or lard. Lard gives you the nicest black seasoning because of the unique way it interacts with cast iron. When I restore a pan I coat it sparingly in lard, leave it in a medium oven for a while, then give it another very thin rubdown of lard and repeat. Pans turn blacker and smoother with lard than any other fat known to man, including bacon fat. And it doesn't take much.I have quit using my stone for pizza now that I have this. It is really good. Somebody said to preheat the Lodge pan before putting your pizza on it, and that works if you aren't using the press-to-pan method of stretching your dough. If you do press dough into this pan, no sweat--just put your crust in to bake 5 minutes before adding sauce and toppings and you'll be fine.I use cast iron for corn bread, brownies, frittatas, pies, cobbler, bread pudding...anything you want to put a tender crispy crust on. Pizza is a natural candidate. You will enjoy the results. My old pizza stone now lives in my kamado as a heat diffuser--and still gets pizzas thrown on it in the grill, and they are very nice. But the quality of my crusts is better using the Lodge pan, even though the smoky char flavor of a grilled pizza is appealing. Lodge wins for me.Now wash your cast iron with a drop of modern detergent and hot water with a stiff nylon brush. The gunk will come right out, and the pan will come out beautiful, clean and as perfectly seasoned as before.

Stowaway Products sells this same exact set on their website for the same sales price...but they have a flat U.S. shipping fee of 5 bucks, compared to $12.50 through Amazon.So I got mine direct from the manufacturer and saved a little money.This is a fine product; the plastics do not melt when you put hot curling or flatirons in them. And the shape is perfect for 99% of the blow dryers out there. This is "found space" in your bath. The price, 45 bucks with shipping, for a couple pieces of injection-molded plastic and a couple hinges, seems steep, and you could indeed fabricate a shelf on either side and attach it. But the design here works quite well given the attachment points available in your average vanity. It needs to be lighter weight than the plywood you'd probably use, because there isn't enough supporting structure for a heavier shelf. I thought of cutting a bookmatched pair of 1/4" plywood shelves to brace under there. but the attachment points are a bit flimsy for such a flat item. This design is lighter weight, allowing you to use the strength of the available fasteners to hold your blow dryer and irons.So yes, with ten bucks for a small piece of plywood, some hinges, some backing brads and a band saw, you could make a shelf around your sink that would do this job. but this kit is ready to go now, and does the job better. What is your time worth?

I have had a large procession of battery cases for iphones 3g-4s. Some were good, some were cheap, and the last three for the 4s were under 20 bucks and excellent.The problem for the iPhone 5 is Apple's bonehead move of putting the headphone jack down where all battery cases, docks, etc. are going to be. So if you are used to listening to your headphones while your iPhone is docked at your desk, kiss that goodbye unless somebody comes up with a dock with its own auxiliary headphone jack--a possibility.For now you are forced to use Apple's own execrable phones, which are pretty much the only phones that will fit through any kind of hole a company can leave in their battery case, or constantly switch cases.And the iPhone 5 needs a case--I found that out the hard way already with a drop that deformed the aluminum unibody shell to the point that it was unrepairable but that a simple case would have prevented. The only reason the phone wasn't in a case was because the case was charging and I was intending to use headphones. I have a slim case but hadn't snapped it on because frankly, switching cases back and forth to accomodate the twin needs of headphone use and battery charging is a pain in the butt.This case addresses that problem neatly. The permanent slim case affords protection when you want to use your headphones, and you don't have to take it off when you want extra battery life. Yes, it is thicker than a standard Ringke Slim case (my favorite iPhone 5 case) to accomodate the keyhole fit design. Yes, it is thicker than other battery cases because you get to keep your slim case on your phone.But if your problem with the iPhone 5 is the same as mine, where you need extra battery and use headphones a lot, this case is state of the art right now--the ONLY battery case out there that addresses this need.I have an idea that will work, it just depends whether Mophie or someone else will implement it. Mophie addressed this problem with the iPod Touch by integrating a 3.5" plug in the case next to the dock connector, then wiring in a separate 3.5" jack on the case. Yes, that takes up space and adds a little bulk. But for so many of us who have a nice pair of headphones, the status quo is just not acceptable yet.I do like this case. With improvements in battery life to the iPhone 5 (much better than the 4 and 4s), the battery in a case doesn't need to be as large to accomodate travelers and power users. 2k mah is plenty now. I do prefer to carry my phone without the battery case, except on days when I know I'll be traveling or working late.I also did a funny thing--I took a pair of Etymotic HF3 earbuds whose cable had failed, and frankensteined them onto the cable/inline remote of the EarPods that came with the phone. The remote and mic work great, and the phones are COMFORTABLE and great sounding as is the case with all Etymotic products. All I'm missing is Etymotic's high quality mic, which blows the Earpods' junk mic into the weeds. Can't have everything, I guess. The upside is that this pair of Frankenstein buds works with all the battery cases out there now and unlike the Earpods, it sounds good and the buds don't fall out of your ears. I did this because I had the buds to work with and I was so frustrated with not being able to use good headphones with any battery case, including Mophie and other expensive ones out there.This 2-piece solution from Maxboost allows me to use any cans I want, and I have a lot of them, and still retain the option of battery life extension without having to constantly switch cases. It's an intelligent solution for a problem that didn't need to happen. Apple, put the headphone jack on top where it belongs.

There are lots and lots of better blow dryers out there for over $100. There are some that may be slightly better in the $80 range. And there is a teeming universe of crap in the $20-$30 range that we've all owned examples of.I wanted better than box-store quality and will not pay the price for the stuff the pros use. This blow dryer is one of the only ones in that in-between "no man's land" that is too expensive for the average consumer and not quite durable enough for constant professional use.It is a GREAT step up product, with better power and lower noise than the best $30 blow dryers. Especially if you have lots of thick hair, the BaByliss will significantly cut your mirror time and will give most a better feel to their hair.What a difference ten bucks makes. Other manufacturers should follow suit and give this dryer some competition. Right now the only competition it has is from products that cost way more.

I hate plastic crap. I should despise this cabinet, but I don't. While my house is for sale in PA, we are renting in RI and must keep expenses low. Needed extra storage space in the kitchen, utility closet and garage. After looking at all the large-cabinet options at the home stores and online, found this one on Amazon and checked around.Found the exact same item at Wally's for $79 so I bought one to see what it was like.Yes, when we buy a home, we'll be going with standard plywood and veneer cabinet construction, granite countertops, etc.But between now and then, these plastic wonders are really getting the job done far better than I anticipated achieving with the budget I had.If you are on a shoestring, this is a product you should check out.And by all means, shop for it on price--you can probably pick it up at your local W**-M**t for eighty bucks.

These are not the last word in bass.Okay, that caveat aside, I have nothing else but good to say about them. They do have good low end, just not tipped up like so many people want. They actually have quite flat response across the audible range and are very musical.iPhone features:  the remote works perfectly and the mic just might be the best inline mic available from any manufacturer. If you spend a lot of time on the phone you're going to like these.Portability is great. With the Shure olive tips attached, the comfort is outstanding as well. Cord length is about perfect. I'd say for the money these are just outstanding. I have a few comparably priced IEMs whose sound I prefer. But none of them have the inline mic and multifunction inline remote.So...these are my favorite under-$200 iPhone IEMs.

Goes up and down fast and travels well. Easy to use at the beach and at the park, and does not take up too much room in the trunk. Fourth of July picnics are so much better with one of these. We chose this one because its white color sheds more sunlight, and it has optional walls. A great item.

Like most, I have suffered through my share of cheap Chinese fuel cans. They are of the very lowest possible quality to get past the safety inspectors, and the safety nozzles never work.No-Spill nozzles are great, and their cans are very high quality. Ever since I found them I have switched all my outdoor power equipment mixes to these cans. No more hands stinking of gasoline, or fuel on the floor. I showed one to my mechanic and now everybody in his shop has them too.Highest recommendation--worth every penny.

...but they sound like crap.I am not terribly demanding of my headphones, but this particular pair does not make the grade. No bass to speak of, highs are not there, everything else is tinny.But my 12-year-old thinks they're the shizznits, so...four stars.

Road warriors with a lot of gear need one of these. Not only can you plug this into your car's aux electrical outlet.This one is equipped with a hardwiring option so you can place it in the system with its own fuse block and leave your stock outlets free.I did that, mounting this outlet block inside my car's center bin to give me charging options for phones, tablets, Kindles, cameras, etc. that will fit inside the bin and charge there.YMMV but if you're starting with this gadget and install it correctly you will have the charging options you need.

Did I say this was soft? Fluffiest fleece throw I've ever seen. Steelers gear, because of the color scheme, can be some of the ugliest stuff out there. This blanket is not only soft and fluffy and warm, it is also almost nice-looking. Not my daughter's fault that she picked a team with ugly colors.It could be worse-she could be a Packers fan.I, on the other hand, have been waiting a couple of years for the Seattle Seahaks blanket. What gives?This thing loses two stars for years-long unavailability of my team.

If you have broadband and dish network, you simply must have one of these. For no extra cost per month, you can view all of your dish programming, including items on your DVR, anywhere you have an Internet connection, including your phone or tablet, as well as any Internet connected computer screen.For me, setup was a breeze. It was just plug in, follow the menu and Bam. I was watching stuff with my iPad. No more wondering what's happening in the game while I'm out with my family. I can check in from the dish app on my phone.Really like this thing.

Yes, I know the swing-a-way type openers last longer. I know this one will eventually have a hard time opening cans and have to be discarded. Even so, it works so well that I am willing to buy a new one to replace the one I just threw away. I just think of it as a wear item.Much easier to crank than any other side opening can opener I have found. Easy to use. Compact and easy to store. I have not found a better can opener anywhere.

Arcoa's E-Z Reachers are the class of a crowded field. They produce a wide variety of lengths, with some more delicate than others to suit for the intended task.I use this one down in the laundry area in the basement--the basement stairs are our "laundry chute," so we always have a pile of clothes on the floor there. I can pick up anything and everything with this guy, from little nylon stockings and footie socks to jeans--though my preferred method with jeans is to grab the end of a leg and bring it to my open hand, then toss them into the rolling laundry cart. It's capable of lifting jeans, but it's easier to do them this way.I live on a main thoroughfare and have neighbors with big old oaks, so before mowing I always have to pick up branches and sometimes a piece of litter thrown from a car. I use the E-Z Reacher Outdoor Pro with rubber cups instead of silicone for the yard. The stainless "fingers" are a bit sturdier so it can lift more weight, and the rubber tips are better suited to heavier items, not so much little delicate things.I started my Pikstik journey with one of those folding things from TV, bought at Wal-Mart. It was fantastic for about a week and then it broke. So I bought a Pikstik and though it is more durable it has some design flaws that make it less useful for me. I keep it in the kitchen now--still very useful for my high shelves.After the Pikstik showed me what was possible I started doing some real research. There's a trash picker called the Grappler that is really good for outdoor work; almost got one of those. But since this E-Z Reacher worked so well helping me with the constant chore of laundry, I decided to go with the heavy duty version for outside. I can see where if I had bigger stuff to move the Grappler-style hawk beak picker would be better. But for what I do this is ideal--though with some heavier garments I sometimes wish I'd opted for the shorter 24-inch model of this same tool for increased leverage and less fatigue to my forearms.Realize when you use one of these things, they can't do everything. Heavy items are beyond the scope of this type of tool, as are large or awkwardly-shaped items. You can pick up a tennis ball with this, not a football. If you misuse it, it is possible to break it, though staying within its parameters, I don't see it happening.Arcoa's stuff is lightweight, but much heavier duty than most of their competition. They also sell replacement silicone or rubber tips that screw right on, so your main wear item is fully replaceable. If you need something heavier-duty than this, they have a "pro" model like the one I use outdoors. Anything sturdier than that, those products are out there, but most of them are not listed in the "home health aid" category but in professional sanitation-worker equipment catalogs. If you are looking for a reach aid in your home, you have found the best all-around tool.Be sure to look at their entire range of products, choose one with the replaceable rubber or silicone suction cup tips, and choose the one that looks best for your needs. I went for the heavier 'Pro' model for outside, and sometimes I use it inside as well. But it uses a little more hand strength and is slightly heavier. This lighter model puts less strain on the forearm and hand muscles, and has more than enough strength to do the job I bought it for.Five stars for me.

Everybody with a riding mower has something like this--the lightweight mower for getting under trees and around fenceposts, tight bed edges, mailboxes, creek slopes and edges with dropoffs your rider doesn't like. The lighter the better, because if you're using it to mow the grass around your creek you don't need any extra weight. I can get the whole job done--riding my 3/4 acre, trimming the weird spots, weed whacking and blade edging, sweeping up and blowing the excess back into the lawn, in about an hour. A lightweight trim mower really adds to the speed and ease of the job. This one has been reliable and as simple as I want it to be.It can be your main mower if you have less than a quarter acre of mowable grass. Good power, good looking cut. I personally prefer a mulching deck to side discharge for that though. Doesn't matter for small trim jobs, but if I were looking for a main mower I'd be looking for a mulcher.

I use these in my Oldsmobile along with their sister hi-beam bulbs. Their color temperature is several degrees cooler than the stock halogens, which means you don't get as good performance in foggy conditions as with halogens. But for 99 percent of the time they're much better, and their fog performance is fine. I installed the hi/lo version of these in my wife's older Infiniti, and replaced the stock fog lamps with PIAA yellows, which really cut through the fog.I like them because not only do I get added visibility but they also aren't blue like so many of the lights you see on cars that get the "brother package." So you can tell the lights are upgrades and you don't immediately assume a teenager is at the wheel. If you are looking for bright white light, you've found it.

The neo-retro, laceless funkiness of these shoes fit my kid's tomboy look to a 't.' I had to return the first pair for a half-size larger, but that is more due to a growing kid than to any weirdness in sizing with these shoes.She loves them and wears them as one of her main fashion statements. They have decent comfort and are Converse All-Stars for real, even if they're more low profile than the originals.Your kid will probably like the look of these. You might, too.

When I mow the lawn, I have an iPod Shuffle that requires inline controls to work. The HF3's Apple control works perfectly. The isolation provided by the triple flange tips means I can put the volume at a very moderate level, and the drone of the mower is nearly inaudible. So they actually protect my hearing.Sound quality is great--a lot of bassheads hate these, but then the stuff they like sounds like muddy boom-boom to me, so I guess there's no accounting for taste. If your taste in sound runs more to Musical Fidelity and Mark Levinson than to Sony or Skullcandy, you might like these quite a bit more than the phones the bassheads prefer. They are not the last word in resolution or bass response, but they are mobile phone IEMs that have an inbuilt mic of exceptional quality (Ety is, after all, a hearing-aid manufacturer), good noise isolation, and a very good price/performance ratio.You can buy other headphones with slightly better sound for the $125 you're likely to spend on these, but not with an inline Apple remote. Hell, I own a few buds that cost significantly less but are just as enjoyable to listen to as these, without inline controls and mic. At this price point, these are pretty much the best you can get in Apple buds and they are very good indeed.I took the EarPods that came with my iPhone and snipped off the drivers--they sound fine but are excruciating in my ears and fall right out as well. But the cord was what I was after. Took the cord from the complimentary Apple buds, and soldered the drivers from my JVC HA-FXC80 to it right below the earhooks. The JVCs cost me $33 and after some EQ they sound very, very fine--maybe as good as these Ety IEMs at a quarter of the price. I use them a lot because they are way more comfortable than these Etys with rubber sleeves. They can't compete in isolation, though. When I'm using a mower or traveling by plane, I take the Etys and enjoy the silence. And if comfort is an issue, Shure Olives fit just fine on these so for the price of some isolation (but still way better than my JVC/Apple Frankenbuds) you can have a very comfortable fit and great, great sound.So if great sound and isolation without EQ or the work of modification are worth the extra hundred bucks to you, this Ety is worth your consideration. For comfort, the Shure sleeves are fantastic. Worth the price for me, and they are the most expensive buds I own. I've listened to some really expensive Shure IEMs, and they sound better. But do they sound $300 better? For you they might, but not for me--and their inline mic/remote setup is only a one-button affair that you have to buy separately.There are a lot of big phones with inline mics you can try for this price. I stay away from them because when I'm home I just listen to my vinyl on my big KEFs, and when I'm out I wouldn't know where to put a big clunky pair of over-the-ear phones. So I'm an IEM guy. If your preferences are like mine, you should give these an audition.UPDATE: I accidentally ran these through the wash yesterday. I went through my pants pockets and forgot the velcro cargo pocket on the thigh. The small filters kept the water from reaching the balanced armature drivers, but I had my doubts about the survival of the mic and inline controls--and wouldn't have been at all surprised if there'd been no sound coming through the right side where the remote is.Put them in and...sound from the right but not the left! A quick filter change and I got great sound--indistinguishable from new. The play/pause button worked, but the volume controls were dead and the mic was non-functional. Decided to let them sit overnight and dry out. This morning the volume controls work normally and so does the mic! So lucky me--except for an early death for a pair of filters and a pair of Shure Olive eartips, these things came through with flying colors.I do not recommend doing anything as stupid as running a $150 set of IEMs through the wash. But I'm happy to report a near miss with these--everything still works.

First off, there are NO cheap earbuds that sound right without EQ, and many whose sound will not really be improved even when you EQ the hell out of them. The JVC Micro HD driver, fortunately for headphone abusers everywhere, is EQable to a very fine degree. The C80 is even more EQable than the workhorse Micro-HD C51, itself a really great budget earbud.Out of the box, the midbass on all Micro HD phones is overboosted. The low bass below about 35 Hz is a bit lacking because of the design of the tiny in-ear driver. Both of these situations can be fixed with a parametric EQ such as Accudio Pro for iOS. The guys at Accudio, with their calibrated mics in a B&K head dummy, have even provided a custom "flat" EQ curve just for this model. I found it a bit sterile by itself so I boosted the low bass band just half a notch.Any electronic EQ is going to introduce artifacts into the sound and Accudio Pro, while designed and maintained by music lovers, still adds a tiny bit of hiss to the mix. Inaudible except in the very softest passages, the real improvement you can get out of a cheap pair of C80s on an iPhone or iPod Touch with this EQ outweighs that for me.So let the review state that if you enjoy overboosted bass, especially midbass, you might love these right out of the box. I love them because their sound isn't so far from flat that a good EQ can't render their sound very, very fine.I love the earhooks that come in the package. Although they make insertion more difficult, the over-the-ear position kills almost all cord microphonics endemic to in-ear designs. Meaning you won't hear every movement of the cord thumping through your skull. Also, the driver design means that for some people these will try to work their way gradually out of the ear canal, and the earhooks are effective at preventing that.What these lack is an option to buy with an inline 3-button remote and mic. Lucky me, Apple included a pair of their new Earpods with the iPhone 5, and while those sound fine they don't fit my ears at all. But the cord and mic are great. So I got out my trusty soldering iron, some shrink tubing and a heat gun, and made my dream cheap iphone buds by frankensteining the JVC drivers onto the Apple cord. It works magnificently. And my kid has a pair of Earpods with a black cord!Once again--out of the box, these are fine, sound great for a pair of $35 buds. Hard to find anything better at this price point. But after searching for quality EQable inexpensive IEMs for years, and owning a rather large collection of them, I can tell you that this is the best sub-$100 IEM after EQ that I have ever tried, and in this configuration it sounds comfortably better than a lot of IEMs that cost $150 or more, even if you EQ them too. So if you are willing to do the work to get these to sound good, they can sound very, very good. Earhooks make them fit securely and comfortably, without annoying cord noise. And if you have a cheapo pair of Apple buds that suck but include an inline mic and remote, these cheap buds are not above a head-swapping mod, which is very straightforward. Just leave enough pigtail to get the earhooks on, if you want them, and measure the Apple cord so the mic hangs where it can pick up your voice right, and there you go--for a little work, a free "donor pair" of Apple buds, and some EQ, your $35 bought you a pair of IEMs that can compete in the $200 price range.So I think these are a steal. If you love your music but are as unwilling as I am to spend hundreds of dollars on earphones, these can be a great solution for you.

...about 1.5 cheers for Carson's version of science. It is demonstrably true that "Silent Spring" lent the popular political voice that led to the worldwide ban of DDT and the subsequent deaths of millions upon millions of primarily black children in Sub-Saharan Africa.It is also apparent from her own words that Carson understood the tremendous humanitarian catastrophe that would result from a ban of DDT and it was devastating to her. So to those who call her "the Hitler to the black race" I say walk a mile in her shoes before you pass judgment.However, to those still living who also understand the untold human suffering and death brought about by the unthinking environmental stampede to ban DDT because of Silent Spring, and who consider those millions of dead black children an acceptable price for Eco-purity, I don't know what to say.I do note that, though she wished it were not so, the most enduring impact and legacy of the whole body of Carson's work remains the Sub-Saharan Negro Holocaust of malaria victims, and any book on her legacy that omits this elephant in the room fails somewhat in its mission--unless the mission is hagiographic in nature, intended to whitewash the worst of this most influential environmentalist's effect on our world. If that is indeed the mission, one must judge this book to be a success.

This is the do-it-all brush for your kitchen sink. Soft enough to safely clean nonstick surfaces, stiff enough to get most dried on crud before it goes into the dishwasher. I rarely use a scouring pad anymore, and the dishwasher is going in record time. I will always have one of these hanging by the sink.
Now this app almost has the functionality of LDS Stake, which the church bought out. Keep developing, Mormon nerds. You're getting there.

I'm not crazy about the sound, size, shape or color of these buds. The 3-button remote is poorly executed with terrible tactile feedback. You basically have no idea whether you are increasing/decreasing volume or pausing playback/answering the phone.That said, my daughter claimed them almost immediately and she loves their fit, look and sound plus their remote control of the iPod Touch.So a winner even though I didn't like them. I guess you might love them or not, depending whether you are closer to her than to me on these. For this price you may as well find out.

We have one of these in each 72 hour kit, one in each car. As compact and useful as it is, there is no reason you shouldn't have one too. If we never need it, hooray. But better to have and not need than need and not have.

Are there more protective cases out there? Sure, if you want to carry a huge lump instead of a thin, light phone you paid for.If the other junk in your purse is the main threat to your iPhone, this case in your favorite color plus a good quality screen protector is perfect.

If you have some shrimp in the freezer, then with a few crushed peanuts and some pea pods and a zucchini you can stir-fry up a super-fast lunch or dinner with this sauce.Is it the same as those great street wok carts in Bangkok? Umm, no.  But real fish sauce and decent tamarind paste are a little hard to come by in central PA, and this is a very good commercial alternative. Plus every street vendor makes their sauce a little different anyway. No two are the same yet it's all pad Thai. Taste of Thai also makes good stir fry rice noodles for pad Thai. Vary your veggies for what's fresh, pad Thai is more about the noodles and sauce anyway. Some of the best pad Thai I've ever had didn't have any veg in it. Hell, I like this stuff just with noodles and shrimp. Squeeze a little lime juice on it at the table and it's great, or crush a few peanuts and chop some cilantro to go with it. Love the pea pods though, and thin slicing or julienning a carrot in there is not a bad idea.Just make sure you only stir fry ONE SERVING AT A TIME. Trying to stir fry more than that releases so much liquid from your meat and veg that you wind up stir poaching them instead. This sauce is great stuff for an easy and delicious pad Thai at home.

I'm a dedicated iPad retina owner, and I love it for its window on the web. Its Kindle app is quite usable and the extra size can be nice. But what it isn't is portable in a lot of cases. Sure you can lug an iPad around, but in certain circumstances it is cumbersome, or you just don't want an $800 device on you, like at the park or the beach. Reading on the iPad is nice in a recliner where you can rest the beast on your torso, or at your desk where you can lay it down on the angled smart cover. In bed it sucks. The Paperwhite is the best thing to happen to in-bed readers since The Clapper.This is a great device. I personally love the implementation of the LED lights with the high tech light diffusion screen material. I don't require a perfectly even white page; I require sufficient reading light. If you want a Kindle with perfectly even color, turn on the light in your room or go outside in the sunshine. If you need a light up Kindle with perfectly even color, the Kindle Fire HD will do that for you, plus a lot more besides. Battery life is not so great, but you do get other benefits with it being an Android based tablet. You can use the Kindle app on the tablet you already have. But if you read good old-fashioned paper books, you'll notice there is a play of light and shadow that causes uneven color on the page in almost every possible reading situation. The perfection some seek has only become possible because of computer screens. If you find variations in color "distracting," it's a wonder you ever read anything at all before books became available on backlit displays.This is my third Kindle e-ink reader, and my umpteenth Kindle when you count daughter's Kindle Fire and the multiple Kindle apps on phones, computers, PDAs and tablets over the years. We own a Kindle 2 which is still going strong, as well as a latest-gen Kindle Touch. We are a Kindle family. I bought the Paperwhite because there are multiple comfy chairs in my house that do not have sufficient reading light, and the Kindle Fire is "not mine." Very happy with the lighting on the display. The fact that there are multiple lights shining on it is not the least bit distracting for me as it seems to be with some nit pickers. But I do have my own nit to pick, having spent twenty bucks to opt out of Kindle's ad-supported discount program.I got my paperwhite, got it all updated with the Kindle library locally on the device, went to the home screen to choose a book, and there was an ad for "Fifty Shades of Sex Perversion" right there where I would never dream of placing the actual e-book. Annoyed, I chose my book and got to reading, thoroughly enjoying the reading experience.But next time I went to choose a book, there was Fifty Shades of Crap again. Now I was getting mad. I did some research and found that for a while after the Paperwhite's introduction, owners were unable to turn these ads ("recommendations") off. But by the time I got the gadget, it had a software revision that allowed me to go into settings and disable the ads.So interesting that you can pay for an 'ad free' product and they put ads in your face. Then when users complain about the deception, they say "Oh, we've updated the software so you can turn those ads off now. We made you pay twenty bucks so you can have the option of going into settings and clicking the opt-out button." Now, there are people for whom ads make no difference at all. Just tune 'em out. They can easily deal with the page space being crowded by advertising. Others flat out will not deal with it because it wrecks their Kindle experience. Not that Amazon is so stupid they need this advice, but here goes:Dear Amazon,The extra 20 bucks I sent you is your clue that I'm opting out of ads on my Kindle. For 20 bucks a pop you can write the software so that ads are an opt-in instead of an opt-out--or just pay some min-wage monkey to go into the Kindle's settings and opt out before you ship the device to me. I don't care what you do. But don't do this again. Don't send me a Kindle with ads on it when I'm paying for a Kindle with no ads on it. I already opted out. Don't make me do it over again. Makes your company look stupid and greedy rather than brilliant, which is what the Paperwhite is.Bottom line...happy customers, happy company. Especially when it costs you nothing to do it right.

The leather is high quality, the fit is snug and correct, the magnetic closure sleeps the iPad every time and holds the cover shut, the "stand" feature works in both steep and shallow modes, the feel and smell are right, the velvet bag the item comes in is a bonus, my New iPad feels secure and protected. It's just bulky enough to give that protection, not too heavy and not in the way. Based on the quality of this cover I got one for my Kindle Fire also from Bear Motion. It was the same materials and basic design, and came on sale for $9.95 with free 2-day shipping from Amazon Prime.So now I have matching cases for the 2 gadgets. I used the iPad for Kindle reading until I put this case on the Kindle--now the Kindle Fire has something to hold on to and it's actually more comfortable to use with the case on it. Too bad the Kindle Fire doesn't have the iPad's magnetic sleep feature.Based on my experience with these two products, any tablet I get in the future will get its own Bear Motion case.

Elis Regina was a premier jazz singer on any continent. The fact that she was able to be firmly within both the jazz tradition and the Brazilian traditions says much about how much Brazilian music influenced jazz, how much jazz turned around and influenced Brazilian music, and how excellent Elis was at being the hinge, along with Tom Jobim and others, that connected the two traditions and showed them off together.This collection gives you a great flavor of her sound and abilities. If you speak Portuguese and have lived in Brasil these songs will be familiar even though you may not have heard them. They are quintessentially Brazilian.I am glad I found this collection.

Expensive for this type of item, but it's really going to last you a long time.Well-made, heavy gauge and just enough embellishment to be somewhat decorative without being fruity. Good for a man's yard or a woman's garden--an item you two can agree on.Also, it's very easy to move from place to place, which can be a big deal for many and really good for bringing it in during winter months. Easy to mow around. Holds a hundred foot hose with a lot of room to spare.If you like the look of it in the pictures, you'll like it in your yard too. It's pretty much the hefty thing you see in the pics.

I am TERRIBLE about facial care. Cleansers, creams, collagen and a thousand other non- C-words are just the type of the iceberg of things I am clueless about. Some of it (like makeup) are because I'm that balance between "Not Giving a Darn" and "I Prefer Sleep Thankyouverymuch"; others (such as facial cleansers), it's because I'm good old fashioned lazy.So while I'm probably not the best person to judge this, based on a counter full of similar competing cleansers, I can at least give a beginner's opinion of the product. And that one is: it seems to do the job nicely, cleaning my skin, clearing up blemishes, yet having a clean, pleasant smell and washing out nicely.The smell is particularly pleasant - light "ocean" or "fresh air" scented. I love that it's a scent without being too "in your face". Application was easy; the bottle delivers a small dime-sized amount which is more than enough to properly wash your face. The texture is smooth and dense, so it's probably better to lather in your hands before applying to the face. Regardless, it goes on smooth and clean. Rinsing is likewise easy; it doesn't slide off with one splash of water, but neither does it stay on like a mask.I definitely enjoyed this product for the time I've used it. The only "problem" is that, given my history with washing my face, I don't know that the price (now unavailable, but I swore I saw $17) would be worth it. I tend to be that person who buys beauty products, uses them a couple of times, realizes what a pain in the rear they are and forget about them for 6 months before the cycle returns. I guess if you have very sensitive skin or are concerned with your skin because of makeup and such, then this would be a good investment.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

Spending time in England this past summer gave me a deeper appreciation for tea - I mean, growing up, drinking it properly also helped, but England has some AMAZING teas that really make me love drinking tea nearly as much as drinking coffee.This tea was pretty good. It was flavorful and tasty - even if it came across as a bit bitter (my steeping method, perhaps, which involves me leaving the tea bag in the cup until I remember to remove it?). The weirdest part, though, was that a lot of tea seemed to leak from the bags and pile up at the bottom - like a fine sandy type "film". I've never seen tea bags do this - tea leaves, duh, it's somewhat inevitable. But I thought the point of bags was to keep the tea out of your cup?I wouldn't mind drinking this brand again, but this will not be my go-to brand like Twinings or Steven Smith Lord Bergamot or Ahmad tea.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

About the most jewelry I wear is earrings. I love earrings - particularly dangly ones. But being a somewhat / part-time girly-girl, I also have expanded my jewelry collection to necklaces and earrings. Being a nerdy girl means that things like the Pi symbol and the Infinity symbol also make me squeal.Pros:+ I love the rose gold color of the necklace! Gold itself is so harsh; my favorite is copper, but rose gold is a close second.+ The pendant is fun and cute! I love that it's just a plain Infinity symbol and not with a bunch of words like "Forever Love" or something else that means you can only wear this is your are in some committed relationship.Cons:+ The chain is flimsy as heck. It's so delicate and thin that I thought I would break it just by holding it.+ Similarly, the clasp is tiny and hard to put on. I had to ask my sister to put it on the first time. The second, I had to bring it to the front so I could see what my hands were doing.+ It hangs oddly. Due to how the chain is connected to the Infinity Symbol, there is the potential for the symbol to be lopsided and look rather strange.Honestly, while I like the concept and the rose gold, I don't really like the necklace itself. As I said above, the chain is so delicate and tiny, I feel like if I sneeze, it'll break. The chain is also very short, so it's nearly a choker (well, not really, but it's a lot higher than most necklaces I wear). And I certainly would NOT have paid the $20+ that it is currently (November 4, 2015) selling at on Amazon.com.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I run, and after a run, I'll occasionally partake in a smoothie or protein shake.This shake is MESSY. The bad is impossible to seal, even with the "Ziplock" at the top, so look forward to a film of white powder over everything. Especially after digging inside this bag for the spoon.The back says to use 8 - 12 ounces of water per cup of powder. My running partner and I used 10 oz at first, and I gagged several times. Admittedly, his snarky warning, "This doesn't taste like soy AT ALL" didn't help, I'm sure, but the taste is pretty - THERE. And it wasn't one of the flavors and textures I find appealing. I did drink all 10 oz, but man, that was a chore!The second time I partook (once again with running partner), I tried to do only 8oz. This time it had the texture of pudding - but nowhere near that lovely taste. I had to add water, it was just too hard to pour and swallow. I managed to only gag once, early on in the endeavor. My running partner, however, powered through and chugged the whole thing.I suppose if you are vegan, well, this might be it or nearly it for you if you want a protein drink. In that case - I'd probably recommend just making a kale smoothie. I mean, this stuff did blend well (with those blender cups), but the taste and texture combination was awful. When the best thing you can say about it was, "At least I gagged only once" - maybe it's just not for you.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I'm not like super experienced with earbuds, but I've owned more than a few brands in my day. The critical components of a good set of earbuds is pretty obvious: sound quality and sturdiness followed by price. (For me, it's also the color, as I love pink, but beggars can't be choosers.) And if you are judging Lenovo earbuds by those qualities, well, they end up firmly in the middle.They are about $20, so that puts them in the "modest priced" category - above the "I just need a pair to ignore that kid on the plane and I left mine at home" set. And for a $20, they are decent. Quality is OK - not sure what they mean by "extra bass" because I don't hear it. (Am I already deaf or do I not have the EAR for that? Get it?! "EAR for it"?!!) I have zero use for the microphone, but the play/pause button works for the iPod classic from 3000 years BC (aka, the one I bought in the late 2000's), so there's that. It's weird to have the cord be long and thin, but I haven't found too many awful tangles. Maybe also it will stand up better to use and not crack near the plug?! We can dream, right?This set comes with a weird flexible plastic thingie that I guess you use to wrap them up when not in use? I don't know, I've never used it for anything but a fidgeting tool. Also, this has three different size ear inserts, though I always use medium. The fit of the earbud in my ears is weird, and even though I do nothing but sit with them in, they are constantly falling out. I shudder to think what would happen should I use them on a treadmill!If you want a set for listening to an audiobook, this isn't a bad one to go with. It's also decent with music, though I wouldn't brag about "extra bass". Also, if you have a use for the microphone feature, it's probably gonna work for you too. And I'll keep an eye on the cord, see how that long, lean feature works. As for me, there are just enough "mehs" and "I don't care"s about this product, that I probably wouldn't rush out to buy a new one, should this one go bad.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

This is a review in two parts: a review on Poo-Pourri the product in general and Poo-Pourri the Rose Geranium scented product specifically.When I first saw that infamous commercial, I was really intrigued! Not only was the commercial HILARIOUS (saw it again recently and near about died with laughter), but it also brought to light a concern we all have: post-pooing bathroom smells. My household always used the Fresh Scent Lysol, which didn't do much to mask the putrescence, but did make me violently hate Fresh Scent (leading me to call it the "Who took a s@#$" scent).Could Poo-Pourri work?Well, people, I've used it and it DOES work! Spritz 3-5 sprays (I use 5) and no more poo smell! It's amazing!What about the Rose Geranium scent, though? How does that turn out? Is that a better scent than, say, Fresh Scent?Well, yes and no. The Rose Geranium scent ought to be called "Citrus" - I couldn't smell a whiff of Roses or Geraniums AT ALL in the bottle. It smelled overwhelmingly like an orange or lemon grove. Not bad - unless you forget how to open the bottle and spill a ton on the floor (Not saying *I* did that!). Then it's somewhat nauseating.Poo-Pourri is definitely a product I'll be carrying around and keeping in the bathroom. The Rose Geranium scent, though, I can't really recommend for people who are looking for Roses or Geraniums - unless my olfactory senses are perhaps broken. For that reason, I've removed a star from what otherwise would have been a 5 star product.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I have had the pleasure of trying AHAVA products in the past, specifically Ahava Dead Sea Water Mineral Hand Cream, which I loved. Not too surprisingly, all of that cream is gone, and the opportunity to review a new product by AHAVA appeared - the Dead Sea Essentials Witch Hazel Hand Cream. How would it compare?Well, AHAVA has done it again with another smashing product. I love the scent, I love the texture, I love the feeling - not greasy at all, yet my hands feel smooth and moisturized. It works fine with my psoriasis - about the only "problem" is that this is a large container that cannot fit easily into a purse for transportability!AHAVA has knocked it out of the park twice; I can't wait to try another of their products!Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I'm sometimes terrible about taking multi-vitamins but I really do try. I know that I need the extra calcium and Iron (my doctor has told me so), so I though I'd check this out as it had bonus points of those.The first thing I find a little odd is that this product boasts about helping "hair, skin, and nails". This is great - who doesn't want healthy shimmery hair? - but it also seems just a little superficial. I don't need model lustrous hair, thank you, and neither do I need obscenely long nails. And while the skin is important, if it's going to start bragging about smoothing those lines and all, well, whatever. I should THINK the most important part of a vitamin is providing nutrients to run your heart, lungs, brain, and digestive system, but what do I know. Maybe it IS all about the hair.Anyway, so the direction said to take 2, so initially I took 2 at a time. That was probably my first big mistake - I noticed almost immediately that my, erm, urine was a fluorescent yellow. That made me alert that I was probably getting more vitamins than I needed. (As to taking 2 at once, in my defense, all the package says is to take 2 a day and with meals. I probably should have known better, but I am a dense one.)From that point, I cut down to 1 a day. I STILL noticed a yellowing in my urine, though nowhere near as pronounced.Perhaps it's just me, that my body is already getting all the nutrients or enough that most of this just comes right back out; I'm a little sad because this product has a lot of iron, and us ladies need that iron. I'll keep trying to stick to 1/day and see what happens; however, unless things change greatly in the future, I doubt I would buy this product again.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

Brookside Dark Chocolate Blueberry with Acai were a tasty treat that made a good satiating snack. All too often these types of bars are either more laden with sugars and fats than a Snickers bar or they taste something like corrugated cardboard. But these Brookside bars tread that line between tasty and healthy pretty well.I like to have some sweet and salty in my bars, and this is exactly what I got. I enjoyed the blueberry flavor (that seemed more pronounced than Acai) as it was definitely unique; most bars seem to be either strawberry or raspberry. The chocolate resonates well with the berry, and there is just enough salt to balance the sweet.Nutrition facts-wise, I was pleased. It was about 180 calories with 9g of total fat and 22g of carbs with 13g of sugar. I prefer bars with a little less than 20g of carbs at that calorie range, but it is a hard combination to find them and to find ones that taste GOOD. This product does have nuts in it but it is gluten-free for those with Celiac's or a gluten intolerance. (I am not gluten intolerant; finding healthy bars sometimes means eating gluten free.) And it's really nice to see a product with ALMONDS and DARK CHOCOLATE as the first two ingredients, instead of sugar and hydrogenated corn syrup.I would not be opposed to buying these in the future. I liked them, and my sister liked them as well. They are a bit pricey though (almost $24/box of 12 right now on Amazon).Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

Why do we cat owners continually buy these cute products for our cats when our cats just insist on using boxes or snuggling in blankets? I have bought so many of these cute containers, but do my two cats ever use them? HAH! They'd rather just play in the box they came in.This short cat post is like a lot of the posts and toys I buy for my cats - attractive to me, undesirable to them. The assembly was easy enough, even though I don't find the top platform to be sturdy enough at all for either of my cats (the clumsy one or the skittish one).As for using this, neither cat really touches it. Occasionally one or the other sits on the bottom platform, but other than that, they have zero interest in it - sitting, scratching or climbing. I've placed them near the post, tried to play around it - nothing.The next step I could take is to coat in catnip and to move it around. That could help. But as of today, neither cat really likes it - a shame, because it seems like a decent post.UPDATE (08/28/15): I absolutely MUST update and revise my rating because last night AND this afternoon, one of my cats used this as a perch! I did NOT expect this! So this wasn't a complete bust after all!Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I've owned like 3 or 4 blow driers in my time. I'm not so good about consistently using them because I'm lazy. Well, I also know how harsh blow-drying can be on hair (particularly colored like mine), so I tend to avoid it. But every so often (more so in the winter), I find I need to dry my hair quickly instead of waiting. My last hair dryer died in a blaze of glory - well, actually it more or less fizzled and refused to turn on. So when this popped up in my Vine selection, I selected it.This Remington hair dryer comes with attachments - one, a diffuser, that looks like an alien product (apparently used for curly hair), and a funnel appendage that reminds me of an airplane wind tunnel. I don't have curly hair so I didn't bother with the diffuser (I really wish it had not been included because all it does it take up valuable drawer space), but I did test out the Wind Tunnel (much as I like pretending it's a wind tunnel for miniature airplanes, I would like to know, what is this thing called really?).I love all the settings! My last hair dryer pretty much had hi-lo, hot-cold and that was it. This has 3 heat settings and 2 speeds along with a cold blast setting, allowing for a more controlled drying experience. I found it really dried my thick, wavy hair well (another reason why I hate drying my hair - it usually takes 30 minutes for it to be all dry) and relatively quickly. The Wind Tunnel also helped to ensure nice, smooth, straight hair - the way I like to style my hair.Overall, I'm impressed and pleased. I wish that the diffuser hadn't been included because I have no need for it and the space it takes up BUT I know that those with curly hair may appreciate it.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I fell in love with all things space at the ripe old age of 11. I found a science textbook talking about space and started planning out my future like teenaged girls stereotypically plan out weddings. I would go to college and get my master's in aerospace engineering (learning Russian alongside it) then work at NASA where they would assign me as a mission specialist on a mission to Mars. I even had my little script of what I would say on Mars planned out. (In addition, I would fall in love with this equally smart guy who supported me and went along with me on the mission to keep me company.) I predicted all this would happen - well, now.Obviously, life does NOT go like you plan at 11. I'm not stepping on Mars reciting my fabulously eloquent lines about how awesome it is to step on Mars, I don't work for NASA, and I didn't learn Russian (I know, I'm sad about that one too).But I still have a soft spot for Mars. I still desperately want humans to reach out and go to Mars - even if it makes more economic and scientific sense to send robots. There is just something awesome about a group of people banding together for a peaceful goal that I love. It's what I pretend was going on during the American Lunar missions; I like to think something like this could still happen today, amidst the stupid Real Housewives reality shows and Adam Sandler's latest insult to humanity.Mary Roach's "Packing for Mars" hinted that it might look at all the details needed to go to Mars. Well, the title anyway - the cover blurb makes it a bit more clear it's just about all the weird things in space that we take for granted on Earth.And that's primarily what "Packing for Mars" is - a book about the strange way we work in space. Psychologically, biologically, and...biologically. Don't get me wrong, there was some fascinating stuff in here, about how people react in closed quarters to another person for extended time, about not bathing, about sexual relations in space, about eating squares of condensed food and what that does to your bowels, about urinating, about pooing...Okay, okay, there is a LOT about body functions here. A LOT. Did you wonder how astronauts poo? It's here. Did you want to see the evolution of the space toilet? It's here. Did you want to get into the analysis of a stream of urine? Yup, here also. How about dead skin and the stench after not bathing for 2 weeks and wearing a suit? Yuppers.And yet, I'm surprised we didn't discuss more about the massive engineering feat it would be to store enough food and water and oxygen for a THREE YEAR voyage to Mars.I feel that Mary Roach spent SO MUCH time on all the "gross parts" of space flight, she really didn't touch enough on the parts I wanted - what is growing food in space like? Is it viable? How about storing food? Storing "souvenirs" from Mars? What does radiation do? I don't even know, it's just I felt the overwhelming take-away, at the end of the book is just going to the bathroom is gross and dehumanizing and I want to take a 4 hour shower.Roach has a humorous, yet educated tone, which I appreciated. It also was a breeze to read this. But I am knocking down from my initial 4 stars rating because I realized that I have been thinking of this book as "It's okay" not "really liked it".It's a decent book with some interesting information, don't get me wrong. It's just not really what I expected/wanted to read about - a disappointment, because I've been pretty much ecstatic about reading this from the moment I saw it debut in hard cover. To wait so long until I am on vacation reading only books I WANT to read just to find it was "Okay"? Disappointing just doesn't cut it.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I've tried many a protein bar or a health bar in my day, all in the pursuit of staving off hungry while trying to maintain a healthy lifestyle. Some bars have been good, while compromising on nutrition (way too much sugar, calories, salt, fat, etc.); some bars have been okay while having suspicious ingredients; some bars have been interesting while being OK.The pure protein line has been great about maintaining a healthy amount of protein, ensuring that you stay satiated. I've also been pleased with their combination of Nutrition Facts, keeping a relatively low carb/calorie count while also not compromising on taste.The Pure Protein Fruit and Nut Bar will be another go-to bar in the Pure Protein family. Once again, it keeps the protein and taste up while keeping the sugars and carbs manageable. It is a sweet bar, and it can be a little gooey if you eat it when it's warm outside, but it's also delightfully salty and a fun departure from yet another chocolate bar. (I love chocolate, don't get me wrong, but I do also like a little savory/salty.)I would definitely buy this product for myself and include this regularly in my health regimen.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

For the last, oh, five or so years, I've owned a Samsung Blu-Ray player. It has worked pretty good throughout the years - it talks well with the Samsung TV and the Samsung Sound Bar and has had good picture quality. But it's also been rather a pain in the butt - some movies took extreme measures to play (such as "Avatar", which required going to disc menu to circumvent the crazy graphics that were in it or something), connecting to the internet could be hit or miss (even when my crappy internet is working perfectly fine), and the Netflix app is glitchy beyond belief and can't/won't update.So I was excited for an upgrade, even if it weren't a Samsung. And now that I've used it quite extensively over this roasting hot holiday weekend, I don't think I miss the Samsung Blu-Ray Player at all.The LG Player is much smaller than the Samsung - the difference between a trade paperback and a coffee table book. There is a weight difference as well too. Setup is ridiculously easy; connecting to the Internet even easier. The unit was so responsive - none of the muddy, slow moving graphics I was used to from the Samsung. I was able to quickly connect to the Internet and pop into Netflix. The Netflix app was one of the newer ones, like I've seen on my sister's PS4 system. It's so much better than the old one! Pandora works great, YouTube is awesome.But what about actually DVDs/Blu-Rays? No problems there - it ran both easily, no problems.One thing that was a bit irksome was that I tried to download a software update through the Settings, but it said there were none. As soon as I got back to the main menu - it wanted to download an update. Frustrating.I really love this little LG and am immensely pleased with its performance. I don't miss the Samsung at all - that said, I'll update in a few weeks/months with more details as time goes on.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

The new biggest problem of the era: Charging your phone.With phones these days basically being mini-computers and walking around with Star Trek-like data pads, power goes down FAST. And it's a pain to be like, "Okay, let's pull over here at this sketchy location with a plug-in so my phone doesn't die!"Well, if it's just one person, no problem. You can use the charging port in your car. But if there's even two, a fight will ensue over who gets the cord.No more.This cord is great! You get FOUR USB plug-ins - sure, that means you still need the USB, but it's a lot better than 1 USB + 1 cord = 1 phone charging.I have found the charging to be rather quick; I have not yet tested with more than one charging at a time. My sister also has an iPad, which I need to have tested. But I like the versatility, and I like how two of the USB ports can be directed towards the back, in case you have friends riding with you. (Because seriously, giving iPads to kids for every little road trip? "Back in my day, I rode in the back of the car and played the ABC game with license plates! While walking uphill in snow BOTH WAYS to school!")Belkin has been a hit-or-miss brand with me; this is one of their hits.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

The Penderwicks - Rosalind, Skye, Jane, and Batty (what an eclectic bunch of names!) along with Dad and Hound - are vacationing in a cottage at Arundel, the home of Mrs. Tifton and her son, Jeffrey. While they are there, numerous adventures and escapades occur - the discovery of Jeffrey, bunnies, a raging bull, a Garden competition, a birthday party, a secret crush, etc. But the threat above all is this: will Mrs. Tifton send her son to Military School to be like his grandfather?Eons ago (at least, it feels that way now), I wanted a fun summery read and was recommended this (thanks, THT!). Unfortunately, as these go, by the time I bought it, I wasn't itching for a summer read - and it went unread for 3 years. Now, I was traveling and I just HIT that vein where I wanted to read short, fun books and weed through my collection of books such as this.I found this book a fun read, though at times, it sent my eyes a'twitchin'. Don't get me wrong; this was a fun, light-hearted read, and it felt like those books I would read as a child - a classic "any time period" feel where kids acted goofy and silly and sometimes dumb, where summer was full of adventure and possibility.That said, I'm an adult now, not 12, so there were things that I just couldn't blow past. For instance, many of the kids felt oddly aged. Rosalind felt much older than 12, especially crushing on the much older Cagney. Now yes, when I was 12, I was more than capable of crushes, but coupled with the way she acted like the Mom (even more than the Dad acted like a dad), it just felt weird. Speaking of Dad, he was barely present in the book, unless to give encouragement or to be called upon when the girls acted like, well, brats. (Because, yes, some of what they did was truly bratty and wouldn't have happened if there was even a modicum of parental attention.) He was in this so little, I almost wondered why bother writing his character at all (which was, of course, goofy, eccentric dad - yawn!).I didn't care for how Mrs. Tifton and Dexter were treated.
