They have one note, one character and that's it.And what's worse, when Bova attempts to create diversity, much headbanging ensues. I would applaud his non-white characters, his attempt to include women if they weren't SO BLAND! If they actually FELT like non-white, non-American characters, instead of whiteboards painted with green and yellow and orange paint! If the women weren't all grouped into whores or madonnas.And Jaime - God, I hate Jaime. He's our protagonist, which means everything he does is perfect and wonderful. He thinks there is something to be discovered in the Grand Canyon of Mars? The ENTIRE mission plan must be changed so they can investigate - who cares if Patel has other plans that he has spent decades on, nope, gotta follow Jaime's intuition! Jaime can sleep with Ilona, but Eddie sleeping around, even though they aren't in a committed relationship? What a vixen!The other grating part of the story is the ludicrous "Mars virus" that the crew catches.HINT 1: It's not a virus.HINT 2: The meteor shower that happens earlier in the book is the cause of this "virus" - a twist that MIGHT have been clever had the disease NOT been one that takes at least 3 months to actually show signs! And even then, it's nowhere near as deathly as is shown in the book!As for the plot: well, it's dated. A bunch of late 80's/early 90's politics crammed into a scifi book. It was mildly amusing in places, but not very believable or well-done. After awhile, I just wanted it to be OVER.And of course, the only female high-ranking official is a cutthroat b!tch. (I wouldn't have a problem with this if there was more than one female politician - women can be b!tches too after all!)This was narrated by Stefan Rudnicki, who had read the "Something Wicked This Way Comes" that I was greatly underwhelmed with. The good news is that he didn't completely bore me with this book as he had with the previous (Obviously I don't care for Bradbury in audiobook form). The bad news is, his accents are silly, and in one case, he gives a character a Russian accent when the text EXPLICITLY STATES that that character had no discernible accent. FAIL. Still, he does have a soothing voice, and it's not completely grating to listen to.What is most disappointing is just how mediocre this book is. From a science standpoint, everything is sound and very probable. (Now politically, I sincerely doubt the crew would look this multi-national, but that's just me.) The subject is fascinating. It's the characters and plot that just flounder and flail. Boring. Racist. Sexist. Badly written. I will not be returning to Mars or any other planetary location with Ben Bova anytime in the future.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I first encountered Katana in the New 52 Birds of Prey line. I enjoy reading comic books about female superheroes, which aren't very common (though there are more now than I get the impression there used to be), so when I saw this trade, I was intrigued. I had heard Nocenti had a, erm, "iffy" writing style, but I am always willing to give new authors and new books a chance.With this one, I am so glad I got this from the library, though I am ashamed that I made them spend money on it.It is BAD. The writing is pretty awful, the art is all over the place, the plot is incomprehensible, the characters are bland and colorless. It's everything I detest in a comic book.Trying to think about what the worst part of this was, I would have to say the plot. Nocenti seemed to change the plot on a panel-by-panel basis. One panel would feature Killer Croc - then next page would be Jack Ryder. Flip a few more pages and we are fighting Coil. It was just so impossible to follow!Then you have the revolving door of artists that appear in this comic. Cliff Richards and Alex Sanchez were just two of the FIFTEEN artists, pencilers, colorists, and inkers that worked on this trade. I won't profess to have read a LOT of comics, but the ones I have read, there were no where near this many involved in the art. So no WONDER the art was all over the place!This comic was such a trial to get through, I could only read a few pages at a time. And that tended to give me a headache, trying to figure out who that character was, why I should remember so-and-so and to figure out what was going on.Not recommended!Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I am not quite sure what person goes to the store (whether physical or online) looking for bum paper and says, "Hm, you know, I REALLY want my toilet paper to smell. And I REALLY want my toilet paper to smell like chamomile." Personally, when I go to get the paper for down there, I want something soft and something that won't fall apart as I'm taking it off the roll. (I mean, there is NOTHING more annoying than being in that store's bathroom and spending five hours sitting on the john, taking individual pieces of TP off the roll because the sheets are so flimsy and awful.)But someone thought there was a market for toilet paper ROLL scented chamomile. Because technically, the paper isn't chamomile scented (that might create particularly painful problems down there, depending on how sensitive your skin is). No, the roll is scented with chamomile.The thought process I suppose is this: as you take off sheets of the TP, wafts of chamomile shoot out and fill the room with the scent of - chemicals? Because this doesn't smell quite like chamomile. Not sure really WHAT the scent is - or if I would like having this scent all over my bathroom after someone drops one. If I want my bathroom to smell nice, I do want normal people do - I put air fresheners. Or *gasp* clean!Only...that's not how it worked for me. As soon as I opened the package, I was inundated with the chemical smell of faux-momile. You can smell a TEENSY BIT as you unwind from the roll, but then we get to the other problem with this paper, the Most Important Problem:It's ROUGH. This is NOT the most pleasant paper to feel on your bum. It's got the quality of a lot cheaper brands out there (we're talking Store-Brand's-Name TP here), and absolutely nothing like even the cheapest Charmin product (Charmin Basic). This is NOT something I would spend $40 (current Amazon asking price) for 48 double-rolls.I really don't recommend; or I should say, I think the better option, if you are really concerned with scent, is to buy one of those cheap $1 air fresheners and buy some quality SOFT toilet paper. This product is smelly, but not in the pleasant way, scratchy, and rather pricey.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

The year before I moved out, I started to accumulate the various items a person may need when moving into a new apartment. Towels, dishes, utensils - and knives. My first knife set was a $20 bargain from Walmart (don't judge!), with 6 steak knives, a paring knife, a serrated knife, a chef's knife, a santoku (I think), a bread knife, a sharpening rod, and a spatula (yes, a spatula!).But when you pay $20 for a knife set like that, you can't expect much. The handles were wood, so I didn't put them in the dishwasher, but the steel still got stained, they didn't cut so hot even when sharp, and the block they came in was at such an odd angle that you either had to not put them under cabinets or move them every time you grabbed one.This knife set is HEAVEN.There aren't as many knives, but I find I don't miss them. These suckers are SHARP and cut AMAZING. The steak knives slide through chicken with no problem, even when you aren't in the best cutting position. The chef's knife is FANTASTIC! It just slides down cucumbers and zucchinis, giving me some of the thinnest, most even slices I have ever been able to prepare. Cheese is no problem for the chef or santoku knife - and I don't have to worry about brie bunching or crumbling on the blade anymore.The handle give a perfect combination of grip and comfort, and I LOVE how they are not wooden. The blades are sharp and shiny. The block is a gorgeous almost mahogany/cherry color - the picture doesn't reflect the gorgeous texture of the wood. And the angle is slim and PERFECT for fitting under the cabinets!Compared to the $20 I spent for the last set, almost $80 may seem like a lot, but I really think it's worth it. The quality is just there.I'm surprised the only "instructions" are "Handwash with warm soapy water" printed on the box, but otherwise, I have plans to pick up the OXO sharpening rod soon, this set has impressed me so much.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

In November of 2012, I started on the MediFast program to lose what ended up being over 100 pounds. In my health venture, I expanded to eat a lot of different "health" foods and protein bars. Some were very good; some were not so good. Some were healthy; others were not much different than candy. But that balance between "nutritious and healthful" and "just a hair's breadth away from a cheeseburger" can be tough - and then throw in the taste and texture factor (trust me, I got horror stories), then it's a challenge.I've tried Atkins bars and shakes, but never South Beach Diet bars. As bars come, they are pretty good. They are your standard granola-type bar, but nowhere near as sweet as I've tasted (a GOOD thing). They have a nice crunch, good texture. I was not fond of the rich toffee taste, but my sister also tried one and she liked it a lot and said she would definitely eat these again. So...your mileage may vary.I was VERY pleased at the nutrition information. It is hard to find ~100 calorie bars with about 10grams of Carbs and not filled to the brim with sugar and salt (also, 7grams of fiber!). I would take care to look at the package for allergen concerns - I have no milk, soy, or nut allergies, but it looks like there are quite a few of those in these bars.I don't know the price of this item, but I think a reasonable price of ~$6 would make me definitely pick these up again (this is MUCH LESS than I typically spend on MediFast or other brands of bars). The biggest factor for the lower rating is that I personally was not fond of the taste, but my sister said she liked the taste, so I think this is personal preference not "Healthy food = yucky taste". But if you are watching your calories, carbs, and sugars, this is DEFINITELY a product to check out.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I've run for 1 year (yay for me!), but my goals are, at this point in my life, primarily reducing my time on 5K runs. I haven't done an 8K, 10K, half marathon or marathon, though I do feel at one point, I'd like to try.What all this blurb means is that I would classify myself as a casual runner, one that enjoys to run but who isn't the most experienced in the field. I won't be able to compare with other compression socks out there, nor to give a good idea how it works in a variety of different runs.I saw this product and thought it would be great for running and especially for my weak knee. And I found this to be true. The socks fit wonderfully - I wear a size 9 women's shoe - and once they were on, I hardly felt they were on and honestly didn't want to remove them. They worked great for my run (they wicked nicely and didn't feel sticky at all) and, best of all, they washed brilliantly.They seem to be a great sock; now whether they are worth what seems to me to be a rather high price tag, that I can't say. I at least have really liked them and almost wish I had more than one pair so that I could wear one while washing the other.UPDATE 12/08/14: These socks continue to work great. I've been using them pretty much once a week, washing them after every use, and they are holding up nicely in the wash. Furthermore, I feel like I do run better with fewer post-run pains when I wear them. And then, it's wonderful how my feet aren't sweaty and disgusting afterwards.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

This age of smartphones is great; constant access to emails and internet, no more pulling over to ask directions, no more standing in line without a book being bored stiff.But that also means the darned things always need to be powered up. Especially in the car, when you aren't' using your phone (PSA: Don't text and drive people!!!), so it's a perfect time for a power up?I got this primarily because my old charger was built only for the iPhone 4S and was, therefore, not compatible with the iPhone 5S lightning port. (I am still unclear of why it needed to be changed.) And so far, the charger is working just as I need. It doesn't seem particularly fast (it charges at a little more than 1%/min), but hey, at least it can move you from being in the red to being in the green! And if you're commute is long, it's better than nothing.The plug-in to the 120V power is a lot smaller than my previous one, so it sits nearly flush. It was a bit of a challenge to plug in, as it was snug. I haven't used the cable to charge to my computer, but given my previous experience with these types of cables, I have no double it will work. I definitely like how I don't have to worry about plugging in the cable, correct symbol up anymore.The Vine only offered green, but I would have preferred pink (I'm a pink girl). Regardless, the cord does stand out, much better than my black charger, so it's easy to find in the mess of cables in my car.Price-wise, $35 (which is what is showing at the time of the review posting) is ridiculous. I believe you can get the Apple charger for about the same or less. At least, I spent $20 for a new cable and could still plug it into my old charger base, which is what I had been doing before I got this. However, if you absolutely don't have anything for charging your iPhone in your car, this is not a bad deal at all (especially if the cable can be used to connect to the computer - I will have to check that part out in a later update).UPDATE 11/02/15: Bumping down a star because the cable, 1 year later, is now torn at the connection to the lightning port. This is the first time in the 4+ years of owning an iPhone that my car charger cable has broken. On one hand, I suppose that a year is pretty good, but on the other, looking at the price a person may have paid, it does not seem worth it.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

I love coffee. No, I ADORE coffee. I love the flavor, I love the community that comes with it ("How about we meet for a cup of coffee?"), I love to find small independent roasters and try their bean. I own a French Press and a Toddy Cold Brew system, and am looking into a filtration system for pour-overs. I've even been considering roasting my own beans! If I spend a lot of money on a monthly basis on one consumable item, it is coffee - from independent shops AND beans (no Folgers for this girl!).So when the Vine Program offered up an automatic espresso maker, I didn't hesitate one bit. I JUMPED on the chance.The Pre-Review:Day 1: I open the box, DELIRIOUS with excitement. I check the instruction booklet, which is very simple: pull out water tank and fill. Fill bean hopper. Attach power cord to machine and plug in. Turn on and hit power button on the front.The problem happened when I hit the front power button. The machine whirred then abruptly stopped and the "Fill Tank" button lit up. Strange. So I opened the water tank and filled it slightly more. No change. Then I removed water. No change. I removed the tank and put it back in. Still no change.Well, then I started to do all the following after turning on and off the machine and unplugging it. No change.I spent a good hour that first day with no change. The "Fill Tank" button remained illuminated, I was royally PO'd and in an incredibly sour mood.Day 2: I emailed Phillips Saeco Department and scoured the internet for help. I posted a comment on a fellow Viner's review. (Results of this action: I never heard from Phillips Saeco as they ONLY have a customer service telephone line, which I will get into more of this later. The Internet had nothing on this error, and the Phillips Saeco website's only advice was to remove water tank and fill. As for the Viner's review, my fellow Viner did not have my problem; that espresso machine worked right out of the  box.)Day 3: I emailed Amazon Vine to let them know my problem. They could not send me a replacement, but gave me an extension on the reviewing time. (In case you aren't aware of the rules, products must be reviewed within 30 days or your Vine account is "on hold".)In the meantime, I pulled out the machine and tried to plug/unplug, turn on/off, fill/remove water from the tank with no results. At the end of this fiasco, I set aside the problem for a few days, so frustrated was I.One Week Later: I checked into calling Phillips Saeco, as I never got an email response. I live on the West Coast and their hours are 8am - 8pm ET, which converts to 5am - 5pm. Excellent, so that means I either have to get up super early or get time off work/call during lunch. I was tired of having a huge machine take up room in my apartment so I called during work. I was promptly given a representative who told me to "Remove and reinstall the tank 15 times, making sure there was no dust and debris" to reset the sensor. Given by this point I had ALREADY removed and reinstalled the tank 15 times, I was desperate enough to try. I took off early from work and gave it a shot.No change.I called customer service back and after a short wait, got a new representative. He told me to try to "Remove the tank, reinstall, then turn off/on the power". I had already done THIS about 80 times as well, but I humored him. Needless to say, this did not work.But then the best thing happened. The representative told me that he would send me a new machine and have me ship back the faulty machine (on Phillips Saeco's dime!). It would take a week, since it was Friday, and they couldn't process until Monday. I didn't have to send the broken machine back until I received the new one either.I was HAPPY. FINALLY, things were looking up.One week later, I came into the apartment to see my sister had received a brand-new Saeco Pure Automatic Espresso Machine. Part of me was scared to remove it and try to use it, for fear of seeing yet another "Fill Tank" error (or perhaps some new error).I followed all the instructions to the letter, taking care to be slow and cautious. But I needn't have worried because it started up on the first button!The Review:The priming process was fairly straight-forward, though a bit long (and it DOES use up your beans, so don't run good, expensive beans when you are going through the priming process!!). You basically run through the entire tank of water, so it probably took a good 15 minutes. But after that, everything was smooth sailing.I estimate that a tank of water can make about 10 espressos, less coffees. The beans last slightly longer (you can fit a 12 oz bag of beans in the hopper which is GREAT!) AND they are ground by the machine itself, so no guesswork here! The machine is a bit noisy, but it is quick and makes great coffee. I've had it, my sister has had it, and I've shared with several others, and everyone has said that it is a VERY good cup of coffee. Smooth, great flavor, no Char-bucks burnt taste to it. I've not used the steamer, as I prefer Americanos and I drink only almond milk which doesn't necessarily steam well, so I can't comment on that function.Refilling the water tank and the coffee hopper is a bit of a pain in the butt because the new working model I got has doors that move straight up, instead of panels that can be removed. So that means, you either have to place the machine with no or high cabinets overhead or move it out from underneath every time you need to refill. Given that most of my counterspace has cabinets over it, this is quite the pain in the butt.Cleaning the machine is pretty easy. Depending on how many cups of coffee/shots of espresso you make determines how often you need to dump the grounds, but it is easy to remove that compartment (though you do need to twist the steamer to remove it). I've also done the weekly cleaning, which is fairly simple, though removing/replacing the coffee grinder is a bit tough. That said, there's a nice little brush that comes with the machine and it brushes the excess grounds right into a removable plate, so that makes the weekly cleaning easier.The biggest reason this doesn't get full stars is the fact that the first machine did not work when I got it. If I had spent a full $600 on this product, I would have been FURIOUS and have probably returned the machine promptly. While the customer service was good (I was afraid I would have to FIGHT to get a new machine or to have them pay for it to be repaired) and DOES somewhat make up for this, I think the hours are highly restrictive to people living anywhere but the East Coast. But the machine itself, when it works, makes a good cup of coffee/shot of espresso, so now that I have a working machine, I am VERY pleased.UPDATE 12/08/14: I have since tried the milk frother twice with almond milk. (I don't drink or buy regular cow's milk.) The first time, I don't think I steamed it long enough because while it had a great froth, it was cold. The second time, my cousin, a barista, came over and frothed the milk, and it turned out perfect.I also have bought decalcifier to use on the machine, as I've heard it can help keep the machine running in tip-top shape. Wish me luck!Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

Seventeen year old Janeal Mikkado wants nothing more than to leave her gypsy home. Salazar Sanso apprehends her one day and coerces her into a deal - he will spare Janeal's father, who is making a deal with the DEA, if Janeal can find the $1million her father is hiding. This leads to a explosive confrontation which changes her life - along with the life of her boyfriend, Robert.DNF at page 193; skimmed the rest.My dad is a big fan of Ted Dekker. I thought, "Well, Dad likes Ted Dekker, I should give him a try to!" I inherited my love of science fiction and fantasy from Dad - why not a love for Ted Dekker too?Perhaps if I had tried one of Ted Dekker's solo books or one that Dad recommended, I may have had better luck. But the book I got, "Burn", didn't impress me. I tried years ago to read this, but could never get much past the first chapter. But this year, my goal is get through my backlog of Amazon Vine ARCs and unread books on my bookshelf, so I settled myself down and read this.I actually found, once I powered through the beginning, it wasn't half bad. The problem comes when Part 1 finishes and Part 2 begins. Part 2 is so slow and boring. Characters just wander around on the page, having mindless repetitive conversations that go nowhere. It's incredibly dry and dull.Not to mention, while I never liked any of the characters, I didn't start to actively dislike them until Part 2. Janeal is a selfish brat in Part 1, but can you blame her for wanting to get out from her dad's wing and want to make her own way in the world? Especially when her community ostracizes her for being only half-gypsy? I can't. Sure, her METHOD of accepting Sanso's offer (after his combination kidnapping/blackmail/"Offer you can't refuse") isn't awesome, but she's young, naive, and stupid.Part 2, though, it's obvious that the authors think that any successful, ambitious woman is evil. Janeal works her way to the top of a ludicrous "All Angles" magazine - a magazine I have trouble believing could tread that miraculous line between accommodating BOTH conservatives and liberals. She is unhappy and discontent, and you can see that in the abusive boyfriend who likes BDSM (fortunately, she dumps him quickly), the fact she drinks a lot, the fact she has no regard for anyone else's personal life, the fact that she constantly has migraines.Compare that to Katie, who is a burn victim with scars and no hair, who lives peaceably in a women's commune. She is passive and demure, out of the limelight, content with her life, gentle, and sweet - basically, a "good Christian woman".**SPOILER**Skipping to the end, it's clear the "good Christian woman" gets rewarded with the "evil ambitious" woman's money, and then promptly spends it all on halfway homes. Because a "good Christian woman" would NEVER do anything with that much money other than give it away and live in humility and simplicity.**END SPOILER**I think Robert was meant to be a Love Interest, but I thought he was absolutely awful. He was supposedly Janeal's girlfriend, all the while his actions to Katie made it seem that he was potentially fooling around with her. At the very least, he was pulling along two women.As for the baddies - laughable. Needed Snidley Whiplash mustaches to make the image complete.Other than the poor way women are treated (one woman is body shamed as being so skinny, she obviously doesn't enjoy life), the story is just BORING. It just doesn't go anywhere fast. And that is my biggest problem with this book. I could handle the characters, even if I hated them with a fiery passion, as long as the story had movement forward.Perhaps Ted Dekkery/Erin Healy fans will like more; if you are new to either, I wouldn't recommend this as the first book you try.Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

This started out REALLY good. I loved John Byrne's introduction, where he talks about the Perez reboot of Wonder Woman, Speculators, and the atmosphere of comics in the 90's. Wonder Woman was great in Byrne's hands as she fought off crime...And then the story walks in, musses up your hair, and walks off, to be replaced by a silly story of an ancient Greek mechanoid being activated by a 14 year-old whiny punk.Wonder Woman is great. I even like some of the art. But the Darkseid plot (what is it with my stumbling upon this character) goes nowhere. I get it's probably part of a longer storyline, but I had expected at least a LITTLE closure and not the wide-open doors that I get at the end of this.And the last issue, Lifelines, is complete goofball. Wonder Woman doesn't even save the day! It's the stupid punk kid who activated the damn thing that fixes it.Obviously, I'm obsessed with Wonder Woman, so it won't make or break my love for her, but geez, talk about a disappointment!Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

It's Twilight if Bella were a boy and Edward moved down South instead of Bella moving up North.And that's the plot in its basic elements. Because really, take any Young Adult book published in the last 10 years, and that's this book's plot, characters, setting, and story. Sure, some people are like, "But this is different! The protagonist is a boy! And it's got Southern Flavor."But you know what? A duck is still a duck if you put it in a chicken suit and sit it out on your back porch. It doesn't matter if it's dressed like a chicken, IT'S A DUCK.DNF at 36%.I bought this many moons ago because of a pretty cover, and I was a Young Adult junkie at the time. I finally decided to read it because 1) I'm trying to weed through my bookshelves and 2) I found the audiobook.Let's talk about cliches and tropes for a moment. Sometimes, they can be useful - a quick descriptor for people, a typical plot or character for a story (like the down and out Private Detective or the Rebellious Emo Teen). Most of the time (99% of the time, to be precise), though, cliches suck. They suck, because they are boring, they are overdone, and they have no nuance.This book is loaded with Cliches. Let's take a look at the Wheel O' Cliches for more examplesWheel O' Cliches:+ The Main Character (MC) reads; he reads classics; his favorite book is a classic that, not only is the discussion book in his English class, but ALSO relates to this book's plot+ MC has quirky "friend", whom he uses and doesn't do anything else with+ MC wants "more" than what his town provides+ Absentee/dead parents (Quadruple points because both the MC and the Love Interest have them!)+ No/incompetent adult figures+ New kid arrives at school, weird because her uncle is a recluse, but super gorgeous and very very hot. Needless to say, she's the Love Interest (LI).+ LI writes emo poetry, which makes her Deep and Meaningful and More Understanding than All the Other Girls+ LI is UNIQUE! and SPESHUL! because she wears long ripped up skirts with Converse Chucks+ MC and LI are mopey, emo teens who are all like, "BUT NO ONE UNDERSTANDS MY PAYNE!!!"+ MC has visions and dreams; one such dream features LI before she even appears physically in the book. Of course, MC falls in lust with her.+ No one ever says anything that is on his or her mind; they just play ring-around-the-rosie with information until about 1/4 of the way through the book+ Slut-shaming!! Because if you wear a black bra and a short skirt, you are totally a slut!+ Bitchy cheerleaders+ High school DWAMA+ Falling in lust before meeting/at first sight+ All conversations center around Love Interest+ Potentially racist characters (Amma sounds like she's supposed to be a Mammy black stereotype)+ Potentially stereotyped setting (small town rejects any newcomers, Southern hospitality, everyone knows everything about everyone else, etc.)+ Neither the MC nor the LI can just ask, "Hey, you wanna date?"+ Neither the MC nor the LI have any sort of real sex drive. They are perfectly content with blushing and giggling about how Deep and Unique the other person is.Even *I* didn't realize how bad this was in the cliche department until I started to type it out! Look at that list! It's enormous! And that's only in the 36% I could stomach!The two highlights of this book were as follows: Macon Ravenwood (whom, thanks to the movie, I imagined as Jeremy Irons) and Ridley.Why is it that authors can never write stories about the interesting characters? I don't care about Dork In Disguise (Ethan as interpreted by two 30-something women) and Emo Poetry Girl (who cares about their names, they don't even really matter in these types of books) - I'd much rather read about Ridley and Macon!At the 36% mark, given how reliant this book is on cliches, I can already imagine how the book ends, and I don't like what I expect. So I decided to end the payne now and stop. To be fair, this book isn't THAT bad (the writing is mostly competent and fortunately Ethan is not abusive like Patch from "Hush, Hush"), but if you've read ANY Young Adult Urban Fantasy, you can predict from page 1 what will happen. It's terribly generic and formulaic, and I don't really recommend to anyone, unless you absolutely LOVE everything from this genre, particularly "Fallen".Brought to you by:*C.S. Light*

When I first saw the cover of the movie Frontera I realized Ed Harris was in this movie and couldn't wait to see it.  I have seen a few Ed Harris movies but couldn't picture him in what looked like a western.  The movie, and Ed Harris, didn't disappoint.Ed Harris plays Roy, a retired sheriff from southern Arizona who has a ranch that borders on the Mexican border.  After a tragic beginning involving his wife (played by Amy Madigan), Roy's life and attitude are tested.  He was never happy about the Mexican's crossing into America through his property and now views what happened as even more reason to stand by his beliefs.  But are things really what they appear?While the movie hits kind of a lull in the middle when it tries to show the plight of these people attempting to cross over into America, it has quite a few twists and features a few well known stars including Harris, Madigan, Eva Longoria, and Michael Pea.Without giving too much away, I will say that the ending may frustrate some people but I found it to be a good one.I would recommend it to people, especially anyone who likes Ed Harris.A copy of this film was provided to facilitate this review. All opinions expressed above are my own.

When I sat down to watch this new Pierce Brosnan film, I wasn't sure what to expect. This film is based on a novel by Nick Hornby, someone unfamiliar to me. The main actor, Pierce Brosnan stars in this dark comedy about 4 strangers who meet while attempting to commit suicide on a building known for its suicide attempts.The odd quartet features Martin (Brosnan) as a former TV star who had an affair with a woman he thought was 25, only to find out she was really 15.  The group also features J.J. (Aaron Paul) as a front man from a band turned to being a pizza delivery man, Maureen (Toni Collette) who is the single mother of a severely disabled son, and Jess (Imogen Poots), a young woman dumped by her boyfriend.  Their reasons for wanting to die are varied yet have similarities.  Both Martin and J.J. have fallen from grace as a star and would-be rocker while Maureen thinks her son would be better cared for if she weren't around and Social Services cared for him.  For Jess, of course, it is the usual thoughts after being dumped by her boyfriend.Except for Brosnan, who's comedy seemed a bit forced at times, the other three characters were enjoyable to watch, except maybe Maureen's portion of the story in regards to her son.At times I found the movie witty, other times it was very emotional and sad. This film is an unpredictable roller coaster ride that I would only recommend to those with an open mind.We gave this movie 3 stars due to the fact that it had some slow spots and Brosnan's not so great attempt at comedy.Still, you could do worse in a movie and overall, I liked it.A sample was received to facilitate this review. All opinions provided are an honest review of the film.

When I first saw the Ozeri Ultra 42 inch Wind Fan - Adjustable Oscillating Tower Fan with Noise Reduction Technology I was impressed by the space saving design.  It looks very modern and fits any dcor.  Its slim design is great for small rooms and it's quiet motor generates more air speed with less noise than any other fan that I have heard.It is hard to say whether I was more impressed by just how quiet this fan was or the air that was generated.  It features 90 degree oscillation for optimal air circulation and it is whisper quiet.Assembly was very easy with only a few screws to put together the base and the optional spacer between the base and the fan.  Total assembly took only a few minutes.It came with a "mouse looking" remote control that worked well from fairly good distances and it stores safely and conveniently right under the top of the fan lid.  The fan includes a 12-hour timer that can be set in 1 hour increments with just the push of a button.The fan features three airflow patterns made to foster sleep, relaxation and comfort that are already pre-programmed.This fan is quiet, easy to use and the front grill slats are recessed, making it a great fan for families with small children and pets. I would definitely recommend the Ozeri Ultra 42 inch Wind Fan - Adjustable Oscillating Tower Fan with Noise Reduction Technology for any household.A sample was received to facilitate this review. All opinions expressed above are my own.

I wasn't sure what to expect when I began watching Ice Cold Gold - Season 1 on DVD.  There are so many reality TV shows out there and thought this might be just another boring show but I was immediately drawn in by the beauty of the scenery and the variety of the cast of characters.Ice Cold Gold features eight members who together form a mining company called Sixty Degree Resources.  This group of men are trying to strike it rich in one of the most beautiful, yet dangerous parts of the world.  Mother Nature provides only a small window for them to search for the treasure they seek as the arctic summer lasts only two months where the longs days melt away some of the snow covered terrain.From rock slides to severe arctic ice storms, this group must endure all that is thrown at them if they want to mine one of the most remote areas of the world.The group features Eric Drummond who is a licensed hydro-geologist and engineering geologist along with a crew consisting of a pair of brothers (Jesse and Josh) experienced in hard rock mining, a driller (Americo), a demo expert (Zach), a dredger (Chad), a wilderness and survival guide (Jack) and a gem recovery expert (John).My intention was to watch an episode or two each night until I finished the series but watched them all in one night.  The 2-disc set was more than I expected and would appeal to a wide variety of individuals. I am truly looking forward to viewing the next season of this series.A copy was received to facilitate this post. All opinions expressed above are my own.

Honestly and truthfully, I had no idea these doodle books were even available. When I offered to review this book it was during the holiday season. How ironic, here I was reviewing a book that would help me with the stress that comes with the holidays and I just couldn't find the time to give it a review. If I couldn't find the time to read some quotes and do some doodling, how could I find the time to relax.Overall, I feel when it comes to stress, we seem to always find the time to feel stressed but not the time to relax or use the tools to help lower our stress levels. When what we really need, is to allow ourselves the time to relax and not allow stress take control of our body and emotions. Does this make sense?Daily Zen Doodles is such a simple book, you may look at it, read the quotes and decide this book will do nothing for you in regards to relaxation and stress. This is exactly what I found myself thinking, that is, until I gave myself the permission to act and actually do some doodling. I other words, I took time out for relaxation and to find a stress free place to be, even if only for a few moments a week.There isn't anything I didn't like about Daily Zen Doodles. It is what it is, a book to doodle in or write a daily affirmation in. It is a tool that removes you from the stress environment, allowing you some time to focus and relax. It fits nicely into my bedside nightstand or into my handbag when on the go. Make it a daily habit to allow yourself time to relax and release stress by using this simple book. Overall, you will find yourself feeling better physically and mentally.A copy was received to facilitate this review. All opinions expressed above are my own.

A great griddle. We use this with our induction cook top. We used to have an electric top and used an AllClad aluminum griddle, but and after we moved that wasn't an option since induction requires magnetic materials to work. This Caphalon griddle fills the gap and allows us to use the induction and still have a griddle.It is quite a bit smaller than the AllClad aluminum one and since it's cast iron it requires different care and handling. We can cook about 1/2 a package of bacon on it at one time, just to give you an idea of it's working size. It comes already 'seasoned' so you don't need to worry about preparing it, but it's a lot heavier too so you do need to be careful not to drop it (it'll shatter!). Cleaning it is a little different too. clean with a brush and after it's dry you should re-spray it with cooking oil and wipe off the excess.If you already know how to deal with cast iron, and you need a griddle and don't mind the smaller size, this is a good choice. If you need a larger cooking area then get 2 or consider looking at other options.One last point, be careful with this on your cooktop since glass surfaces and be scratched by metal. Avoid sliding this around when it's in use.

This is a nice topper for your (or your kid's) Zuca. My only complaint is if your kid 'rides' the Zuca, balancing on the 4 wheels, then this cushion drags slightly on the ground where it covers the frame (in the picture it's the left side that forms the short leg of the triangle), so it gets dirty and I expect it will eventually tear, but it's easy to replace and install on the Zuca so when that happens I'll buy a replacement.

I usually get the Bassets but decided to try Gustaf's and I'm not disappointed. They have the same texture and mostly the same flavor. Most importantly, the black/purple one tastes of black current, and truth be told, that's the reason I love these!You get 3 large, non resealable  bags so I recommend putting them into a sealed container or a 1 gallon ziplock back to keep them fresh. Hopefully these will last a very long time!

Refurbished! A great way to save some $$$ (ok, $30).The remote came with new batteries but was a little scratched up, but that's ok since I'll control it via the Android Ap or from my home automation system via IP.The Roku3 I got was the 2014 (4200R) model, which doesn't have voice control of the 4230), which is just fine with me anyway since I use it as media player for Amazon, Hulu and Plex. The unit had problems initially connecting to my network (wifi, with the correct password). I kept getting an error 014. A few minutes with Google and I found out how to get into the secret menu and disabled the "network ping".http://www.letstalk-tech.com/roku-error-014-connect-roku-3-wi-fi-network/After that the player connected to my account and the software upgraded (it may have upgraded before connecting to the account - I don't remember exactly). After that it was perfect and it's streaming great from the various sources.Save some $ and but refurbished.

Very shot memory stick. I used this in my car to provide music playback. I looked specifically for a short memory stick since I would be leaving this plugged into the car's USB plug almost full time. This way it won't catch things and snag.SanDisk makes good memory and has been in the business for years. Yes, sometimes there are bad individual untis, sometimes I'm sure there are even bad batches, but overall I've been very happy with Sandisk memory (I have CF, SD micro SD and USB formats from them) and this mini thumb drive in specific fit's the needs I have for storage in my car. I don't need super fast memory, so I haven't tested that aspect, but USB3 speeds should be good enough for most general purpose storage needs and transferring songs to this memory stick on my computer (MBP 15+retina, late 2013) was quick enough that I didn't have to worry about transfer rates. I'm sure there are other reviews that have those numbers posted. For me, it was good enough.

Left, Right Center, in case you haven't played this fast turn game before. Roll up to 3 dice (or 2 or 1 depending on how many chips you have left - 1 for 1, 2 for 2 3 for 3 or more chips). Then move your chips to the left hand player, right hand player, to the center (surrender them) or (hopefully) keep them.This is a fast paced game that's quick to learn and doesn't have any strategy. It's just fun to play. Good for ages 7 and up.It's great to travel with too since it doesn't take up much space, just the 6 inch long tube that holds everything.

This is a good coax cable for your sub-woofer. I got the 35' length for a powered Energy subwoofer with an 8" driver. The connection is solid and stable and does the job. If you have the RCA style connectors on your sub and amplifier, don't try to use RCA cables that you have lying around, buy a cable designed for the subwoofer, notice the relief cuts in the outer connector?The cable appears well made and sturdy enough for many years of service.Ships in a cardboard box and is coiled around 7-8" in diameter. No damage happened to the cable or connectors.

These are well machined, solid connectors. Use them before trying to connect the speaker cable to the speakers if your amplifier and speakers have the banana plug connector/posts. My rear channels (Polk dipole surround speakers) had a colored (red/black) plug in the bana plug, which popped out. My center channel doesn't support the banana plug, but my front left/right floor standing Polks do, as did my Denon receiver, so once I measured out the cable lengths and screwed on these connectors, plugging everything in was a piece of cake. I got one wire backward which was picked up when I did the Audyssey sound checks, so flipping around the plug polarity was a piece of cake.The trick to these connectors is to push the cable through from the end and then have it fan out at the end so it will be pinched when you screw the 2 pieces together. The fastest way I found to do this is to unscre the connectors so you can see all the way through the hole, then lightly twist the speaker cable and thread it so it goes through the end easily then when it comes out at the hole use another plug end to push the cable part way out the side of the hole, then screw connector together, pinching the cable strands. After the first 2 it's quick and easy.No sound distortion, good connections and easy assembly and management. I wish I had these years ago.Don't forget to buy enough for both ends of the cables, and if you have patch panels for the speaker cables, you might need even more!

Decent lighter weight speaker cable.Don't buy ($$$) into the marketing hype of those monsterous marketing companies and others that claim better sound from "pure copper", oxygen free, conditioned wire and all that.These are decent speaker cables made from stranded copper that get the job done nicely and cost effectively. Keep in mind this is 14 AWG, so it's a little thin if you're driving 1000W speakers. I have this cable with the brass banana plugs running to Polk RT800 home theater speakers at around 250W per channel and at less than 50 foot distance per speaker this cable is more than sufficient.Interesting read here: http://www.roger-russell.com/wire/wire.htm#differences

good mount for the GoPro but the screw that holds the case to the arm isn't a thumbscrew, it requires a Philips screw driver and the size/length of the arm segments means this doesn't fold up very small. While thet's not a big problem most of the time, I sometimes have the camera mounted high on the windshield and want the camera to be mounted high too (keep it out of the sight lines), but it's not possible with this arm to keep it folded up since that's not how the arms are designed.Besides that, the suction cup and lock mechanisms are very good and hold the camera securely. Overall this is a well thought out, well designed and well built product.This isn't a knock against the product but just a general piece of advice when using suction cups to secure items. Check your windshield where you think you may use the suction cup. If you have the shade dots (nearly flush paint dots on the inside to add some tinting, usually right around the edge of the glass), they don't work well with suction cups. The camera may detach and fall. Be careful if you are at the track since you don't want the distraction of a camera coming lose inside the car at the wrong time.

Very easy to setup. I only installed one so far and did some speed tests. Using Ookla I was getting 125Mbps using a wired connection to my HP switch. Going wireless with this AP I got just over 100Mbps. Not too bad. I'm using a MacBook Pro 15 from late 2013 and my Internet connection is the 125Mbps connection from Comcast.The setup application uses Java and works well enough. Setup is easy but I tried to 'cowboy" it at first and needed to do a factory reset on the AP and try again before it worked. Just make sure to read the dialog boxes (I didn't the first time). So far it's great and I'll be buying 3 outdoor APs and a 2nd indoor AC AP to make sure I have good coverage around the house and yard.It's nice these APs come with the POE injectors, although that requires an additional AC plug for the injector near the switch. The 24 port fanless HP switch I have doesn't do POE and my Juniper EX2200c has a few ports that stopped working, so I'm stuck with the HP switch for now. I don't want to use the Ubiquity Edgeswitch 24 (ES-24-250W) switch, although it does do POE, the Edgeswitch isn't fanless and the network gear is all in an open rack in our master closet, so I'm going for quiet. Maybe if I needed 10G uplinks or L3 routing, but I just need a high density L2 switch and I already had the HP.Anyway, these Ubiquity APs are nice. Very clean and low profile design. The square design is a little different, but only the AC model is square. The inner swuare has LED backlights that can be, white or blue and signal different conditions.Fast and easy setup and they appear well made.

These are really nice pans. We've had a set of All-Clad aluminum pots and pans (with the anodized gray exterior finish) for 15 years... we got them for our wedding. Now we're moving to a new house that has an induction cook top and the old pans won't work. Induction tops require magnetic cookware. We thought about getting those small metal rings that heat up and transfer heat to the pan so we could keep using the wedding set. We also looked at converting to a gas cooktop, but neither option was good for various reasons (cost and inefficiency being the main ones).So I went to check if All-Clad had induction compatible ones and of course they did. 3 Different models. The D5, the Bright stainless and the copper core. The copper core doesn't get good reviews due to uneven heating, which left the D5 and the other stainless. Both seemed the same, although the D5 is their newest line, so I went with them.No regrets! These are as well made as the originals we had and look like they will last 50 years (or until the next new heating technique makes metal pans obsolete). Everything about All-Clad coos sets is high quality. They come well boxed and protected. The finish is perfect on every item and they have a few nice little things that my old set didn't. Besides the 5 layers to better distribute the heat on the bottom, they also have a small ridge at the base of the handle to rest your finger on and so you don't get too close to the hot pan. Nice but subtle touch.I think my only complaint is that the 10 piece set (which is what I bought) needs a few more item, like a small frying pan for melting butter and maybe a steamer but the 14 piece set doesn't have these, just 2 large pots and lids. Not that helpful. To me the 10 piece is a very solid start for a cook set and you can fill in the missing pieces that you need for your cooking style.If you're looking for stainless, stick (opposite of non-stuck) cookware, this is the best set you can get. Do it and enjoy a lifetime with these.

the app might be free but you pay to play. The controls are not great but they work. If you like it, the game is $6 (not free!), otherwise you'll deal with adds and the requests to buy tokens to play. I loaded it, played one game and was annoyed by the lie to get you to install it. Immediatly deleted it. Not worth it.

Not sure how to do this review. Basically this is Apples to Apples (if you have kids you probably played that game), but for adults. Very adult themes. At first you may be embarrassed to play. After you get over that.... well, you will probably either have a great time or give up. There's not really any middle ground. You'll be watching over your shoulder to make sure your HR department isn't there... even at home. Yep, it can be that bad.We played it with some friends and weren't sure if they would like it. 20 minutes later we were all laughing so hard that we could barely breath! Everyone enjoyed it so much they all ended up wanting to buy their own copy.Honestly, it's really fun and can be silly, raunchy and offensive.. you'll love. It depends on what cards you get for the answers and how twisted you are, but even a bad hand of answer cards can make some of the funniest, most amusing answers. Even if you don't win, you'll enjoy the game.Just be sure to invite your crazy friends over to play.

What a fun game for parties with a mix of kids and adults. Great for those with tweens that want to play too. Do it now before they turn into teens and don't want anything to do with you! It's a matching game where you have to find the matching image on each card. Call it first and you keep the card. It's a fast paced game that will keep everyone at the table paying attention!

My daughter loves it! It easily packs a lot of clothes and a few stuffed animals when we travel. Be aware that it's bigger than a normal carry-on bag. I have been able to get it into the overhead bin but it was difficult and required the bin area was a little flexible.Around the airport it's great. My daughter can sit on it and balance on the 4 wheels. Rolling through the Seattle airport it turned a lot of heads! The wheels flash and she appears to be floating along. You can push or pull your kid and with practice they can roll along a good distance.

A good sharpener for your knives that have a decent (but dull) blade. The holder and "stone" are good quality, holding the "stone" firmly and being stiff. It's taking a little "getting used to" to sharpen my knives with this diamond stone (vs the traditional honing stone), but after a few  less than successful attempts I finally have the hang of it and can (and have) put a decent edge on all the kitchen straight knives and my pocket knives.Don't try to use this with a serrated blade, it won't work, otherwise, it's goof for most normal blade lengths.You may want to consider a sharpening guide if you're getting this, like me, without much experience. The guide will help you avoid scratching the finished surface of the blade (if that's important to you) and will help put the right angle on the cutting edge so you don't round the current one or blunt the edge.
Got them for my wife and they look great on her and have held up to daily use quite nicely

This isn't a stunt kite so flying it takes a little getting used to if you're already used to smaller parafoils.The backpack it comes in is nice, keeping everything together and the control bar is good quality as are the lines and bridle. In fact, everything about this kite is high quality, it's just not an agile kite (it turns slowly). I haven't yet reconfigured it to a 4 line, I've only flown it as the 2 line with control bar as it ships, and to be honest, it's been a bit frustrating. The controls seem to be reversed, but to be fair, I've only flow it twice on very light wind days and it was 'wallowing' so I may bave been trying to over control it and dumping the wind instead of turning it. Hopefully I'll get it to a beach or get it out on a windier day and be able to update this review.

If you're a Futurama fan and don't already have the comics then this is a good book to have. Fox was very short sighted to take it off the air, but then entertainment isn't really their priority (was it ever?). Comedy Central tried but I think the momentum had been lost since it was a second or third death and revival for the series.Keep in mind this is a published collection of comic books, so the artwork varies and the stories aren't as good as the televised versions, but these are generally new stories and aren't bad. This is a must have for Futurama fans!

Nice case for the Note 4. There aren't many choices for accessories on the Note 4 yet, but this is a good one to protect the phone. This case protects all 4 sides of the phone and the clear back keeps the apparent bulk of the case minimized. This does make your phone wider, taller and thicker, such that the already fair sized Note 4 will be even bigger, but the soft plastic/rubber feel will give you a better grip so you will be less likely to drop the phone and protected in case you do.Please note that this case won't fit the wireless charging back when that's released (assuming it's like the one for the Note 3), so be aware of that if you're considering going that route when it's available. I had the wireless back for my previous Note 3 and the only option with that back is the bumper/ring style cases (or using the wireless charging enabled S-View flip covers). I don't know if the insert style wireless charging antennas will work with this, we had some luck with an S3 and a wireless charging antenna with a hard plastic case, but the case never really fit the phone properly with the antenna inserted inside the back cover, so we ended up not using the antenna on that phone. A 3rd party wireless charging antenna inside the back cover may work with this case since it's not rigid, but since there are no wireless charging options of any kind at the time of this writing (Nov 1 2014) there is no way to be sure, but my hunch is it probably won't fit properly and you'll need a bumper style cover too.

So far this is great but it does add a fair amount of bulk to the 13" Air. The laptop is no longer razor thin at the front edge and no longer has the sharp edges that can be easily dented from normal use!The fit is secure on the Mac once you get the clips on. Be careful to make sure you get all the clips over the edge, otherwise the shell may pop-off unexpectedly. I had a little difficulty getting all the clips on the first try.This shell has a glossy finish, not the soft touch/matte finish of the other shells. This glossy finish means you will see all the finger prints when you carry your Mac around. If that thought bothers you, consider the matte finish, or get a small microfiber cloth to wipe the fingerprints off. This gloss finish will also show all the scratches you get from normal use, so be careful when moving the laptop around. However, since this shell is there to protect the laptop, each scratch in the plastic is a scratch avoided in the aluminum of the laptop. That's a reasonable tradeoff for me.I haven't had any problems with the back edges breaking, like others reported, but I haven't had the shell too long and I can see how it could happen since there's not a lot of plastic on the back 2 corners. Just be aware and be careful.My only complaint is the price. Many other shells are available and Speck is the most expensive of the main stream ones. If it's any consolation, they cost the same on Amazon as they do at the Apple store. I got a pink one for my wife when we bought her 11" Air, it was the same price as here on Amazon. The advantage of Amazon is they have all the colors available. Not so at the Apple stores.

I've been looking for a secure way to hold my Note 4 in the car. This mount works pretty well. The arms for the phone are spring loaded and hold the Note 4 with a Spigen Air cushion bumper case securely. You can even put the phone in 1 handed once you get the hang of it. I haven't tried the tablet holder part yet, but it seems like it would hold pretty well too. I bought this for my phone (phablet?) The base can take either the phone holder head or the tablet holder head. Either head slides into the top part of the base on a rail with a plastic spring lock that's molded into the part. iKross also includes a small extension that allows you to offset the head from the base by about 3 inches, however in my use, I found that the offset extender caused the phone to bounce too much and that the press lock on the extension didn't engage properly with the base and the phone holder, so it had a tendency to slip out. I just use the phone holder/head with the base directly and have no phone bounce and it's locked in place.The tilt and rotation adjustments allow you to get the phone so it's legible and not crooked. It takes a bit of trial and error to get it right, so please don't do this while the car is moving!The base is interesting and works well in the cup holder.  You need to be careful to avoid over expanding the base when you put it in the cup holder. This expansion is what keeps the holder stable, it's expands to keep the mount stationary. It has a collar that you twist to expand or contract the base. The base has 4 sections that expand from the center when you twist the collar, expanding the  bottom half of the base in 4 pie shaped pieces. There's an edge (rim) around the expanding pieces that seems like it can sit flush with the top of a cup holder, or, in my case, can sit inside the body of the cup holder. I have the base all the way down in my cup holder (2013 VW Passat TDI SEL in the US) and the rim seems like it could be expanded enough to break the cup holder body if you weren't careful. You just need to take time to make it tight enough without going crazy and you should be ok.This design will only work with cup holders that are sturdy since this works by applying pressure to the inside of the cup holder. The cup holder that you put this mount in doesn't need to be a single continuously piece, but it will have some pressure put on it by the holder so it can't be a skeletal frame design like BMW used in the E39 (1997-2003 5 series) or some of the newer BMW holders that pop out from the dash board near the vents. I think Porsche uses this in the current 911 models. It should be good in most GM cars that I've seen.

Great hard case and a very good fit for my Audio Technica ATM-M50s. You don't need to collapse the headphones to put them in this hard case. The case offers reasonable protection from crushing so you can take your headphones with you on trips. There's space in the case (between the headband and above the ear cup) to store the leather bag from the headphones, the spare cables (straight, both lengths, didn't try the spiral cord), the 1/4" adapter and maybe a small headphone amplifier.  The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is that since this case is so large, it really needs a strap or loop so it can be attached to your bag. For example if you have a backpack and you're flying, this case is fairly large and will take up a lot of space inside the backpack. It would be nice to clip it to a loop or secure it some other way outside the backpack. The only thing you have on the outside on this case is the dual zippers. The finish of the outside is a semi-rubberized hard plastic and the zippers seem to be high quality and move freely, without binding.

Great drive, fast and quiet with good capacity. The really odd thing is Amazon limits you to a maximum order of 2 (lifetime!!), at least they did at the time I ordered these (Aug 2014). When you're trying to populate a NAS with 4 or more drives (common!) and you can only order 2, that's pretty silly. I ordered the other 2 from NewEgg for the same price, although I could have ordered all 4 from them if necessary.@Amazon, why do you make it so frustrating for your customers?

So far this NAS is great. I've had it 2 weeks now, so not a lot of run time yet, but setup was super easy, it took about 10 mins to install 4 4TB Seagate NAS drives (ST4000VN000). There have been 2 firmware updates already, so there are probably some stability issues lurking with the original software, but I haven't experienced them yet. I'm replacing an old ReadyNAS NV+ and the speed difference is night and day! Directories load very quickly (using a single GE link right now and connecting through wireless at 150Mbps (2 MIMO) speeds at the laptop. I've setup a  Time Machine partition and have 2 MAc laptopns (OS X 10.9.5) backing up to it. I also had the ReadyNAS push the directories of 60K+ pictures and 900MBs of music over without any problems, although it took a long time to complete.In terms of noise, it's very quiet. I haven't measured the DBs but the fans are spinning at low speed, around 400 RPMs and the drives are very quiet too. My only complaint is that with the original firmware the SSD that I'm using (OCZ Deneva 2 250G) isn't recognized correctly. It reports an overtemp but says the drive is OK. I don't think it's reading the registers correctly and that may be the reason I can't use it for SSD cache. I just upgraded to the current firmware this morning and the drive can now be see by the cache settings, so hopefully that's resolved.I haven't tested Plex yet since I use a Mac Mini as my Plex server for faster transcoding, but will eventually migrate to this NAS for that too since it has the extra cores (and is the reason for purchasing this over the lower CPU models).So far, this has been a very positive experience.The packaging that Amazon used was very low quality cardboard and the shipping container arrived fairly banged and torn. There was a lot of tape added to hold the cardboard together, I assume UPS added that. Thankfully the packing from QNAP was only slightly damaged on the outside but the Styrofoam packing inside did it's job and there's no visible damage to the NAS itself. Come on Amazon! Please use better packing for $1100 electronics!

OK, here we go again. I seem to be down on APC lately. They once were a great company but that was a long time ago. See my other review of a APC UPS for a really bad experience with APC support. This time it's false advertising in the recycling plan. The description clearly states"APC recycles used batteries and almost 100% of the battery lead content is reused, protecting the environment. With each purchase of a genuine APC replacement battery, you get free freight back to APC for proper disposal of your old batteries (currently available in USA only.)"This was one of the main reasons for buying a genuine APC replacement battery instead of relaceing the unit completely or going with a 3rd party battery for less money.There is no return shipping of any sort. APC is partnering with call2recycle.org which then searches for a loal recycling center that you can take the battery to. Mine is at a Home Depot several miles away. Sure, it's not too much hastle for me to drive 30 mins to the HD on my weekend, but that's wasting my time when I purchased this replacement for the easy recycling. That's clearly false advertising and even borderline bait-and-switch. Shame on APC/Schneider Electric. This is clearly a cost cutting move that shifts the cost directly to the customer (in terms of my time/gas/frustration). That is not what I purchased this unit for.-3 stars for false advertising!Otherwise, the battery is an exact match/fit for the old one in my BT1000.If you do purchase this battery for your BT1000 and don't mind having to drive somewhere across town to recycle the old battery, then realize that there is a correct side and incorrect side to insert the battery... have the cable on the right side of the UPS, where there's a cutout. Also, there's an up and down to the battery that's not labeled. If you have to twist/rotate the cable to get the key in the plug to align, then take the batter out and flip it over that way you won't have to stress the cable and the cover will fit back on a little easier.Correction/edit 10/2/2014. I made a mistake with my original review and I'm leaving it above unchanged but setting the review to 5 stars. The URL that is referenced is not very obvious on the page and it in turn takes you to another page which then links to the UPS page to generate the return label. It's convoluted but it is there. I was incorrect about that in my review. The direct URL to the UPS login page to generate a return label is here for US customers: http://www.apc.com/solutions/display.cfm?id=35898A73-5056-AE36-FE910E4E9F5B9B7B&ISOCountryCode=us&tsk=j337w&pc=13729&keycode=j337w&promocode=13729&promo_key=137290I don't know why APC doesn't just put that on the page instead of all the other stuff about buying a replacement battery or upgrading the UPS with a trade-in value.Anyway, bottom line is the battery is good, it fits and is recyclable so if you need a battery for your BT1000, this is the one to get.

Great batteries for bikes. I've use this brand in Honda and BMW motorcycles for years and they last well. Recommended!Make sure you follow the instructions... after adding the acid you'll need to let the battery stand for a while with the top cover on loosely, then connect it to a charger until it's fully charged... then finally seal the top cover. This will let it vent if necessary and gives the best battery life. It's in the small, multi-language instruction pamphlet that's included.

Yep, these are batteries for the mini helis like the Scout or some of the ParkFlyer models. They include a small hook and loop sticker set to allow various positions for CG adjustments. These are OEM batteries and will last like the originals.

Apple created a nice, feature packed mouse and it works well with Macs, however there are some things you may want to be aware of that can frustrate you, unless you know what to expect:1) the scrolling sensitivity on certain apps (Microsoft Office 2011 specifically) is way too high. This got really bad after the Mavericks release of OSX so it's something in the mouse driver, but it can't be tuned down (made less sensitive) without messing up scrolling in other applications.2) Mavericks also seems to have broken stray finger detection when clicking, so you will click and your other fingers will be read by the mouse and the window will scroll. This happens with all applications and is Mavericks specific. It didn't happen in Mountain Lion or earlier versions but those had different problems and are best avoided anyway.3) MagicPrefs! If you get this mouse, you will want to get this free utility to adjust things like the scroll area (see #1 and #2 above). If you have problems with inadvertent scrolling in applications (i.e. your other finger grazes the side of the mouse) then this app will reduce the area on the mouse that detects scrolling. It does a bunch of other things too, but this is the single best feature. (This is not an age or degenerative nerve damage thing, it happens when you use this mouse and Mavericks)Overall this mouse is great. I've had mine for 2+ years now and it has held up well to daily use, including the Teflon skids on the bottom. Battery life is decent, lasting 2-3 months and it doesn't get confused when other BT devices are in use.Be aware that this is not an ergonomic mouse. It hurts my wrist after a few hours of use and when that happens I need to switch to a different mouse for a few days. Your experience may be different but this started after using this mouse. The problem is that this is a good mouse for productivity so I keep coming back to it. Much better than the corded Apple mouse with the scroll ball.This mouse works with Windows too (I use it with Win XP, Win 7 and Win 8.0 - haven't tried 8.1 but I don't see why it wouldn't work there too), but only for basic mouse functionality. So if you use Fusion, Boot Camp or Parallels, the cursor will move, the mouse will support left and right clicks and it will scroll up and down, but don't expect page forward/backward swipes to work or any of the fancy programming you can do with MagicPrefs.

This shell for the Macbook is a perfect fit with vent holes in the right places and all the ports have easy access. The plastic feels a little flimsy when you receive it but after putting it on the Mac it's just right. The texture/feel of the rubberized finish is just enough to give you a little extra grip on the laptop. I'll report back over time to see if it has developed any cracks or has come loose. So far so good and I'm very happy with the purchase.Update after several months of use: It's holding together ok, but I'm taking away 1 star since one of the feet fell off. It's still sticky, so I put it back on, but I'm now watching to make sure it doesn't fall off. I don't pull/drag the computer across any surfaces, so it's the adhesive that's not holding up. My laptop stays indoors and doesn't travel, so I suspect that if you were more active with it, you might be "footless" before too long. Otherwise, I don't have any cracks and the fit is still good for my late 2013 MBP 15 with Retina.

I did receive 24 Flake bars and the packets were boxed and packed so they were not damaged in shipping, however Premier Life is sending 6 packets of 4 flakes, and not the "Case of 24" as advertised. They should say they will send you 6 packets of Flakes with 4 bars in each packet. These are not the individually wrapped Flake bars as pictured. Once you open the packet there will be 4 bars lose and unwrapped and drying out. They are fresh now but it's not what they advertised and it's not worth sending them back to the UK for a refund.

This is a nice, compact, fairly quiet and fairly fast BR/DVD/CD player. It's really nice that it only needs a single USB cable. It's odd that it uses a USB mini (not micro) on the player side, since it seemed like those all went away a few years ago as all the phones have standardized on the micro plugs.For DVD/CD playback and recording it works great out of the box for both Mac and Windows 7. I did a quick test burn on a Win7 laptop (64 bit Home Premium) and it quickly and error free burned a few hundred megs at 24x to a CD. On a MacBook Pro late 2011 (running OS X 10.9) it worked nicely with nothing extra needed, as both a DVD and cd player (perfect for Air or Retina machines). For BR playback I needed to use Macgo (I used a trial version) as that seems to be the most popular SW available. It worked well with no stuttering or problematic playback of movies. I tested with the BR Avengers and BR 5th Element. Keep in mind that for BR playback there is an extra cost on top of the player itself. Macgo is currently priced at $40 (including a 30% discount) so factor that cost in if you need BR playback on the Mac. The same is true for Windows, where the price for the BR playback software seems to be about the same. The player does include some bundled trialware software for the PC, nothing for the Mac, but regardless, it's trial-ware and will eventually require you pay extra for the SW. I haven't loaded that SW but it looks like it's PowerDVD and you will need at least the Pro version to play back BR since the Deluxe version only plays back DVDs and not BluRay (look for the logo!)I should also point out that there are a lot of discussions out on the web about using VLC on Mac and Windows, and that may work for some discs but the encryption keys seem to have changed so only some older BR discs will play using the 2 files you need to add to VLC. Be sure to do some research first if you play to go this route.

This is a fun set of quotes from Warren Buffett's letters to share holders with some comments from the author included. It's a fun read but the quotes are taken out of the letters so lack the message and context. The author admits this is the case right from the start, so it's not a fault, just a feeling of missing information. For information about the person, I prefer the book, "The Snowball", which goes into Mr Buffett's life history and puts a story together that connects the dots and paints Mr Buffett as a real person, with real struggles, conflicts and successes.

Scooby-Doo has quickly become a favorite TV show in our family. I watched these as a kid and the DVD set is all of the old episodes without all the commercials. The only bad part is the inclusion of season 3 with Scrappy-Doo. That's not the fault of the set though, that was a pathetic attempt to make the series appeal to a broader audience, and failing!this set comes in a cardboard Mystery Machine case. the drawer slides open and all the discs are available inside. It's a fun way to have the series!

This is a fun game with Lego characters, and probably one of the best to date. I really like that like the other Lego adventure games, you unlock the characters on each level and can use them in the free play mode later. This is a fun game for me and my daughter to play together. She's 9 and has a lot of fun with me or with her friends when they play together. There's no "grown up" language and the violence is limited to disassembled Lego pieces. The game is long and difficult enough that younger kids will get a lot of game play out of it. My daughter will sometimes need my help to solve the puzzles to move on, but for the most part she can play it alone when she wants. There's a good variety of characters, including some female characters, but my daughter prefers playing Superman since he flies.

This is a good port of the old Sega Sonic game and brings back memories, but the controls make some of the jumps difficult. It's really designed to be used with a controller. The on screen controls do a good job most of the time though. My daughter really likes the game. It plays smoothly and at the right speed. Amazing that this used to be a cutting edge game on a console and now runs just as well on a phone.

Fits in the phone, under the OEM cover, without any problems. It will create a small bulge in the OEM cover, which may cause some cases to have slight fitment problems. We have a cheap 2 piece hard plastic cover we picked up at a mall kiosk, and it just barely fits together now.Be aware that if you use a magnetic mount phone holder in your car (e.g. Infiniapps or imagnet) then don't use a wireless charger. The metal plate you use to hold the phone on the magnet will interfere with the wireless charging and may get excessively hot if you try to make it work. I recommend using one or the other, but not both.Otherwise, this wireless charger works well and fits nicely. It connects to the 2 charging points inside the Samsung S3 phone's battery compartment, has a small adhesive tab to help hold it in place inside the phone and it works. It doesn't come with any instructions, but it's straight forward to install:1) Open the phone's battery cover and locate the 2 copper colored metal tabs one the phone next to the battery.2) on the wireless charger, pull back the cover for the matching 2 metal connectors on the tab. On my Sainsonic antenna it was glossy black paper-like cover on the connector of the antenna3) align the 2 metal contacts on the wireless antenna with the 2 matching points near the battery on the phone4) test fit your cover and case to make sure it all fits back together5) if everything is good fit-wise, then open the phone again and remove the small paper cover (on the antenna) that covers a small sticky patch which will hold the antenna in place on the battery. Don't try to peel open the antenna, it's just a small patch of adhesive on the antenna. Press the antenna in place, making sure to align the connection points again.6) reassemble the cover and case and that's it, you're now ready to enjoy wireless charging.

The design of this HRM is nice and clean. The unit itself is a little bulkier (thicker) than other units like the Garmin Premium soft strap (also sold on Amazon). The battery cover uses a coin to twist open and the unit uses a single 2032 lithium battery. It's a robust design that allows users to easily change the battery. The strap is decent, flexible and appears strong enough for several years of use.The only problem I had, and I'm hoping I'll be able to resolve soon is; I can't use it since it won't pair with my Samsung Note 3 phone. Both are supposed to be ANT+ compatible, but my phone has never been able to see any ANT+ accessory. I suspect I'm doing something wrong and hope to sort it out quickly.Update 3/28: The ANT+ service was disabled on my phone. Everything is great now. If you have a supported Android phone and are having pairing problems, make sure to check in the Application Manager for the ANT Radio Service to see that it's running.

I only wish these weren't so expensive! at $11/jar it's extremely expensive. I will have to talk with the local gourmet grocery stores to see if any can order this instead.
