I took a paper towel, pressed the dispenser and cleaned around the hole.  No more leaking.I'm starting to see a pattern here! :)
I've decided I prefer my current 2455.On the negative side, no DASHBOARD!!!  The improvements weren't enough to sway me.Also, no Emily (or any other TTS voice).

2 stars="I don't like it".  However, how you'll like them depends on you.  Here's what I see as the issues.(+)* Nice sound, better than my Skullcandy, not better than my Phiatons.  (More expensive than my Skullcandy, less expensive than my Phiatons).* They come with just about every type of tip you can think of.(o)* DO NOT try to use these as in the ear buds. (Okay, who am I to tell you what and what not to do?)  However, if you use them as in the earbuds you may find the cables heavy and that the buds don't stay in your ear;.* However, THEY WORK FINE as the over the ear style they were intended to be.  I found their seal better than my that of my earbuds.(-)* They're bulky and I find them awkward to put on. No big deal you might think, but I feel like why should I have to deal at all? I found it awkward to put the cord behind my head with my mp3 player in my shirt pocket.  I've had some trouble keeping the cables over my ears.  Maybe this wouldn't be a problem with practice, but practice to use a set of earbuds?!?!?!Bottom line: nice sound, but awkward trumps sound.  I'll stick with what I'm using.(I was sent a set of earbuds to review. They did not come with a return postage envelope.  If they had, I would return them and not miss them.)

I CANNOT BELIEVE I AM GIVING THIS 1 STAR DEVICE 3 STARS.!This tuner deserves 1 star because it is only a matter of time until its ratchet fails and the tuner will no longer stay on the instrument  The reason I can't award 1 star is because I continue to buy and use them. It is otherwise the ideal ukulele tuner where weight is paramount if the tuner will be left on the instrument most of the time.  If the ratchet didn't fail, this would be one of the easiest 5 star reviews I've written.Also, I have a workaround for when one fails:* I put the tuner on the instrument.* I squeeze it to how it should be if the ratchet hadn't failed.* I slide the tuner off the instrument without moving the ratchet.* I use superglue to fix the ratchet so that it won't move.* I let the tuner dry overnight, just to be safe.* I slide the tuner back on the instrument.So, flimsy = 1 star.  Without flimsiness, 5 stars.  There are things one can do should (when) the ratchet fail(s). I give up!  3 stars.My original reviews follow.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This could have been a great tuner.  It's one of those situations where first opinions can be misleading.  I got one, disliked it for the reasons stated below, and threw it in a drawer.  Lately, I decided that this tuner would be IDEAL for the ukulele, where weight is paramount.  I have a few ukes, so I bought two more!  What I' now finding out is that the ratchet system wears out, and no wonder. The ratchet is an inexpensive piece of plastic with tiny grooves. There's no spring. It appears that its the piece that fits into the groove that's worn out. No matter which part it is. It will no longer stay on.  It's a shame.  I was really starting to like this tuner and change my rating to 5 stars for use with a ukulele.  But, one star it is.----------------------Most other tuners have s spring loaded clamp that affixes the tuner to the instrument. This one doesn't.  It has a ratcheting device.  You squeeze it. and the tuner is "held in place" by pressure and slight friction from rubber pads on the inside surfaces. There's a plastic piece on the back that holds the ratchet closed.  Touch it (like when an instrument is in its case and the tuner touches a surface) and the tuner pops off.Those looking for something small might consider a Son of Snark (aka mini-Snark).

Every once in a while, Amazon messes up.  This is one of those times.  I wanted "Roll Down to Rio". If you click on the sample for "Roll Down To Rio" you'll find that it's "Sir Richard's Song". With Some experimenting, I found that "Dayspring Mishandled" is, in fact, "Roll Down To Rio", which is just what I wanted.Listening to the samples told me that I have to give another listen to the entire Bellamy/Kipling canon.  Kipling was a master wordsmith. Bellamy was a master at pairing traditional (mostly) tunes with them.

Wow!  It's just as advertised...and more.  What the listing does not say (and, for that reason, I don't know whether it will always be true) is that it comes with one Guitar Extension Pack.The stand is one piece, collapses, and comes fully assembled. I got mine to hold 3 open-back banjos.  It does that just fine, but I couldn't help thinking that it might be a bit wider than necessary and perhaps I could have gotten something a bit narrower. But, the light bulb went on almost immediately. I slid the spacers to the left, still leaving a comfortable amount of room for each instrument, installed the extension pack, and the stand now holds three open back banjos and a dreadnought size acoustic guitar.  Four instruments that used to take up a room now occupy only a corner of it.Somewhere (maybe not here) states that the stand can hold up to six guitars. I can believe it if they have thin Strat or Tele types of bodies. Not 6 acoustics, though.

Install software, download updates and state forms, enter data in a straightforward manner, file returns--federal electronically, state via USPS (d*mned if I'll pay to save the state work). All done in less that a few hours with no stress. What else is there?

Does exactly what it's supposed to do, but seems a bit dear.  I've used the mini for years.  This one is just like it, but bigger.  It would have been nice if there were a mini ZTS model that tested coin batteries like the CR2032 to complement the mini, but there isn't.

Paige capos of this design get 5 stars.  They do what they do extremely well.  Just as good as the ultra high end and ultra high end expensive McKinneys and Elliotts.  Uniform tension across the strings.  Not too little, not too much.  (Unless you set it that way on purpose!)However, for an "off label" use--a UKULELE CAPO--I award it 4 STARS.[Everything that follows is about Paige capos.]I'm looking for a ukulele capo that I can slip over the nut when not in use.  The guitar capo is too wide. (It works, but it looks like it violates Mr. Natural's rule about using the right tool for the job.) The regular banjo/mandolin capo is oh-so-slightly too narrow.  I was hoping the wide banjo/mandolin capo would be just right.  It's better and it works, but it's still a bit wide. The ideal uke capo would be between the banjo/mandolin and wide banjo/mandolin capos. Still, I don't know anything that works better if being able to slide the capo over the nut is an important consideration, unless one wanted to spend 7+ times the cost of a Paige for an Elliott.  That's a bit much, even for me...at the moment, anyway.

Keeps my drink cold all day long. I'm really not usually found of stainless steel anything but my grandma says in her day that was what everything was made of and it held up and kept drinks cool. VERY PRETTY, great price! It looks like the photo. The corset alone is worth the price of the entire costume. As long as you know to order up one to two sizes, these corsets are beautifully made, high end corsets for a great price. There is a trick to hooking the stays, do the bottom stay, then the top stay, after that hooking up the middle stays will be much easier. Also make sure the laces tie at your waist so you can adjust the back. After the stays are hooked, pull the laces from the waist and it will cinch right up, then tie it.

I like Gary's approach.  He is a straight shooter and it really seems like he genuinely wants to help people.  I stumbled upon this because he is speaking at a conference I may go to and I wanted to read about his story.  His father's work ethic obviously was passed on to him.  Gary has been able to make a name for himself for hosting Wine Library TV, which discusses wine tasting flavors and he gives his opinion.  The Wine Library is a store in NJ and is considered one of the best Wine stores in the country.  Gary has been a large part of that growth.  There is no denying his ability to build a business and to brand himself.The reason I am giving this book 3 stars is because it is dated.  A lot of the book is about branding yourself.  Gary suggests doing this by creating your own website, and blasting yourself out there on social media.  This is all old info, albeit, still very sound advice.  I agree, it's important to get out there and make a name for yourself.  It's easier said than done.  For those that don't have the extroversion to go out there and start a youtube channel, or find a way to gather 30,000 twitter followers, the task is daunting.  Gary suggests using a "Flip Cam" which I haven't seen in years.The point is this.  Get out there and market yourself.  Whatever it is you're good at and passionate about, get out there and build an image and brand based on that.  I wish this book was updated because I think it needs to be.  The world, and technology in particular, change at a rapid pace.  This is basic information in this book.  I still believe it's worth the read because it's pretty short and easy.  It's not a timeless classic, but it's still a good read.  I hope to hear more from Gary in the future.

I have been doing Hot Yoga for a couple of years now.  I have gone thru multiple mats.  Even more expensive mats, I needed to add a yoga towel  in order to not slip. This selfie stick is really well made.  It comes with an attachment for a cell phone and also a GoPro.  You can fit digital cameras on it also. The twist locks are easy to use and the pole feels sturdy at full length. 2 other features I really like are the strap that unscrews so you can mount the stick on a tripod, and the clip it comes with so you can clip it to a bag or belt loop.  If I had to pick potential negatives, the handle is short so those with monster hands may go past the foam grip.  The other thing is while it does extend, there are poles that do go a bit bigger.  Neither of these bothered me but I wanted to point them out in case they bother you.  Overall, this is a great product, and certainly one of the better quality ones out there.  The reason for the 4 stars?  While I received this at a discount for my honest feedback, I think the regular price is too high.  I think there are other sticks out there that may have more bang for the buck.  Other than that, it's a quality product.  Thanks!

Very easy to install.  I took off the wall plate, unscrewed the switch from the wall.  I only had 3 wires.  2 black and 1 copper ground.  I unscrewed the wires, and used the provided yellow caps to connect the wires together ( the Lutron wires come already connected to the unit so you have to use the screw caps to connect the wires from the wall).  It didn't matter for me which black wires I connected, so i just used the "bottom" one to connect to the left Lutron wire, and my old "top" wire to connect to the Lutron right wire( right meaning if I am facing the back of the unit from the wall).  It was a little tough shoving the wires back into the wall, but I got it done.  I'd say the whole thing took me 10-15 minutes.  I am medium handy.  This is actually the second one I've done.  The other I installed was a 3 pole switch was a bit more involved.  I've also installed 2 solar timers which the 1st took about an hour, because I had to continuously run up an down the stairs to turn the power off , test, etc.In any event, don't be afraid.  Just shut the power off and make sure you only need a single pole switch, meaning there is only 1 location to turn the light on, as opposed to a 3 way pol, meaning there are 2 different switches that control the light.  If you need that, it's slightly more involved, but Lutron sells that as well.  Enjoy!

I will start off by saying that I am still in my first month, but I wanted to get a review out there for those who are looking to get started.  I will be updating this a few times as I progress.My background: Male, 160 lbs, just turned 36 at the time this review was written.  Body fat was around 11.5% , but too many Christmas cookies got me recently back over 12.5% ( since starting Max 30, trending back down ).  I have completed multiple rounds of Insanity, Insanity Asylum, P90X 1,2 and 3, most recently doing P90X 3 for the last year.  As with most other workouts, as much as I Loved it, I started to plateau.  New Year, new program, I randomly stumbled upon Max 30 in Men's Health.  I had no idea it was coming out and I was pumped and ready for the change.Generally, I like to start new workouts on a Monday, as that's how the schedule for Max 30 sets up ( monday-friday), but I couldn't wait, and started on a Saturday.  Ok enough BS , let's get down to bizness...The Workouts:As I stated earlier, the calendar starts on Monday.  U do 5 workouts, then 1 optional light recovery workout, followed by a day of rest.  The workouts are all 30 minutes ( hence Max 30) , except for the Pulse (optional) workout which is only 20 minutes.  There is also an ab workout that you can add which is 10-15 min.  Each workout ends with a 2 minute cool down.Weeks 1 and 2 schedule:Cardio Challenge- Pretty standard Insanity style.  Jumps, sprints, burpees, and some absTabata Power- Intervals with 20 seconds on and 10 seconds offSweat Intervals- Similar in style to Cardio ChallengeTabata PowerFriday Fight, round 1: Absolutely brutal.  No water break for the first 15 minutes. Awesome workout, but tough.Pulse or RestRest.After 2 weeks u substitute Tabata Power with Tabata Strength.Month 2 adds MAX OUT Cario, Power, Sweat, Strength and Friday Fight round 2.  I will review these when I get there.Are the workouts hard?Yes!  But that's what you want right?  Perhaps you are a Beachbody vet like myself , or maybe you are a treadmill junkie looking to make the change.  Unless you are seriously overweight or have major health issues, you can do Max 30.  I get exhausted, and I get short of breath and I'm dying for water, but I make it through and by the end of the workout, I feel amazing.  You sweat like you can't believe, but the workouts go by fast.As much as I love p90x3 (it's my favorite Beachbody workout), I didn't come close to sweating like I do with Max 30.  Shaun T is the ultimate motivator.  He pushes you to succeed, like having a personal trainer right there with you.  The big thing with this workout is that Shaun T invites you to write down your Max Out minute.  For example, let's say you push to 11 minutes, then finally you're just dying for a break, you've maxed out, and you write down which minute that is ( there is a little max out timer on the screen ), and you try and push just a little further than last time.Cons?Only 1 right now.  There is no really intense stretch at the end.  The 2 minutes is  a brief cool down and very light stretch.  After a workout like that, I feel you need a real stretch to properly prevent injury.  That being said, I do appreciate the brevity as I know they are trying to keep it around 30 minutes, and I can always do extra stretching on my own.In conclusion, I really love Max 30 and I'm pumped they came out with it.  I skipped T 25 because I heard mixed reviews.  This to me is an awesome workout.  1 caveat tho.  You can do as much Max 30 as you want, but if you eat lots of cake , sweets, and fried foods, don't expect too much.  If you are investing in this workout, invest in yourself, and the food you eat.  Little by little make smarter decisions on how you eat, follow his program, and you will be looking and feeling great in no time.  I'll be back for more detail.  If you like my review and you thought it was helpful, please click the yes button below..Thanks!

Admittedly, I am probably not your prototypical reader of this genre.  I am a 35 year old married male with children.  That being said, one of my guilty pleasures is reading a feel good Christmas book every year; that and watch Christmas originals on Lifetime and Hallmark.  I can admit that I am in touch with my sensitive side, especially during Christmas time.  I decided to read this book based on the reviews and I was pleasantly surprised.The book has your typical layout.  Lonely divorced woman meets someone to share the holidays with.  Of course, she has a sad back story.  In the end, they are happy.  Pretty typical stuff.  So what was so special about it?  Well, it was a bot different in terms of how it was set up.  The story is that Elise enters into a "contract" with a guy from her building, who is also sick of spending the holidays alone.  With this contract, she will attend all of his holiday parties, and all expenses will be paid.  I don't want to go into too much detail, but I was sympathetic towards the characters and I had a clear picture of them in my mind.  To be honest, when I first started reading it , I rolled my eyes a bit.  I've read too many cheesy Christmas books in the past.  But about 30 pages in, I started to look forward to reading it.  I'm glad I stuck with it.Hurry up and read it. Christmas is Near!

I have been looking for one of these for a while.  Since I use my iPhone as my GPS in my car, I needed something to hold it in place.  The Cup holder wasn't working and neither was the armrest.  I bought the car mouth and it works GREAT!  I have an iPhone 6 and it fits perfectly.  It's easily adjustable to fit most phones yet small enough to be non invasive. Buy with confidence!

This was a great watch for my soon to be 4 year old.  I say WAS, because he had it for 3 days before it went missing.  Like most little boys, he tends to forget where he puts (drops) things :)  These are the joys of having young children.  Anyway, it worked fine and looked cute, but as you can see, I can't attest for the longevity.  It was inexpensive, but it seemed to work and fit well.  This is my little guys 2nd lost watch this year.  He still asks about it all the time, but sorry little guy! You'll have to wait!

Cute, but it's inexpensive for a reason.  It's one and done.  My kids ripped thru it in 5 minutes.  Every year arund this time, I get excited for Halloween.  My kids are young, so I buy them a couple of these to get them in the spirit ( as if they need any help!), but it's really for me to get excited about it!  A few little spooky things, or activity books is all I get.  So this one was cute, but really from the time I took it out of the box til the time they were finished was literally under 8 minutes.  Take a shot, just keep your expectations low.

This book has been very helpful to me getting up and running with my blog.  A lot of people write books about how to blog just so they can throw their websites or other products in there for you to buy.  And while I'm all for promoting your product and brand, for some people, we just want to know what to do!  I don't want to hear about how I can click the link to your website, or your affiliates sites.  This book goes in depth, teaching you about the actual business of blogging.  I have literally read about 10 books about the subject.  I've learned a little from each one, but if you are gonna choose 1, this is it.  I have gone through it twice now.  Also, for those looking on how to setup wordpress, I recommend Wordpress for Beginners by Dr. Andy Williams.  Also, sorry 1 last thing. If you are gonna start an online business, I suggest subscribing to Kindle unlimited.  This way, at least if you want to try other books, you can read them for free before you decide if you want to buy it.  Good Luck!

The quality of this product is outstanding! Not too thick, not too thin but just right. The aroma is of light cucumbers. Very relaxing. Once applied in the evening I awake without puffy bags under my eyes! Although I have only used this product for a week, I've noticed some fading in those potentially pesky crowfeet I was beginning to see. This was a great purchase and I just placed an order for the moisturizer too!
The lights are larger than expected which is a good thing. Very bright and and look more expensive than they are!
Very good spotlights. Seem to work well at illuminating my back garden walls.

Costs a lot because it's one of the few RIGID WATERPROOF  ornanment containers. The others look like your heirloom glass ornament  bulbs will fit fine but crush and break to shards the second the dog sits on them or the carrier gets smushed in the closet, or is all cardboard and will mush up if it gets wet in storage, and has some fabric cover that gets filty dusty in no time.  This won't.It's the ONLY one I've found that has rigid walls and won't get water damage. .But it costs a lot and the plastic, while rigid is cheap. Mine ARRIVED wih one of the corners dented, and so the thign had to be taped to hold.I kept it. I would imagine many of these crack during shipping but it's STILL the only rigid one out there, and for the cost of a iece of duct tape (the universal solver of all problems) it was not worth the hassle of return to get another probably cracked one anyway.Downsides- WAY expensive, cracks easily. Upside, only rigid one around, and tape will fix it- I'm - oddly, recommending it as rigid non cardoboard (non-water damageable) heirloom ornament storage. I'm warning of the cracks and the high price. I just don't see an equivalent or better (or even cheaper) alternative.

Color warning- I got it for the cotton dobby - which is fine but also largely for the COLOR- the bright rich lime green.It's not that color. It's the same EXACT 'sage' pale celery color you see in bedding everywhere. It's one thing to say 'the monitor this, the photo technology that, dye lots, the other,  we can't guarantee exact color".But this is is almost a frank attempt at misrepresenting the same standard pale sage bedding, to look like a hip vivid desginer color it is not. Shame on them.that said, it's a cotton, which is great, not a microfiber and it fits and it's fine.

I'm in love. Saw a LOT of other clothes hampers, tried a few. this is the highest quality in a low cost item. (I was surprised. Flimsy net basket ones cost almost as much.)Quality shock-pole assembly, takes about 2 minutes to assemble, really holds up.LOOKS fantastic. Far more chic than the other cloth ones (and even some wood or wicker or...) and doesn't fall over. Plus two coordinated colors for sorting ('brown' and 'other brown', essentially) both of which look great.

I read the reviews, I liked the plastic dollies, but this is the one to get. Heavy duty. Won't bend. Center wheel. small wheels but they go over doorways, RUBBER wheels, not plastic, metal attachement (won't crack like plastic. Ugh, I've had that happen. those are great dollys for five seconds, then suddenly, they're just a costly door-stopper.)This has handles on both sides, the weels swivel 360 degrees.I've hauled so much on this. no bend. Non slip padding. Rock solid. great wheels. and unlike the also heavy duty wood 1x4 dollies (the standard ones old as the hills) - this you can slide thigns onto.Can't ask for more. thought it was a bit costly. Nope. Best value i've seen, most durable / versatile so far.

It looks low key and stylish in the photo. But when I got it, cheezy cheap dated styling on the buckle.Plus, warning, this is the post and hole style buckle.I got it because I'm looking for leather alternatives in ordinary belts (not brightly colored plastic or sports franchise belts) and got tired of webbing belts- plus they are not good for anything business or formal.The belt is okay but the buckle is silly. It looks like a cheap gloss that will wear off and it's sort of conspicuously disco-era. It wants to be worn with tight polyester and a Members Only jacket.I kept it because it was too cheap for a return and I'll wear it with a sweater over it. (As a belt, it holds pants up. But, my bad in that I didn' think it through, this is not a chinch belt bucle. It's the one you flip in and out of the belt hole. Not a great design.)I'm keeping it cause it was cheap and I can cover it but I don't recommend this.

Does NOT fit Dirt Devil Featherlite Cyclonic. NOr can it be altered TO fit. It's  LISTED to fit the Dirt Devil Featherlite Cyclonic, but it does not. And it's cheapishly made and wouldn't stand in as a 'replacement' if it did. But it doesn't anyway.

I cannot see the product on the photo. I have a Dirt Devil Featherlite Cyclonic. Suppose to fit.Does not.  In fact, I cannot FIND, anywhere, even from Dirt Devil, a replacement filter that fits this.It's rated to fit my machine, the numbers line up. It's too big, and the wrong shape and has no sealer ring...

Best cost per quality- best heavy duty wire shelving EVER.I wish I found the Omega Precision BEFORE i got the cheaper stuff. And, Omega Precision is not even expensive. Tiny bit more, because the quality is not 'cheap'- the quality is OUTSTANDING. It's real, quality steel, and real heavy duty design- buy it for life. It is built to hold a rated limit, but it will withstand a lot more than that. (don't DO that- but if you're sick of sort of 'works for now sort of) Get the real one.  Best casters ever, by the way. I've purchased, used, assembled a LOT of many brands of wire shelving. Good stuff, but- the casters are weak, or the stuff chips, or it won't come together twice, or it won't fit standard sizes, or it's weight-over-rated and gets bendy, or it lands shakey and stresses it'self out.Not Omega precision. Wish I found this much sooner. This is the one I've been looking for but thought it cost thousands of dollars for this quality. NOPE! The tall one i got, no 'little rods you screw together and hope for the best' as you load it down with your tools, or stored boxes, or heavy pots and pans.My tall steel rods came separately SOLID high-grade steel, will last probably a few lifetimes, and still LOOK GREAT!  They are the real deal for long-term heavy storage, no chipping, flaking rusting, straining or bending with these.They have sizes to choose from. I wanted something TALL. I don't want to buy everything 60" or under, I want all the storage space. And because I load things down (don't we all...)  it really HAS to be heavy duty. And it has to have wheels, and GOOD wheels at that. (casters alone, are either cheap, or very costly.)  AND- I needed long and narrow, to go next to my refrigerator.I'm sold on this. I tried others but this is the real deal. They are all modular, and if you have to add, Omega has a lot of options. (and if you hit the hardware store for an add on, it will fit, so you'er not limited that way.) This conforms to the usual standards in sizes, but BETTER than what's in the hardware store, for your basic unit.I like and am going back to the same company, because they also have this quality for wall-mount shelving. (I'm sick of those wire closet shelves- white wire adjustables that look like a dish-drain, and always get gooey, and fall down after a few years)This Omega company, it turns out, makes gorgeous chrome (two different styles) for heavy duty adjustable closet shelving.  They have full serivce add ons, not just 'chrome buy and go'. They have  butcher block liners for kitchen use that are amazingly cost effective, as well as anti-microbial shelf liner, I looked them up- they have full support and all the add ons I wanted but was unaware of or thought I'd have to get piecemeal and hope for an okay fit. They have tons of options and the company stands behind them. (Best customer service ever.)This is the one to get.  They stand behind their products, it's true industrial grade but works lovely for a house /apartment and the whole line is industrial grade interchangeable with professional add-ons and options at household, not huge industrial costs.You see one for cheaper with little plastic wheels and screw-together construction and no real other options for shelf lining or other usage, no coordinated wall shelves.  Or it's not the right size but you'll make do, or it doesn't really fit other systems.Skip that, and get this one. Then  thank yourself.

I stil cannot believe they send mattresses in the mail. This came rolled up. Nobody knew it was a queen sized mattress.  (they put it in a heavy plastic vaccum bag, suck the air all the heck out and roll it up.)  It's heavy but- the days of having to arrange mattress delivery are history. this is 'click. mattress you can carry in it's box or bag.) Open it up and it 'inflates'.  In less than an hour it's a mattress. Overnight or so (jump on it) and you can put your must have separate purchase dust and bug/ allergen cover on it. (Don't put that on right way. You can sleep on the mattress in an hour or so, and put sheets on certainly. But you'd want to give the mattress a day or two to fully fluff, before putting any protective cover on it.)It's real quality. The look is great, the quilted top really is breathable and comfortable and it's an ecellent several layer memory foam (so it HAS some body to it. it's not all sinking into mush you can't get out of).if you've had memory foam before, the ones with denser regular foam sandiwich below with some gel foam and some ohther stuff and JUST a few inches of that wierdly comfortable visco-eleastic  is the better way to go.  (I've lied down on '$2000 solid block of costly memmory foam" and it's too danged gushy. Not 'soft'- just oddly gushy.) I will update a I use it over time, but for ~$400  (less, I think) for "Quality Memory foam gel- nicely styled, nicely quilt topped Mattress In A Can"- I could not be happier. I've spent a lot more on a lot lower qualtiy mattresses.Ps- if you're torn, the click and ship roll up spring pillowtop is also good. But innerspring v memory foam gel is personal.)This is a total HIGH RECOMMEND.

Love these so much I bought two. I foster animals so, tons of pellet litter, tons of dry food. Nobody wants lots of odd random storage or things air, moisture and PESTS gawd forbid, could get into and who wants to lug those pet totes around?Problem SOLVED.  Airtight durable locking storage WITH scoop, in GREAT colors, ON WHEELS.  Not heavy duty wheels- and the wheels do not lock in tight. If you lift the tote, they can sorta slide back out.But rolling heavy duty (I really pack these things) air tight, watertight, pest tight storage that can sit under my kitchen table and look neat.The WHEELS and the Airtight were the selling points. The PRICE is great.  I had one for almost a year, for litter, loved it so much I got another one for dry food.Plus you get the airtite other storage box (and it's a generous size) coordinated for your other pet stuff.I've spent more on pet food and litter totes that were not nearly as good.  This is a total 'click and get THIS one'. Nothing is PERFECT in plastic rolling storage but this super-excellent and GREAT price.Yay!

Sterlite makes good not too pricey  plastic storage but you really have to buy in bulk to get a value.I'm a little iffy on this STYLE, in that the plastic itself is a bit soft, pliable. SO- if you overstuff these (and who doesn't overstuff storage- these are good sweater boxes, winter or summer clothing storage etc.) the lids DO tend to smoosh up. There's no tight waterproof seal, no rigid grip all around the rim. So I'm now wary of two locks on the long end).That said, 12 pack is a GREAT  good truly stackable locking storage. WAY bonus points for the color. Would buy again for some purposes. BUT- be aware that if you overstuff, the lids will mush up and expose the contents to moisture and air.

I got this when Feline Pine sold out to  Arm and Hammer, and A&H turned excellent Feline Pine into regular horse bedding anyway, but at a specialty cat product price.Note- for  kitty litter- I use the pine pellet litterbox and recommend it. that $20-10 shipping $30 dollar- so, expensive for an open  pan-style-  cat litter box has saved me a fortune in clean up, in litter cost, in evil muddy dusty bad-for-cats clay litter. Any pine beats clay and the drop down pan system, all my cats and fosters love not getting their feeties wet. Great system these sieve down pine litter trays.Back to THIS product?  A bit of pine dust, crumbly, but now Feline Pine is cheap chop anyway but costs more.this- $8 plus $17 for shipping- that's $25 dollars for forty lbs of very entirely serviceable all pine cat litter. GREAT(A note. I tried using wood stove pellets also- they're cheap. BUT - most are made of mixed wood- hicory, etc. These do  not smell good with wee, and do not absorb wee and break apart as readily. If you've jumped the costly Feline Pine ship when they sold out, this bedding is great, there are good horse beddings out there too- just the same pine pellets cheap in bulky but non pine Stove Pellets are not good for kitty litterboxes.)UPDATE- The prices for this, and the price and formulation of Feline Pine changed since I first wrote this review. This now costs $1 dolalr per pound through Amazon distributors and is no longer a good buy!  And the price on FB is down- I find it on pet supply websites (with free shipping on orders over $50, so I get cat food with it) and now FPs formula is better, AND the price comes to about $20 per 40lb bag including (free) shipping.Whatever you use- this or FP or another pine pellet litter- there are many easy bargains. If you pay more than 50 cents a pound (or less) for pine pellet litter, including shipping, you're paying too much - look around on pet sites or check back on Amazon for bargains on say, Feline Pine or other pine pellet products.

I got these once, trying to get cheap resuable washcloths KNOWING- and be advised, that these are BABY washcloths. I just wanted something inexpensive and thin that I could use a lot, thin enough to wipe and wash and then toss in the laundry without thick ones (lint buildup) and without the cost of laundering regular 12x12 ones. They ARE soft and great and a bit smaller for babies, but they are ALSO really durable for quick wipes, body or sink baths.I have purchased bulk cotton washcloths. Turns out they cost more to launder and aren't as soft and don't hold up well.Here is the real bonus on these small, but soft  NOT thick cloths- they are super-durable and while soft on skin, they hold up GREAt for household cleaning.My first pack was for elder care.  My SECOND purchase- best value in durable household cleaning cloths!  I highly recommend them for all these things. Babies, elders, frequent washings without high laundry cost or shredding and falling apart or lint (they're virtually lint-free) AND- they actually scrub without damage (even though they are very gentle on skin, so it's a magic trick how this is so) they scrub kitchens, windows, floors, furniture etc without damage and wash clean well.this is excellent.

This is as thick and fluffy without being also cheap and linty, as you want a bathmat to be, it comes in sizes (my bathroom is small- so I got a soft absorbent thick durable bathmat that looks GREAT- really luxe modern clean, not like a 'towel, but on the floor'- AND because I could order the 17X23" - I could get that at a decent price for quality  WITHOUT being obligated to spend more and / or buy the 23X30 or any other larger 'on size fits all' thick bathmat.How does this help? If you've ever laundered your bathmats, you know they soak up laundry and dryer money and energy.This is great, any size, the quality is real fluffy bathmat, not cheap. AND bonus, order the smaller one and you get the luxe feel but save (by my calculations) about $20 a year off your laundry costs.

Got this to wear under turtlenecks and pullover sweaters this fall  / winter. Went small so it would fit under those. It looks nice but feels a bit cheapish. (Like, I would get it a gain maybe but really I'm on a mission to find something soft and non 'stinky microfiber' or supercostly tech-gear - also stinky microfiber with some 'anti stink'. My cotton stuff doesnt NEED anti-stink technology in the first place.) This runs small.  It follows the formula of reverse-vanity sizing and comes from the land where everyone is sort of supermodel thin or pre-pubescent even when they're a full grown adult.But it's a decent enough quality. It's just not AS comfortable and it does run tiny-gal-tight, which I hate. I don't need 'big', I just feel a bit ripped off when the one that should fit, it just runs narrow everywhere, just to save the mfg twenty cents in materials. Hey.Not two, but not four.  It does work but, it isn't the soft 'forget it's there' warm undershirt I'd hoped for.

This is a bargain. Good fit, cheap cotton 'derwears you can toss out frequently. But - and there is NO misrepresentation, you can see from the photo- you will be stuck with four pairs of white cotton undies and and at least two pairs you consider ugly.  I haven't worn white cotton undies since I was 10 years old, and yet, I pass them off as 'chick tighty whities for ladies' to myself with some ironic humour. (and if we are really talking 'undies', gals- buy a bottle of peroxide, use it on even  your colored underthingies. I'm very clean to begin with but I thought "wow, undies need oxyclean or peroxide.".For the bargain and every day use, this is a quality brand that fits the way you'd expect, and the small fits my oversized ass so that's a bonus- I'm not a 'small' for anything BUT bulk underwear, but the medium (6) was big.This is a great staple (yay. Except for frilly special stuff, I'm done with everyday undies for six months or so) and they are, as 'derwears should be, more or less disposable. (they will last. but daily 'derwers should be tossed frequently. And if you've spent $15 dollars a pair on 'really cute' but cheap ones, you know you should do that but paid too much. So hygiene take a back seat).  These you can toss sort of guilt free if the wash or hand wash doesn't come out they way it should after a few wearings. They always tell us to toss those things, here you're not throwing out your paycheck. Or holding onto ones you should toss 'just a little longer, so cute, cost so much'.At this price, with this quality and more durability than they need to have,  while no glamour obtains, the kind of thing you feel fresh (cotton! No tag! Elastic doesn't crimp or peel off!) - they're really good go-to stuff.And if you are a shopper, and have (as I have) bought for $5-20 each 'cute panties!' that looked cute but rode or felt like hell or fell apart or..  it turns out whatever color these are, they are great go-to good fit, 'tighty whities for gals'.Why the missing final star?  Because, come on, FOTL, put at least ONE really awesome cute pair in each pack. They ARE ladies underthingies. Would it KILL you to do some designer print instead of just 'well, dots, stripes, at least that's not ugly'.If they swapped a white pair for anything cute (hey. purple. Lime green. girls do acyually want to have fun you know.) they'd get the fifth star.

If you know anyone who does not like a) alchol b) a burning sensation or c) MINT (and or 'cinamon), this is the ONLY working mouthwash I can find. I HATE mint. I can tolerate toothpaste, but it KILLS me that EVERYTHING 'home oral care' Is MINTY MINTY MINTY and burny and so on. (I like to rinse my mouth after I eat. My elder father needs to rinse after eating for his health). But not everyone wants to top off a good meal, or even a pizza- with a blast of alcohol and menthol.Grab this wherever you can find it. It's EFFECTIVE as a mouthwash, it's MILD on the mouth, and it won't ruin your life. It tastes- not too sweet but like a mild fruit flavored gum.It's also the only NON-mint one on the market (besides a few herbals which replace 'burning mint sensation!" with equally 'burning cinnamon sensation!")Excellent, and finally, and the only thing like it on the general market. I got tons of it. It always sells out. Stock up, if you like it.

Orange pop up mesh laundry basket, just like they have all over.  A bit more than the cost of the ones at the dollar store. but, orange. Bright and motivating is always a ;us with chore-related items. What can you say? It's fine. And cheap and will break dow  and will be replaced by another cheap bright laundry basket.BUT- for $10-$12, you can get a REALLY nice, slightly larger stand  up cotton canvas swanky looking one with a sturdy frame, in decorous tan and brown. I recommend the OTHER ones. This is cheapo dorm style stuff, fine for what it is, but invest in better for anything else.

This is a perfectly good compact motorized fold up treadmill, which works just fine.  I almost did not get it, I am glad I took some negative remarks about it with a grain of salt, and did NOT worry and go for much pricier equipment. This is a low-to-mid priced folding but not compact, MOTORIZED treadmill, in NARROWER size for small spaces,. It's perfect. I really like it. I saved a mint. I have USED other gym and home treadmills, but have not owned others. This is just what I wanted. Read on if you're on the fennce abut this- it's really good!Caveat:  this review is from a SHORT LAZY person, in a studio apartment- I can't comment on long stride, or if it works for big-and-tall persons, nor households looking for large or fancy (laptop or phone plug in, or work-desk enabled, or high variable incline or multiple home heavy use, or wider, nor- really compact- machines.)  But for a regular user, in a small apartment, this is GREAT- the negative reviews are not necessarily entirely true. (Though excercise equipment is very individual- so no dis on any other reviewers' experiences) .- Setup in under 20 minutes -solo (I'm 50 years old, not an athlete or gym rat)  It weighs sort of middling for treadmills, getting it out of the box was the only 'hard' part. And not that hard. Assembly was a complete piece of cake.I'm glad I disregarded some negative reviews on this - I almost did not buy it- almost got one a lot costlier (on a credit card. Debt. Yike!) but this is a great little (heavy, but compact folding) walking AND JOGGING, Sturdy, Quiet, Freehand- walking AND jogging machine,1- Yes, you can jog - it is not just for walking. It's well-sturdy enough for jogging.2- Yes, freehand walking and jogging. NO you do NOT have to 'hold onto the bars' unless you have a sense of unsteadyness, prior injury, etc.  Eg- I'm uncoordinated and a total klutz. For walking or jog, I DID get the benefits of the arm-swinging balancing-  that was a dealbreaker for me with treadmills. I read "you MUST hold the bars". I took a shot. Works fine, truly, freehand for me, the ordinary clod. (NOTE: I cannot give medical recommendation- so DO know your own balance and limits, check with your doctor etc.) But I found the stated I found the REQUIREMENT that you 'grip the bar'-  even for a normal klutz with no sense of coordination- was excessive. I had NO problem at 1-3 mph (walking speeds) walking and jogging,  freehand for long time periods. Like, I was reading the manual and watching tv.)3- This is STURDY. The tray/ dashbord is cheap, - some space for a book or magazine, and two cup holders for your gin and tonics (j/K) but no real 'working table' as such. (forget that. Get a different treadmill.) But the machine is very sturdy and metal, blalanced- no rattle, thump-a-thump etc.  I'm impressed!  I expected it to be all but disposable.But this was really adequate (MIND YOU I AM SHORT) - for walking and jogging, freehand, while reading and watching tv. (It's not recommended that a person be distracted, but it's not a flimsy thing that will topple or explode or fall over or so on.) Nice reasonably solid feel. (I've seen $1,300 treadmills that are HEAVIER by far, but not appreciably STURDIER for normal use.)  But- pay SOME attention. ANY treadmill can throw you clean into a wall if you hit it on, or hit a fast speed.) But this is not wobbly badly made thing overall.4- QUIET Motor -  Yay. BIG plus.  I expected and worried it would sound like a lawnmower. In a studio apartment with neighbors all over- I worried that a lower cost machine would have a loud motor and be a thing that also registers and transmits footfalls (Brzzzzz! Bonk Bonk Bonk!- "Oh, I see the neighbor got a treadmill.") NOPE. It's not silent but it's really quiet. I don't have to raise the tv volume (which I keep relatively low), I don't have the 'oh there goes that MOTOR", and it doesn't klonk when I jog. (Note: Secure all bolts AND the console screws tightly, and re-tighten them as needed.)It's really surprisinly quiet. My sewing machine is noisy. My FAN is noisy. This thing is just a steady low not-unpleasant hum that lets me know the machine is on. But does not let my NEIGHBORS know, nor do you hear it from the kitchen.Go with the motor treadmill if you are not an athlete and have no willpower. I looked at the $100 dollar cheaper 'no motor' treadmills. For that, I can just use 'pavement' or 'the park'. Which I never do because my laziness spectrum is vast but as to things I've at least sort of sometimes dabbled in or do once a week un-dilligently - semi-yoga stuff?  okay. Light weights?  okay. Stretching, okay- feels good if done short term. but AEROBIC stuff? No WAY!. So I need the pavement moving underneath me on it's own to motivate me to move forward. I would take a cab from my door to the corner bodega if I could. I'm THAT 'walk-lazy'. I will help you mover your furniture from your apartment up and down four flights of stairs slowly as to lifting and 'hard work' - while sweating profusely, but if someone has to make a one block run for potato chips, it will be 'you, not me'MOTORIZED treadmills solve the motivation problem and THIS has a relatively quiet, relatively smooth motor, it starts at 1mp always so I don't fling into the wall, it moves up in 1/10 mil of an hour increments, so I don't go from 1 mp directly to two (you CAN, but you have the butto that slowly gradually increases speed at your direction- it doesn't 'automatically speed up')I clip the 'stop' thingie- the clip- the magnet that auto- stops it, the lanyard- whatever that thing is- to my NECK not my waistbelt. I want it to brake if I stumble, not 'by the time I've already fallen down'. But it has a slow brake, It doesn't 'jerk to a stop, on a dime' making a stumble into a disaster.  It's a great thing. It goes 'slow, slower, stop" so you can catch your balance, without getting chewed into the machine.This machine- granted- has NO bells or whistles on this thing- effective but obviously cheap console. (mph, miles, calories burned, cupholder for your whiskey sour... j/k.. cupholder, water-bottle holder (two, in fact) and you have to put your finger on an alleged 'heart rate monitor' but no plug in pulse ox or heart rate, no "google maps.  It has a few 'excercise' modes, but, I have not explored those and I probably never will. If you want a machine to be also a sort of workout trainer buddy, you will have to spend a lot more to get the fancy computer stuff. I have enough apps on my phone to cover that.But it HAS an incline and it forces you to lift your feet.  And if you want NO inlcine, it is enabled to remove the incline for flat walking if you have knee injuries or so on.FOLDING- It does fold. Not tiny but it DOES-- fold and latch for upright, for  'out of the way-ness'.  It will not fold into a 3" flat but it is not an 'always out and huge' thing. It is the dimensions they state, but in real life, that is bigger than it looks. That said, fits in my cramped tiny apartment reasonably okay. It's not 'compact'. But I don't want anything  so compatct that is also too flimsy. Plus if I store it under the bed, it will build itself a forever-home there, and I want to USE it. For things besides 'Just a handy clothing rack'. Which is what I see many treadmills and excercicles used as. I leave mine out. Not decorous but it is not UGLY, and it does say "Less of a sofa spud than I used to be" so that's fine, as decor goes.It is about $300, and it is a 'no frills motorized'. In sum,  I have used ,but have not OWNED other treadmills to compare it to. I live in a studio apartment, and I am not athletic.-this is small but it IS heavy (for stability) so don't expect 'small equals portable' in terms of weight, but it is for Walking, freehand, Jogging, freehand, it has a long enough bed for a reasonable stride, you can use the dashboard thign for reading- it holds a book magazine or table.I'm really REALLY impressed at how much BETTER than described, this is. I cannot speak to long term wear- but so far, it's quite, it is sturdy, it is small enough but also BIG enough (for a shot person), it is surprisingly QUIET, and it works freehand for a balanced strided very well.If you were going to go with a non-motorized because of noise, consider this instead if you need motorized motivation. (for $100 more, I have a treadmill I will USE!) and if you were thinking it would cost at LEASt $600 to get a decent treadmill and really more like $1000- and up, unless you need the 'trainer' features, this is great.

Good for smoke and mild mold mildew- BETTER than expected. And not a heavy perfume odor- but it does HAVE a perfume scent- but evaporates quickly, removes mild musty or cigarette lingering.  But it is NOT an industrial deoderizer. For that you have to was the thing and for mold- bleach or a mold eradicator, and for smoke- quit smoking, open windows, wash fabrics, wipe surfaces to remove tar residue. It's 'commercial' and truly good commercial grade (beats Febreeze). BUT- not INDUSTRIAL ( not for any real pet scent, smoker's home, damp mildew area.)  Four stars. Better than three, but not a five star deodorizer.

Unlike the hosptital brand I was using, these come individually wrapped. Which is really great if you want to give an infirm or elderly person a hard time at or after each meal or oral hydration moment, a nice fussy time trying to open the plastic package, while also contributing to a lot of waste.  Yes it's more hygenic for throwing in your purse. But very few people who actually use these, are using them while running around town or commuting.  And here, the individual packaging DOES count, because it's just fussy and they fall all over when you want an open bag in a drawer or on a counter or medicine cabinet.The product is okay but there are better ones out there, these are sort of cheap. I can't explain what it means for an oral sponge to be cheap. But if you've seen them, these are the type that is smaller and less flexible of a sponge and not as beneficial, doesn't hold fluid as well, and doesn't last long enough as a toothbrush.More on quality, less on fussy unnecessary packaging. BUT- if you DO need individually wrapped ones, this IS the product for you so three stars, not two.  There are better ones out there. Next time I copy down the hosptial brand and get that one.  Sorry Dynarex Swabsticks Unflavored.

Too many scattershot ideas and graphics, not enough organized well delivered information. Mishmashes modern physics wiith ancient philosophy, common sense, cluttered graphics in a way that does NOT simplify or elucidate the issues. It's the sort of thing, you'd have to stop and wiki every other page. ("Stephen Hawking. Sundials. Is time real?" plus cartoons puts a lot of concepts on the table which people have probaby already glanced at, but gives no more than a glance and no clarification.) However, it gives good jumpoff poins to then google. then really read, even a bit. Not one star. but, no three either.

Very good book, got it for myself and home aids with my father. Surprisingly informative for a 'layperson' guide- easy enough for those without time to do biology, but enough real solid swallowing disorder information to be informative even if you've been speaking with your (or your loved one's doctor and or speech / swallow therapist. BUT- it is a layperson guide. AND  it has a bias towards hyper-restrictive soft diets, overly broad (as in institutional settings.) Do note that dehydration and getting adequate nutrition are risks of the (often overprescribed) Dysphagia 1 (all puree and honey thick liquid) diet. It does not advise people to use this as a rough guide, but TAILOR the diet to your or your loved one's specific abliities and needs. No diet is good if the person then refuses to eat or drink enough to stay adequately hydrated and with adequate nutrition. For exposing people to THAT risk without an adequate fair balance warning, it has to lose a star. Otherwise, a very good guide for the perplexed!
Good product. Febrees Air Effects is good stuff.  But the price for the pet one is ($10??) WAY too much.

Great. Not flimsy, the top does not pop off, and the sleeve is a real sleeve, not just kraft paper. Not bad for the price. NOTE- cups stack easily but managing the lids and sleeves- you need a bag or box if you don't want those tumbling all over the counter.Works better than the cups some delis around me have. So, again- impressed. I have actually re-used these (just for myself, not used mine for another person- they ARE paper!) BUT STILL- very good for the price, compared to coffee. And no, I've LOST too many re-usable mugs, and Those are completely un-recycleable. Plus I LIKE my coffee in a paper cup. i WANT it to cool down a bit, and I use my coffee cup AS a hand-warmer / beverage holder in the chilly months SO- so insulated thermoses and polystyrene or foam cups are not for me. :)(note: I haven't tried the all white "Paper Hot cups with Lids and Sleeves White" at (currently) two dollars more. This style allows one to stack cups with lids on one another while full.)These are professional grade, come WITH lids AND sleeves.  At 34 cents per cup-set, this saves me a lot- my premium grade coffee at home costs less than a cheap deli coffee, doesn't spill, and keeps my hands warm in the cold.This is a win!

Zero Odor Smells like Bleach-Zero odor works immediately. But I don't know about long term odor removal. Honestly, besides a slight mint tracer odor, it smells rather heavily of the ordinary Clorox bleach dilution I used to clean the cat odors- which of course, for 25 cents worth of bleach in a quart of water, NEVER worked anway. (It worked for two days and then the kitty scent would rise up again, lighter but still quite pungently- forcing me to go over to the high price enzymem formulas.)Did anyone else notice this? I wonder if I'm paying $17 dollars for a one dollar bleach product.Anyone know what is in this, and if it works for more than just a day?

Must for modern art crit students and interested readers. Includes canonical moder art crit essays and a very insightful introduction and thesis. You need not agree with the views, but to understand some of the modern art perspectives and crit theories.

Hi. These are not 'five star hotel washcloths' BUT- they are a remarkably decent quality for the price! I expected them to be cheap and flmsy but they hold up great! We use these all the time, launder them daily, and while they are for bathing car (elder care- for which they are excellent)- I've  hijacked a few to do scrubbing and cleanup- and for BOTH sorts of tasks, and frequent washings they stand up VERY well.  And this price - $15 (prime, so delivery cost included) is great. Couldn't ask for better. Higher quality-to-cost ratio than I would have ever expected. If you find better price to quality for service-washcloths- let ME know- I have not! These are a keeper. I recommend them.

I hate folks who review plants without having planted them and seen them grow.  But here I go- I had to give a five star, when I just got my plants yesterday and here's why:  So often, photos are lush blooming trees, but plant comes small, dry withered, etc. Here, they show you a small but healthy plant- and you get a really healthy plant!  (Note- sometimes plants and cutttings come dormant, which I think some people mistake for 'the plant is dead'. Please do give brown dry plant arrivals a shot, if you can!)I ordered two plants. They are not shipped BY Amazon so I didn't get Amazon updates in my e-mail, AND, me being lazy, and expecting a big package for plants, I didn't even THINK to check my little mailbox for the tree seedlings. DOH! The plants came PRESTO- two days later, and sat in my mailbox. (MY bad ENTIRELY. If I had even so much as checked my order on Amazon OR my own mailbox, I'd have seen readily that they'd arrived. The grower updated me via amazon, with shipment tracking and all. I just waited for a 'box' and didn't even think to check my mailbox or look track the order.)Stupid me left my plants Five days in my mailbox- but the plants came out- PERFECT-- healthy, watered, lovely green leaves and the height you see in the photo- yet not overwatered either- great healthy roots on both!I was thrilled that they were grown, packed and shipped so well that my own stupidity didn't kill them. Not only that, they transplanted into soil (i used a commercial 'citrus & cactus' potting soil) and they're both now very cheerful and happy on my windowsill- BECAUSE the grower grew and packed them so well.Note that I have an indoor apartment building mailbox, but ordered them while we still had late cold-snap and they survived the mailing just fine, and very gently packaged as as well. I don't know if these guys could survive five days on a sub-freezing outdoor box or porch, but they were cared for very and shipped very well.They say to leave packing off the reviews, but live plants are one 'product' where shipping and packing are integral to the quality of the product. Five stars on BOTH counts for this plant.I will update on how the plants do, but they came SO healthy- in spite of my own dumb error - but a five day wait and opening the box to find happy green well packaged, well-tended little 5" or so plants smiling at me? How they do is now up to me- I'll treat them well from here on, and let you guys know how they do. I hear people get lemons from seedlings in as soon as one year for some plants, two for others. I will update. But the company and plants get five stars. Biggest bang for your Meyer Lemon buck! Happy healthy- and 'idiot-proofed' - plants in the mail! Who knew?

Hi, This is a must. I've bought many kitchen and working aprons before- which were nice in the photo, or 'a great deal' but in person- were short, or skimpily made, soiled and pilled easily, or- poly-cottons that just looked 'plastic-ish, or cheap. This is poly cotton for cleaning but looks classy. Very good detailing. This is not a heavy canvas, but it is no lightweight- nicely substantial,washes out great. The styling is full, generous and long enough. It is adjustable at the neck- and still covers your legs/ pants even when pulled 'short'. And the striping pinstripe is well done, hides stains while working, really looks good. It IS premium-it's a far higher quality than I anticipated and especially at the price. Very professional, works and looks great in a home kitchen as well. Skip the fancy print high priced flimsy ones, or slightly cheaper industrial whites which which tart crisp, but get- and stay- looking dirty, quickly- and get this. Premium quality, low price. And an even better deal, considering you won't have to replace them as often. Hands down, five stars.

These are great. 60/20 cotton percale, $20 with shipping, REALLY nice look and comfortable, low maintainence. Nice split between 'pretty' and 'fun' for the guest room.  (My gripe? I wish they came in Full/Queen).

Period. I've used a bunch of them. This is a bit gangly-looking. And it makes more noise (it does) and takes up a bit more room of course than the more covered, low profile ballers we all get.But this will do huge AND very small amounts. It holds a TON of yarn for larger things, if you're combining two strands or more, it puts a bit of a twist into them to keep them together (WHICH IS AN EXCELLENT FEATURE you won't find in most yarn ballers.) and it is STURDY and well-designed. (It clamps to almost any table. Though I put padding to damp the winder-grind noise from my wobbly wooden desk, you need not.) .If you are wondering- the design is open so you might think it 'catches' more yarn by misake here and there, gets tangled. This is a beauty-feature though. If you've ever gotten yarn or threads caught in the 'closed-mechanism'  style ballers, which are supposed to be closed to prevent yarn-tangles - but never do, and had to pull yarn out of a closed-mechanims (with pliers etc)- this is low enough that it seldom catches stray yarn, BUT- when it does, you can untangle it from the mechanism in a jiff. without pliers.I've had six ballers, electric and hand crank. This is the best.  (But you may want this as a 'second' to your small baller, which is more quiet.)Big capacity, adds twist to multiple yarns, easy to use, fast wind ratio, ergonomic on the wrist, hard to break this thing, well-made, I just can't recommend it more highly.

Little things make a huge difference- and while it seems insane to spend this money on something as otherwise bulk-inexpensive as 'drinking straws' - this is the most fun, and sophisticated palette I've seen, and (if it matters) durable enough to be re-usable if you're really killing yourself over the high price of these things.Huge hit. Brightens the counter. For two or three bucks more than even pretty pasetl or bulk bargain straws, it makes a huge difference in how people feel, and just having them on the counter brightens everything, without being at all 'kitsch' or 'tacky' or just a crazy-part of random 'rainbow assortment' stuff.Worth every penny, huge difference, I don't know anyone who doesn't love these.

Plastic drinking straws are ubiqutous and dirt cheap. But these are wonderful and worth it. (Note: if you're budget bulk purchasing for a cafeteria, institution or large costly one-off, or you need sanitary paper-wrapped straws for public use- these are obviously not for that.)But the colors here are decorous, sophisticated and eye popping. I cannot TELL you how much a difference it makes to spend the extra on these colors. They're  just great. Even just sitting on the counter, they just MAKE the place cheerier, make people happy. (Friends want to take them home and re-use them. For a drinking straw?? That's impressive!)My only comment is that for I think, a bit more (prices on Amazon fluctuate a bit) Faberware has a product that has a different, and also unique but slightly more subdued tasteful color palate. (beiges, orchids...) I get one pkg of each brand- they coordinate rather than clash. (Which to choose? Both!)But by the time you're talking about the huge added bonus- real surprise and happiness that a small item can make, this sudden cheer and tastefulness of 'huge color palette of flexible drinking straws'- you've already hit it out of the park.I'm frugal, especially with disposables- yet, these? SO worth it. Worth every penny over all the 'pretty' but kiddie-color ordinary straws, and worth it over the volume discount ones. Try them. You will be hooked. Take the money you saved on all the other invisible' kitchen incidentals and 'disposable' items- to go for this fun -and sophisticated - standout.

I forget the exact price but this is in the ten dollar range. I've had it for a few months. It hasn't rusted, and the air holes at the bottom, the silverware CAN slip out (as with all these grid-metal utensil things) but with THIS one, doesn' tend to.Sits on my dish drain. It's small enough to slide in a narrow area (which for space issues is great)It looks fabulous, not like tiny cheap rusty wire (as others have rusted out on me in DAYS!).It's long and compartmentalized enough to hold a lot of silverwareYou can dry, AND have at the ready, your entire ordinary tablewareThe half-dozen OTHER silverware drier/ caddies I've used are too small, AND cost more but rust or get icky quickly, and have holes the silverware falls through.Goes with everything, and it's sturdy.Of the VERY many on the market, this is the one you'll actually like and have around a while. I've tossed so many lesser ones (that cost more, or looked good in the picture.)this surpassed my expectations. Hit the 'go' button on this one. Ten bucks or so? Brilliant.

These are not BAD, but - fill them 1/4 of the way with water and try to carry them. They WOBBLE and splash. Which is not great, but not good if the water is at all hot. If you're placing these in a tub or sink, that's not a problem, but if you have a sink where you need it, why would you need these? You might but - you could do better just the same.If you got these, you were not the 'sucker' in the 'flimsy breakable awful stuff' arena- they're thick and durable. The sort of plastic they are made out of, however, is itself just a  flexible bendy wobbly plastic, outright, even though these are not thin and cheaply made, as such.But if you have a mere two dollars more to spend, get a name brand. Or if you  have a dollar-store nearby- get ones you can feel are made of a more rigid plastic, for the sorts of tasks you'd want such a thing for.Sorry, manufacturer.  It's not a cheezy product. It's just easier to do better for serviceable rigidity in a soft plastic tub, for a tiny bit more that will pay off in the long run, OR even cheaper but with a bit more time in-person purchasing.

It's a bit hard to buy housewares online, because you can't see, hold and compare them. I have bought several (in person and online) low-cost tableware sets. (You know the drill- dorms, summer homes, campers, new apartment, starter-apartments where you want a nice full set, but before you get the 'real' $1000 one you probably end up never getting anyway- and here- also multiple low cost sets for small catering- parties or so on where even 'silver-like' plastic is just not going to work.) ..)Cost matters, and disposables add up. BUT- you don't want to get stuck with flimsy industrial silverware, yet that seems to be your option.This is sturdy real silverware. The handles have heft, the tines pick up food, the knives cut, the spoons are ergonomic, the handles don't look at all 'institutional'- nothing about this feels cheap- and yet the price is so low.This whole line seems to be surprisingly well made for the cost.Do yourself a favor- and price out the cost of disposables, or the (often pretty) but separate plastic-handle sets (they tend to be pretty but feel 'plastic'- the handles come off over time, and the whole multipiece arrangement- sorry, gets grungy fast, harbors bacteria.)Even if you plan to upgrade, this is really decently made REAL, and very much NOT the 'pretty pattern, but klunky easily bent' 'cafetria /institutional silverware'.It's impressive and it will save money, because it will be around for years and people will WANT to use it.  It's cheaper- I priced it, for long term, but also cheaper for even temporary use- dorms, short vacations, small parties, than shiny metal-like plastic.Best I've found, of all sorts of 'bargain' options. This is real silverware at a 'temp/ disposable' price and is the same or cheaper than 'low cost' options otherwise. Bye-by industrial, bye-bye 'pretty, short term' and bye bye-bye plastic.this is a winner.

I highly recommend Kendall's Xeroform, AND I highly recommed the hard-to-find but so-worth-it 4"X9' roll form of the product. And this one was not overpriced, which also matters when you use this regularly.I'm doing leg-sore care for an elder.  If you're reading this, you probably already know Xeroform is medicated moist (petroleum jelly) barrier gauze. It's not just 'petroleum jelly and/ on gauze' and the medicated moist but drying agent makes a difference. Xeroform costs a lot but it is entirely worth it.  We tried dressings with petroleum jelly, with triple antibiotic (which is also good) but Xeroform is not just 'convenient' (while pricey) it very MUCH helped with elder skin sores/ blisters/ abrasions.This recommendation is for Xeroform, but also for the 9 FOOT roll form, which is hard to find. Tearing open individual little one-time application packets of smaller Xeroform is more sterile, for deep wounds or in a contamination-likely environment - BUT in a clean Home-care and clean would care setting the roll outperfoms the packets.I find we go through so much of it, that the 4"X 9 foot ROLL is a) Hard to find- so, thank you Amazon and Amazon vendor for making it available- but also makes wound care faster. You can wrap an entire limb without peeling open packets- OR you can cut it to length for larger or smaller coverage. This is really important for wound care, but also for the quick work when dealing with a painful sore on a (here, also impatient and somewhat confused) elderly person- to have a good medicated dressing, AND- to be able to do the job- get the length you need, without stopping to open multiple packets, and so you use what you need, and spare the person time, and save in waste and clean-up. Just be careful not to contaminate the unused portion of the roll - I put it back in it's pouch and then in a seal-baggie. But as to keeping bandages clean and  unconaminated- you already know this. Just adding, you CAN keep the unused portion of the roll safely clean if you're conscientious. .I had to hunt for the rolls, and I and the aids and the person we're doing this for- and I am SO happy Amazon and the vendor carry it.

Need I say more? Sure. It looks nice. It's small and it's clever and it's great looking JUST the same. (It's about a foot or so hig and a 'rectangualr foot' all around) But if you planned it as rolling seating and storage or as anything you could put weight on- think of it as not having wheels. Even though you probalby bought it FOR the wheels.That said, still looks great, still works as visually fine storage and you can still sit on it for low work or put your feet on it, and put on slidey- thingies to slide it around or away.

This item is plowed with undeserved high ratings.Shame shame shame on Eureka's well meaning department of 'theoretical engineering' for making the world's chic-most  heating unit / weight lifting equipment and otherwise born-wrong and set to break waste of money. Save yours and get an even lower cost and slightly less attractive one.Ditch this, and get the Mighty Mite BAGGED vacuum, or the Pet one, or if you're noise-tolerant, a bagged Dirt Devil.Pro's - Under $100 dollars, Bagless, Less noise, hepa, large wheels, easy open canister, small light easy manoevering, genuine quality metal wand, ergonomic curved handle set of attachments and crevice tool, no loss of suction, retractable cord, compact, emits nice 'new car' smell.Cons- All of the pro's are deficits PLUS there are cons - like, this product line overheats and breaks readily (and that's a pretty serious design flaw.)  There IS a lemon in every lot, so any high volume item will have a number of one stars, but BAD DESIGNG affects all the units the same.Under $100- get a bag vacuum for that price, and lower. 2 Less noise- you can't TELL if it's cleaning, so the trade off is you THINK you've cleaned when you haven't. The familiar rattle of something hitting (even losing suction IN) a bag is a GREAT thing- trust me, you'll see.3- Bagless: I cannot THINK of a worse design for 'easy clean' than this particular bagless design. A) you take it off the  insertion/removal site has NO lip, so as you remove it, you dump dirt on your floor. b) it gets static and so the dirt sticks ALL over the inside.  You don't flip the lid open and empty it. You actually have to take the whole thing apart and rinse it, or there's just dirt all over, and by the way, emptying it even without that throws dirt all over (negating the hepa filter. And negating having vacuumed in the first place. Re-using a bag, those even EMPTY far more neatly.)It's really convenient BUT- only if you really enjoy the convenience of cleaning up a huge mess of dirt on the floor AFTER vacuuming and then having  doing the equivalent of a small sinkful of awkward sticky dishes.Hepa- again idiotically bad design. Hepa filter is in the wheel, so it happens to pop out if you bump into anything. and blows dirt all over. B- it has a side vent, not a rear-vent so you're happily blowing the dust around that you want to vacuum up- Chase away, my friends, it's a new form of excercize.Small light manoevering- LOOKS ARE DECEIVING- it only rolls forward and back. Enjoy carrying your heavy new vacuum around your place. And, enjoy the convenience of not being able to easily store this massive klunky design. Maybe you can throw out six pairs of shoes or rent storage from the guy in the next apartment. But those are your 'small convenient' storage options if you don't live in Suburbia (and if you do, why did you get an apartment vacuum?)Happily it won't damage the furniture too much as you snag it on everything you own. Because, again, it only rolls forward and back- and not particularly well. But at least when you carry it, it also weighs a ton.Quality Metal Wand- nice work, you seldom see these on anything under a hundred dollars. But what the heck were the engineers thinking? "America's small home dwellers simply don't get enough of a workout doing housework. Let us add a few unnecessary awkward pounds to that equation"  This is great for people who like to wear ankle and wrist weights and look forward retro clunky storage and that 50's housewife feel. Save the chrome for the NON-portable appliances. Like, refrigerators, stoves and wine coolers.Comes with attachments- the awkwardly ergopsychotic handle is great for catching and clogging with things that cannot be removed by even the most dedicated plumber. Which is really only a problem for that percentage of American households that has a fur bearing pet, a child, or anyone who drops anything. That's almost nobody- no worries there- great OVER-thinking! The geometry is also fabulous for those of us who vacuum in a ballet first position- this will ONLY ever pose a problem for the handful of folks who like to clean UNDER their furniture.Comes with cleaning Attachments- how swell of them to include a high quality suction brush. Which only cleans backward, only when held at a certain angle, and which has front brushie- things- all of which a pretty hefty and complex design youd' think would be good for you, except it's not. It prevents the vaccum from being able to pick up- dust, hair, dirt and almost anything you'd want off your floors. BUT- at least the crevice tool is 4" long- shortest one I've ever seen. Which is great for cleaning all those crevices you can clean WITHOUT a crevice tool. (Really what was the point of that??)  And there is some other wierd thingie that also takes up space and does nothing.What it lacks is any sort of small tool that fits under furniture (even with the yoga-enhancing freakshow of an 'ergonomic' handle and heavy long metal wand...) or a small ordinary funnel cleaner that allows you to vacuum up things that are in the proximity of the business-end of the sucker-device, without also being directly underneath the hyper-articulated tools it comes with.  So, you clean 1/4 of the area in twice the time. (Look out ZUMBA!)Retractable cord- what better thing to do with a retractable cord than to allow it to roll up and cause all kinds of heat and also absorb heat, directly from the motor WHILE you vacuum!Doubles as a space heater with fan, and so much the better because if there's one thing you LIKE in a vacuum you DON'T like- it's the vacuum's own engineering-built-in predisposition to commit suicide.Here's it's lifecyle. It's pretty! It's quite! It weighs a ton, it has more suction that you EVER want this side of a sawdust factory! And it's all designed to defeat itself! it sucks up EVERYTHING. Then you add an attachment and it sucks up NOT MUCh, unless you are getting drunk and playing twister with it! Then it just SITS there making you drag it's hulking mass around and moving furniture on it's behalf! Then you try the small attachment and end up crawling on the floor the long heavy wand was supposed to make EASY. Then you empty it and dirties the Room! Then you clumsily dismantle the Easy Clean Dust Compartment. Then you Wash it. Then you dry it! Then you go for the NEXT area while half the cable cooks the motor and the motor cooks the cable. Then it sucks up something TERRIBLE when you toss and just use the want without the goose or donkey attachment that fits nowhere and picks up nothing! Then the "no loss of suction" looses suction!Then it overheats and dies! And you get to go nowhere because you thought it was great and tossed it's supplies and it's a NIGHTMARE to return this broken piece of garbage.In the meantime you've lost ten pounds, and since you can't even GIVE it away or fix it, you have a lovely item that is just big enough to make a large modern art sculpture on your dining room table.Jolly testetment to bad design. I'd Bronze this hunk of junk if I could, it's the 1974 Pinto of vacuums!

What a rip off!!! Yes, you get to download it for free; however, you have to pay to play. I uninstalled it in less than 5 minutes after downloading it. Honestly, I never got to play because I refuse to pay to play for something I don't even know what it is!!!

I'm thoroughly enjoying this skirt. Only have one problem, the draw string didn't dye the same as the skirt. The draw string is a mottled blue color. The part of the draw string that was showing when it arrived was black; but, while wearing it & drawing the string tighter, the mottled bluish color began to show. Just guessing, it looks to me like it might have been dyed after it was attached to the skirt & didn't absorb the dye properly. It hasn't stopped me from wearing it; but, I felt it should be mentioned for those it would really bother!!!

I like this skirt. It's comfortable & flows when I walk. I took off one star because the color of the brown one is NOT as chocolaty as the pic makes it look. It's NOT a terrible color of brown; but, just NOT what I was expecting!!!
I'm really enjoying this game!!! I play it pretty much daily.
I'm really enjoying wearing this liner...so much do that I recently purchased 2 more colors.
I love playing Chuzzle; but, Rescue left me feeling sad & frustrated. ONLY good thing was that it's free!!! I deleted almost immediately!!! I would give it a minus 10 if possible.

I purely love this dress!!! The smocking at the waistline shows off my waist. I liked it so well that I bought a 2nd one in purple. Honestly, I find the black one looks better on me than the purple one; but, I'm enjoying BOTH of them!!!
I had misplaced my original remote & this took care of my problem!!!  Received it fast & it works seamlessly; so I am more than satisfied!!!

This  top is very comfortable!!!  I have a black sundress that I enjoy wearing a good bit.  When I need to dress up a little more than my simple black sundress, I slide on this top & it dresses up everything!!!  PLUS...the orange brightens up my skin tone & I get a lot of compliments on how pretty I look that day. Sometimes I let it flow loose & others I wear a tie belt. One particular restaurant I frequent doesn't hold back on the A/C & this top protects my arms from the A/C to where I'm more comfortable without needing to carry a bulky wrap!!! After reading some of the reviews, I was concerned with the fit. I found that it runs true to size so I had no problems with it being too large or too small. It was PERFECT!!! I've thoroughly enjoyed this top & am NOT sorry that I bought it!!!
