Songs I liked were Go Power at Christmas Time, Soulful Christmas and Christmas in Heaven.Ironically, JB died on Christmas Day 2006. But if you're looking to funk up your holidays with some new and different material, pick up this CD.

I originally got this on cassette back in 2000. I finally got around to getting the CD version of it. It's hard to believe Charlotte was 14 years old when this compilation was recorded. She sings like a seasoned pro well beyond her years. A value packed selection featuring 19 songs, with some rarities. Ding Dong Merrily on High, Gabriel's Message and Lo How a Rose E'er Blooming are not heard that often. but Charlotte makes them shine. She adds wonderful vocals to whatever she does. The duet with Billy Gilman, Dream a Dream, is nice but Charlotte is the star attraction here. She didn't need any duets.Favorite songs of mine are Little Drummer Boy, Ding Dong Merrily on High, The Coventry Carol, Joy to the World, Ave Maria (Gounod), Gabriel's Message and Silent Night.  Great CD from a 14-year-old (at the time) with a powerful voice.

The Manhattan Transfer (MT for short) have been together since the 70s, so that makes it 40 years, give or take. I enjoyed listening to this CD traveling to see friends and family on Thanksgiving weekend. Jingle Bells starts the CD out very well. On all tracks, the voices are loud and clear, soothing and not overbearing. My favorite tracks besides Jingle Bells are White Christmas, Christmas Time is Here (from A Charlie Brown Christmas), Good King Wenceslas, Toyland, I'll Be Home For Christmas and Christmas is Coming. The latter is a rare song that I've only heard Bing Crosby and The Brothers Four sing.My only complaint about this CD is that it's too short - just 10 songs. I wish they had done a few more. Other than that, a nice CD with a couple of songs you don't hear that often.

I got this CD back in 2010 when it first came out. Annie is not shy or demure. She sings at full power - nothing held back on this interesting assortment of holiday tunes. Some tunes are not as popular as others. Lullay Lullay (The Coventry Carol), In the Bleak Midwinter, The Holly and The Ivy and When Joseph Was Walking (The Cherry Tree Carol) are not heard as often as God Rest Ye Merry Gentleman, The First Noel and O Little Town of Bethlehem. The latter song has a completely different musical arrangement from what I'm used to hearing, but the lyrics are the same and Annie pulls it off.Annie comes through loud and clear, almost like she's angry. She's definitely put her own spin of this collection of 12 songs. Most of them come off well, a few of them sound too "intense" for me. An interesting tidbit - Annie Lennox was born on Christmas Day. Overall, this CD is a collection of holiday songs that's different - mostly in a good way.

This CD, Susan's second holiday effort is better than the first. On "The Gift," Susan sounded like she was straining her voice. On this CD, she sounds more natural. Also, ALL the songs on this CD are holiday related, whereas "The Gift" had a couple of non-holiday songs. All of the songs here are great but the standout is her duet with Elvis on "O Come All Ye Faithful." I predict this song will become a holiday staple on the radio for years to come, much like "Little Drummer Boy" by Bing and David Bowie.Little Drummer Boy on this CD sounds fresh and new, especially with the bagpipes. Susan teams up for Johnny Mathis for "When a Child is Born," a song Johnny has recorded solo and with Gladys Knight. Susan and Johnny play off each other well. Each song on this CD holds up on its own. Susan has one of those voices that comes across as sincere and powerful. This CD Is a MUST GET for your holiday collection.

I believe this is Johnny's sixth Christmas CD, or album if you prefer. His first one was way back in 1958. On this CD, he teams up with other top singers for some holiday caroling. Billy Joel, Natalie Cole, Jim Brickman, Gloria Estefan and Susan Boyle are just a few of the names that were chosen to pair up with Johnny. The result is more memorable music from the man who is arguably the best living interpreter of Christmas songs.Billy Joel is a rarity for a Christmas song. Susan Boyle and Johnny were a perfect match for Do You Hear What I Hear, which Johnny originally recorded back in the 60s. He may not be able to hit the notes as high, but he can still hold and phrase lyrics like a pro. He also tackles some newer songs. Merry Christmas Darling and Decorate The Night were originally done by The Carpenters and Dobie Gray, respectively. Count Your Blessings was written by Irving Berlin and sung by Rosemary Clooney, among others.Johnny still looks and sounds good. He still sells out when he appears in person. By the way, if you ever get a chance to see Johnny perform in person - go! If you can't, this CD is the next best thing.

This CD was recorded by Julie in 1982 when she was with Columbia/Sony Records. Most of the 14 songs are ballads with a slow tempo, the type of song Julie does best. O Come All Ye Faithful picks up steam though once it gets going. Other songs I like on this CD are What Child is This, Rocking, Away in a Manger, Patapan and Silent Night. The songs are a mix of well known and not so well known. Of course, Julie adds wonderful vocals to any song she does. Hey, she's Maria Von Trapp. A good CD for sipping hot chocolate and sitting by the fireplace.

This CD/album has been heard at holiday time since the 60s. There are six musical numbers. Four are medleys. Ring Christmas Bells and The 12 Days of Christmas stand on their own. I think the version of the latter heard here is the definitive one. I learned The 12 Days of Christmas by listening to this version of it on the radio every year. This CD has great songs that express the Christmas spirit. Get it and enjoy.

I got this game as a promotional copy from Out of the Box since I run meetup groups in New York City. It's gone over well the few times I've played it. You have six cards in your hand, each with a different word. When it's your turn, you have 30 seconds to sell a product by putting two cards together. How about trying to sell a Ninja cloth, or an invisible alarm? Not always easy, but mostly fun. This party game will liven up your next party or game night.

I got this game as a promotional copy from Buffalo Games to try out with my meetup groups that I run in NYC. It's gone over well all four times I've run it. It's a twist on the Apples to Apples format, but it's fun and easy to learn. Here's how it works:There are celebrity cards with names of the rich, famous and otherwise prominent, past and present, real and fictional. There are situation cards that list a scenario for each round, like "Which celebrity would you want to friend on Facebook?" In each round, someone picks a situation card and reads it aloud, Everyone, including the reader submits a card that has a famous name on it. Cards are then placed on the table for all to see. Cards are then eliminated one by one, starting with the person who read the situation card. The person whose card was eliminated picks the next card to eliminate, and so on till only one card remains. The person submitting that card gets the situation card. Depending on how many players there are, the first one to get a certain number of situation cards wins. According to the rules, up to eight can play. You could probably squeeze in one or two more if need be.This is a fun game that's easy to learn and everyone plays at the same time in all the rounds. This is a new game, so the list of famous people are very current. Lindsay Lohan, Britney Spears, Kim Kardashian, Snoop Lion (Snoop Dogg) and others are mixed in with Bill Clinton, Donald Trump and Thomas Jefferson. This game makes name dropping fun. By the way, this game was created by Reiner Knizia, who's known mostly for his strategy and "Euro" games. Give this game a try if you want to spice up your next party game night.

TP has been around for over 30 years, but the folks at Hasbro keep coming up with different twists to keep it fresh. This 2013 version has different rules from other past versions. Here they are in detail:Each question in the game can now win you a wedge (or piece). No more having to land on a "headquarters" to win a wedge. Some people have played the game this way for years, but this version makes it officialYou can ASK A FRIEND if you don't know the answer. If they're right and you go with it, you and the friend EACH get a wedge. Like "phone a friend" TP style. Since the friend can get a wedge, there's a motivation to help you rather than screw you over. You can accept or reject the friend's answer in all cases. The ask a friend does NOT apply in the WILD CARD spaces.The WILD CARD spaces let you pick your category. On these, after hearing the question, if you think you know the answer you can say GOT IT. If more than one person says it, go in the order of who said it first. The person choosing the question gets to answer first. On multiple choice questions, only the first GOT IT shouter gets to answer. The GOT IT rule does not apply to 50/50 questions, since the answer is obvious if the first person gets it wrong.According to the rules, "the first player or team to collect six wedges by successfully answering questions" wins. If I interpret that correctly, you no longer have to go for the "game winning question." to win. This speeds up the game, but I know some die hard TP fans will not like this.The categories on the cards have symbols instead of letters. They are:Blue - PlacesPink - EntertainmentYellow - EventsPurple - The ArtsGreen - Nature & TechnologyOrange - Sports & HobbiesSince you can win a wedge on all questions, the wedges are now all generically grey, but the tokens are all in the colors of the game. The game comes with only 1,200 questions, so your chances of hearing a repeat question will come sooner. The questions are in smaller print than previous TP versions, which I find annoying.  The game seems to have a balance of easy and hard questions. This version of TP is a bit friendlier, but purists may not like it as much.

The game from Hasbro Gaming, features cards with quotes on one side and pictures on the other. A special die tells you whether to lay out pics or quotes along with the amount you have to put up. You start with $10,000. You have to put the stickers on the die the first time you play.Everyone gets $10K, five cards with pics & quotes and one "funny" and "die" chip. Players in turn roll the die. If it says lay out three pics, players will submit quotes and vice versa. Each player then submits a pic or quote on ONE of the three cards on the table. After everyone submits, players vote on the "funny" card and the "die" card. You place your chip face down and you can't vote for your own. The player who submitted the pic or quote with the most funny chips gets all the money in the pot. In case of a tie, players vote on the cards that tied. Players submitting tied cards don't vote since they can't vote for their own and those votes cancel each other out.After the winner is decided and paid, discard all the used cards and replenish you deck so that you have five cards. You should have five cards each time someone rolls the die. The person to left of the last die roller rolls next.Play continues until one player runs out of money. At that point, players count their money. Most money wins. In ties, you can declare a tie or do a sudden death thing where those players submit a pic or quote and the others vote on which is funnier.Overall, an enjoyable game with a nice twist on the "Apples" theme. The game comes with "joker cards" where you can write in your own quotes and submit your own pictures. There is also a disclaimer stating that some pics and quotes might not be suitable for kids under 13. Up to six can play, game takes about a half hour to play. It's available at Toys R Us and other fine stores.

I purchased this book a couple of years ago when it first came out. Johnny Olson was best known for his long-time association with Goodson-Todman as their main announcer for their game shows for over 25 years, but he did so much more in both TV and radio. Author Randy West gives detailed accounts of how Johnny took on all sorts of jobs and how he had an effect on those he worked with as well as the final product of the show itself. Nobody said anything negative of him. In the world of show biz, that's practically unheard of.The book is an amazing account of covering a man who made a name for himself by the late 60s. He was ready to take it easy when Goodson-Todman relocated him to work in California for what would be the busiest and most productive years of his life. It was all really unexpected to him. He had a bought a farm in West Virginia and commuted regularly to CA to do his shows. Through it all, he had an energy level and work ethic of a man in his 20s. I remember seeing him at The Price is Right and Match Game, running around the place and dancing like a teenager during his audience warm-ups, and he was in his 60s at the time.Johnny O was the best game show announcer there was. The Price is Right had a HUGE hole to fill when he died in 1985. Ironically, Johnny was on his way to a "Price" taping when he felt ill and pulled his car over. So he went out "with his boots on" so to speak. If you get GSN, the Game Show Network on your cable TV provider, you can still hear Johnny O on Match Game every morning. If you want to know all about the man, this book definitely does him justice. I got my copy at Amazon.

Bill Cullen's career as a radio and TV host and personality is one for the books. He hosted more game shows than anyone else and made any game show interesting to watch by just being on it, either hosting or playing. And through it all, he came across as a regular guy with no scandals or backstage drama, like a few other hosts. This book gives a detailed story of Cullen's life from his youth in Pittsburgh PA to his last days in California.As a high school student, I used to attend tapings of shows with Cullen in New York City in the 70s. Shows like Three on a Match, To Tell The Truth, Winning Streak, The $25,000 Pyramid and the ill-fated Blankety Blanks and Pass The Buck. Cullen lived in NYC till 1978 when he moved to California. I got to talk to him out in the parking lot for a few minutes during a Love Experts taping out there.The author does an excellent job of covering Cullen's extensive career. You wonder where he found time to do all he did. Considering he had polio and walked with a limp (which is why you didn't see him walking on camera) and that he didn't look like Adonis. he beat the odds to cover a nearly 50-year career in entertainment. Though he was a top-notch host, his longest running shows were those where he was a panelist, namely I've Got a Secret and To Tell The Truth.Interesting tidbits about Cullen are covered here as well, like the advice Ralph Edwards gave him early in his career, why he ultimately turned down the Price is Right revival in the 70s, how he got to host The Jokers Wild and what he really thought of Milton Berle when he was a guest on Hot Potato.If you get GSN, the Game Show Network, you can still see Bill there every now and then as a guest on various game shows. If you really want to know about Bill Cullen, GET THIS BOOK. Nuff said. Amazon has it. That's where I got my copy.

I got Brian Setzer's "Christmas Comes Alive" CD, so that made me curious. I got this CD and "Dig That Crazy Christmas" for about $5.00 each at Best Buy. I got a GREAT buy for my money. The songs are mostly upbeat and range from familiar (Jingle Bells, Winter Wonderland, Sleigh Ride) to not-so-familiar (Cactus Christmas, The Amens, So They Say It's Xmas - the latter written by Brian Setzer).My two favorite songs on this CD are "The Man With The Bag" and the "Nutcracker Suite." You've never heard the latter like this before. Ann-Margaret teams up with Brian on "Baby It's Cold Outside." If you're looking for somthing a little different to add to your holiday music collection, get this CD. You'll be glad you did.

This collection is Brian Setzer's second holiday effort. In the past decade he's become one of those people you hear on the radio in December, like Bing, Nat, Johnny, Andy, the Carpenters, Harry Connick Jr. and Mariah Carey. He takes familiar and not-so-familiar songs and gives them the "swing" treatment. He wrote a couple of songs on this CD, namely "Santa Drives a Hot Rod," "Hey Santa" and "Getting in the Mood" - done to the beat of Glenn Miller's "In the Mood." "My Favorite Things" is an instrumental.The song range is quite varied. Brian takes on "White Christmas" and "Angels We Have Heard on High" but he also does "Zat You Santa Claus?" and "You're a Mean One Mr. Grinch." This CD will liven up any holiday event.

The classic album, originally released in 1959 (the year I was born) features songs you hear every year on the radio and in shopping malls. The songs still hold up well. Mostly familiar and upbeat songs on the secular side. What Child is This is the one exception to this, but like all the other songs, it sounds great. Jingle Bells, White Christmas, Here Comes Santa Claus - they're all here. I believe Christmas Bride is an original song, and "Rudolph" has a completely new verse that I haven't heard on any other version of it.This was Ray's first holiday album - the one that started it all, as it were. If you like your holiday songs in a traditional and upbeat style - this album (or CD) is for you. You'll probably find it in the budget bin - or you can get it here on amazon.com.

Once upon a time, when chorale singers were popular, Percy Faith, Mitch Miller and Ray Conniff were churning out mainstream and holiday albums that get radio play every year. This CD has 12 songs that will put you in the holiday spirit. My favorites are Here We Come a Caroling, God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen, Joy To The World, What Child is This?, O Tannenbaum and O Little Town of Bethlehem. Nice tunes tastefully done for any holiday party or activity. You can get this CD on amazon.com - that's where I got it.

The songs on this CD are from Rosemary's days at Columbia. So these songs are from the 50s when she was in her 20s. She does her versions of Irving Berlin's White Christmas and Count Your Blessings (Instead of Sheep). She teams with Gene Autry for The Night Before Christmas and Look Out The Window. Other songs I like are Suzy Snowflake, Let's Give a Present to Santa, Snow and Happy Christmas Little Friend. A total of 11 songs (one has a reprise). Nice songs that have been remastered for a new generation of fans.Rosemary left us in 2002. She was George Clooney's aunt.

Stevie recorded these songs in the 60s when he was a teenager. This CD features the 12 songs originally released along with two bonus tracks from the vaults, per Motown's marketing strategy. Three of the songs heard on the radio over the years are Someday at Christmas, What Christmas Means To Me and One Little Christmas Tree. The two bonus tracks are The Miracles of Christmas and Everyone's a Kid at Christmastime. The latter one is a bit upbeat and I like it better than the former. Familiar tunes like Silver Bells, The Christmas Song and The Little Drummer Boy are featured. The rest is mostly original material, though Twinkle Twinkle Little Me was first heard on the Supremes Christmas album.Amazingly, Motown never had Stevie do a Christmas album as an adult when his music career was thriving in the 70s and 80s. But this selection of songs still holds up. Only Stevie could do Ave Maria with a harmonica solo and make it sound so good.

Songs from this Percy Faith compilation are heard on the radio each year. Some songs have vocals, like Christmas Is, Happy Holiday and We Need a Little Christmas. Others like Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas are instrumentals. Holiday standards like White Christmas and The Christmas Song are also featured. Nice easy listening selections on a CD that sells at budget prices.

I've had this CD for quite some time. It's one of many reissues on the Colombia/Sony label. Percy Faith was one of the busiest musicians at one time conducting and producing albums for himself and other artists, Johnny Mathis among them. Of the selections, We Three Kings and I Saw Three Ships are my favorites, but all the selections are beautifully done and wonderfully orchestrated. It's like hearing a concert at Lincoln Center. If you're a fan of instrumental holiday music, this CD is a must.

Christopher Cross is probably best remembered for hits like Ride Like The Wind, Sailing and Arthur's Theme (Best That You Can Do). Those songs go back over 30 years. Cross has decided to go the holiday route. The selection is quite good. It starts out with one instrumental verse of Silent Night. It then moves to Christmastime is Here, from the Charlie Brown special. Chris contributes three originals, Does it Feel Like Christmas, A Dream of Peace at Christmastime and The Best Christmas. I've heard the latter before. Chris also takes on some tunes not often on Xmas CDs, Irving Berlin's Count Your Blessings Instead of Sheep and O Come O Come Emmanuel.Chris adds great vocal touches and the CD flows smoothly from song to song. This CD apparently is a re-release and can be bought at budget prices. I recommend picking it up and adding it to your collection.

Frank left us a whole legacy of music in general, but his Christmas collection is quite impressive. I believe he recorded holiday albums with Columbia, Capitol and Reprise. On this collection, Bing Crosby joins him on four songs, We Wish You The Merriest, Go Tell it on The Mountain, The Christmas Song and White Christmas, the latter after Bing says "Don't just stand there." His kids join him on I Wouldn't Trade Christmas, The 12 Days of Christmas and The Bells of Christmas (Greensleeves). The others all feature Frank front and center. A few selections you don't hear that often, like Christmas Memories, A Baby Just Like You and Whatever Happened to Christmas? Overall, a nice selection by one of the most famous musical voices ever.

These are a four LED bulb. I have never seen this design before, Two rows of two LED.Also, the color temperature equals a incandescent, old school bulb it replaces. Around 2500-2700 degrees.They also have a 6 LED version at a lower price! I would of gave this 4 starts, but it is somewhat overpriced.

Pros,1. Small size,2. Lens disperses light better than a clear lens,3. Two position output switch.Cons,1. Polarized plug, it only can be inserted one way,2. Bluish light out put (probably around 4500-5000 degrees),Comment;Medium light output, can't call it a positive or negative, depends on how bright or dim you want it.
Hard to find night lite with a on/off switch. A large switch to boot and the price is right. It's too bad they don't use a LED bulb instead of a outdated incandescent.

This can only be used with magnetic ballasts which I have never saw in a small, plastic outdoor fixture. If you try to use it in a fixture than has the common electronic ballast, it will die after a couple of days.

Pros;1. Frosted lens disperses the light better then their clear lens version (but see below),2. Photocell dims display when ambient light level increases,3. Non-polarized plug. Insert either way into outlet.Cons;1. Photocell is not sensitive enough to dim or shut off the LED's. A common problem with these. It's on when it's not needed,2. Very warm color temperature (around 2700 degrees),3. Much lower light output then their clear lens version (both have 5 LED's). This my not be a negative,4. This may block the other outlet depending on the plug that is inserted.

Review for a Maxxima MLN-50 5 LED Night Light With SensorPros;1. Bright.2. Photocell will dim the array when ambient light level rises enough, but see below.3. Non polarized prongs allows insertion either way.4. A good portion of the light is directed upwards (from top of unit).Cons;1. May be too bright even though it can dim. A frosted cover would of helped disperse the light better,2. Photocell isn't sensitive enough. Stays on when ambient level is high enough not to be needed. This is a problem with most light fixtures that use a photocell, indoors or out,3. Typical bluish light (around 5000 degrees),4. Kinda expensive.5. No manual way to turn it off.6. Might block using the outlet outlet depending in what's being plugged it..

This is the 55" B2 model which has a different panel than all the other size panels. That includes models of the E and P series also.PROS:1. IPS panel mostly solves the narrow viewing angle of a typical VA panel (but see below),2. FALD (Full Array Local Dimming). Not a edge lit panel that usually suffers from flashlighting and bright spots (but see below),3. US based support (South Dakota). No worry about trying to converse with someone from who knows where,4. Direct input selection (with an optional programmable remote). No more cycling through the input list to use another device. This is a huge plus.5. Fast boot up (7 seconds) and fast channel changing unlike many other tuners,6. Ability to skip the channel search and add channels later without doing a full scan thus preventing unwanted stations to be skipped in the channel list.7. Generous advanced picture adjustments, (but no gamma adjustment),8. No unwanted 3D or other so called questionable 'features'CONS:1. The fine detail (especially noticeable with facial closeups and any scene with fine detail (grass for example) is lacking. Not a huge difference, but noticeable with side by side comparisons of numerous other sets. Setting the sharpness up to 60 partly solves the problem without adding excessive enhancement though many purists will frown doing this.2. Without the local dimming on, black levels will suffer with a IPS panel. But at least you don't have to be glued to one "sweet spot" with a VA panel.3. Local dimming will cause some 'odd effects' which are usually just noticed during 'dark scenes" (nighttime shots and dimly lit indoor scenes),4. The only function available on the set itself is power and input selection. No column, channel and most important NO menu access. If your remote and/or IR receiver goes south you are out of luck, Bad place to cut corners,5. One combined composite/component shared input. Another bad idea to 'cut corners'. Many still have legacy equipment that need both types. At least provide one of each.6. The tuner signal level/condition indicator is buried under "System Info" instead of being available in the 'Info Bar' as it is for the WiFi connection and many other sets.7. Small remote, small buttons, small text that is hard to read, especially on the back side with the keyboard. The main side is not lighted which adds to the problems, but the keyboard side is. Where is the logic there??  Then add a short timeout of the backlight (3 seconds). If you aren't a typist, forget it unless you have decent lighting.8. Firmware updates are fully automatic which sounds good, but there is no notice that you are getting one and no easy way to stop it from happening. It is well known that firmware updates can cause new problems. Real bad idea. At least give the owner a choice of manual or auto updates.9. Slightly higher power consumption than some others (160 watts with the backlight on full, 100-120 watts in normal operation). Surely not a Plasma or a 4k set, but it is higher than many. (Yes, these 4k sets are the new power hogs).10. Poor stand. The metal base that is used is too thin which causes forward & backwards rocking when bumped. It doesn't appear unsafe, but there is no reason for this. Also, the stand has to be completely assembled to the set first before placing it on the table. With other sets,  their stand allows the panel to be lowered into place, then the screws are inserted. A far better design.11. The gray/silver plastic cover to that stand is cheap looking and distracting as is that trim piece around the bezel. The stand should not stand out visually.12. Lastly, as far as I can tell, part of the problem with damaged Vizio sets is the lack of depth to their boxes. They are too thin with insufficient packaging material protecting the panel. I was able to compare this set with a 60" Sharp that were both boxed, on the floor of a local retailer. The Sharp was much larger. More so than just a larger panel. It looked like it was a 65" set, not 60". They have much thicker Styrofoam inserts than Vizio has..Some of these 'Cons' can, or should be fairly easy to fix. Many are just not fully thought out when these were disigned..Note about the reports of problems using wireless Ethernet. I had no problem with connectivity, but my router is only 15-20' away. I had no intention of using wireless due to reception issues and the hassle of security. Besides, running a Cat5e (or Cat6) cable isn't a big deal (if you know what you are doing). You never have to worry about interference of security issues.I can't believe some actually returned their set just because of WiFi problems. That's the same as returning a vehicle just because a radio station wasn't receivable..

Sharp has five model series for their 2014 LCD sets (note; LCD not LED);LE, EQ, SQ & UQ series. The LE is a carryover from 2013 (or earlier, it is a step down from this model).Update 1/7/15;There is what appears to be a firmware glitch. If you turn off that "Resolution Enhance" on the 'SQ' model, it causes a very noticeable gray scale shift to green-yellow. On Mode 1 or 2, which is where the set was gray scaled, it is ok. I did contact Sharp on this with photos and was told it will be sent to "Management". I noticed something similar on the EQ where if you use the 240Hz mode, the shift is to a magenta tone. Not as noticeable, but never the less noticeable. I also discussed the uniformity issues again with photos.Update  12-30-14After trying SIX different panels, one from the SQ series to see if that was different (it wasn't), I will now call this Sharps "black hole" representing the dark area in the center of the panel. This apparently is due to the very limited viewing angle, worse than most VA panels. This is really too bad since it has the 2nd best UI (1st being Vizio) and a great set on inputs & outputs. The hype over the extra sub pixel is nothing more than marketing, not that it really does any good with their consistently bad panels. Really disappointed. Now, I do give up.Updated 12-13-14After trying FOUR different sets I have to give this a two star rating which is still generous. The 1st was the worst, by far. A dark area in the middle half of the panel. The 2nd & third better, but still bad with similar dark and light areas. The 4th was the best, but it still was not acceptable.There is a obvious pattern to the uniformity issues. On all four, the center is the darkest and the rest varies widely. One has a hot spot in the upper right, another, the opposite corner; bottom left.The odd thing about all of this is, Samsung uses Sharp panels on many of their models and on their 6350 model I wound up getting, it has almost no issues with poor uniformity. One reason may be that model uses direct lit (full array) vs edge lit. That and/or Sharps QC standards are far lower. I was planning to post the photos I have of all four screens, but I see no option to do so.Pros; 1. Detail level and motion handling rivals Samsung, 2. Inputs; 4 HDMI, 2 composite, 1 component NONE SHARED! The only line of LCD sets that has this that I know of, just about all the others have the lame, single shared composite/component setup. Needed for legacy equipment, CCTV cameras and it also give your a 5th HD input (though analog). 3. Ability with an optional programmable remote for direct input selection. No more jumping through inputs to get to the device you want to use. 4. Sturdy base. The panel slides in from the top unlike many where you have to screw it together before you stand it up. Far better than Vizio & Samsungs' design, 5. No 3D or other questionable, so called features including that 4k input ability on a 1080 set, 6. Manual firmware updating. You choose if you want the update or not. Far better than it automatically happening without your knowledge. Also, I believe with files from their website you should be able to revert back if there is a issue. 7. Fairly easy access to the picture adjustments menu, though it could of been better with a single button shortcut. 8. Service literature is available, unlike some other importers where the manual isn't even available to 3rd party service shops. How can you fix something properly w/o a service manual? To the importers that don't offer one; what are you hiding? This is a nice plus, 9. Decent sized owners manual (downloaded from their website, not supplied), though it could of been composed better, combining pages to reduce the overall number, 10. Full menu functions are available on the set itself (backup if the remote or IR receiver goes south), not just power, volume & channel change, unlike Vizio, (note; the 2015 models apparently will not have this) 11. Ability to add channels without doing a scan. Saves time, eliminates removing unwanted channels in your channel list later on, 12. Enhanced (US, as far as I can tell) service with these 60" and above models. Reasonably prompt response and call back. 13. Well packaged, wider box than others. Nylon straps securing the bottom to the top (instead of those plastic 'clips' that are inserted through the upper carton) making it easier to carry.Cons; 1. Panel uniformity is the deal breaker. All six sets (from different dealers) had issues, one very sever, 2. Edge lit, more chance of flashlighting and 'hot spots' over a back lit panel though in spite of the other defects, that hasn't been the problem with the six sets I have had, 3. Leans towards a bluish tint with the highlights and greenish blacks, no doubt due to that yellow sub pixel. One of the review sites hit the nail on the head with that call. 4. Between two and three times the current draw than the M60 Vizio, 5. Limited light output. Darker than other manufactures sets even at the highest settings. The warmest color temperature drops the output even more, 6. Unnecessary picture modes. Why do we need two 'Vivid' settings. No ability to rename modes or bypass ones not used, 7. Slow boot time (17 seconds) and slightly slow channel changing. 8. Buried channel signal level indication. Why it's not in the info bar is beyond me, 9. When you are in a input other than 'TV', accidentally hitting the channel up or down automatically switches to the tuner input, 10. Menu times out too quickly. Annoying when you are doing picture adjustments, 11. That wasteful "wallpaper mode" "quick on" function defeats the concept of energy saving. Consumption is around 45 watts, even more of a waste if no one is there to see it. (yes, you don't have to use, it but it's the principle of this 'gimmick' which is counterproductive) 12. Non lighted remote (I use a learning/programmable remote, so it's not a issue), 13. Note sure this can really be called a negative, but Sharp is NOT one of the more popular names here.Believe me, I realty wanted this to be the choice. Unlike so many here that don't even try a 2nd set. Real stupidity. At least give the manufacture/importer a 2nd chance. These are mass produced consumer products. There will be differences and defective unit sold. Two, maybe, just maybe three bad ones? But, four? Sorry, that is neither bad luck nor is it a coincidence..
Bought these refurbished. No problems so far. I didn't expect them to be 6 or 8 years old. Seller did make good with a price adjustment.
Bought these refurbished. No problems so far. I didn't expect them to be 6 or 8 years old. Seller did make good with a price adjustment.

I have seen these terminators at 2x the price. Though  at over $5, it's still high.It's also easy to loose due to it's size, or lack of. The biggest complaint is the shipping charges which were a considerable portion of the order (I ordered four of these, two are spares).

Definitely worth the $6 extra for the larger capacity pack.Compared to most new 'hi-tech' packs, this is inexpensive. It's internal which protects it from the elements and from getting damaged though it doesn't allow standing the drill upright mostly due to the design of the drill itself.

Over what they are selling now.The two main issues are noise and the inability to easily change the two AA NiMh cells. The problem with their less expensive models is no ability to charge the cells and shave at the same time. The manufacturing cost has to be very little. It's just more profit for everyone involved.Screens & cutters are inexpensive (if you know where to look). I found a package of two cutters & two screens for $9.. I have also seen the same thing go for $25. Like printers, I always look at the cost of consumables since that will be the major expense over the products lifetime.

But, it was listed as "OEM" which means not box.This benchmarks better than the less expensive LG GH24NSB0B (in a retail box) model. Processor usage is higher, burst rate & access times are worse also and it does run quieter.

Really inexpensive for a Logitech USB mouse. Decent tactile feedback from the scroll wheel, though not as good as Logitech's better models. I would prefer a more rounded top to reat the palm of my hand on. This sits kinda low.

Using Nero DiscSpeed to benchmark this a Asus drive I purchased, this benchmarks poorly.Burst rate & access time, are lower and CPU usage is higher. But, at almost 1/2 the price of the Asus DRW-24B1ST drive ($22), one can't expect too much.

There is little if any (varies between units, I bought three) feedback when one uses the scroll wheel. Instead of having distinct indents for each advance, you can barely tell if there is any at all. This varies between the three that I bought. One is sort of Ok, the other two have little.Yes they work, but I prefer distinct and noticeable, tactile feedback when I use the scroll wheel. Also, the price is high compared to the cheaper (by $3.35) and better Logitech V7 mouse also sold through Amazon that has adequate feedback.

Depending on what you are doing, these are hard to position without help. They just seem kinda "clumsy" to me for lack of a better term. I got them to pull off a faucet handle (knob) in the shower that has rusted itself on the shaft, but it doesn't look like it will work due to the design of the knob (not really the fault of the pullers).
Strong fibers, nice color (thought I would of preferred a light shade of gray). This should holdup for a long time. Perfect size.

Pros;1. Known good name,2. Size and weight (or lack of), fits in tighter places where depth is an issue (between studs for example),3. Excellent keyless chuck. Easy to tighten down without wrenching your hand,4. Fast battery charge,5. Stands by itself, well balanced,6. Fast braking when trigger is released.Cons;1. Speed in the lower gearing is too fast. Yes it is variable, but when using it as a screw gun, it's hard to modulate the speed down to a more manageable level especially with longer screws. The tendency of running it full trigger is too great, that speed is just too fast for most screw driving. (I'm sure I'll be blasted with this point),2. Expensive replacement batteries (but probably not much different than other power tool manufactures),3. I'd like to see a larger battery supplied,4. Built in light can get blocked by your hand.

Replacing a 2008 Samsung 32" LCD display, this literally blows that set away. It exceeded my expectations.(Note; this is the non "i" version w/o the third HDMI input, Internet access & the mostly useless 120Hz processing for around $100 more)Pros,1. Very good video quality, decent blacks (direct viewing),2. Analog audio out for small amps to power external speakers,3. Optical out,3. Thin bezel,4. No unneeded bells & whistles (so called Internet applications),4. Decent menu layout, easy to access without jumping through hoops,5. Direct backlighting, no flashlighting,6. Separate video settings for each input,7. Low power consumption and little heat generation,8. Sturdy stand,9. Lightweight,10. Lastly; US support in English!Cons,1. Only two HDMI inputs and one combined composite/component input (this is a huge problem with just about all TV's now due to cost cutting),2. Contrast drop off and black level increases when viewing off axis, but no different than most other LCD displays except IPS panels,3. Side mounted controls on set hard to see and/or feel (yes I do actually walk up to something to turn it on or off without using the remote),4. Some dirty screen (clouding) effect. On white scenes (snow, hockey etc) there are some slightly darker 'patches' due to mild uneven backlighting though you have to look for it.Contrast ratio on all LCD's falls off from center. I've seen worse, but improvements over the past 5 years make it more livable. The 'pop' goes away off axis due to the black level increasing, washing out the video (depending on how far one goes off axis). Many times you don't notice it, it depends on the program material and room lighting.Would I buy this again and recommend it to others, Surely. Vizio has come a long way.

The 2nd largest rail hub in the country gets recognized here with some never seen before shots that made this a great buy for not just NKP fans, but for fans of other East coast roads. Worth the cost.
There is a good amount of material around the are I live, unlike many other publications that seem to miss the 2nd largest rail hub in the US before the 60's. Many shots I have not seen before.

I read up of many of these repair kits that had various results. I didn't think much of it, but I gave it a try.I cleaned the pads, I only put a thin layer on each pad and gave it ample time to setup. They were no better than before and in a couple of cases, it was worse.This may of partly been the composition of the pads on the remote, but bottom line, it just didn't work.Pros,1. I really can't think of any other than the mixture would be enough for two or three remotes (depending on how many buttons and how heavy you apply it.Cons,1. This is a two part mixture which I unfortunately didn't realized,2. The two containers are very small (admittedly, it doesn't take much) and you really have to be careful you don't spill any (not much to spill),3. Cost, just overpriced for the few drops you get ()and I mean a few drops),4. There is a two or three day time limit after you mix this. Afterthat, you toss out any that is left over. To me this is the biggest issue (if it worked).

Pros:1. Large backlite readout,2. Holds readout long enough to get the reading,3. Apparent, accurate readings,Cons,1. More expensive than many other gauges,2. Button battery replacement, I'd prefer more common AA's or AAA's, but space wouldn't allow,3. My first one died after five or so years only showing "low" on the display (it wasn't the battery, a serach turned up similar reports).There is a light under the stem, but it's hard to hold on. It would be nicer if it would stay on after a press, then time out the same time the display times out.

Updated & revised 6/12/15There is no free ride. The low price has it's downfalls. Of course how this affects you is dependent on your background, experience with Spectrum Analyzers and application.If this is your first SA, it's more than adequate. If you are using it for OTA (over the air) monitoring as in broadcast and/or 2-way communication, it might not be. Coming from a Agilent or similar, it surely won't be.Having experience with a number of scopes under $10k, this is surely a good deal, but the major 'beef' is the slow "update rate"of the display of the sweep. This is NOT the refresh rate, but the rate data is sent to the screen. Many didn't know what I was talking about. Rigol did, to their credit and was able to supply specs which no one else could. While discussing the problem with both of these scopes, I was told the "update rate" is only 5Hz with the 815 & the 1030. The new model; DSA832 rate is substantially faster at 25Hz.Two related problems which are not limited to just this model or brand; reported sweep speeds:1. The readout shown is not always correct. The actual speed is usually slower. Example: 100ms is actually closer to 150ms. 750ms is actually 1,000ms (one second). This is not the only SA that I have seen inaccurate speeds reported. Some will report different rates under the same setting.2. Dropping below 100ms will rarely display a faster updated trace. The 'choppiness' will still be there. The same applies to the older 1030 series. While you can manually dial down to 20ms, it will not show any difference. In other words, while the actually sweep is faster, you won't visually see it.  At least you are able to change the sweep speed up or down, Instek's scopes you can only increase the time..Pros;1. Price (what else can one say),2. Size & weight,3. Decent color display,4. Decent US support in English, unlike Instek which seems rare these days (but see below),5. Tracking generator is close to free ($200 option). I've seen many TG's add $2k to the price. You would be foolish not to equip it this way,6. Preamp included. You do get a warning 'beep' when the input is at the overload level,7. Conventional menu structure unlike R&S, Agilent & Anritsu,8. Perfect entry level SA, especially for hobbyists,9. Decent boot time (20 sec) and immediate shut down,10. Low standby current (1 watt).11. Free 3rd party remote screen capture available that captures in 3.5 seconds (see below).Cons;1. Overload input is 10db/m less than most others; 20dBm vs 30dBm2. Inability to update the display to show sweeps faster than 100ms (depending on other settings) due to 5Hz update rate.3. Very noisy fan which doesn't seem to be necessary since this runs cool,4. Outdated 480 line NTSC resolution. At least give us 600,5. Repair and alignment will probably have to be done in China with a 4-6 week turnaround time though hopefully this will change,5. You can only save screen shots to a USB stick, not to internal memory like Instek's,6. No white screen option for the screen saves, you have to use PC software to invert colors if you wish to print the results to save ink,7. You are forced to name the screen saves with a confusing text entry setup that requires jumping past the  Chinese symbols entry every time you switch from numbers to letters. You have to keep switching back and forth between letters and numbers since you can't use the number keypad unlike Instek,8. Overall specs are in a lower tier class (as expected at this price). Noise floor and phase noise specifically.9. No optional battery or DC operation.10. No 'jog' dial, only a small knob. Navigation buttons are only up & down,11. The 'feet' that fold out to tilt the unit up have a tendency to collapse when you lift the scope from the bench. Instek's system is far better,12. Only 4 markers,13. 3rd party remote control software is bloated and expensive. Surely not worth it. Why can't Rigol provide a basic version?14. Measurement software included with the 1030 series is now a option.

I had a Extech 8:1 IR thermometer that I was questioning the accuracy of. I also wanted one with a tighter spot size.After doing some research and asking questions to a couple of manufactures, I now know exactly what the deal with the "distance to spot" ratio means.With just about all IR thermometers, the minimum distance to get a proper reading is around 12". Some may go down to 9" no matter what the "distance to spot" ratio is. A higher ratio allows measuring a smaller "spot" when you are further away. Measuring closeup, as in electronic work, it will make little difference since it only focuses down so far.IOW's, spending more for a higher ratio D/S will do you no good unless you are interested in measuring smaller areas further away.The lens used in these, I bet all come from the same manufacture. Stepping up in S/D ratio gets you a tighter ratio lens and a couple more features, It does not increase accuracy as far as I can see.Pros;1. Known name,2. Decent price,3. Compromise in price and S/D ratio with the above use and capability (stepping up would be a waste of money),4. Hold & average readings,5. 9V battery,6. Some customizing available.Cons;1. Supplied pouch is mostly useless. Pouch is way too small to properly hold device,2. There is a USB port, but there is no software option as there is for the 750,3. There is no mention of the USB port in the specs, nor of the supplied cable. See below,4. 10+ degree difference when measuring temps around 150 degree over mu Extech. Which is correct?The only use I see with the USB cable is using a PC (Laptop) as a power source when the battery dies. When I called support, they didn't even know that it had a port or cable. I got a copy of the 750 software, but it didn't connect with the device which was no surprise.

4/15 update. Button cell life is terrible as stated. I'm replacing these cells every 6-9 months. Again, the cells are only down a fraction of the normal voltage. I assume it is just this unit since I haven't read other complaints regrading this. I adjusted the rating down to 3 stars/4/14 Update on button cell life:I had to replace what tested to be a 'good' button cell when the display showed "Lo". Apparently this sensitive to low cell voltage. The cell I replaced after 10 months tests good under load in a battery tester.The biggest adjustment is getting use to NOT tapping the scale to get it to display.Pros;1. Just stepping on the scale activates the display, no annoying tapping to get it to activate,2. Footprint is too large for smaller bathrooms,3. User replaceable button battery,4. Better designed plate (if that is the proper term) that others,5. Seems very consistent with multiple readings (unlike other scale reviews), but see below.Cons,1. Display should be wider to proportionately display the digits better (digits are too narrow, they could be easer to read if spaced further apart),2. Display is not backlite. Hard to read without proper lighting,3. Apparent limited button cell life (nine months for me), the circuity is very semsisitve to voltage drop,4. AAA or AA cells would be cheaper to replace and probably last longer (but would raise the height of the scale from the floor),5. Kinda slow to show weight. Up to 10 seconds from first stepping on to get a reading,6. If you want a 2nd reading, you have to wait 10 seconds for it to shut down, there is no 'reset' function to get another reading.When stepping on the scale, there is a two second delay for the display to show, then five or more seconds to stabilize the reading depending on how much you move around. The instructions do say it has to be on a level surface. I can't imaging bathroom floors not being flat, but with cheap, modern construction, anything is probable.

If this was 10 years ago, it would be Ok, but it isn'tSDTV (standard definition) is long gone (for the most part). Sure, this receives and can record HD stations, but only at DVD quality which is SD (as in NTSC). The editing ability is good without the hassle of a PC, but come on Funai, lets get with the program.As important, the HDD has been downsized to a 2 1/2" Laptop drive (see below). This is a HUGE disappointment as they went backwards, since the mount for a full size drive is still there. It was adapted to a smaller drive with the associated smaller SATA & power interface that won't allow a full size drive to be used. The power supply was modified to reduce power consumption, which is good, BUT, it was discovered this caused issues with the full size 3 1/2" drive so they did this fast fix.Pros;1. Self contained ATSC/QAM/NTSC tuner (see below),2. HDD & DVR recorder,3. Able to record from composite, S-Video & DV inputs,4. You can swap drives between units (yours or anyones) and use as large as a 1TB replacement,5. Edit out commercials (or any other material),6. Edit recording titles,7. Transfer recordings from the HDD to a DVD and vice versa (as long as the DVD isn't copy protected),8. Low power consumption (21 watts). less than older versions, (but see below).Cons;1. This does not record HD, nor does it even show HD when using it as a tuner,2. HDD has been changed to a smaller 2 1/2" Laptop drive format. This is due to cutting corners in the PS (power supply). This in turn caused issues with the larger 3 1/2" drive, forcing this modification,3. The tuner is called a 'hybrid' that forces the user to switch between analog & digital channels when operated on a CATV feed,4. Two ugly oversized and unnecessary buttons on the front panel that should be replaced with full menu & navigation functions. After all, this can be used as an editing deck that can be used at a desk. You don't need a remote to use this,5. No front panel pause button,6. No component record ability (no issue with DRM, it isn't digital),7. No Guide of any kind for recording off air. Recordings have to be labeled to program names,8. High power consumption when in standby by todays standards (4-5 watts),9. Can not combine titles,10. Some operational procedures are confusing causing one to jump back and forth though the menu.I dropped the rating to two stars due to the downsizing of the PS & HDD.

Update 11/27/13;A slightly revised model with the new, larger remote is now available at the same price as the original. Cosmetically it is the same with the same board (chipset), but a couple of changes to the display were made. The term "boot" is replaced by the term 'menu" when one is using the menu. Also, a new website replaced their current, slow to respond site. The firmware page needs a lot of work. I wouldn't try to figure out what is what, but go to the thread in AVScience forums to get the current (or past) versions.For OTA (Over The Air) the latest FW version is probably the best. For CATV users, it will depend on you system. For systems that provide virtual channel numbers for their OTA stations use versions labeled (virtual). For systems that don't provide this, use versions that are labeled "physical".Pros; 1. Tuners: one ATSC/QAM, NO analog (NTSC) capability, 2. Ability to enter individual channels without doing a complete scan, 3. Ability bypass a initial scan in the Installation setup, 4. Ability to remember both channel tables; OTA & CATV in one list as long as you don't do a scan. You would need to add a A/B switch to access both. (see photo) 5. Allows complete removal of channels, not just skipping them, 6. Lightning fast boot time of 10 seconds. Yes, I said 10 seconds, 7. Fast channel changes, unlike many other DVR's, 8. HDMI, component, coaxial audio, composite & analog audio outputs, 9. Extremal HDD capacity has been reported to be as large as 3TB not just 500GB as stated, 10. Ultra low power consumption of less than 1 watt off, 7 watts on and 11 watts with a 2 1/2" HDD attached to the USB port (but that requires an cooling fan), 11. You can rename recordings. Unfortunately, all recordings are a overly long cryptic number, 12. Timeshift is adjustable in size, not time from .5GB to 4GB. Timeshifting does not start automatically, 13. Adjustable volume and mute, but not when HDMI is set to 'Raw' audio, 14. Unusual recording info screens showing data transfer rates among other details. Huge plus, 15. This is capable of more than one storage device using a USB hub (thanks to jjeff), though there is only one front panel USB jack, 16. Internal power supply instead of another wall brick, 17. The format utility is fast. It's a quick version and takes around 5 seconds. (I didn't try it with a blank drive, it was formatted to ext2), 18. Recordings off the connected hard drive can be played to a PC and/or transfered there with no issue. The photos section didn't display some .jpg's for some unknown reason. It had no problem with .ts files from DVD's. 19. Choice of RF pass through (loop through) or modulated RF ch 3 or 4 (NTSC) for old school TV sets with no a/v inputs. But, only when powered up, 20. Music files can be played while in the Photo mode. Selections automatically advance no matter how thew pics are being viewed,Cons;1. Channels numbers on the display are just consecutive numbers starting with the lowest virtual channel number and ascending upwards. What on earth were they thinking here?,2. Some recordings do not get recorded. Hard to find a pattern to this. No where as bad as before,3. Bright ugly red display. Surely can't use it in a bedroom at night,4. The very small enclosure size doesn't allow it to be placed under any other equipment.There is also the probability of heavy cables pulling it off the shelve due to lack of size & weight,5. The remote is just as small, so are the labels. Very hard to see and push buttons. The button layout is not logical either,6. There is no indication on the display of recording status. Nothing preventing it from getting turned off which will cancel the recording,7. The manual misses a lot of functions and there are numerous mistakes. It's too small to read (though you can download a full size manual off their website). Being written for the Chinese market with mis named terms is a major problem,8. No skip function,9. Clock can not be set manually. If the reference stations clock is wrong, you can't do anything about it. Also it is only a 24 hour format,10. You can't playback and record at the same time,11. Only one tuner,12. The single USB port is on the front panel. While practical for a memory stick, it surely isn't for a HDD connection with the cable hanging off the front.13. There is no mention anywhere other than in the system information screen that this has a ATSC tuner, only QAM. there is also little mention about the recording capabilities,14. There is no analog capability.update: added info on different firmware versions
Saw a few reviews that the Prime Instant Video app isn't working on the M8. Installed it and having the same issue. Soon as I select "play this episode" the app crashes.

This stuff is amazing. Not much I can say that hasn't already been said, but I will have a can of this around from now on. Makes other polishing products pale by comparison. As a test, I tore off just a small piece of wadding and tried it on our old kitchen faucet. It took some elbow grease, but when I was done, the faucet literally looks like brand new. Took off all the tarnish, old waterspots, everything; and just left a mirror finish. Nevr-Dull just replaced several cleaners that I've relied on for years, wish I'd tried it sooner.

The battery itself looks sharp - mirror finish black, and it includes a mesh carrying case. It also includes a USB>MicroUSB cord that can be used to charge the battery itself, or portable devices if you don't have their original cord available. I haven't noticed that my devices charge any faster from this unit compared to others I've used; but I did notice that after completely charging my HTC One M8, the Anker was still near a full charge. I haven't had the opportunity (or patience) to completely drain it yet, but I'm pretty confident I'll have more than enough power in reserve when I need it with this unit. And for $40, why would you want anything less than 15,000 mAh?

My new favorite app! I got lucky and found this when the Amazon App store had it for free. Took just a little tinkering to get it to play well with my firewall, but once that was straightened out, it's been smooth sailing. I'm able to stream movies & episodes of my favorite shows that I've downloaded and watch them anywhere. It also gives me access to my entire photo library, plus all my music. It's like taking all of your media with you, without needing the storage. I would've gladly paid full price for the app had I known all it could do before.

I normally don't comment on other reviews, but in this case I felt it was appropriate. This may not look like real CF on close inspection, and it may not contour to every application; but it also costs 10x less than you'd pay for one that does. $5 and free shipping for 5 feet of this material is an awesome deal, and no I wasn't asked or paid to say that.That said, I found this material very easy to work with. I bought it for a couple small applications I'd been wanting to try and it's been fantastic - easy to trim with an X-acto knife, can be stretched slightly to conform to shape, even more so with some heat. I made a custom wrap for my wife's Fitbit and she's remarked how well it's holding up even wearing it daily. I've also used it to wrap a couple of my ecig devices that get used daily, and it looks great while protecting the finish (see pic). Maybe it's not 3M, but for the price, this stuff is a great deal.

I've always been an Otterbox fan, particularly the Defender series for the extra protection. But the looks of the HTC One M8 were too nice to completely cover, so I opted for the Supcase instead. I realize it won't offer the same level of protection a Defender would, but I am glad to see that it's a fairly sturdy case for a 1-piece. The fit is very snug; a little tight getting it on, but that's to be expected. Very impressed with how well the port cutouts are placed. The rear mic in particular is so small that a slight mis-fit would cover it; but it lines up perfectly. The raised bevel on the front is just high enough to keep my tempered glass screen protector from touching when face down. I haven't tried the IR blaster since putting it on, but others have had no problems.The only "con" I'll add is the back panel. The listing states Frost Clear, so I was expecting mine would look identical to the one pictured. However instead of clear, it seems to be slightly tinted, giving the gunmetal grey a bronze look. Not exactly what I was hoping for since I picked this case based on its ability to show off the phone. I'll post a few pics in the customer images section to show what I mean. Overall a good case, but I would've preferred that the "Frost Clear" option was as depicted.

I typically like to spend some time with a product before reviewing it, but I'm already so impressed with this screen protector I decided to post right away. I've always used screen protectors on my devices. Typically I get the static type, as the wet applications are just a mess. This however, was my first tempered glass protector; and I've already decided I'll be using them for everything from now on. Installation was the easiest I've ever done. Zero issues with air bubbles. The glass itself looks flawless and is crystal clear. The reason I chose this one over others was because one of the main complaints I read with other brands was the sharp edge. The rounded edges on this one are smooth, comfortable on the fingers, and actually look really good. I'll post a couple pics in the customer images section to show the fit and finish on these. Definitely recommended-**Update** 07/28/14 Almost 2 months with this screen protector and it still looks like the day I put it on. I wanted to update to say I've had 2 different cases on my M8 now, including an Otterbox Commuter, and the PThink Protector has worked great with both of them, and doesn't affect case fit whatsoever.

First, the plastic this case is made from is way too thin to provide any actual protection. It would most likely fracture from a bump, much less survive a fall and offer protection to the device. That hard to open plastic packaging that most store-bought items come in nowadays feels sturdier than the plastic this is made from. Even the cheap cases from the Verizon store are twice as thick as this.Second, for a case that is brand new, it looks used right out of the package. Scratches and scuffs are evident on most of the edges, most likely from poor handling of these cheap, bulk produced products. (See my pic in customers images)I'm glad is was so cheap, because it's definitely a throw away case.

Although I knew by the price that this was no "Otterbox-quality" case, I still expected a bit more from a brand new item. The first thing I noticed was the flexible sides of the case have a cloudy, dull finish instead of clear (see my photo in customer images). Second, one of the edges where the hard plastic back is mated to the flexible portion is not attached. I'm not sure if they were glued or heat sealed together, but regardless, right out of the box, this one is falling apart. It's going right in the trash.

I was very hesitant buying a non-oem battery for my daughter's Droid X. However after reading numerous poor reviews on ones claiming they're original Motorola batteries, I decided on this one at about twice the cost. Glad to say I did though, as this replacement performs as well as, if not better, than the original battery did when new. It arrived with a 70% charge, and didn't take long to reach full once plugged in. I instructed my daughter to allow it to fully drain before she charged it again and it lasted over a day and a half. I'll be using LS replacements from now on.

First off, I'm not gluten free; but my wife and kids are. I've become accustomed to not having certain foods around the house, but I wasn't a fan of most things gluten free. However, since getting this cookbook for my wife, I've found a new appreciation for GF meals. The convenience of a slow cooker and the variety in this book has produced some wonderful results. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone looking for ways to add more flavor to their gluten free diet.
Not much you can say about a stirrer I suppose. It stirs well. I'm more impressed by getting this quantity of them at such a good price. No more spoons for me, these should last quite a while.

I rarely find a product that I can't find at least one "con" to list in a review, but since owning this, I cannot find one. This charging station should be standard equipment with every Xbox. No more buying batteries, or rotating through rechargeable AA's for controllers. Just put it back on the charging rack when you're done, and it's ready to go next time. On top of that, it's a tidy way to store them when they're not in use, instead of the kids just leaving them laying around. Definitely a must have for any Xbox owner

I had been using drill bits and other small dia. tubes for wrapping wire till I found this mandrel. This works great for me, allowing a more precise wrap. I also like the fact that the "handle" end is dipped in a non-slip material for better grip. These were well worth the money.
Since I wasn't in need of absolute accuracy I figured this pump would be an inexpensive solution. Great for home use, good price, and completely fulfills my needs.

I was in need of a small number of economical pipettes, and these perfectly fit the bill. Glass wasn't a necessity, and I didn't want to order hundreds of them that I wouldn't use. Glad to see these offered here at a very reasonable price.
Gave this frame as a gift for my dad along with a picture of the grandkids. Its sitting on his mantle now and he loves it. For me that's enough to give this a 5 star rating.

I bought two of these to help with household organization/communication. One is on the fridge to leave notes for the kids, and the other is for our ever updating shopping list. When I started looking I had no idea what dry-erase boards would be priced at, so the $5-6 pricetag on these was a welcome surprise. These boards work great - well put together, they come with magnets for hanging on the fridge, in a word, they were perfect. The dry erase marker that's included seems a bit dry, but I also purchased a multicolor set, so it wasn't an issue for me. Would highly reccommend these.

Purchased this to have a place under the sink to store foil and wraps. Height and depth is great for thinner packages (foil, saran wrap, wax paper). **Watch when ordering**- this is not made to hold bulkier packages such as some sandwhich bag boxes. Install was simple and included screws. Screws were the appropriate length for installing on a cupboard door.

Good fit, well put together shoes. I purchased these to replace an identical pair I use for work.The new ones, however, don't seem to have quite the arch support that my original ones had. The only difference I can see is the country of origin. I suppose different manufacturing methods could account for that. I'm hoping these will break in and be as comfortable as my first pair.

As most of the reviews have already said, this thing moves alot of air. And it does it at an acceptable volume as well. Not the quietest fan out there, but I'm not sure you could find one this strong that's any quieter. I've come to like Lasko fans, and this one is no exception. I use it to blow air from the cooler parts of the house to the warmer areas and it does that well. My only con to list is the base could be a bit wider. It's stable if left alone, but if a pet bumps into it, it's going to fall over. Other than that, this is a great product.

I bought this fan to replace an old one that had quit on me. I live in FL and even with A/C, some areas of the house get warmer than others, namely the bedroom. When the ceiling fan wasn't enough I put a pedestal fan at the foot of the bed and found it helped quite a bit. When the old one ( an OceanAire )died, I shopped around and found this Lasko model. Had I known how strong this fan was I would've replaced the other one long ago. The lowest setting on this fan is equal to the old one on high. I'm not kidding when I say the first night I had it set up my wife grabbed an extra blanket for herself, and that was only on the medium setting. This thing really pushes alot of air.Assembly was fairly easy. The front grill took a few minutes of fumbling with since the tabs and slots didn't seem to want to align correctly. They did eventually, it just took a few tries. The base is nice and wide, although it could be a little heavier to help with stability. I actually placed the stand between the footboard and the edge of the mattress on my bed so as not to have to worry about it tipping- problem solved. At first glance, the lightweight plastic construction doesn't instill much product confidence, but once you turn this on, it's a whole other story.

My wife recently started using DoTerra oils and was still keeping them in the box they had arrived in. I purchased this for her for Mother's Day to organize them and make it easier to transport them. She loves the case. She's since bought the labels for the top of the caps so they're easier to identify while still in the pockets of the case. It's a decent quality product, keeps the bottles from getting knocked around much, and it conserves space. I'll probably be buying her the 30 bottle size case in the future.

I wish all surge protectors would be designed like this. The pivot feature on this allowed me to condense 2 power strips worth of odd shaped plugs to just one, and still have outlets left over. With extra wide/long power adapters these days, this type of versatility is a real space saver. I haven't needed the surge protection capabilities yet, but the pivot feature alone was worth purchasing this for. I've always had good luck with Belkin, and will probably buy more of these to replace others strips in my house.

1st off, I found this on another site on sale for $39.99. Amazon usually has the best prices, but I was able to find this cheaper this time.I do occasionally game on my PC, but my main reason for buying this particular keyboard was the backlighting. I have a slide out for my keyboard so working in the dark always left me straining to see keys. With this one it's no longer necessary. There are 3 lighting levels to choose from. I prefer the highest, but the keys are visible (in the dark) on any level. When the room is well lit you don't really notice the backlighting.I have tried the macros, just to see how they work. They're easy to set up and function as they should. The media and calculator buttons open their respective programs (I did install the included software, not sure if they work without that installed). The keys have a solid feel to them, and are on the quieter side. They are a bit smaller than my old standard keyboard though, I can already tell I'll be inadvertently hitting other keys. The palm rest is non-removeable. A non-issue for me but be aware if you have limited space.

Love this poster, so does my son. He's jealous I ordered this for myself, so I'll probably be buying another one. Came rolled in brown paper and a cardboard shipping container - arrived in perfect shape. Couldn't beat the price either. I'll be ordering more from this seller, even if they aren't Prime eligible.

Good quality hat. Fits well, but just barely. I consider my head average size, but had to extend the strap to the max for a comfortable fit. If anyone has ever told you you've got a big head, this may be too small for you.The Patches are great. A few loose threads, but nothing that can't be trimmed easily.Looks great after a week or two of wear, I just hope the black doesnt fade in time from the sun and/sweat. I'll update in a few months.

My fault for not reading closely, I bought a few other patches at the same time and assumed all were 2x3. This one is only 1x2, but still a cool little patch. Love the evil grin, and the glow in the dark works great.

Bought this for my son's Kindle Fire in hopes it would help him use his imagination. Although at first he thought it was a blast to be able to break anything he wanted, he's now seeing that he can use this to design anything he can think of. I bought Pocket Edition for my tablet also and we've had a great time adventuring together. There are a few things I wish they'd bring to P.E. from the full edition (Redstone mining, TNT, etc), but overall this is an awesome mobile version of the game that will keep you busy for hours, if not days and weeks.

I purchased two of these Timex alarm clocks for my wife and I.First off, for the price, this clock is packed with features. My main reason for choosing this was the multi level display dimmer; some clocks are just too bright. This one offers different levels of brightness and is perfect for me at the lowest level. The USB charger is convenient since I alway keep my phone on my dresser at night. Having a battery backup is also a must. I don't really have much use for the 2nd alarm or nightlight, but it doesn't hurt to have them.The only 2 flaws I see are 1) every time you set the alarm, it beeps a confirmation that it's set (rather loudly). This is irritating when your partner is already asleep, but there's no way around it that I've found. And 2) Except for the large snooze button, the rest of the buttons are close together and are hard to differentiate in the dark by feel alone. Some space between them or raised surfaces on the buttons would have been welcome.Overall I'm happy with these clocks. I would've given them 5 stars if there was a way to silence the beep when you set the alarm.

My wife bought this for my daughter who had recently lost her favorite pet, Emma. Since receiving it, her new "Emma Kitty" rarely leaves her side, literally. She goes about daily tasks with "Emma" under her arm constantly, and sleeps with it every night. We enjoy that its given her so much comfort, but also like the fact that it's held up so well.

I'd been wanting a trimmer like this for a while, and couldn't pass up the good price I saw here. Pros: Easy to use, makes trimming a cinch, easy to clean, saves alot of time over using the scissor method. Cons: none so far. For the price you can't go wrong with this. One word of caution: You can use the water rinse method to clean this, but if you take the trimmer section apart like I do to make sure its spotless, make sure you use a steady hand. The blades could very easily get bent and render this useless.

Bought this for the wife to use her laptop while sitting on the couch. She was constantly hunched over the coffee table typing and using the mouse. This lets her comfortably sit back with the laptop while still using the cordless mouse via the pull-out section. The "Fuschia Burst" accents add a little personality to it, and also match her mouse and her desktop background pic. Very convenient accessory, and a good deal for the price.

I've used this pillow for some time now. The Pros: It's definitely better than a standard pillow for cpap users. Even with nightly use, the higher edges have held their shape and height, which allows you to position yourself so the mask hangs over the side and is not pushed into your face. It is a firm pillow, but still fairly comfortable, either on your back or on your side. The cons: Overall size is a bit small, could be a little wider. Also, as opposed to some other styles, while using this pillow on your side, it offers little/no support for your forehead. I often feel as if I have to hang my head over the edge of it to get the benefit of not having the mask smashed into my face. It's still superior to using a regular pillow, but I may eventually try one that has more of a cut-out for the mask while offering better support for the whole head.

Bought this to replace the first one I had on my wife's phone. The clear ones tend to get a yellow tint to them after a year and a half or so, but for this price, it's worth it to replace it every so often. Protects the custom "skin" I installed on her Droid Incredible, while still allowing it to be seen; and protects the phone from bumps and scratches. All the port/charger/camera holes line up well, and the overall fit is good. Decent case for the cost.

I've put several of these through numerous charging cycles so far for my kids' Wii remotes and other video game accessories. They take several hours to charge, but they also last for quite a while. Worth the money they cost not to have to keep buying single use batteries.

I've been using this for about 6 weeks and it's held up very well so far. Mine holds very little weight (only a few badges) but the pull and retract mechanism has worked smoothly every time. Definitely much better built than the cheaper, smaller versions.UPDATE: 5 months now and still performs like new. Pull & retract are still smooth and without a hitch. Wish I would've got one of these a long time ago

Fun and challenging, def provides hours of entertainment. However upgrading towers often fails. Its distracting and puts you at a disadvantage having to" fight" with the game to make it do what its supposed to. Froze up a few times too- droid x 2.2
had to find online guide to figure out how to use 2 items together. the whole point is just to open a door?  now we have to wait for part 2? lost interest pretty quick

For quite some time my wife has wanted to replace our old, dull set of kitchen knives. After seeing that sets can run anywhere from $20 to $1000, I started reading reviews on Amazon and finally settled on this set. We weren't disappointed. First, shipping was faster than anticipated (glad I used the free shipping and didnt pay for the upgrade) and the packaging was sufficient and the product arrived intact. Second, The price was very reasonable for a set that included so many pieces.The knives all came in a thin plastic sleeve with a cardboard sheath over the blade. They have a heavy, sturdy feel to them and the stainless handle gives them a professional look. Although my wife could name each knife on sight, I was impressed with the array of different knives even if I didnt know the intended purpose of some of them. The utensils are a nice addition as well that will surely get put to use.The blades on these have been very impressive so far.
