They were sort of ok, but they started fogging up after about 2 or 3 miles every time. I can't deduct points for that since it's not their intended use, but they at least kept my eyeballs from freezing. I may look into some anti-fog ski goggles in the future.

My wife has adult braces and wanted to try one of these out based on a friend's recommendation.  She said it has made it a lot easier to wash all the crud out from around her braces and between her teeth, so she doesn't have to spend as much time using the flosser things.  I've started using the Waterpik Ultra in addition to my normal flossing because I think the two are complementary.  Each one does a better job in some respects, but is not as good as the other in some other respects. For example, flossing goes a great job wiping the scum off the surfaces of your teeth that the toothbrush can't reach, and the Waterpik rinses away gunk from all the nooks and crannies where you cannot floss. I always use a full tank of water--first I make a pass around my entire mouth cleaning around my teeth, then I increase the power and make another pass just hitting my gums.After watching a video review comparing the new WP-660 with this older WP-100 model, we decided to go with the older model which seems to be built and designed better. The only features this older model lacks compared to the WP-660 are the timer and intermittent "massage" setting, but I don't see that feature as very useful, and you could mimic it yourself by using the thumb "stop" button on the wand. We like the larger storage compartment, longer coiled tube, heavier construction, and better wand holder.The only thing I dislike about the Waterpik Ultra is that the pump controls are on the base unit rather than the wand, but I understand this is a simpler and more reliable design.

At my wife's small bakery/restaurant we burn through at least one or two 6-Qt Kitchenaid mixers every year, so I jumped on this mixer when there was a deal on it. Unfortunately this mixer's bowl is narrower and deeper than those of our other mixers, so the bowl and paddle are not interchangeable with any of our other mixers. When I tried retrofitting this mixer with the bowl lift from a broken mixer to use the standard 6-Qt bowl and paddle, the paddle scraped the bowl. I ended up having to revert the mixer to factory specs and we've relegated this mixer to just being a backup.

I ordered this clip-on double loupe for part of my wife's costume for an upcoming steampunk event at a nearby historic railroad and museum, but I'll also use them to examine the cutting edges of my woodworking hand tools and for removing splinters.These loupes seem to work ok for the price, but the product photo is inaccurate and the description does not seem to be accurate.  The bar for each loupe extends past the main shaft, making it easy to flip each loupe up or down.  Despite the product description which claims 5x and 10x magnification, the package says 3x and 10x.  Elsewhere the package claims there are two 3x lenses, which would produce 3x and 9x magnification levels. I don't have another loupe for comparison, so I can't say for certain what the actual magnification powers are.  I'm docking a star for the ambiguity, but as a costume piece it's great and as an inexpensive tool it works fine.Shipping was very fast from hobbytoolsupply; I ordered on Feb 17 and received the package on Feb 21 via USPS.

You might be wondering why there are so many people who say these magnetic featherboards work great and can practically lift a table saw, while there are so many who say they slide around or lift right off. I'm pretty sure the distinguishing factor is that some of these people's saws have nice thick cast iron tables and the others have thinner steel tables.My table saw and bandsaw have thick cast iron tables, and the pair of 150lbs magswitches will still slide once engaged, but they require a fair amount of force. I think the force required to slide them is greater than the force you would typically apply with a featherboard anyway.I've also tried it on thinner steel surfaces with disappointing results. For example, on my steel front door, refrigerator, and even on the steel casings on a couple tools, it required almost no force to slide the featherboard around, and it was also relatively easy to lift the featherboard off the surface even when the switches were locked on.If your saw has a steel table instead of cast iron, I suspect you'll be sorely disappointed with this starter kit. And of course, magnets don't stick to materials such as aluminum and granite, so if your tool's table is made of any non-ferrous material you shouldn't even be looking at magswitch-based accessories. But if you have a nice thick cast iron table, this thing will stay put well enough.If you want a Magswitch featherboard, they're all expensive but this one is the most versatile because you can remove the mag switches and attach them to your own jigs or fixtures. If you use the included multipurpose base and featherboard attachment, you can flip the featherboard around to use with a table saw or bandsaw in the typical configurations, or to use it with the table saw fence on either side of the blade. Magswitch Technology also offers several accessories for this featherboard, such as a resaw guide and vertical featherboard adapter, though for the price you might be tempted to make your own attachments.The main thing I don't like about Magswitch products (or most magnetic accessories, for that matter) is the price. Even when it goes on sale, this kit only goes down to $60.

I bought this activity tracker because I was disappointed with the Garmin Vivofit and wanted to see how the cheaper Pivotal Tracker 1 compared. My wife and I both tried this simultaneously with the Vivofit and both bands gave similar step counts. Given the price difference, buying the Pivotal Tracker is a no-brainer if you have a compatible smartphone, assuming you don't wind up having the static shock problem. Even though it requires an annual subscription, it would take at least 6 years to equal the cost of most competing wristband-type activity trackers. But on the downside, it isn't compatible with my phone so I had to sync with my wife's phone.  It's also really uncomfortable to wear (compared to the Vivofit), and it reset on its own numerous times before I decided to send it back (apparently due to static shock).My wife also tried the Pivotal Tracker and although it stayed put on her wrist when adjusted to the smallest size, there was about a 3/4" or larger gap on either side of her wrist because the rigid part of the band is significantly wider than her wrist.  This device is definitely not for people with small wrists.What I like:- Cheap!- OLED screen is readable in the dark- Wristband doesn't immediately fall off if it accidentally gets unsnapped- Somewhat works as a standalone pedometerWhat I don't like:- The device sometimes randomly resets (apparently due to static shock)- Device lost my data on several occasions (when I synced, the app didn't show any data for the previous day)--maybe this was related to the random resets- Screen not bright enough outside- Requires a relatively new phone (iPhone 4S or newer, or a late 2013 or newer Android phone running Android 4.3 or newer)- Not compatible with laptops- Wristband is "one-size-fits-all" (i.e., made to fit a very large wrist)- Wristband is uncomfortable- Recommended charging procedure is a hassle (instructions warn NOT to charge it overnight)- It's effectively a disposable device which you can replace every year with your subscription renewal, but the company doesn't offer a recycling program- If purchased directly from Pivotal Fitness, the company itself does not allow you to return it for a refund under any circumstances (though they will offer an exchange if the band is defective)--so if you want to try it out despite all the known issues, make sure you buy through Amazon so there's at least some hope of returning it if it doesn't work for you.

These razor blades are awesome--just sharp enough, but not so sharp that you slice your face open every time you lightly snag the razor on some contour of your skin. Out of a sampler containing Astra, BlueBird, Feather, Gillette 7o'clock (super and platinum), Gillette Goal, Vidyut (super and platinum), Trig, Derby, and maybe a couple others, my favorites by far were Astra and Gillette. Of those two, the Astra were the cheapest and easiest to find.

I knew these were going to be small, but they are comically small. Even when you consider the dimensions, you can't fully appreciate exactly how tiny they are until you see them in real life.For less than 3 bucks you can't really ask for more, but I'm interested to see how well they hold up over time.

This cord winder is NOT a wonder.  When it's cold out, the rubber winding wheel doesn't grip the cord and fails to wind it at all.  The hand crank requires you to place the Wonder Winder someplace within arm's reach, so it isn't as handy as a self-retracting cord reel.Also, I need to look at mine again because I must have assembled it wrong or must be using it wrong.  I had assumed one-hand operation to wind a cord, but I have to pull and hold the top lever to push the cord against the winding wheel, which is kind of a pain and further limits placement.  But even if I do manage to resolve this issue, the product is still a dud if it can't wind up a cord when it's cold out.Once I started to question its usefulness in my garage shop, I thought I'd try salvaging it by using it as a portable cord winder.  Whenever I see my wife using the "around-the-arm" technique to coil a cord (which damages the cord over time), I try showing her how to properly coil a cord.  She inevitably gets annoyed at me because the over-under technique hasn't "clicked" for her yet and she doesn't have the patience to keep trying until it does.  I thought the Wonder Winder could help this situation whenever she needs an extension cord outside.  My wife does prefer using the Wonder Winder this over any hand-coiling technique, but the whole assembly is really clunky to use in this way so I ended up buying an extension cord storage reel instead.

Irwin's XP600 line is a huge step up from their wimpier SL300 line, but these clamps aren't great for woodworking and are overpriced considering you can get top-of-the-line parallel clamps for the same price.  The SL300s are good for holding jigs and stop blocks in place.  The XP600s have a lot more clamping power, and they work great for general clamping or spreading.  They're probably good for rough carpentry but I don't have any experience in that area.However, if you're a woodworker these are not the clamps to stock up on. They'll work fine with cauls but they don't function very well on their own as parallel clamps for glue-ups, even with the rubbery plastic throat extensions for the jaws.  It wouldn't hurt to have a couple of these clamps for the convenience of their one-handed operation, but you're better off buying some Jet parallel (K-body) clamps during one of the 50% off sales, if you can hold off until Black Friday or one of the other big sales throughout the year.Of course, you also obviously won't want to use them for welding because they're plastic and they'll melt.

First off, I'm no costume designer but the look and fit of this shirt are genuine enough that I think a casual observer would be hard-pressed to notice any flaws in your costume if you decided to film your own new TNG fan series.  Black threads are visible at the seams, but I think that's forgivable for an article in the $25-$30 price range.  I like that the pips are actual pins rather than stickers or embroidered on, and that they include a little reference sheet so you know which ones to use for a given rank or character, in case your memory is a bit rusty or you didn't quite pay attention to those subtle details.  The communicator pin is a heavy rubbery pin, and mine is poorly-painted...but hey, it's still better than a cheesy embroidered-on design, and I suppose I could always touch it up.I have a hard time describing the fit based on Amazon's answer options to the question, "How does this product fit?"  I'm a 6'1", 175 lbs man with a slight belly and the medium shirt fits well except for the weird armpits.  It's hard to describe, but I think the armpits of the shirt basically extend further down the side of the shirt in order to produce a sleeker look, so when you lift your arms it feels like you're pulling the side outward a little.  Imagine a flying squirrel spreading out its limbs--okay, maybe that's a bit of an exaggeration, but you probably get the point.  Based on the sizing chart, I think the small definitely would have been too small, and I suspect the large probably would have been baggy.  Then again, with free returns I probably should have ordered 2 or 3 sizes and sent back whatever didn't fit.I understand that I'm a bit biased, but I think the shirt looks great on me if I suck in my gut a little and don't raise my arms any higher than the guy in Amazon's product picture (he has his hands on his hips).  It feels like if I lift my arms much higher than that, the armpits or sides will rip open.  I also understand now why the TNG crew constantly have to tug their shirts down.  The elastic at the bottom of the shirt is probably supposed to hold the shirt down at your waist, but what really happens is that every time you lift your arms or take a deep breath (thus lifting your diaphragm), the shirt rides up your torso and the elastic prevents it from sliding back down.  For better or worse, this shirt seems almost *too* authentic!

I have to say, I feel more than a little ripped off by Festool with this interface pad.  This product is nothing more than a squishy lightweight foam (like that used to package electronic components) sandwiched between two respective pieces of hook-and-loop material.  Oh, and it has the hole pattern cut for dust collection.Does it work?  Yeah, sure, it helps but it doesn't seem very durable.  But the box it came in probably cost just as much to produce as the materials for the interface pad itself.  The materials couldn't have cost Festool more than $.25, yet they charge $24 for the interface pad--that's an obscene markup, even for Festool.  I don't know, maybe getting the hook-and-loop layers to adhere at all to the foam was an engineering nightmare and they have to charge so much because they don't sell very many.  Even at $6 it would be overpriced, but I wouldn't feel like I had been scammed.I guess I'll see how long it lasts, but if I need another one after it wears out, I'll just try making my own.

I bought my wife a Garmin Vivofit because it seemed the easiest to use and requires less maintenance than all the other options.What I like:- Low maintenance: you only have to replace the battery once a year- Waterproof, so you can shower with it- Includes an extra rubber clasp to help keep it from falling off (which was apparently a problem early on)- Includes 2 sizes of wrist bands- Multi-function LCD shows step count,- Includes USB dongle to sync with a laptop, in case you don't have a smartphone or your smartphone isn't supportedWhat I don't like:- Grossly exaggerates your step count by a random amount- PC application didn't save workout details that my wife entered- Doesn't have a vibrate modeUnfortunately, the first dislike in the list is enough to ruin this product.  The entire point of an activity tracker is to record how much exercise you get, but the numbers are completely inconsistent.When my wife used it for a few days, it consistently logged more than 16,000 steps a day.  On days when she *didn't* go to the gym, it counted more than 20,000 steps.  I thought perhaps we could figure out a baseline and just ignore the first 15,000 steps or so, but if it records more steps when she doesn't exercise, how can she even begin to set goals?It recorded more than 10,000 steps during a day when when I mostly spent my afternoon sitting or standing in one place at a basketball game, and had very little physical activity outside of that.  I'm pretty sure the most sedentary couch potato could reach Garmin's default goal of 7500 steps during the course of a day.  The kicker?  It counted 30 steps when I put on my socks, and another 20 steps when I put on my shoes.I contacted Garmin about the inaccuracy, and they said it's an activity tracker and cannot differentiate between a step and other motion such as driving, brushing your teeth, or cooking.  Maybe I expected too much, but I had assumed if all the fitness band manufacturers were reporting "number of steps" that implied they had some advanced software algorithms capable of distinguishing different types of activities.  I'm tempted to try a few more types of fitness bands to see how they compare, along with a standard pedometer as a control, but I'm hoping I can find someone else who's already run that experiment.

I bought this particular model because of the large display, and because it handles imperial units in both decimal and fractions, as well as metric.  The deciding factor was its performance in a side-by-side comparison with a much more expensive digital caliper.I don't have anything else by which to gauge this caliper's accuracy, but at the very least it seems to get consistent, precise readings.  The jaws aren't perfectly parallel, but they're certainly close enough, especially considering that I'm using this for woodworking.  If I measure a piece of paper with the tip vs. at the inside (near the bar), I get ever-so-slightly different readings, but the difference is within the tolerance specified in the user manual.One nice feature is that the caliper remembers its position even when turned off--that is, you don't necessarily have to zero it each time you turn it on.  Maybe this is standard on digital calipers, but I expected the tool to automatically zero each time it's turned off and on, regardless of the jaws' position.  I'm glad that's not the case.

This filter is sort of a necessary evil if you have a small shop-vac.  It doesn't have particularly great filtration, but it's better than nothing.  I had to buy this because I had my original filter sitting out and my wife threw it in the trash, thinking it was no longer needed.

I bought this to test some paint on a trailer but it isn't clear to me whether it's detecting lead, or even whether the test kit is any good to begin with.  The instructions say to crush the swab at both ends and shake it twice, then squeeze until yellow liquid comes out of the end.  This is where the problems start.  The liquid is a tiny dot of brown, not yellow as stated in the instructions.  After rubbing it on the test surface, the entire tip turns brown.  It's supposed to turn pink or red if there's lead, but the brown color makes it difficult to tell whether there's any red.  I also rubbed it on a test spot on the test card, and the test spot turned pink but the end of swab itself remained brown.  If it was supposed to turn pink, as well, I don't know how I would have been able to tell.
I don't know how I had never seen this episode before; it's easily in the top 5 out of all episodes of any Star Trek series, and I'd say it's tied with The Inner Light (S5E25) for #1 TNG episode.

This dust collector hose is heavy-duty enough and it easily stretches to about 10 feet.  I just use long zip ties on the ends instead of hose clamps, and it stays attached to my dust collector and table saw/planer just fine.  I can even move the tool end back and forth between the table saw and planer without having to replace the zip tie.

I bought this Braun/Oral-B Professional Care power toothbrush to replace my previous Philips SoniCare toothbrush.  Although the brush heads are equally expensive, the Oral-B was sealed much better and did not succumb to moisture that seeped inside and eventually shorted out the electronics, which is what killed my SoniCare toothbrush.At first I was disappointed that the Oral-B toothbrush's head didn't spin/vibrate as fast as my previous SoniCare, but I quickly found that it had much better reach inside my mouth, and could really clean every little crevice, nook, and cranny around my teeth and gums.  Overall, the Oral-B's maneuverability allowed me to get my teeth a lot cleaner.I tried some generic toothbrush heads to save on cost, but the bristles were much harder than those of the genuine Oral-B brush heads.  (Ideally, you want to use the softest brush possible to help avoid damaging your tooth enamel.)Alas, after almost ten years of faithful service, the Lithium Ion battery no longer holds a charge.  I might try replacing the battery, but for the time being I just steal my wife's brush handle, which is a newer, faster model.
I got this vacuum free in a promotion.  It was a noisy piece of junk with poor suction.  Anything this can pick up, you're better off using a damp paper towel instead.

What I like:- Microsoft Natural-style ergonomic keyboard- arrow keys have the standard layout (compared to the diamond layout of the Natural Elite)- multimedia functions are a nice bonus- well-built like previous incarnations of Microsoft's Natural keyboard lineWhat I don't like:- only one Windows key! -- which makes it impossible to lock your workstation with a single one-handed keystroke (Windows+L) unless you have gargantuan hands- goofy layout of the Home keypad (Insert/Home/Delete/End/PgUp/PgDown) and a couple other keys makes it difficult to touch-type if you're used to the more standard key positions

By today's standards, this 256 MB flash drive is a relic.  Although it supports USB 2.0, the write speeds were are only okay if you're writing large files.  It's horrible at writing many small files.The Cruzer Mini isn't very "mini" compared to more recent models, some of which are smaller than my thumbnail.  On the bright side, that means it's a lot harder to lose.  But the downside is that you have this huge "lever" hanging out of your USB port.  Its plastic shell is acceptable, but it certainly isn't very rugged.  My boss accidentally smashed one in his car door, and of course it was damaged beyond repair.  (A few of us at the office each chipped in a couple bucks and gave him a tougher model with a titanium shell after that incident.)My biggest gripe, however, is that the cap is easy to lose--which I'm sure is the main reason why they include three caps in the package.  And the more you remove and reattach the cap, the looser it gets over time.  The lanyard is nice, but I've never really been one to wear a lanyard around my neck unless I'm at a conference.  You certainly wouldn't want to attach this flash drive to your keys, because the little tab that's meant for the lanyard is just plastic and will break off in your pocket.All in all, it's okay compared to other models of the same vintage, but even back in 2004, there were other models that held up better on your keychain, were more compact, and didn't have such an easy-to-lose cap.  Really the only thing this had going for it was that it was one of the cheapest flash drives you could get.

C++ FAQs is a great reference not only if you happen to have one of the frequently-asked questions, but also if you are interested in some of the more esoteric language features or want to learn about corner cases which could come up.  Highly recommended if you work with the internals of compiler technology and want to handle various language features correctly.

If you've walked down the oral hygiene aisle in the store lately, you've probably noticed that there's pretty much no such thing as a standard tube of toothpaste any more.  "Whitening" is the new standard toothpaste.  All you have to do to see why is to watch an 80's or earlier movie and pay attention to everyone's "realistically yellow" teeth.  Back then, you didn't really notice it.  But now...yuck!This toothpaste is blue, tastes minty, and has little square "mini breath strips" init.  The cap on the tube is one of those little flip-type caps which can also screw on and off.  Every time I have a tube with that style cap, the cap breaks at the joint.  The larger flip-type cap on the end of my old tube let me stand the toothpaste tube up on its end.  But on the bright side, I guess this tube's cap uses less plastic and it will be easier to squeeze out every last bit of toothpaste out of it than with my old stand-up tube.

We gave this as a gift to our friends who watch a lot of movies at home.  My wife and I have the older 80's version that my parents gave us (they received two as wedding gifts decades ago).  Both the older model and newer model seem to work best if you make the maximum-sized batch.  The 80s version seems a little better because it swirls the popcorn around in a low-angle spiral, whereas the newer model seems to blow the air more upward, causing unpopped kernels to just fly out if you try to just make a small batch.  I wish the popcorn chamber was a little taller so fewer unpopped kernels would escape toward the end.What I like:- no cooking oil- takes up less space than other types of popcorn makersWhat I don't like:- plastic lid/deflector starts to bubble and deform with heavy use- toward the end of a batch, it starts to throw out a lot of unpopped kernels--some of which "explode" in the bowl, causing a mess

I bought this for our vintage travel trailer.  The ball part fits up into the coupler and the shackle goes down over the top.  Our trailer's coupler, the closing mechanism has a lever with a loop on the end, and the loop pushes down right where the shackle goes.  With a little finagling I can route the shackle through the loop so that the closing mechanism is locked onto the ball, in addition to the coupler lock's normal locking method.The only thing I'd change is that I would prefer to have a lock without a universal ball.  Because the universal fit, the lock fits kind of loose in a 2" coupler, so in order to lock it snug on your coupler, you have to squeeze the shackle and lock body together while locking it.  It would be nicer if you could just replace the ball on the lock, that way it would fit snug on its own and you wouldn't have to hold the body of the lock up against the bottom of the coupler while turning the key to lock it.The lock has a lot of angled and rounded surfaces so it should be somewhat impact resistant, though I'm sure anyone who wants a trailer badly enough would figure out a way to break or otherwise defeat the lock.

I love Lindt chocolates, especially the delectable, filled spherical truffles, but somehow had never been face-to-face with one of the caramel variety.  I thought I liked the dark and milk chocolate ones, but these caramel ones put those others to shame.  My only regret is that my box of 60 won't last long enough.  And no, I'm not sharing them, even if that was the original plan.

This game won't run on my Droid X2.  I'm not sure if my phone is just too slow, or what.  I even tried uninstalling some other apps, but the game just stayed on a black screen and never loaded up, even after several minutes.

I bought the Bosch Vertical Quick Clamp for use in my Kobalt (Lowe's-exclusive brand) 10-in sliding compound miter saw.  In some ways it's an improvement over the clamp that came with the saw, but in other ways it's a step backward.The clamp is such a simple device that there's not much to say about it, but I'll start with the good.  The quick toggle lets you quickly release and clamp items of the same thickness.  With my old clamp, I had to turn the adjustment knob several times to loosen and tighten the clamp enough to swap in a different piece.Unfortunately, all of the thought went into the toggle mechanism, leaving shortcomings in other areas.  The only adjustment possible is the threaded part.  On my other clamp, there's a hex screw that I can loosen and tighten for quick coarse adjustments.  If most of your material is the same thickness, the lack of a quicker coarse adjustment won't be an issue and this clamp will save you time.  But if you often work with materials of different thicknesses on a given project, I highly recommend making shims of several different thicknesses to use for coarse adjustment.The other drawbacks might only apply to me because I don't have a Bosch miter saw, but I think they're worth explaining anyway in case someone else wants to use this clamp on a non-Bosch saw.  Although the Bosch Vertical Quick Clamp  fits into the clamp holders on my Kobalt saw, it just barely fits.  The diamond-textured part of the shaft is actually slightly larger in diameter than the smooth part of the shaft, so although I'm sure it's more than adequate, it just doesn't feel as secure without as much of the shaft in the clamp holder.  I'm also a little concerned about the diamond texture itself scraping the paint off of my saw around the clamp holders.  Update: also tried the clamp in a DEWALT DW715 15-Amp 12-Inch Compound Miter saw and it does fit better in that saw because of the larger, tapered clamp holes.

This Belkin 12-outlet surge protector is awesome--there really isn't much room for improvement.What I like:- 12 outlets, so you can plug in a ton of stuff- 6 of the outlets can accommodate the chunky brick/wall wart power adapters- flat plug only requires about an inch of clearance (great for plugging in behind furniture)- swivel plug lets you angle the cord off to either side- phone and coax surge protection- inexpensiveWhat I don't like:- Middle strip of outlets can be blocked by especially chunky wall warts plugged in along sides- Some of the outlet safety covers are too hard to slide and others slide too easily (not a serious issue for me, but it might be an issue if you have kids)- doesn't have RJ45 (Ethernet) surge protection--though there might be a different model which does have thisOne thing that I'm not sure about is the design of the surge protection circuit.  I've always used Panamax surge protectors on my more expensive electronics like my desktop PC and my home theater equipment, because Panamax physically disconnects the power when the surge protector finally blows and is no longer capable of absorbing a surge.  As of a few years ago, most other brands, including the well-known brands like APC, did not disconnect the power to any plugged-in devices after the surge protector exhausted its surge protection capacity.  I'm not sure which surge protection design the Belkin uses, but for most applications it should be adequate--and if it isn't, you can always file a warranty claim with Belkin or file a homeowner's insurance claim.

When I put this DVD in my DVD player and pressed Play, it just went through an hour and forty-three minutes of deleted scenes.  (Ba-dum-bum)  But seriously, folks, if you've ever wondered what it would be like to watch a movie almost entirely composed of deleted scenes that shouldn't go into the special features (let alone, the final script), you can stop wondering, because Grown Ups 2 is just that.  If you haven't seen the first Grown Ups, watch that one and forget this sequel ever existed.  If you did see the first Grown Ups and expect a coherent follow-up in the sequel, you're in for a big disappointment.Grown Ups 2 is a continuous sequence of mostly-lame gags, though there were a few genuinely funny parts that did did make us laugh.  There are no deleted scenes in the special features, because if they had deleted everything that should have been deleted, they would have only had enough material left to make a 3-5 minute webisode around each of the handful of funny bits.  There were two or three times in the last half hour where I thought they were finally setting up a big, incredible adventure, but it never materialized.  I guess I was okay with that, because the movie was already dragging on forever and starting the adventure at that point would have made it even longer.SPOILER ALERT=============The premise of Grown Ups 2 is that all four guys (three of whom are married with kids) have moved back to the hometown where they grew up, and now on the last day of school they're collectively having another mid-life crisis.  David Spade's character is set up as the worst off, having a teenage punk kid visiting from out of town--a son which the all-but-forgotten mother only told him about over the phone a couple days prior.  Supposedly the kid is in high school, but he looks like he's in his twenties.  Spade's character tries makes some wisecracks in an attempt to bond.  The kid obviously doesn't like him from the start but is willing to give him a chance.The four friends go back to their old hang-out spot so one of the guys can jump off a cliff into a lake (something which he always managed to find an excuse not to do back when they were  young) and finally earn his man card.  But there are a bunch of college kids hanging out at the lake, and up on the cliff the four grown-up male friends encounter a bunch of stereotypical fraternity jerks.could say the theme of the movie was "bullies."  Insults ensue, the four guys get ready to fight, then one of the frat boys makes a cheesy battle cry and an army of frat boys jumps out from behind bushes and rocks, surrounding the four doomed friends.  Frat boys make them jump off the cliff naked one at a time, with the other college party kids watching from the lower level of rocks on the other side of the water.  Kevin James lands on David Spade, who then cries, disgustedly, "I was inside of you!"The middle part of the movie is basically a bunch of half-baked attempts at humor, desperately hoping the audience keeps watching until the two big showdowns at the end--it's almost like they didn't have a single professional comedy writer or script writer on the crew.Near the end, Sandler's character throws a big party.  The first showdown is with the main bully from Sandler's past (bully played by none other than Stone Cold Steve Austin).  This part is pretty much the one good bit of writing in the entire movie.  Sandler wants to teach his son how to be a man and stand up to bullies.  Upon hearing this, Austin's character (who has been a huge jerk the entire movie) can finally relate to Sandler and immediately hatches a plan--Sandler can punch him, and he'll go down like a sack of bricks.  The plan changes a bit as the two chat in their boxing poses, and eventually Stone Cold is cowering and pleading for mercy.  Sandler continues his trash talk to milk the situation for all it's worth, and then some.  After that situation is resolved, the frat boys show up for revenge because someone previously trashed their frat house and they assume it's the four Grown Ups whom they shamed earlier at the lake.  (As it turns out, Spade's son was the one who vandalized the frat house, but  nobody cares at this point.)  Everyone gets in a big fight which the "townies" eventually win, a little later there are some warm fuzzy moments, and finally the credits roll.

Mine is bigger than yours.  Yeah, you read that right.  How big is your TV?  50"?  60"?  Maybe 75" if you really splurged?  Well, just for comparison, my 170" screen gives me a larger picture than a 3x3 grid of 50" TVs.  That's more than 9x the screen size of the most common "big screen" TVs.When I was going to replace my old 24" tube TV, I had a few options and didn't like any of them.  For $500, I could buy a 32" TV, for $800 I could get a 40" TV, and for $1200-$1500 I could get a 50" TV--which seemed obscene to me.  I couldn't see myself ponying up even $800 for my minimum "desired" TV sizewhen I could get 9x the size for not much more by going with a projector.  I ended up settling on a 32" TV and a projector...now the only thing left was to choose the projector.At first I was going to buy one of the sub-$1000 projectors that had just hit the market, but they all had a relatively short throw and poor mounting options--I would have had to have an ugly appendage sticking out of the middle of my living room ceiling, and it would have been a pain to run the electrical and video connections to that spot.  I started looking into projectors with lens shift and a longer throw and longer zoom range, and soon realized I would have to increase my budget for the projector to about $1300-$1400.  My plan was to mount the projector on the back wall above the entrance to my living room.  I didn't plan on really needing the lens shift, I wanted it just because it seemed like it would make setup a little easier and because I could shift the image down (vertically) by a little bit instead of having to deal with distortion and keystone correction.Using the calculators at ProjectorCentral.com, I narrowed down my options to the Epson PowerLite Home Cinema 720 LCD projector and a competing Mitsubishi DLP projector.  Although I don't suffer from the condition that causes some people to get headaches and nausea when watching a DLP picture, I didn't want any guests to feel less than awesome when watching movies at my place.  I ended up snagging a sweet deal on the Epson PowerLite Home Cinema 720 on sale for less than $1000, and cashback and a free (by mail) replacement bulb brought the cost of the projector itself down to around $600 (after factoring in ~$300 for the replacement bulb).It wasn't until I tried to "temporarily" set up the projector immediately upon getting it home that I began to truly appreciate just how much versatility lens shift adds to a projector.  I set the projector on top of my DVD shelf in the back left corner of my living room.  All I had to do was aim the projector straight forward, level it, then fiddle with the zoom and a couple of dials (horizontal and vertical lens shift) to perfectly size and line up the picture!  For the uninitiated, lens shift lets you turn a dial to literally shift the rectangular image up or down (or left or right) without distorting it.  You can literally put the projector anywhere in the room, so long as the throw distance and zoom range allow you to properly size the image for your screen.  *This* is why you find some people on audio visual systems forums who insist on having a projector with lens shift.That initial temporary setup worked so well, I gave up on the idea of putting the projector on a shelf above the entrance in the back of the room and left the projector on top of the DVD shelf.  Eventually I moved the DVD shelf to the back right corner of the room so people walking in and out of the living room couldn't walk in front of the projector beam as easily.  Now if you're just heading for a couch, you pretty much don't bother anyone else who's trying to watch the show.The picture is incredible...and did I mention enormous?  The blacks are a bit muted, but that's to be expected with an LCD projector.  It's true that the colors won't be quite as vibrant as those from a high-quality HDTV, but everything looks great nonetheless.  And from the couch about 20 feet away (heck, even from the one that's 10 feet away), 720p still looks pretty sharp.  DVDs, Blu-ray, and streaming Amazon Video and Crackle via my Roku HD (which maxes out at 720p anyway) look good enough that I'm starting to wonder if I'll be able to skip 1080p and jump to a 4k projector a few more years down the road.  I've also played VHS tapes on the projector, but--as you might expect--the picture was so fuzzy and lacking in detail that I almost might as well have been watching without my eyeglasses.The main downside, picture-wise, is that I need to supplement my living room curtain with another layer or two of blankets or sheets if I want to watch something on the projector when it's really bright outside.  Alternatively, I could turn up the brightness of the projector's lamp, but that reduces the lamp's life and causes the fan to run much faster (i.e., much louder).  Although the projector has almost every type of home theater video input that has been commonly used in the US since before the turn of the century (HDMI, VGA, SCART, component, S-video, and composite), it would be nice if it could output a digital audio stream to my receiver (which is still a great 7.1 receiver but predates HDMI).Several years after buying this projector, I still think it was one of my best big-ticket purchases.  Even though it's a little outdated, it still puts up a great picture and impresses guests.  And because we don't have an eyesore hanging down from the middle of our ceiling (thanks to the lens shift and long throw), most visitors can't even figure out where the picture is coming from until we point it out in the back corner of the room.

I bought the Spotbot Pet because one of our cats pukes practically every day.  The poor guy just can't keep his food down a lot of the time, and we haven't been able to figure out the cause (most of the time it isn't a hairball).To use the machine, first pick up any solid part of the mess.  Then you just make sure the machine has water and cleaning solution in the tank, center the big round brush area over the mess, plug it in, press a  button, and walk away.  About 3-6 minutes later (depending on whether you pressed the button for "fresh" or "set-in") you can empty and rinse the dirty tank and put the machine away.What I like:- easy to use- no excuse not to clean up the mess right away- works ok on fresh messes- completely automatic: start it and walk away- onboard hose and accessory tool storage works wellWhat I don't like:- doesn't work very well on set-in messes- leaves the floor much wetter than our full-size Hoover Dual-V carpet cleaner- just as noisy as our full-size carpet cleaner- power cord storage works okay, but could be improvedMost of my likes and dislikes above are pretty self-explanatory.  We've tried it with both hot and cold water, and the temperature of the water doesn't seem to make much difference in the machine's ability to clean up a set-in mess.  I'd recommend pretreating with a foaming or spray carpet cleaner if you have a set-in stain.Unfortunately, after using it on the living room carpet, I kept stepping on the spot that had been cleaned, and for more than a day it continued to make my socks wet whenever I stepped on it.A minor gripe is that the power cord storage isn't as good as it could be.  If you wrap the cord in a circle around the two storage pegs, the cord will get twisted and over time will become damaged internally.  It's too difficult to use the over-under cord coiling technique.  If you wrap the cord in a figure-8 around the pegs in an attempt to keep the cord from twisting, it starts to bulge out too much in the middle of the figure-8, and the loops of the figure-8 can come off of the pegs.The Spotbot also has a manual brush, and while it can be somewhat useful for trying to scrub in corners where the spotbot itself can't reach, the manual brush isn't anything special.  But at least it's on par with the other portable spot cleaners.

Intel has a reputation for making reliable SSDs, and their best-in-industry 5-year warranty backs that up.  I've used the following SSDs:Crucial M4 256 GB - laptop boot drive (Windows 7)Intel 520 Series 240 GB - laptop boot drive (Windows 7)Samsung 840 PRO 256 GB - tethered via USB to host external VMware VMsIntel 530 Series 240 GB - laptop boot drive (Windows 8.1)I replaced the Crucial with the Intel 520 after a month or two because my laptop was crashing, but I now think the crashing was the result of a defective secondary SATA cable in my laptop.  Over the course of about a year with the Intel 520, my laptop would occasionally fail to boot with a "No bootable media found" error when I powered it on.  Power-cycling the laptop always solved the issue, so I'm not sure if it was a problem with Windows, some quirk related to the SSD, or the laptop itself.  For several months now, I've been storing my many VMware VMs on an external Samsung 840 PRO and the VMs run as fast as if I were running the guest OSes natively on my laptop.So, what about the Intel 530?  I haven't done any formal benchmarking, but I can say that, in practical terms, it's just as fast as the Crucial M4 and the Intel 520, if not faster.  So far I haven't had the weird temporary "No bootable media found" boot hiccup with the 530, but I'll update my review if it does come up.Since I haven't used the Samsung 840 PRO as my boot drive, I can't give any direct comparison between that and the Intel 530, although the spec sheets suggest the Samsung is considerably faster.The SSD is only 7mm thick, but if you buy the retail kit, it contains an adhesive shim to make the SSD fit into a 9mm slot.  This is a slight downgrade from the Intel 520 series, which included a screw-on shim.  Both the 530 and 520 series also include the 3.5" mounting adapter and the silly "Speed Demon" sticker.As with the 520 series, the 530 series performs background optimization of free space--in other words, while TRIM is supported, it's not required in order to preserve performance (assuming the drive is not constantly under 100% load).Although there are faster SSDs on the market, if you just want to buy a current-generation SSD (as of 11/2013) manufactured by a company with a proven history of reliability, this drive is a no-brainer.

For the price, these are a great value.  I ordered them on Nov 12 and the estimated delivery window was Dec 9-Dec 26, but the USPS delivered them at the beginning of the delivery window.We use Square Register for the cash register at our store, and people prefer signing with a stylus instead of their fingers.  Some people expect the tip to be hard instead of soft, so it throws them off at first, but otherwise these work fine.  Aside from the color selection, these styluses are identical to the brand-name Targus stylus that sells for $15 in stores.  Just as with the Targus, the tips eventually tear and render the stylus useless, but each one usually lasts us at least a few months.  At about $0.14 each, that's not much more expensive than a BIC pen, but you don't have to deal with a finicky pen.The only thing I really hate about these things is that I keep having to throw away the aluminum stylus rods after the tips wear out.  I wish I could just unscrew the bad tip and screw on a new one.

We use this scale at our bakery/restaurant.  For a while, our products were baking up inconsistently because sometimes the kitchen staff would get distracted and lose track of how many cups of an ingredient they had added.  Now they just set the bowl on the scale, zero it, fill it with the first ingredient until it's close to the prescribed amount, zero it again, add the second ingredient, and so on.Occasionally the measurement will fluctuate by a fraction of an ounce (or gram), but let's be realistic--for the ingredients that you weigh, you're not going to ruin a recipe by adding a tiny fraction of an ounce too much or too little of anything unless you're trying to prepare an unreasonably-small batch.  The quantities of any recipe are always fudged into nice ratios of convenient units.  It's not like all the eggs in a carton are guaranteed to be within 0.01 oz of one another, after all.The scale is a nice, easy-to-use machine and the units are easy to read.  We tape plastic wrap around the front of the scale to make it easier to clean and to keep powdery ingredients from working their way inside.Unfortunately, this is our third scale of this type in about 3 years because we keep wearing out the buttons.  It isn't made for commercial use, and I'm sure it won't last any longer than the others--but it will be put through a lot more punishment in our commercial kitchen than it will in anyone's home.

I didn't know anything about trailers or hitches until I started shopping for a trailer and hitch for our 2009 Chevy HHR.  This one is identical to several other brands and mounts firmly to the frame.I had to buy a step drill bit to slightly enlarge the rear passenger-side mounting hole on the car frame.  In hindsight, I probably could have gotten a (much cheaper) 1/2" grinding bit instead.The most difficult part of installation was properly torquing the forward driver's side bolt, because it was hard to get a good angle between the muffler and the bolt with my non-ratcheting torque wrench.This kit comes with everything you need except the ball, a locking pin for the receiver, and a lock for the trailer ball latch.  If I had thought of it sooner, I would have bought a replacement Euro-style drawbar with the welded-on ball for a little more security (I'll probably do that anyway sometime further down the road).  On the other hand, if you pull several trailers which require different-size balls, you can save a few bucks by using the included drawbar and just swapping the ball instead of having a drawbar for each ball.

These coin holders are nice and sturdy, they fit well into my wife's vinyl coin holder pages, and the window in each one is just the right size for a penny.  I've read that another brand is difficult to write on.  Although the white side on this brand (DOMAGRON) looks somewhat glossy, it is textured enough that you can write on it with a ballpoint pen.

4 stars - it works ok for a simple plastic fixture. I use one to close off an unused output of the pump, together with a piece of tube. It works, and if it breaks, I` will have four others for spare parts. A bit pricey for what they are, though.I also received a bag of splitters (t-connectors) with the same shipment that I did not order as far as I can tell. I wonder if the seller is providing these now because of the misleading item title ("Splitter Tube Connector"). A nice gesture.

I purchased my first air pump in the 1970s. I believe it was a Rena 100. I later added a Rena 200. I wish I still had one. These pumps were small, quiet, powerful, and lasted forever.Fast-forward to 2015, this Tetra pump replaces a $10 pump from Walmart that lasted 5 months and then rattled into pieces. I had it suspended on a rubber band inside the aquarium cabinet. It was not silent, but the noise was tolerable and it could only be heard around the tank.I suspended the Tetra pump as well but it took two rubber bands. The odd shape of the housing gives it a large footprint. There is limited shelf space in the cabinet and this was necessary. It isn't really designed for suspension, but it worked.For those not realizing this - you have to connect tubing to both outputs, otherwise it will be loud i.e. emitting noise not just vibration.The pump's vibrations are of a lower frequency than the inexpensive pump and the vibrations result in a low but omnipresent humming noise. The vibrations travel through the framing of the house and can be felt 3 rooms away and from the basement to the 2nd floor. I am really not impressed.

The snails arrived quickly and all three are still alive after 5 days. I cannot confirm that they will "remove all pest snails" - so far they have been fairly uninterested in the other snails. A failure, I would say.Update day 6: I saw one empty snail shell in the front of the tank today. It looks like one of the assassins remembered his purpose. However, at this rate they will not make a big dent into the pest snail population. I am upgrading to 3 stars but I am not optimistic.

I have had my Tyl (notice the dots!) heater for 6 years now. I agree with the other reviewer who complains about the lack of support in the US. I also tried to contact the manufacturer but was ignored.The issue with these models is that the are configured to shut off above 150F which prevents you from ever getting the Sauna experience. You have to actually physically alter the location of the temperature sensors to be able to operate the Sauna at higher temperatures (after you have altered the control panel as well). Vendors and installers know this, but why doesn't Tyl make a product that works out of the box?
Didn't last 6 months. The plastic assembly inside is made from very brittle material that does not withstand the vibrations. Into the landfill it goes.

Someone had broken the skimmer door during a recent pool party. In my 2nd attempt I managed to order the correct part - this was the correct replacement for my skimmer. Snapped right into place and now the leaves stay in the skimmer and no longer float back out when the pump shuts off.

The picker shipped in a massive box that could have held a ground-air missile. I got quite a deal on this item with the free shipping, maybe by error. Not surprisingly, it is no longer available at this price.I find the picker too heavy and the handling is not as easy as one would like. My grandfather had a fruit picker with a cloth bag and wood pole that was so light and agile that a child could hold it at the very end of the pole. I was surprised how heavy this one is when I took if out of the box. You need to hold it with the hands at least 3 feet apart to have enough leverage.My daughter struggled quite a bit with this. It works ok, but I am not entirely impressed.

The product seemed like a great idea. In practice, I am struggling a bit with figuring out how to use it. The containers are too big for things like ketchup and mustard and mayo - too much would go to waste. They are too small for salad items. They would be right for bar ingredients, like lime, olives, cherries, but I don't generally offer these things to guests unless we are making one specific drink, and then I don't need 5 compartments.There is actually not much room underneath the containers for ice, probably only one layer of ice cubes that melts quickly.

I installed this on an LGA 1150 board. Keeps the Intel Core i7-4790K Devils Canyon Quad-Core cool hands-down at all times. The fan is silent. The only warning - it is big/high and you need a full-size case that is wider than ordinary graphics cards. After all, the 140mm fan is going to be mounted vertically. Add to that the height of the base and the heat pipes and this becomes a large hunk of metal.

I just built a new computer based on the ASUS Z97-A/USB 3.1 motherboard and the Intel Core i7-4790K Devils Canyon Quad-Core. I used this disk as a data (non-boot) drive. The disk is very quiet and remains cool all the times. See the attached HDTune screen shot for performance metrics.

Nice power supply, very quiet. Fit in the case, all the mounting holes were in the right places. It comes with enough cabling for most applications and the Velcro straps keep them nicely organized.One comment about sizing: The 80 Plus certification guidelines only require efficiency measurements at 20% of the nominal load and above. It does not say anything about smaller load levels. So if you computer consumes 40W most of the time, which mine does, you are not doing yourself a favor by getting an expensive 650W power supply.

Some reviewers question the concept of solar covers per se. I don't - I like having one, despite the odor. Here in New England, it is a necessity early and late in the season.This is the 4th or 5th cover that I purchased for my 16x32 inground pool in 10 years of pool ownership and I can safely say that it is the lowest quality one that I have had, including one that cost $70 at a local overstock store. I keep the cover in the basement on the reel over the winter. None of my previous covers lasted more than 2 to 3 seasons - they never hold up longer.There seems to be a manufacturing problem with the lamination process because the bubbles on this new cover are all collapsed and don't contain much air. As a result, my cover takes on water and about half of it floats below the surface, which defeats the purpose of reducing evaporation losses and heat loss.

The light color and general appearance is very comparable to the old decorative bulbs that I had in the outdoor fixtures. From this aspect alone, they appear to be a great replacement. I do not dim these lights.I could not find anything that is outdoor-rated, so I am going with these and we'll see what happens. The bulbs are protected from the elements in the wall fixtures, so it will just be a matter of working in a wide temperature range. I will find out and report back at the end of next winter.

I  bought the punch bowl set and needed a few extra glasses for a big party that we have coming up, so I ordered these. They match the ones that came with the bowl, but I am equally unimpressed with the quality. Definitely not glasses for expensive wine. Ok for a summer party outside where you expect a couple to break.Ikea sells very similar glasses for a little less money - check them out first if you need a lot of them.
If you want to curl up cozily on the couch with a book or for a movie, these things become solid obstacles. Big, hard, scratchy, not comfortable. They are nice to look at, though.
If you want to curl up cozily on the couch with a book or for a movie, these things become solid obstacles. Big, hard, scratchy, not comfortable. They are nice to look at, though.

Wow, is all I can say. This light wows me every time I use it, and everyone who I ride with. If your mantra is like mine "Only the one with the brightest light survives". and this is true on the road or of-road, then you will be a survivor with this light. On the road, you can teach the *&@#^$ who don't turn off their high beams a lesson. On the trails, a moonless night turns into daylight. I have been trying to take some pictures of a fully lit trail so that I can post it here, but my phone's camera does not do it justice.I have only used the handlebar mount so far and it is all I need. The beam is wide enough that I can see ahead in turns. The Velcro straps keep the battery firmly attached to the frame even on the most rugged rocks. I actually find that I am faster going down steep hills at night with this light because I can see the contours of the trail and rocks better with this light than with day light.If money is not an issue, by all means, get this light..

The set arrived a week late because of a shipping mix-up and I expected torn boxes and damaged pieces, but it came on a pallet and everything was in perfect condition, even the glass table. The welded aluminum frame appears to be strong and durable. All pillows were there as promised, including the extra pillow for the table/ottoman and the three throw pillows.The feet are hard plastic and I would replace them with rubber feet for a wooden deck. My set will be on a concrete pool deck and these type of feet will probably work there, even when the individual pieces get pushed around.One thing I don't know yet is how well the cushions will take wet bathing suits etc over time. I think we will have to remove the covers and throws the cushions into the dryer when they get really soaked, but we will see. I will report back in a year on this.

I wish I had read D. Davis' review before I purchased these shoes. I can't put my finger on what it is, but I can't walk straight in them. They look like dress shoes but feel as soft as sneakers. Some people might like this, but I don't. I like the precision of a stiff dress shoe with leather soles. These shoes make me trip a lot over my own feet.The quality seems to be a problem as well, but after only wearing them for a day I can't say yet.

All-plastic item that looks and feels a bit better and sturdier than comparably priced products I have seen in local stores. The stand is metal, though. I ordered a 2nd one for the big party next week. I have seen replacement spigots here on Amazon - comforting to know for when it should become necessary.The one-star deduction is for the design of the ice insert - it is too small and only reaches down about 1/3 of the height of the dispenser. It will keep cooling the air inside the container after the first few drinks have been dispensed, which is better than nothing. Unless you want to pour ice directly into the drink and dilute it with water, you'll need a better solution.Overall, I think this is a good value and I would purchase another one myself. For the dinner party where we serve the food on fine china I would use something nicer.PS: So the 2nd unit came and I am disappointed. It was missing the protective plastic shoes but came with two spigots. Go figure. I had some extra plastic shoes from the first unit that I used. It has a big, very visible scratch in the front going down from the top edge. And why does a set of two cost more than two individual ones? Again, go figure.

The quality of the paper, binding, and the print process is rather poor, too poor for a $30 paperback edition. This is a true let-down. I don't like to hold this book in my hand or even look at it. It reminds me of self-published books.The anecdotal background stories are old lore and the recipes are ok, but you will need another source for comparing ingredients and cooking processes - this one is not complete enough nor is it free of errors and it cannot be your only reference. We use both the recipe companion of the Time Life book "Cooking of Vienna's Empire" by Joseph Wechberg and "Die gute Kche. Das sterreichische Jahrhundertkochbuch" by Ewald Plachutta for that purpose - they both are good reference books.

I ordered two of these in different colors and from different sellers. I received 3 - the seller in China must have mixed up the shipping. The ones that came from China had a "free gift" included - a stylus and a whistle(?).I removed the screen protectors from the iPad 4s and in they went. Like someone else here I noticed the oily pattern that forms between the case and the screen at first when pressure was applied. This could have been residue from the old screen protectors. After removing the front again and wiping the screen and the inside of the front cover with a micro fiber cloth, this no longer happens.The process of inserting the iPad into the case requires a bit of strength - the white clips can be stubborn - and takes time. You will not want to do take it out of the case often.The kids complained that they have to remove the rubber flap that covers the rear camera before they can take a picture. They reported that this piece was the first to break on their friend's cases.The screen protectors are not the same quality as regular screen protectors - they get easily scratched. It does appear, though, that this is a popular case for school iPads because of its simple design. Overall, I am not unhappy with the purchase and think that these are a good value and should last for a year of daily use in school.

Arrived in one piece in spite of the thin box and lack of protective padding. As others have noted, the bowl is smaller than advertised, a bit too small for parties with more than 15 guests. The bowl is the size of a large salad bowl and will certainly be used for this purpose. The bowl and glasses are made of thick glass and look inexpensive. I find this set not that great a value, considering the size and quality. Ikea sells stemless win glasses for a couple of bucks.I bought another plastic ladle for 99 cents that looks almost identical. I could have put together my own set for half the cost from local sources.

I purchased the camera a few months ago for 30% more than what it is listed now, but did not have time to install it until recently. Today, at under $100, this camera is even more attractive. I have been using IP cameras around the house for nearly 15 years now. With the DS-2CD2332-I I can finally say that I have a good product that is worth the money.I am using it outside, mounted to the ceiling of the front porch, with PoE from a Cisco SMB switch. It is protected from direct sunlight and the elements there and I am not worried about its life expectancy.The camera's image is crisp and detailed, better than of my much more expensive Acti TCM1231 that is now several generations older, has fewer features, and still retails at around $600.There is not much ambient light on my street at night and the night recording conditions are challenging. There is this plant hanger right in front of it that is very bright in the IR illumination, but the front yard behind it remains largely obscure. I will have to combine this with a motion light if I want to see who or what is roaming around my yard at night.The other challenge of the location is the high contrast between sun and shade in the afternoon. I attached a separate image showing how the camera performs there.In any case, I do not see the plates of cars driving by, or even the make and model of the car in most cases. Fast moving objects are burred. Don't expect that kind of performance.The camera and its firmware can do more than you will want or need. It was detected by the Surveillance Center on my QNap NAS and I use it on one of the NAS channels. The camera can write to a NAS itself and does not need other software for that, but I like to see all camera channels on one screen, and with all different vendors and models this works best in the QNAP software.I purchased $100 IP cameras nearly 10 years ago that are still operating, but the difference is staggering. I feel that with the Hikvision we are getting so much in this price segment that it will be at least another 10 years before another product will surpass it in image quality and overall value.

I can no longer record all my cameras because QNap reduced the number of available camera licenses to 2. The original Surveillance Station still supports 4, but the software has not been updated in 5 years and the camera support is a bit outdated, so there really wasn't a choice but to install Surveillance Station Pro. I initially gave the QNap NAS glowing reviews after coming from Synology because of this very fact - the support of 4 cameras out of the box. I feel betrayed now.

Perfect fit for my Smart-UPS 1500 RM X138. It took less than 5 minutes to replace the batteries. The unit passed a self test and shows 28 minutes of runtime for everything in the rack. Glad I did not spend $200 again. Let's hope they'll last as long as the last set (4 years).

I am glad I went with this goal (6.5x18.5). It goes up and breaks down so easily and quickly that a 13 year old can do it with his younger sister. I was concerned that having to take it down would be a compromise over a permanent goal, but the opposite is true. You WANT to take it down when not in use, to prolong its life and the free up yard space, for mowing the lawn, partying, etc - because it is so easy. When up, it is strong and sturdy, and when packed, it stows away easily in the garage. It travels to sleep-overs and field trips to parks where no goals are available. I would buy this again.

Make sure you review the shipping terms AFTER selecting a color and, implicitly, the vendor. This is one of the SKUs here on Amazon were you can be in for an unpleasant surprise if you don't. Some of the vendors do not stock this item in the US and will ship from China, and some color combinations are at times only available from such a vendor. They will charge your card right away but you may not see any merchandise for months.Now to the case. It is study and protects the iPad well. The stand can be removed. When it is on and even when folded, it sticks out at an awkward angle and the back is not entirely flat. I am not convinced that a front cover is the way to go. Inevitably, there is a compromise between protection and tactile responsiveness. I will go with a back-only case and a screen protector the next time.

I installed this in a tiled shower a week ago and so far is has been holding to the wall. Dispensers that are falling off the wall must either not have been glued properly, i.e. with as much surface of the plate contacting the glue and the wall as possible, or no surface preparation was done. It needs to be dry and oil-free. Or maybe certain tile material does not work, e.g. if it is too porous.I also installed a Better Living Classic dispenser a couple of weeks earlier in a marble shower, so I can't help but measure the simplehuman one against the Better Living.What I like:- the modern "chrome" design- the easy one-hand operation- it dispenses a good amount of gel with each squeezeWhat I do not like:- the almost invisible label on the cover. Clearly this product has not been designed for the 50+ demographics. If the content is roughly the same color, you will be struggling to remember which is which for some time. I have to take the cover off and hold it against the light to be able to read what is in it.- you are stuck with shampoo/conditioner/soap. Better Living includes additional labels.- post-shower cleanup is more cumbersome in comparison. I have to remove each container from the plate to be able to wipe the back and the wall behind it.- pricey!

I bought this lamp in 2011, i.e. it is over 4 years old now, still working fine and still charging the original battery. I use it and charge it very irregularly, sometimes not for months. I think it was a decent purchase.

What a fun movie. It's made for children, but adults all seemed to love it, and we did too. I honestly bought it originally because of the various YouTube videos of people teaching their Cockatiels to whistle the theme song. The orchestrated version is extremely catchy. But after doing some reading up about the film, I found it's one of the currently still most popular children's films worldwide. We loved the storyline, and the crazy characterizations. Japan is definitely the place for weird, but usually workable ideas. Totora himself, the Catbus, and all the creatures help two young sisters cope with moving and an ill mother in the hospital.The 2-disc Blu-Ray/DVD version does contain both the newer Disney version - voiced by the Dakota and Elle Fanning - who do a fine job, as well as the original Japanese version (with various subtitles included). Some purists only like the Japanese version, while others like a previously released English-speaking overdub with different actors, that is no longer in distribution. Regardless, at least the original is included, and the new version is just fine. I see no reason for complaints at all. Very enjoyable, and some great extra bonus features as well.

What a great film. Very eye-opening storyline, if a bit unbelievable. The concept is that in the future, humans will be so lazy as to send in, basically, android clones of themselves, to do their daily routine, while the real people hide out at home. The biggest selling point is that the clones can look any way you want. Disfigured or self-loathing people can give themselves great bodies and looks. It says a lot about the future of image and what it means to be a "real" person. And, just as many do live in faked lives today, the question comes with what happens if a wrench gets thrown into the machine, after everyone is comfortable and set in their hiding ways. What if the system stops working, and real people must venture outdoors once again to face each other as they really are. Interesting topic and conversation starter film. And Bruce Willis does a very good job in his character.
Fun product that I had ordered for a girlfriend's 5K run, that had a theme to it. They enjoyed these thoroughly. Decently priced as well.

I am thrilled with this product. I had just come to own several various old books, some over 60 years old, and some of which were quite dusty. I had done some research on what professional book restorers do, and all of them recommended the soot sponge (aka "chemical sponge," although there are no actual chemicals) as one very useful method. It definitely worked wonders.Now, just to clarify, this WILL NOT remove stains - as in, anything that has soaked into the material. I noticed many bad reviews complaining about this. Think of this product as a large eraser. You wouldn't expect that to absorb dried in coffee stains or anything, would you? Same principal. It only removes "surface" dirt and soot, whatever is able to be "released" from the material. This is a very important point to take note of.Having said that, I had gone through the process of wiping down the books, which still appeared dingy, with some musty smells. Some restorers recommend vacuuming, but I think that is not necessary in most cases. I then used the sponge, and could immediately see the difference. The covers brightened up right away. Just to be clear, you cannot expect it to "put back" what is not there. That means, if colors have faded due to sunlight or ink fade, that is what you get, faded colors. What this will do is remove any dirt, soot, and dingy materials that are covering the material. And so, while not looking completely brand-new, all the books definitely improved in appearance, as I said, right away.If that is not enough, there is a follow-through method using a "Chemical Clean Cover Gel," but that gets into some serious commitment, and is using harsh, toxic petroleum-based chemicals, best to use only if you know exactly what you are doing. That said, this sponge is the best way to start the restoration process.------To Note:  This product can also be used on window and lamp shades, blinds, various upholstery and more.And note that, since it does behave like an eraser, it will leave "droppings" behind, that you will need to clean up as you use it.And you can wash it after use, but never use it wet. Dry it completely.

"How others" get free.... Yeah, how con artists get free stuff. If you are an absolute skin-flint cheapskate (there are other less family-friendly words for that), then this is the book for you. Learn how to be an absolute leech on society by making far-fetched attempts at not paying for things. I originally got this book sent to me to do a review years ago. Even then, this just seemed like much more trouble than it was worth, just to pinch a few pennies. And if you really need that much trouble just to save a dime, then you've got bigger problems than finances. My advice would be to skip this book. It's neither practical, nor amusing.
I found an older portable home phone of mine, that I needed to use, and found the batteries dead. Thankfully, these did the trick. They work well, no problems at all, and charged up easily.

Wonderful vacuum sealer. A friend of mine had been recommending that I should get one of these for quite some time. I had initially resisted, thinking it's "just another kitchen item" that won't get used, and will eventually just be put away and forgotten. Now that I got one, I find I was quite incorrect. Since I have gotten more into food dehydration, as well as other aspects of food saving, I have come to find that this is quite an invaluable tool - and I use it quite regularly.It is easy to operate, well, for the most part (when trying to seal bags that are not usually used in it). Actually, it has done very nicely with bags that are not the usual recommendations. But it performs exactly as promised. This model also can use the zip-lock bags that use a vacuum pump. Everyone is so neat and tidy, and it's so nice, and easier for me to store foods now - and for longer periods, without having to worry about spoilage.

One of my favorite quirky "cult" movies. I have loved this film since it first came out, and enjoy watching it again here and there. I never had it on DVD before, so it's a nice addition to my collection. The story line is great. It sucks you in right away with that curiosity of whether or not it will be boring, but ever so carefully, the twists begin and before long you are entranced until the end... which is worth waiting for.As well, John Turturro and John Goodman are both excellent in their roles, as this showcases their best attributes.

These are very basic, but very nice to use. If you work around a lot of paper products, especially in an industry that handles old papers (think antiques), your fingers can get very dirty, and get that odd feeling to them. Wearing these really does a great job protecting your fingers from all the negative aspects of paper handling. I love these. Very easy to use, and very efficient. The knobs definitely help in grabbing papers.

A very handy product that performed as well, if not better, than promised. So easy to use, and definitely helped in my guitar cleaning routine, keeping the strings nice. I actually can probably find a few other uses for this product around the house, so I might suggest advertising it for more than just a guitar product.

I have to be honest in saying that this product didn't work. I don't understand why. The batteries worked. The element heated up. But even when used on the flimsiest of plastic bags, for some reason not enough, or no heat was generated to even warm the plastic. I even followed the directions on the video as seen in the reviews. The concept is great, it is easy to hold and use... it simply didn't do what it was meant to do. How does it burn my finger, but not warm up a plastic bag??I will say that the seller was very understanding and helpful and offered an immediate refund. I am thankful for that. But I felt I must post an honest review based on my own experience.

Very handy to use, especially for me having arthritis. While I don't use it all the time, it does come in handy when pain flairs up. It seems to have a slight learning curve to using it, but that's fine. Great little pen.

I didn't know what to expect, since I had read varied reviews about different bulbs and companies, but... these were very nice. Relatively easy to pop in, and the function nicely. Now... keep in mind, if you are using these on a dimmer system... they will NOT go as dim as your halogens or whatnot. The reason is that these use so little energy, that they stop registering on the dimmer switch long before a different bulb would. This is why you can get a lower ambient light on the halogens, because it's still sucking power. But, these dim just fine, just not quite as dark. They have a nice hue, and have been a big help in reducing power costs at home.

Very nice cleaning cloths. I wasn't sure what to expect when ordering them, but they are very nice to use and do the job well at cleaning anything. Great for wood furniture, stainless steel, jewelry, etc. Whatever you have, it'll take care of it. And a nice price for the bunch.

After trying to make something like this myself (and not doing a great job of it), I decided to buy this stand. I am glad I did. Very simple, elegant, and functional. Its weighted bottom is balanced nicely to hold both the razor and the brush. I am very happy with this, and the price.

After buying Merkur razor recently, I wanted to try something a bit heavier in the hand, and with the old styled butterfly opening. This one stuck out at me. I am really glad I purchased it. Easy to use, and for my big hands, I appreciate the added weight in the handle that makes shaving a bit easier for me. It offers a somewhat aggressive shave, and it is a bit of a learning curve, but not too much if you are used to the idea of using a safety razor. Solid, nice appearance, and very effective. I am very please with how it works.
Nice, compact sharpener that handles quite a bit. This is something equally in place in the kitchen, or on camping trips. Very easy to use, and does the job well. Impressed

I bought this book on a whim, after seeing it on the website of America's Test Kitchen. I am so thrilled with this book. I enjoy reading the occasional good cook book, and recipes of foods that appeal to me, but in this case, I took a blind chance on just a few items mentioned in it. I could not be happier. The foods shown within, the layout of the book, the way in which it is written, the clear and concise recipes... makes this a true joy to own.
